And\r\nsuch a heavy cornice round the room!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut when they removed to their new house in Milton, the obnoxious papers\r\nwere gone. The landlord received their thanks very composedly; and let\r\nthem think, if they liked, that he had relented from his expressed\r\ndetermination not to repaper. There was no particular need to tell them,\r\nthat what he did not care to do for a Reverend Mr. Hale, unknown in\r\nMilton, he was only too glad to do at the one short sharp remonstrance\r\nof Mr. Thornton, the wealthy manufacturer.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII.\r\n\r\nHOME SICKNESS.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cAnd it\xe2\x80\x99s hame, hame, hame,\r\n    Hame fain wad I be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nIt needed the pretty light papering of the rooms to reconcile them to\r\nMilton. It needed more--more that could not be had. The thick yellow\r\nNovember fogs had come on; and the view of the plain in the valley, made\r\nby the sweeping bend of the river was all shut out when Mrs. Hale\r\narrived at her new home.\r\n\r\nMargaret and Dixon had been at work two days, unpacking and arranging,\r\nbut everything inside the house still looked in disorder; and outside a\r\nthick fog crept up to the very windows, and was driven in to every open\r\ndoor in choking white wreaths of unwholsome mist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Margaret! are we to live here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Hale in blank dismay.\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart echoed the dreariness of the tone in which this\r\nquestion was put. She could scarcely command herself enough to say, \xe2\x80\x9cOh,\r\nthe fogs in London are sometimes far worse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut then you knew that London itself, and friends lay behind it.\r\nHere--well! we are desolate. Oh Dixon, what a place this is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure it will be your death before long, and then I\r\nknow who\xe2\x80\x99ll--stay! Miss Hale, that\xe2\x80\x99s far too heavy for you to lift.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all, thank you, Dixon,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Margaret coldly. \xe2\x80\x9cThe best thing\r\nwe can do for mamma is to get her room quite ready for her to go to bed,\r\nwhile I go and bring her a cup of coffee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale was equally out of spirits, and equally came upon Margaret for\r\nsympathy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret, I do believe this is an unhealthy place. Only suppose that\r\nyour mother\xe2\x80\x99s health or yours should suffer. I wish I had gone into some\r\ncountry place in Wales; this is really terrible,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, going up to\r\nthe window.\r\n\r\nThere was no comfort to be given. They were settled in Milton, and must\r\nendure smoke and fogs for a season; indeed, all other life seemed shut\r\nout from them by as thick a fog of circumstance. Only the day before,\r\nMr. Hale had been reckoning up with dismay how much their removal and\r\nfortnight at Heston had cost, and he found it had absorbed nearly all\r\nhis little stock of ready money. No! here they were, and here they must\r\nremain.\r\n\r\nAt night when Margaret realised this, she felt inclined to sit down in a\r\nstupor of despair. The heavy smoky air hung about her bedroom, which\r\noccupied the long narrow projection at the back of the house. The\r\nwindow, placed at the side of the oblong, looked at the blank wall of a\r\nsimilar projection, not above ten feet distant. It loomed through the\r\nfog like a great barrier to hope. Inside the room everything was in\r\nconfusion. All their efforts had been directed to make her mother\xe2\x80\x99s room\r\ncomfortable. Margaret sat down on a box, the direction card upon which\r\nstruck her as having been written at Helstone--beautiful, beloved\r\nHelstone! She lost herself in dismal thought: but at last she determined\r\nto take her mind away from the present; and suddenly remembered that she\r\nhad a letter from Edith which she had only half read in the bustle of\r\nthe morning. It was to tell of their arrival at Corfu; their voyage\r\nalong the Mediterranean--their music, and dancing on board ship; the gay\r\nnew life opening upon her; her house with its trellised balcony, and its\r\nviews over white cliffs and deep blue sea.\r\n\r\nEdith wrote fluently and well, if not graphically. She could not only\r\nseize the salient and characteristic points of a scene, but she could\r\nenumerate enough of indiscriminate particular for Margaret to make it\r\nout for herself. Captain Lennox and another lately married officer\r\nshared a villa, high up on the beautiful precipitous rocks overhanging\r\nthe sea. Their days, late as it was in the year, seemed spent in boating\r\nor land-picnics; all out-of-doors, pleasure-seeking and glad, Edith\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlife seemed like the deep vault of blue sky above her, free--utterly\r\nfree from fleck or cloud. Her husband had to attend drill, and she, the\r\nmost musical officer\xe2\x80\x99s wife there, had to copy the new and popular tunes\r\nout of the most recent English music, for the benefit of the bandmaster;\r\nthose seemed their most severe and arduous duties. She expressed an\r\naffectionate hope that, if the regiment stopped another year at Corfu,\r\nMargaret might come out and pay her a long visit. She asked Margaret if\r\nshe remembered the day twelve-month on which she, Edith, wrote--how it\r\nrained all day long in Harley Street; and how she would not put on her\r\nnew gown to go to a stupid dinner, and get it all wet and splashed in\r\ngoing to the carriage; and how at that very dinner they had first met\r\nCaptain Lennox.\r\n\r\nYes! Margaret remembered it well. Edith and Mrs. Shaw had gone to\r\ndinner. Margaret had joined the party in the evening. The recollection\r\nof the plentiful luxury of all arrangements, the stately handsomeness of\r\nthe furniture, the size of the house, the peaceful, untroubled ease of\r\nthe visitors--all came vividly before her, in strange contrast to the\r\npresent time. The smooth sea of that old life closed up, without a mark\r\nleft to tell where they had all been. The habitual dinners, the calls,\r\nthe dancing evenings, were all going on, going on for ever, though her\r\nAunt Shaw and Edith were no longer there; and she, of course, was even\r\nless missed. She doubted if any one of that old set ever thought of her,\r\nexcept Henry Lennox. He too, she knew, would strive to forget her,\r\nbecause of the pain she had caused him. She had heard him often boast of\r\nhis power of putting any disagreeable thought far away from him. Then\r\nshe penetrated farther into what might have been. If she had cared for\r\nhim as a lover, and had accepted him, and this change in her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nopinions and consequent station had taken place, she could not doubt but\r\nthat it would have been impatiently received by Mr. Lennox. It was a\r\nbitter mortification to her in one sense; but she could bear it\r\npatiently, because she knew her father\xe2\x80\x99s purity of purpose, and that\r\nstrengthened her to endure his errors, grave and serious though in her\r\nestimation they were. But the fact of the world esteeming her father\r\ndegraded, in its rough wholesale judgment, would have oppressed and\r\nirritated Mr. Lennox. As she realised what might have been, she grew to\r\nbe thankful for what was. They were at the lowest now; they could not be\r\nworse. Edith\xe2\x80\x99s astonishment and her Aunt Shaw\xe2\x80\x99s dismay would have to be\r\nmet bravely, when their letters came. So Margaret rose up and began\r\nslowly to undress herself, feeling the full luxury of acting leisurely,\r\nlate as it was, after all the past hurry of the day. She fell asleep,\r\nhoping for some brightness, either internal or external. But if she had\r\nknown how long it would be before the brightness came, her heart would\r\nhave sunk low down. The time of the year was most unpropitious to health\r\nas well as to spirits. Her mother caught a severe cold, and Dixon\r\nherself was evidently not well, although Margaret could not insult her\r\nmore than by trying to save her, or by taking any care of her. They\r\ncould hear of no girl to assist her; all were at work in the factories;\r\nat least, those who applied were well scolded by Dixon, for thinking\r\nthat such as they could ever be trusted to work in a gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s house.\r\nSo they had to keep a charwoman in almost constant employ. Margaret\r\nlonged to send for Charlotte; but besides the objection of her being a\r\nbetter servant than they now could afford to keep, the distance was too\r\ngreat.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale met with several pupils, recommended to him by Mr. Bell, or by\r\nthe more immediate influence of Mr. Thornton. They were mostly of the\r\nage when many boys would be still at school, but, according to the\r\nprevalent, and, apparently well-founded notions of Milton, to make a lad\r\ninto a good tradesman he must be caught young, and acclimated to the\r\nlife of the mill, or office, or warehouse. If he were sent to even the\r\nScotch Universities, he came back unsettled for commercial pursuits: how\r\nmuch more so if he went to Oxford or Cambridge, where he could not be\r\nentered till he was eighteen? So most of the manufacturers placed their\r\nsons in situations at from fourteen or fifteen years of age, unsparingly\r\ncutting away all off-shoots in the direction of literature or high\r\nmental cultivation, in hopes of throwing the whole strength and vigour\r\nof the plant into commerce. Still there were some wiser parents; and\r\nsome who had sense enough to perceive their own deficiencies, and strive\r\nto remedy them. Nay, there were a few no longer youths, but men in the\r\nprime of life, who had the stern wisdom to acknowledge their own\r\nignorance, and to learn late what they should have learnt early. Mr.\r\nThornton was perhaps the oldest of Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s pupils. He was certainly\r\nthe favourite. Mr. Hale got into the habit of quoting his opinions so\r\nfrequently, and with such regard, that it became a little domestic joke\r\nto wonder what time, during the hour appointed for instruction, could be\r\ngiven to absolute learning, so much of it appeared to have been spent in\r\nconversation.\r\n\r\nMargaret rather encouraged this light, merry way of viewing her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nacquaintance with Mr. Thornton, because she felt that her mother was\r\ninclined to look upon this new friendship of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s with jealous\r\neyes. As long as his time had been solely occupied with his books and\r\nhis parishioners, as at Helstone, she had appeared to care little\r\nwhether she saw much of him or not; but now that he looked eagerly\r\nforward to each renewal of his intercourse with Mr. Thornton, she seemed\r\nhurt and annoyed, as if he were slighting her companionship for the\r\nfirst time. Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s over-praise had the usual effect of over-praise\r\nupon his auditors; they were a little inclined to rebel against\r\nAristides being always called the Just.\r\n\r\nAfter a quiet life in a country parsonage for more than twenty years,\r\nthere was something dazzling to Mr. Hale in the energy which conquered\r\nimmense difficulties with ease; the power of the machinery of Milton,\r\nthe power of the men of Milton, impressed him with a sense of grandeur,\r\nwhich he yielded to without caring to inquire into the details of its\r\nexercise. But Margaret went less abroad, among machinery and men; saw\r\nless of power in its public effect, and, as it happened, she was thrown\r\nwith one or two of those who, in all measures affecting masses of\r\npeople, must be acute sufferers for the good of many. The question\r\nalways is, has everything been done to make the sufferings of these\r\nexceptions as small as possible? or, in the triumph of the crowded\r\nprocession, have the helpless been trampled on, instead of being gently\r\nlifted aside out of the roadway of the conqueror, whom they have no\r\npower to accompany on his march?\r\n\r\nIt fell to Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s share to have to look out for a servant to assist\r\nDixon, who had at first undertaken to find just the person she wanted to\r\ndo all the rough work of the house. But Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s ideas of helpful girls\r\nwere founded on the recollection of tidy elder scholars at Helstone\r\nschool, who were only too proud to be allowed to come to the parsonage\r\non a busy day, and treated Mrs. Dixon with all the respect, and a good\r\ndeal more of fright, which they paid to Mr. and Mrs. Hale. Dixon was not\r\nunconscious of this awed reverence which was given to her; nor did she\r\ndislike it: it flattered her much as Louis the Fourteenth was flattered\r\nby his courtiers shading their eyes from the dazzling light of his\r\npresence. But nothing short of her faithful love for Mrs. Hale could\r\nhave made her endure the rough independent way in which all the Milton\r\ngirls, who made application for the servant\xe2\x80\x99s place, replied to her\r\ninquiries respecting their qualifications. They even went the length of\r\nquestioning her back again; having doubts and fears of their own, as to\r\nthe solvency of a family who lived in a house of thirty pounds a-year,\r\nand yet gave themselves airs, and kept two servants, one of them so very\r\nhigh and mighty. Mr. Hale was no longer looked upon as Vicar of\r\nHelstone, but as a man who only spent at a certain rate. Margaret was\r\nweary and impatient of the accounts which Dixon perpetually brought to\r\nMrs. Hale of the behaviour of these would-be servants. Not but what\r\nMargaret was repelled by the rough uncourteous manners of these people;\r\nnot but what she shrunk with fastidious pride from their hail-fellow\r\naccost, and severely resented their unconcealed curiosity as to the\r\nmeans and position of any family who lived in Milton, and yet were not\r\nengaged in trade of some kind. But the more Margaret felt impertinence,\r\nthe more likely she was to be silent on the subject; and, at any rate,\r\nif she took upon herself to make inquiry for a servant, she could spare\r\nher mother the recital of all her disappointments and fancied or real\r\ninsults.\r\n\r\nMargaret accordingly went up and down to butchers and grocers, seeking\r\nfor a nonpareil of a girl; and lowering her hopes and expectations every\r\nweek, as she found the difficulty of meeting with any one in a\r\nmanufacturing town who did not prefer the better wages and greater\r\nindependence of working in a mill. It was something of a trial to\r\nMargaret to go out by herself in this busy bustling place. Mrs. Shaw\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nideas of propriety and her own helpless dependence on others, had always\r\nmade her insist that a footman should accompany Edith and Margaret, if\r\nthey went beyond Harley Street or the immediate neighbourhood. The\r\nlimits by which this rule of her aunt\xe2\x80\x99s had circumscribed Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nindependence had been silently rebelled against at the time: and she had\r\ndoubly enjoyed the free walks and rambles of her forest life from the\r\ncontrast which they presented. She went along there with a boundless\r\nfearless step, that occasionally broke out into a run, if she were in a\r\nhurry, and occasionally was stilled into perfect repose, as she stood\r\nlistening to, or watching any of the wild creatures who sang in the\r\nleafy courts, or glanced out with their keen bright eyes from the low\r\nbrushwood or tangled furze. It was a trial to come down from such motion\r\nor such stillness, only guided by her own sweet will, to the even and\r\ndecorous pace necessary in streets. But she could have laughed at\r\nherself for minding this change, if it had not been accompanied by what\r\nwas a more serious annoyance.\r\n\r\nThe side of the town on which Crampton lay was especially a thoroughfare\r\nfor the factory people. In the back streets around them there were many\r\nmills, out of which poured streams of men and women two or three times a\r\nday. Until Margaret had learnt the times of their ingress and egress,\r\nshe was very unfortunate in constantly falling in with them. They came\r\nrushing along, with bold, fearless faces, and loud laughs and jests,\r\nparticularly aimed at all those who appeared to be above them in rank or\r\nstation. The tones of their unrestrained voices, and their carelessness\r\nof all common rules of street politeness, frightened Margaret a little\r\nat first. The girls, with their rough, but not unfriendly freedom, would\r\ncomment on her dress, even touch her shawl or gown to ascertain the\r\nexact material; nay, once or twice she was asked questions relative to\r\nsome article which they particularly admired. There was such a simple\r\nreliance on her womanly sympathy with their love of dress, and on her\r\nkindliness, that she gladly replied to these inquiries, as soon as she\r\nunderstood them; and half smiled back at their remarks. She did not mind\r\nmeeting any number of girls, loud spoken and boisterous though they\r\nmight be. But she alternately dreaded and fired up against the workmen,\r\nwho commented not on her dress, but on her looks, in the same open,\r\nfearless manner. She, who had hitherto felt that even the most refined\r\nremark on her personal appearance was an impertinence, had to endure\r\nundisguised admiration from these outspoken men. But the very\r\noutspokenness marked their innocence of any intention to hurt her\r\ndelicacy, as she would have perceived if she had been less frightened by\r\nthe disorderly tumult. Out of her fright came a flash of indignation\r\nwhich made her face scarlet, and her dark eyes gather flame, as she\r\nheard some of their speeches. Yet there were other sayings of theirs,\r\nwhich, when she reached the quiet safety of home, amused her even while\r\nthey irritated her.\r\n\r\nFor instance, one day, after she had passed a number of men, several of\r\nwhom had paid her the not unusual compliment of wishing she was their\r\nsweetheart, one of the lingerers added, \xe2\x80\x9cYour bonny face, my lass, makes\r\nthe day look brighter.\xe2\x80\x9d And another day, as she was unconsciously\r\nsmiling at some passing thought, she was addressed by a poorly-dressed,\r\nmiddle-aged workman, with, \xe2\x80\x9cYou may well smile, my lass; many a one\r\nwould smile to have such a bonny face.\xe2\x80\x9d This man looked so careworn that\r\nMargaret could not help giving him an answering smile, glad to think\r\nthat her looks, such as they were, should have had the power to call up\r\na pleasant thought. He seemed to understand her acknowledging glance,\r\nand a silent recognition was established between them whenever the\r\nchances of the day brought them across each other\xe2\x80\x99s paths. They had\r\nnever exchanged a word; nothing had been said but that first compliment;\r\nyet somehow Margaret looked upon this man with more interest than upon\r\nany one else in Milton. Once or twice, on Sundays, she saw him walking\r\nwith a girl, evidently his daughter, and, if possible, still more\r\nunhealthy than he was himself.\r\n\r\nOne day Margaret and her father had been as far as the fields that lay\r\naround the town; it was early spring, and she had gathered some of the\r\nhedge and ditch flowers, dog-violets, lesser celandines, and the like,\r\nwith an unspoken lament in her heart for the sweet profusion of the\r\nSouth. Her father had left her to go into Milton upon some business; and\r\non the road home she met her humble friends. The girl looked wistfully\r\nat the flowers, and, acting on a sudden impulse, Margaret offered them\r\nto her. Her pale blue eyes lightened up as she took them, and her father\r\nspoke for her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank yo, Miss. Bessy\xe2\x80\x99ll think a deal o\xe2\x80\x99 them flowers; that hoo will;\r\nand I shall think a deal o\xe2\x80\x99 yor kindness. Yo\xe2\x80\x99re not of this country, I\r\nreckon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, half sighing. \xe2\x80\x9cI come from the South--from\r\nHampshire,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, a little afraid of wounding his consciousness\r\nof ignorance, if she used a name which he did not understand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s beyond London, I reckon? And I come fro\xe2\x80\x99 Burnleyways, and forty\r\nmiles to th\xe2\x80\x99 North. And yet, yo see, North and South has both met and\r\nmade kind o\xe2\x80\x99 friends in this big smoky place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret had slackened her pace to a walk alongside of the man and his\r\ndaughter, whose steps were regulated by the feebleness of the latter.\r\nShe now spoke to the girl, and there was a sound of tender pity in the\r\ntone of her voice as she did so that went right to the heart of the\r\nfather.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid you are not very strong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, \xe2\x80\x9cnor never will be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpring is coming,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, as if to suggest pleasant, hopeful\r\nthoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpring nor summer will do me good,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl quietly.\r\n\r\nMargaret looked up at the man, almost expecting some contradiction from\r\nhim, or at least some remark that would modify his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s utter\r\nhopelessness. But instead, he added--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afeared hoo speaks the truth. I\xe2\x80\x99m afeared hoo\xe2\x80\x99s too far gone in a\r\nwaste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall have a spring where I am boun\xe2\x80\x99 to, and flowers, and amaranths,\r\nand shining robes besides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor lass, poor lass!\xe2\x80\x9d said her father in a low tone. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m none so sure\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 that; but it\xe2\x80\x99s a comfort to thee, poor lass, poor lass. Poor father!\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99ll be soon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was shocked by his words--shocked but not repelled; rather\r\nattracted and interested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you live? I think we must be neighbours, we meet so often on\r\nthis road.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe put up at nine Frances Street, second turn to th\xe2\x80\x99 left at after\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99ve past th\xe2\x80\x99 Goulden Dragon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your name? I must not forget that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m none ashamed o\xe2\x80\x99 my name. It\xe2\x80\x99s Nicholas Higgins. Hoo\xe2\x80\x99s called Bessy\r\nHiggins. Whatten yo\xe2\x80\x99 asking for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was surprised at this last question, for at Helstone it would\r\nhave been an understood thing, after the enquiries she had made, that\r\nshe intended to come and call upon any poor neighbour whose name and\r\nhabitation she had asked for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought--I meant to come and see you.\xe2\x80\x9d She suddenly felt rather shy\r\nof offering the visit, without having any reason to give for her wish to\r\nmake it, beyond a kindly interest in a stranger. It seemed all at once\r\nto take the shape of an impertinence on her part; she read this meaning\r\ntoo in the man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m none so fond of having strange folk in my house.\xe2\x80\x9d But then\r\nrelenting, as he saw her heightened colour, he added \xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99re a foreigner,\r\nas one may say, and maybe don\xe2\x80\x99t know many folk here, and yo\xe2\x80\x99ve given my\r\nwench here flowers out of yo\xe2\x80\x99r own hand;--yo may come if yo like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was half amused, half-nettled at this answer. She was not sure\r\nif she would go where permission was given so like a favour conferred.\r\nBut when they came to the turn into Frances Street, the girl stopped a\r\nminute, and said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99ll not forget yo\xe2\x80\x99re to come and see us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, aye,\xe2\x80\x9d said the father, impatiently, \xe2\x80\x9choo\xe2\x80\x99ll come. Hoo\xe2\x80\x99s a bit set\r\nup now, because hoo thinks I might ha\xe2\x80\x99 spoken more civilly; but hoo\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nthink better on it, and come. I can read her proud bonny face like a\r\nbook. Come along, Bess; there\xe2\x80\x99s the mill bell ringing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret went home, wondering at her new friends, and smiling at the\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s insight into what had been passing in her mind. From that day\r\nMilton became a brighter place to her. It was not the long, bleak sunny\r\ndays of spring, nor yet was it that time was reconciling her to the town\r\nof her habitation. It was that in it she had found a human interest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX.\r\n\r\nDRESSING FOR TEA.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cLet China\xe2\x80\x99s earth, enriched with coloured stains,\r\n    Pencil\xe2\x80\x99d with gold, and streaked with azure veins,\r\n    The grateful flavour of the Indian leaf,\r\n    Or Mocha\xe2\x80\x99s sunburnt berry glad receive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              MRS. BARBOULD.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe day after this meeting with Higgins and his daughter Mr. Hale came\r\nupstairs into the little drawing-room at an unusual hour. He went up to\r\ndifferent objects in the room, as if examining them, but Margaret saw\r\nthat it was merely a nervous trick--a way of putting off something he\r\nwished, yet feared to say. Out it came at last--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear! I\xe2\x80\x99ve asked Mr. Thornton to come to tea to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Hale was leaning back in her easy chair, with her eyes shut, and an\r\nexpression of pain on her face which had become habitual to her of late.\r\nBut she roused up into querulousness at this speech of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton!--and to-night! What in the world does the man want to\r\ncome here for? And Dixon is washing my muslins and laces, and there is\r\nno soft water with these horrid east winds, which I suppose we shall\r\nhave all the year round in Milton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wind is veering round, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, looking out at the\r\nsmoke, which drifted right from the east, only he did not yet understand\r\nthe points of the compass, and rather arranged them ad libitum according\r\nto circumstances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t tell me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, shuddering up, and wrapping her shawl\r\nabout her still more closely. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, east or west wind, I suppose this\r\nman comes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh mamma, that shows you never saw Mr. Thornton. He looks like a person\r\nwho would enjoy battling with every adverse thing he could meet\r\nwith--enemies, winds, or circumstances. The more it rains and blows, the\r\nmore certain we are to have him. But I\xe2\x80\x99ll go and help Dixon. I\xe2\x80\x99m getting\r\nto be a famous clear-starcher. And he won\xe2\x80\x99t want any amusement beyond\r\ntalking to Papa. Papa, I am really longing to see the Pythias to your\r\nDamon. You know I never saw him but once, and then we were so puzzled to\r\nknow what to say to each other that we did not get on particularly\r\nwell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know that you would ever like him, or think him agreeable,\r\nMargaret. He is not a lady\xe2\x80\x99s man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret wreathed her throat in a scornful curve.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t particularly admire ladies\xe2\x80\x99 men, papa. But Mr. Thornton comes\r\nhere as your friend--as one who has appreciated you\xe2\x80\x9d--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe only person in Milton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo we will give him a welcome, and some cocoa-nut cakes. Dixon will be\r\nflattered if we ask her to make some; and I will undertake to iron your\r\ncaps, mamma.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMany a time that morning did Margaret wish Mr. Thornton far enough away.\r\nShe had planned other employments for herself: a letter to Edith, a good\r\npiece of Dante, a visit to the Higginses. But, instead, she ironed away,\r\nlistening to Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s complaints, and only hoping that by an excess of\r\nsympathy she might prevent her from carrying the recital of her sorrows\r\nto Mrs. Hale. Every now and then, Margaret had to remind herself of her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s regard for Mr. Thornton, to subdue the irritation of weariness\r\nthat was stealing over her, and bringing on one of the bad headaches to\r\nwhich she had lately become liable. She could hardly speak when she sat\r\ndown at last, and told her mother that she was no longer Peggy the\r\nlaundry-maid, but Margaret Hale the lady. She meant this speech for a\r\nlittle joke, and was vexed enough with her busy tongue when she found\r\nher mother taking it seriously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! if any one had told me, when I was Miss Beresford, and one of the\r\nbelles of the country, that a child of mine would have to stand half a\r\nday, in a little poky kitchen, working away like any servant, that we\r\nmight prepare properly for the reception of a tradesman, and that this\r\ntradesman should be the only\xe2\x80\x9d--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mamma!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, lifting herself up, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t punish me for so\r\ncareless a speech. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind ironing, or any kind of work for you and\r\npapa. I am myself a born and bred lady through it all, even though it\r\ncomes to scouring a floor, or washing dishes. I am tired now, just for a\r\nlittle while; but in half an hour I shall be ready to do the same over\r\nagain. And as to Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s being in trade, why he can\xe2\x80\x99t help that\r\nnow, poor fellow. I don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose his education would fit him for much\r\nelse,\xe2\x80\x9d Margaret lifted herself slowly up, and went to her own room; for\r\njust now she could not bear much more.\r\n\r\nIn Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s house, at this very same time, a similar, yet\r\ndifferent scene was going on. A large-boned lady, long past middle age,\r\nsat at work in a grim handsomely-furnished dining-room. Her features,\r\nlike her frame, were strong and massive, rather than heavy. Her face\r\nmoved slowly from one decided expression to another equally decided.\r\nThere was no great variety in her countenance; but those who looked at\r\nit once, generally looked at it again; even the passers by in the\r\nstreet, half-turned their heads to gaze an instant longer at the firm,\r\nsevere, dignified woman, who never gave way in street-courtesy, or\r\npaused in her straight-onward course to the clearly defined end which\r\nshe proposed to herself.\r\n\r\nShe was handsomely dressed in stout black silk, of which not a thread\r\nwas worn or discoloured. She was mending a large, long table-cloth of\r\nthe finest texture, holding it up against the light occasionally to\r\ndiscover thin places, which required her delicate care. There was not a\r\nbook about in the room, with the exception of Matthew Henry\xe2\x80\x99s Bible\r\ncommentaries, six volumes of which lay in the centre of the massive\r\nside-board, flanked by a tea-urn on one side, and a lamp on the other.\r\nIn some remote apartment, there was exercise upon the piano going on.\r\nSomeone was practising up a morceau de salon, playing it very rapidly,\r\nevery third note, on an average, being either indistinct, or wholly\r\nmissed out, and the loud chords at the end being half of them false, but\r\nnot the less satisfactory to the performer. Mrs. Thornton heard a step,\r\nlike her own in its decisive character, pass the dining-room door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn! Is that you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer son opened the door, and showed himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has brought you home so early? I thought you were going to tea\r\nwith that friend of Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s; that Mr. Hale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I am, mother. I am come home to dress!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDress! humph! When I was a girl, young men were satisfied with dressing\r\nonce in a day. Why should you dress to go and take a cup of tea with an\r\nold parson?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Hale is a gentleman, and his wife and daughter are ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWife and daughter! Do they teach too? What do they do? You have never\r\nmentioned them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! mother, because I have never seen Mrs. Hale; I have only seen Miss\r\nHale for half an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care you don\xe2\x80\x99t get caught by a penniless girl, John.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not easily caught, mother, as I think you know. But I must not\r\nhave Miss Hale spoken of in that way, which, you know, is offensive to\r\nme. I never was aware of any young lady trying to catch me yet, nor do I\r\nbelieve that any one has ever given themselves that useless trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton did not choose to yield the point to her son; or else she\r\nhad, in general, pride enough for her sex.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! I only say, take care. Perhaps our Milton girls have too much\r\nspirit and good feeling to go angling after husbands; but this Miss Hale\r\ncomes out of the aristocratic counties, where, if all tales be true,\r\nrich husbands are reckoned prizes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s brow contracted, and he came a step forward into the\r\nroom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother\xe2\x80\x9d (with a short scornful laugh), \xe2\x80\x9cyou will make me confess. The\r\nonly time I saw Miss Hale, she treated me with a haughty civility which\r\nhad a strong flavour of contempt in it. She held herself aloof from me\r\nas if she had been a queen, and I her humble, unwashed vassal. Be easy,\r\nmother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! I am not easy nor content either. What business had she, a renegade\r\nclergyman\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, to turn up her nose at you! I would dress for none\r\nof them--a saucy set! if I were you.\xe2\x80\x9d As he was leaving the room he\r\nsaid:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Hale is good, and gentle, and learned. He is not saucy. As for Mrs.\r\nHale, I will tell you what she is like to-night, if you care to hear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHe shut the door, and was gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDespise my son! treat him as her vassal, indeed! Humph! I should like\r\nto know where she could find such another! Boy and man, he\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nnoblest, stoutest heart I ever knew. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care if I am his mother; I\r\ncan see what\xe2\x80\x99s what, and not be blind. I know what Fanny is; and I know\r\nwhat John is. Despise him! I hate her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X.\r\n\r\nWROUGHT IRON AND GOLD.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cWe are the trees whom shaking fastens more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              GEORGE HERBERT.\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton left the house without coming into the dining-room again.\r\nHe was rather late, and walked rapidly out to Crampton. He was anxious\r\nnot to slight his new friend by any disrespectful unpunctuality. The\r\nchurch-clock struck half-past seven as he stood at the door awaiting\r\nDixon\xe2\x80\x99s slow movements; always doubly tardy when she had to degrade\r\nherself by answering the door-bell. He was ushered into the little\r\ndrawing-room, and kindly greeted by Mr. Hale, who led him up to his\r\nwife, whose pale face, and shawl-draped figure made a silent excuse for\r\nthe cold languor of her greeting. Margaret was lighting the lamp when he\r\nentered, for the darkness was coming on. The lamp threw a pretty light\r\ninto the centre of the dusky room, from which, with country habits, they\r\ndid not exclude the night-skies, and the outer darkness of air. Somehow,\r\nthat room contrasted itself with the one he had lately left; handsome,\r\nponderous, with no sign of female habitation, except in the one spot\r\nwhere his mother sate, and no convenience for any other employment than\r\neating and drinking. To be sure, it was a dining-room; his mother\r\npreferred to sit in it; and her will was a household law. But the\r\ndrawing-room was not like this. It was twice--twenty times as fine; not\r\none quarter as comfortable. Here were no mirrors, not even a scrap of\r\nglass to reflect the light, and answer the same purpose as water in a\r\nlandscape; no gilding; a warm, sober breadth of colouring, well relieved\r\nby the dear old Helstone chintz-curtains and chair covers. An open\r\ndavenport stood in the window opposite the door; in the other there was\r\na stand, with a tall white china vase, from which drooped wreaths of\r\nEnglish ivy, pale green birch, and copper-coloured beech-leaves. Pretty\r\nbaskets of work stood about in different places: and books, not cared\r\nfor on account of their binding solely, lay on one table, as if recently\r\nput down. Behind the door was another table decked out for tea, with a\r\nwhite table-cloth, on which flourished the cocoa-nut cakes, and a basket\r\npiled with oranges and ruddy American apples, heaped on leaves.\r\n\r\nIt appeared to Mr. Thornton that all these graceful cares were habitual\r\nto the family; and especially of a piece with Margaret. She stood by the\r\ntea-table in a light-coloured muslin gown, which had a good deal of pink\r\nabout it. She looked as if she was not attending to the conversation,\r\nbut solely busy with the tea-cups, among which her round ivory hands\r\nmoved with pretty, noiseless, daintiness. She had a bracelet on one\r\ntaper arm, which would fall down over her round wrist. Mr. Thornton\r\nwatched the replacing of this troublesome ornament with far more\r\nattention than he listened to her father. It seemed as if it fascinated\r\nhim to see her push it up impatiently until it tightened her soft flesh;\r\nand then to mark the loosening--the fall. He could almost have\r\nexclaimed--\xe2\x80\x9cThere it goes again!\xe2\x80\x9d There was so little left to be done\r\nafter he arrived at the preparation for tea, that he was almost sorry\r\nthe obligation of eating and drinking came so soon to prevent him\r\nwatching Margaret. She handed him his cup of tea with the proud air of\r\nan unwilling slave; but her eye caught the moment when he was ready for\r\nanother cup; and he almost longed to ask her to do for him what he saw\r\nher compelled to do for her father, who took her little finger and thumb\r\nin his masculine hand, and made them serve as sugar-tongues. Mr.\r\nThornton saw her beautiful eyes lifted to her father, full of light,\r\nhalf-laughter, and half-love, as this bit of pantomime went on between\r\nthe two, unobserved as they fancied, by any. Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s head still\r\nached, as the paleness of her complexion, and her silence might have\r\ntestified; but she was resolved to throw herself into the breach, if\r\nthere was any long untoward pause, rather than that her father\xe2\x80\x99s friend,\r\npupil, and guest should have cause to think himself in any way\r\nneglected. But the conversation went on; and Margaret drew into a\r\ncorner, near her mother, with her work, after the tea-things were taken\r\naway; and felt that she might let her thoughts roam, without fear of\r\nbeing suddenly wanted to fill up a gap.\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton and Mr. Hale were both absorbed in the continuation of some\r\nobject which had been started at their last meeting. Margaret was\r\nrecalled to a sense of the present by some trivial, low-spoken remark of\r\nher mother\xe2\x80\x99s; and on suddenly looking up from her work, her eye was\r\ncaught by the difference of outward appearance between her father and\r\nMr. Thornton, as betokening such distinctly opposite natures. Her father\r\nwas of slight figure, which made him appear taller than he really was,\r\nwhen not contrasted, as at this time, with the tall, massive frame of\r\nanother. The lines in her father\xe2\x80\x99s face were soft and waving, with a\r\nfrequent undulating kind of trembling movement passing over them,\r\nshowing every fluctuating emotion; the eyelids were large and arched,\r\ngiving to the eyes a peculiar languid beauty which was almost feminine.\r\nThe brows were finely arched, but were by the very size of the dreamy\r\nlids, raised to a considerable distance from the eyes. Now, in Mr.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s face the straight brows fell low over the clear, deep-set,\r\nearnest eyes, which without being unpleasantly sharp, seemed intent\r\nenough to penetrate into the very heart and core of what he was looking\r\nat. The lines in the face were few but firm, as if they were carved in\r\nmarble, and lay principally about the lips, which were slightly\r\ncompressed, over a set of teeth so faultless and beautiful as to give\r\nthe effect of sudden sunlight when the rare bright smile, coming in an\r\ninstant and shining out of the eyes, changed the whole look from the\r\nsevere and resolved expression of a man ready to do and dare everything,\r\nto the keen, honest, enjoyment of the moment, which is seldom shown so\r\nfearlessly and instantaneously except by children. Margaret liked this\r\nsmile; it was the first thing she had admired in this new friend of her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s; and the opposition of character, shown in all these details\r\nof appearance she had just been noticing, seemed to explain the\r\nattraction they evidently felt towards each other.\r\n\r\nShe rearranged her mother\xe2\x80\x99s worsted-work, and fell back into her own\r\nthoughts--as completely forgotten by Mr. Thornton as if she had not been\r\nin the room, so thoroughly was he occupied in explaining to Mr. Hale the\r\nmagnificent power, yet delicate adjustment of the might of the\r\nsteam-hammer, which was recalling to Mr. Hale some of the wonderful\r\nstories of subservient genii in the Arabian Nights--one moment\r\nstretching from earth to sky and filling all the width of the horizon,\r\nat the next obediently compressed into a vase small enough to be borne\r\nin the hand of a child.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this imagination of power, this practical realisation of a gigantic\r\nthought, came out of one man\xe2\x80\x99s brain in our good town. That very man has\r\nit within him to mount, step by step, on each wonder he achieves to\r\nhigher marvels still. And I\xe2\x80\x99ll be bound to say, we have many among us\r\nwho, if he were gone, could spring into the breach and carry on the war\r\nwhich compels, and shall compel, all material power to yield to\r\nscience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour boast reminds me of the old lines--\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve a hundred captains in England,\xe2\x80\x99 he said,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x98As good as ever was he.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt her father\xe2\x80\x99s quotation Margaret looked suddenly up, with inquiring\r\nwonder in her eyes. How in the world had they got from the cog-wheels to\r\nChevy Chace?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is no boast of mine,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Thornton; \xe2\x80\x9cit is plain\r\nmatter-of-fact. I won\xe2\x80\x99t deny that I am proud of belonging to a town--or\r\nperhaps I should rather say a district--the necessities of which give\r\nbirth to such grandeur of conception. I would rather be a man toiling,\r\nsuffering--nay, failing and successless--here, than lead a dull\r\nprosperous life in the old worn grooves of what you call more\r\naristocratic society down in the South, with their slow days of careless\r\nease. One may be clogged with honey and unable to rise and fly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, roused by the aspersion on her\r\nbeloved South to a fond vehemence of defence, that brought the colour\r\ninto her cheeks and the angry tears into her eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cYou do not know\r\nanything about the South. If there is less adventure or less progress--I\r\nsuppose I must not say less excitement--from the gambling spirit of\r\ntrade, which seems requisite to force out these wonderful inventions,\r\nthere is less suffering also. I see men here going about in the streets\r\nwho look ground down by some pinching sorrow or care--who are not only\r\nsufferers but haters. Now, in the South we have our poor, but there is\r\nnot that terrible expression in their countenances of a sullen sense of\r\ninjustice which I see here. You do not know the South, Mr. Thornton,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe concluded, collapsing into a determined silence, and angry with\r\nherself for having said so much.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd may I say you do not know the North?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, with an\r\ninexpressible gentleness in his tone, as he saw that he had really hurt\r\nher. She continued resolutely silent; yearning after the lovely haunts\r\nshe had left far away in Hampshire, with a passionate longing that made\r\nher feel her voice would be unsteady and trembling if she spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate, Mr. Thornton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will allow that Milton\r\nis a much more smoky, dirty town than you will ever meet with in the\r\nSouth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I must give up its cleanliness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton, with the\r\nquick gleaming smile. \xe2\x80\x9cBut we are bidden by parliament to burn our own\r\nsmoke; so I suppose, like good little children, we shall do as we are\r\nbid--some time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I think you told me you had altered your chimneys so as to consume\r\nthe smoke, did you not?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMine were altered by my own will, before parliament meddled with the\r\naffair. It was an immediate outlay, but it repays me in the saving of\r\ncoal. I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure whether I should have done it, if I had waited until\r\nthe act was passed. At any rate, I should have waited to be informed\r\nagainst and fined, and given all the trouble in yielding that I legally\r\ncould. But all laws which depend for their enforcement upon informers\r\nand fines, become inert from the odiousness of the machinery. I doubt if\r\nthere has been a chimney in Milton informed against for five years past,\r\nalthough some are constantly sending out one-third of their coal in what\r\nis called here unparliamentary smoke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only know it is impossible to keep the muslin blinds clean here above\r\na week together; and at Helstone we have had them up for a month or\r\nmore, and they have not looked dirty at the end of that time. And as for\r\nhands--Margaret, how many times did you say you had washed your hands\r\nthis morning before twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock? Three times, was it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, mamma.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou seem to have a strong objection to acts of parliament and all\r\nlegislation affecting your mode of management down here at Milton,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMr. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have; and many others have as well. And with justice, I think.\r\nThe whole machinery--I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean the wood and iron machinery now--of\r\nthe cotton trade is so new that it is no wonder if it does not work well\r\nin every part all at once. Seventy years ago what was it? And now what\r\nit is not? Raw, crude materials came together; men of the same level, as\r\nregarded education and station, took suddenly the different position of\r\nmasters and men, owing to the motherwit, as regarded opportunities and\r\nprobabilities, which distinguished some, and made them far-seeing as to\r\nwhat great future lay concealed in that rude model of Sir Richard\r\nArkwright\xe2\x80\x99s. The rapid development of what might be called a new trade,\r\ngave those early masters enormous power of wealth and command. I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmean merely over the workmen; I mean over purchasers--over the whole\r\nworld\xe2\x80\x99s market. Why, I may give you, as an instance, an advertisement,\r\ninserted not fifty years ago in a Milton paper, that so-and-so (one of\r\nthe half-dozen calico-printers of the time) would close his warehouse at\r\nnoon each day; therefore, that all purchasers must come before that\r\nhour. Fancy a man dictating in this manner the time when he would sell\r\nand when he would not sell. Now, I believe, if a good customer chose to\r\ncome at midnight, I should get up, and stand hat in hand to receive his\r\norders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s lip curled, but somehow she was compelled to listen; she\r\ncould no longer abstract herself in her own thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only name such things to show what almost unlimited power the\r\nmanufacturers had about the beginning of this century. The men were\r\nrendered dizzy by it. Because a man was successful in his ventures,\r\nthere was no reason that in all other things his mind should be\r\nwell-balanced. On the contrary, his sense of justice, and his\r\nsimplicity, were often utterly smothered under the glut of wealth that\r\ncame down upon him; and they tell strange tales of the wild extravagance\r\nof living indulged in on gala-days by those early cotton-lords. There\r\ncan be no doubt, too, of the tyranny they exercised over their\r\nwork-people. You know the proverb, Mr. Hale, \xe2\x80\x98Set a beggar on horseback,\r\nand he\xe2\x80\x99ll ride to the devil,\xe2\x80\x99--well, some of these early manufacturers\r\ndid ride to the devil in a magnificent style--crushing human bone and\r\nflesh under their horses\xe2\x80\x99 hoofs without remorse. But by-and-by came a\r\nreaction; there were more factories, more masters; more men were wanted.\r\nThe power of masters and men became more evenly balanced; and now the\r\nbattle is pretty fairly waged between us. We will hardly submit to the\r\ndecision of an umpire, much less to the interference of a meddler with\r\nonly a smattering of the knowledge of the real facts of the case, even\r\nthough that meddler be called the High Court of Parliament.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there necessity for calling it a battle between the two classes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cI know, from your using the term, it is one which gives\r\na true idea of the real state of things to your mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true; and I believe it to be as much a necessity as that prudent\r\nwisdom and good conduct are always opposed to, and doing battle with\r\nignorance and improvidence. It is one of the great beauties of our\r\nsystem, that a working-man may raise himself into the power and position\r\nof a master by his own exertions and behaviour; that, in fact, every one\r\nwho rules himself to decency and sobriety of conduct, and attention to\r\nhis duties, comes over to our ranks; it may not be always as a master,\r\nbut as an overlooker, a cashier, a book-keeper, a clerk, one on the side\r\nof authority and order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou consider all who are unsuccessful in raising themselves in the\r\nworld, from whatever cause, as your enemies, then, if I understand you\r\nrightly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, in a clear, cold voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs their own enemies, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, quickly, not a little\r\npiqued by the haughty disapproval her form of expression and tone of\r\nspeaking implied. But, in a moment, his straightforward honesty made him\r\nfeel that his words were but a poor and quibbling answer to what she had\r\nsaid, and, be she as scornful as she liked, it was a duty he owed to\r\nhimself to explain, as truly as he could, what he did mean. Yet it was\r\nvery difficult to separate her interpretation, and keep it distinct from\r\nhis meaning. He could best have illustrated what he wanted to say by\r\ntelling them something of his own life; but was it not too personal a\r\nsubject to speak about to strangers? Still, it was the simple\r\nstraightforward way of explaining his meaning; so, putting aside the\r\ntouch of shyness that brought a momentary flush of colour into his dark\r\ncheek, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not speaking without book. Sixteen years ago, my father died under\r\nvery miserable circumstances. I was taken from school, and had to become\r\na man (as well as I could) in a few days. I had such a mother as few are\r\nblest with; a woman of strong power, and firm resolve. We went into a\r\nsmall country town, where living was cheaper than in Milton, and where I\r\ngot employment in a draper\xe2\x80\x99s shop (a capital place, by the way, for\r\nobtaining a knowledge of goods). Week by week, our income came to\r\nfifteen shillings, out of which three people had to be kept. My mother\r\nmanaged so that I put by three out of these fifteen shillings regularly.\r\nThis made the beginning; this taught me self-denial. Now that I am able\r\nto afford my mother such comforts as her age, rather than her own wish,\r\nrequires, I thank her silently on each occasion for the early training\r\nshe gave me. Now when I feel that in my own case it is no good luck, nor\r\nmerit, nor talent,--but simply the habits of life which taught me to\r\ndespise indulgences not thoroughly earned,--indeed, never to think twice\r\nabout them,--I believe that this suffering, which Miss Hale says is\r\nimpressed on the countenances of the people of Milton, is but the\r\nnatural punishment of dishonestly-enjoyed pleasure, at some former\r\nperiod of their lives. I do not look on self-indulgent, sensual people\r\nas worthy of my hatred; I simply look upon them with contempt for their\r\npoorness of character.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have the rudiments of a good education,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Mr. Hale.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe quick zest with which you are now reading Homer, shows me that you\r\ndo not come to it as an unknown book: you have read it before, and are\r\nonly recalling your old knowledge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,--I had blundered along it at school; I dare say, I was\r\neven considered a pretty fair classic in those days, though my Latin and\r\nGreek have slipt away from me since. But I ask you, what preparation\r\nwere they for such a life as I had to lead? None at all. Utterly none at\r\nall. On the point of education, any man who can read and write starts\r\nfair with me in the amount of really useful knowledge that I had at that\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! I don\xe2\x80\x99t agree with you. But there I am perhaps somewhat of a\r\npedant. Did not the recollection of the heroic simplicity of the Homeric\r\nlife nerve you up?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot one bit!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Thornton, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cI was too busy to\r\nthink about any dead people, with the living pressing alongside of me,\r\nneck to neck, in the struggle for bread. Now that I have my mother safe\r\nin the quiet peace that becomes her age, and duly rewards her former\r\nexertions, I can turn to all that old narration and thoroughly enjoy\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say, my remark came from the professional feeling of there being\r\nnothing like leather,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. Thornton rose up to go away, after shaking hands with Mr. and\r\nMrs. Hale, he made an advance to Margaret to wish her good-bye in a\r\nsimilar manner. It was the frank familiar custom of the place; but\r\nMargaret was not prepared for it. She simply bowed her farewell;\r\nalthough the instant she saw the hand, half put out, quickly drawn back,\r\nshe was sorry she had not been aware of the intention. Mr. Thornton,\r\nhowever, knew nothing of her sorrow, and, drawing himself up to his full\r\nheight, walked off, muttering as he left the house--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA more proud, disagreeable girl I never saw. Even her great beauty is\r\nblotted out of one\xe2\x80\x99s memory by her scornful ways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI.\r\n\r\nFIRST IMPRESSIONS.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s iron, they say, in all our blood,\r\n    And a grain or two perhaps is good;\r\n    But his, he makes me harshly feel,\r\n    Has got a little too much of steel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              ANON.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale as he returned from showing his guest\r\ndownstairs; \xe2\x80\x9cI could not help watching your face with some anxiety, when\r\nMr. Thornton made his confession of having been a shop-boy. I knew it\r\nall along from Mr. Bell; so I was aware of what was coming; but I half\r\nexpected to see you get up and leave the room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, papa! you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that you thought me so silly? I really liked\r\nthat account of himself better than anything else he said. Everything\r\nelse revolted me, from its hardness; but he spoke about himself so\r\nsimply--with so little of the pretence that makes the vulgarity of\r\nshop-people, and with such tender respect for his mother, that I was\r\nless likely to leave the room then than when he was boasting about\r\nMilton, as if there was not such another place in the world; or quietly\r\nprofessing to despise people for careless, wasteful improvidence,\r\nwithout ever seeming to think it his duty to try to make them\r\ndifferent,--to give them anything of the training which his mother gave\r\nhim, and to which he evidently owes his position, whatever that may be.\r\nNo! his statement of having been a shop-boy was the thing I liked best\r\nof all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am surprised at you, Margaret,\xe2\x80\x9d said her mother. \xe2\x80\x9cYou who were always\r\naccusing people of being shoppy at Helstone! I don\xe2\x80\x99t think, Mr. Hale,\r\nyou have done quite right in introducing such a person to us without\r\ntelling us what he had been. I really was very much afraid of showing\r\nhim how much shocked I was at some parts of what he said. His father\r\n\xe2\x80\x98dying in miserable circumstances.\xe2\x80\x99 Why it might have been in the\r\nworkhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not sure it was not worse than being in the workhouse,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nher husband. \xe2\x80\x9cI heard a good deal of his previous life from Mr. Bell\r\nbefore we came here; and as he has told you a part, I will fill up what\r\nhe left out. His father speculated wildly, failed, and then killed\r\nhimself, because he could not bear the disgrace. All his former friends\r\nshrunk from the disclosures that had to be made of his dishonest\r\ngambling--wild, hopeless struggles, made with other people\xe2\x80\x99s money, to\r\nregain his own moderate portion of wealth. No one came forward to help\r\nthe mother and this boy. There was another child, I believe, a girl; too\r\nyoung to earn money, but of course she had to be kept. At least, no\r\nfriend came forward immediately, and Mrs. Thornton is not one, I fancy,\r\nto wait till tardy kindness comes to find her out. So they left Milton.\r\nI knew he had gone into a shop, and that his earnings, with some\r\nfragment of property secured to his mother, had been made to keep them\r\nfor a long time. Mr. Bell said they absolutely lived upon water-porridge\r\nfor years--how, he did not know; but long after the creditors had given\r\nup hope of any payment of old Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s debts (if, indeed, they\r\never had hoped at all about it, after his suicide), this young man\r\nreturned to Milton, and went quietly round to each creditor, paying him\r\nthe first instalment of the money owing to him. No noise--no gathering\r\ntogether of creditors--it was done very silently and quietly, but all\r\nwas paid at last; helped on materially by the circumstance of one of the\r\ncreditors, a crabbed old fellow (Mr. Bell says), taking in Mr. Thornton\r\nas a kind of partner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat really is fine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pity such a nature should\r\nbe tainted by his position as a Milton manufacturer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow tainted?\xe2\x80\x9d asked her father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, papa, by that testing everything by the standard of wealth. When he\r\nspoke of the mechanical powers, he evidently looked upon them only as\r\nnew ways of extending trade and making money. And the poor men around\r\nhim--they were poor because they were vicious--out of the pale of his\r\nsympathies because they had not his iron nature, and the capabilities\r\nthat it gives him for being rich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot vicious; he never said that. Improvident and self-indulgent were\r\nhis words.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was collecting her mother\xe2\x80\x99s working materials, and preparing to\r\ngo to bed. Just as she was leaving the room, she hesitated--she was\r\ninclined to make an acknowledgment which she thought would please her\r\nfather, but which to be full and true must include a little annoyance.\r\nHowever, out it came.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, I do think Mr. Thornton a very remarkable man; but personally I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like him at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I do!\xe2\x80\x9d said her father laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cPersonally, as you call it, and\r\nall. I don\xe2\x80\x99t set him up for a hero, or anything of that kind. But\r\ngood-night, child. Your mother looks sadly tired to-night, Margaret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret had noticed her mother\xe2\x80\x99s jaded appearance with anxiety for some\r\ntime past, and this remark of her father\xe2\x80\x99s sent her up to bed with a dim\r\nfear lying like a weight on her heart. The life in Milton was so\r\ndifferent from what Mrs. Hale had been accustomed to live in Helstone,\r\nin and out perpetually into the fresh and open air; the air itself was\r\nso different, deprived of all revivifying principle as it seemed to be\r\nhere; the domestic worries pressed so very closely, and in so new and\r\nsordid a form, upon all the women in the family, that there was good\r\nreason to fear that her mother\xe2\x80\x99s health might be becoming seriously\r\naffected. There were several other signs of something wrong about Mrs.\r\nHale. She and Dixon held mysterious consultations in her bedroom, from\r\nwhich Dixon would come out crying and cross, as was her custom when any\r\ndistress of her mistress called upon her sympathy. Once Margaret had\r\ngone into the chamber soon after Dixon left it, and found her mother on\r\nher knees, and as Margaret stole out she caught a few words which were\r\nevidently a prayer for strength and patience to endure severe bodily\r\nsuffering. Margaret yearned to re-unite the bond of intimate confidence\r\nwhich had been broken by her long residence at her aunt Shaw\xe2\x80\x99s, and\r\nstrove by gentle caresses and softened words to creep into the warmest\r\nplace in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s heart. But though she received caresses and fond\r\nwords back again, in such profusion as would have gladdened her\r\nformerly, yet she felt that there was a secret withheld from her, and\r\nshe believed it bore serious reference to her mother\xe2\x80\x99s health. She lay\r\nawake very long this night, planning how to lessen the evil influence of\r\ntheir Milton life on her mother. A servant to give Dixon permanent\r\nassistance should be got, if she gave up her whole time to the search;\r\nand then, at any rate, her mother might have all the personal attention\r\nshe required, and had been accustomed to her whole life.\r\n\r\nVisiting register offices, seeing all manner of unlikely people, and\r\nvery few in the least likely, absorbed Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s time and thoughts for\r\nseveral days. One afternoon she met Bessy Higgins in the street, and\r\nstopped to speak to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Bessy, how are you? Better, I hope, now the wind has changed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter and not better, if yo\xe2\x80\x99 know what that means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot exactly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Margaret, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m better in not being torn to pieces by coughing o\xe2\x80\x99 nights, but I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nweary and tired o\xe2\x80\x99 Milton, and longing to get away to the land o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nBeulah? and when I think I\xe2\x80\x99m farther and farther off, my heart sinks,\r\nand I\xe2\x80\x99m no better; I\xe2\x80\x99m worse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret turned round to walk alongside of the girl in her feeble\r\nprogress homeward. But for a minute or two she did not speak. At last\r\nshe said in a low voice,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBessy, do you wish to die?\xe2\x80\x9d For she shrank from death herself, with all\r\nthe clinging to life so natural to the young and healthy.\r\n\r\nBessy was silent in her turn for a minute or two. Then she replied,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf yo\xe2\x80\x99d led the life I have, and getten as weary of it as I have, and\r\nthought at times, \xe2\x80\x98maybe it\xe2\x80\x99ll last for fifty or sixty years--it does\r\nwi\xe2\x80\x99 some,\xe2\x80\x99--and got dizzy and dazed, and sick, as each of them sixty\r\nyears seemed to spin about me, and mock me with its length of hours and\r\nminutes, and endless bits o\xe2\x80\x99 time--oh, wench! I tell thee thou\xe2\x80\x99d been\r\nglad enough when th\xe2\x80\x99 doctor said he feared thou\xe2\x80\x99d never see another\r\nwinter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Bessy, what kind of a life has yours been?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNought worse than many others,\xe2\x80\x99 I reckon. Only I fretted against it,\r\nand they didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what was it? You know, I\xe2\x80\x99m a stranger here, so perhaps I\xe2\x80\x99m not so\r\nquick at understanding what you mean as if I\xe2\x80\x99d lived all my life at\r\nMilton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf yo\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 come to our house when yo\xe2\x80\x99 said yo\xe2\x80\x99 would, I could maybe\r\nha\xe2\x80\x99 told you. But father says yo\xe2\x80\x99re just like th\xe2\x80\x99 rest on \xe2\x80\x99em; its out\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 sight out o\xe2\x80\x99 mind wi\xe2\x80\x99 you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know who the rest are; and I\xe2\x80\x99ve been very busy; and, to tell\r\nthe truth, I had forgotten my promise--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99 offered it; we asked none of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had forgotten what I said for the time,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Margaret quietly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should have thought of it again when I was less busy. May I go with\r\nyou now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy gave a quick glance at Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s face, to see if the wish\r\nexpressed was really felt. The sharpness in her eye turned to a wistful\r\nlonging as she met Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s soft and friendly gaze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ha\xe2\x80\x99 none so many to care for me; if yo\xe2\x80\x99 care yo\xe2\x80\x99 may come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo they walked on together in silence. As they turned up into a small\r\ncourt, out of a squalid street, Bessy said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99ll not be daunted if father\xe2\x80\x99s at home, and speaks a bit gruffish at\r\nfirst. He took a mind to ye, yo\xe2\x80\x99 see, and he thought a deal o\xe2\x80\x99 your\r\ncoming to see us; and just because he liked yo\xe2\x80\x99 he was vexed and put\r\nabout.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t fear, Bessy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Nicholas was not at home when they entered. A great slatternly girl,\r\nnot so old as Bessy, but taller and stronger, was busy at the wash-tub,\r\nknocking about the furniture in a rough capable way, but altogether\r\nmaking so much noise that Margaret shrunk, out of sympathy with poor\r\nBessy, who had sat down on the first chair, as if completely tired out\r\nwith her walk. Margaret asked the sister for a cup of water, and while\r\nshe ran to fetch it (knocking down the fire-irons, and tumbling over a\r\nchair in her way), she unloosed Bessy\xe2\x80\x99s bonnet strings, to relieve her\r\ncatching breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think such life as this is worth caring for?\xe2\x80\x9d gasped Bessy, at\r\nlast. Margaret did not speak, but held the water to her lips. Bessy took\r\na long and feverish draught, and then fell back and shut her eyes.\r\nMargaret heard her murmur to herself: \xe2\x80\x9cThey shall hunger no more,\r\nneither thirst any more: neither shall the sun light on them, nor any\r\nheat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret bent over and said, \xe2\x80\x9cBessy don\xe2\x80\x99t be impatient with your life,\r\nwhatever it is--or may have been. Remember who gave it you, and made it\r\nwhat it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was startled by hearing Nicholas speak behind her; he had come in\r\nwithout her noticing him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I\xe2\x80\x99ll not have my wench preached to. She\xe2\x80\x99s bad enough, as it is,\r\nwith her dreams and her methodee fancies, and her visions of cities with\r\ngoulden gates and precious stones. But if it amuses her I let it abe,\r\nbut I\xe2\x80\x99m none going to have more stuff poured into her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut surely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, facing round, \xe2\x80\x9cyou believe in what I said,\r\nthat God gave her life, and ordered what kind of life it was to be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe what I see, and no more. That\xe2\x80\x99s what I believe, young woman.\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe all I hear--no! not by a big deal. I did hear a young\r\nlass make an ado about knowing where we lived, and coming to see us. And\r\nmy wench here thought a deal about it, and flushed up many a time, when\r\nhoo little knew as I was looking at her, at the sound of a strange step.\r\nBut hoo\xe2\x80\x99s come at last,--and hoo\xe2\x80\x99s welcome, as long as hoo\xe2\x80\x99ll keep from\r\npreaching on what hoo knows nought about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy had been watching Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s face; she half sate up to speak now,\r\nlaying her hand on Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s arm with a gesture of entreaty. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nvexed wi\xe2\x80\x99 him--there\xe2\x80\x99s many a one thinks like him: many and many a one\r\nhere. If yo\xe2\x80\x99 could hear them speak, yo\xe2\x80\x99d not be shocked at him; he\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nrare good man, is father--but oh!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, falling back in despair,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat he says at times makes me long to die more than ever, for I want\r\nto know so many things, and am so tossed about wi\xe2\x80\x99 wonder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor wench--poor old wench--I\xe2\x80\x99m loth to vex thee, I am; but a man mun\r\nspeak out for the truth, and when I see the world going all wrong at\r\nthis time o\xe2\x80\x99 day, bothering itself wi\xe2\x80\x99 things it knows nought about, and\r\nleaving undone all the things that lie in disorder close at its\r\nhand--why, I say, leave a\xe2\x80\x99 this talk about religion alone, and set to\r\nwork on what yo\xe2\x80\x99 see and know. That\xe2\x80\x99s my creed. It\xe2\x80\x99s simple, and not far\r\nto fetch, nor hard to work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the girl only pleaded the more with Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t think hardly on him--he\xe2\x80\x99s a good man, he is. I sometimes think I\r\nshall be moped wi\xe2\x80\x99 sorrow even in the City of God, if father is not\r\nthere.\xe2\x80\x9d The feverish colour came into her cheek, and the feverish flame\r\ninto her eye. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you will be there, father! you shall! Oh! my heart!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nShe put her hand to it, and became ghastly pale.\r\n\r\nMargaret held her in her arms, and put the weary head to rest upon her\r\nbosom. She lifted the thin soft hair from off the temples, and bathed\r\nthem with water. Nicholas understood all her signs for different\r\narticles with the quickness of love, and even the round-eyed sister\r\nmoved with laborious gentleness at Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9chush!\xe2\x80\x9d Presently the\r\nspasm that foreshadowed death had passed away, and Bessy roused herself\r\nand said,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go to bed,--it\xe2\x80\x99s best place; but,\xe2\x80\x9d catching at Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s gown,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyo\xe2\x80\x99ll come again,--I know yo\xe2\x80\x99 will--but just say it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will come again to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret.\r\n\r\nBessy leant back against her father, who prepared to carry her upstairs;\r\nbut as Margaret rose to go, he struggled to say something; \xe2\x80\x9cI could wish\r\nthere were a God, if it were only to ask Him to bless thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret went away very sad and thoughtful.\r\n\r\nShe was late for tea at home. At Helstone unpunctuality at meal-times\r\nwas a great fault in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s eyes; but now this, as well as many\r\nother little irregularities, seemed to have lost their power of\r\nirritation, and Margaret almost longed for the old complainings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you met with a servant, dear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, mamma; that Anne Buckley would never have done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose I try,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody else has had their turn at\r\nthis great difficulty. Now let me try. I may be the Cinderella to put on\r\nthe slipper after all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret could hardly smile at this little joke, so oppressed was she by\r\nher visit to the Higginses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you do, papa? How would you set about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I should apply to some good house-mother to recommend me one known\r\nto herself or her servants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good. But we must first catch our house-mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have caught her. Or rather she is coming into the snare, and you\r\nwill catch her to-morrow, if you\xe2\x80\x99re skilful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, Mr. Hale?\xe2\x80\x9d asked his wife, her curiosity aroused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my paragon pupil (as Margaret calls him) has told me that his\r\nmother intends to call on Mrs. and Miss Hale to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Thornton!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mrs. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mother of whom he spoke to us?\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Thornton; the only mother he has, I believe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale,\r\nquietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall like to see her. She must be an uncommon person,\xe2\x80\x9d her mother\r\nadded. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps she may have a relation who might suit us, and be glad\r\nof our place. She sounded to be such a careful economical person, that I\r\nshould like any one out of the same family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale alarmed. \xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t go off on that idea. I\r\nfancy Mrs. Thornton is as haughty and proud in her way as our little\r\nMargaret here is in hers, and that she completely ignores that old time\r\nof trial, and poverty, and economy, of which he speaks so openly. I am\r\nsure, at any rate, she would not like strangers to know anything about\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake notice that is not my kind of haughtiness, papa, if I have any at\r\nall; which I don\xe2\x80\x99t agree to, though you\xe2\x80\x99re always accusing me of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know positively that it is hers either; but from little things\r\nI have gathered from him, I fancy so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey cared too little to ask in what manner her son had spoken about\r\nher. Margaret only wanted to know if she must stay in to receive this\r\ncall, as it would prevent her going to see how Bessy was, until late in\r\nthe day, since the early morning was always occupied in household\r\naffairs; and then she recollected that her mother must not be left to\r\nhave the whole weight of entertaining her visitor.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII.\r\n\r\nMORNING CALLS.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cWell--I suppose we must.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              FRIENDS IN COUNCIL.\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton had had some difficulty in working up his mother to the\r\ndesired point of civility. She did not often make calls; and when she\r\ndid, it was in heavy state that she went through her duties. Her son had\r\ngiven her a carriage; but she refused to let him keep horses for it;\r\nthey were hired for the solemn occasions, when she paid morning or\r\nevening visits. She had had horses for three days, not a fortnight\r\nbefore, and had comfortably \xe2\x80\x9ckilled off\xe2\x80\x9d all her acquaintances, who\r\nmight now put themselves to trouble and expense in their turn. Yet\r\nCrampton was too far off for her to walk; and she had repeatedly\r\nquestioned her son as to whether his wish that she should call on the\r\nHales was strong enough to bear the expense of cab-hire. She would have\r\nbeen thankful if it had not; for, as she said, \xe2\x80\x9cshe saw no use in making\r\nup friendships and intimacies with all the teachers and masters in\r\nMilton; why, he would be wanting her to call on Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s dancing-master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwife, the next thing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so I would, mother, if Mr. Mason and his wife were friendless in a\r\nstrange place, like the Hales.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! you need not speak so hastily. I am going to-morrow. I only wanted\r\nyou exactly to understand about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are going to-morrow, I shall order horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, John. One would think you were made of money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot quite, yet. But about the horses I\xe2\x80\x99m determined. The last time you\r\nwere out in a cab, you came home with a headache from the jolting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never complained of it, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! my mother is not given to complaints,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, a little proudly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut so much the more I have to watch over you. Now, as for Fanny there,\r\na little hardship would do her good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is not made of the same stuff as you are, John. She could not bear\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton was silent after this; for her last words bore relation to\r\na subject which mortified her. She had an unconscious contempt for a\r\nweak character; and Fanny was weak in the very points in which her\r\nmother and brother were strong. Mrs. Thornton was not a woman much\r\ngiven to reasoning; her quick judgment and firm resolution served her in\r\ngood stead of any long arguments and discussions with herself; she felt\r\ninstinctively that nothing could strengthen Fanny to endure hardships\r\npatiently, or face difficulties bravely; and though she winced as she\r\nmade this acknowledgment to herself about her daughter, it only gave her\r\na kind of pitying tenderness of manner towards her; much of the same\r\ndescription of demeanour with which mothers are wont to treat their weak\r\nand sickly children. A stranger, a careless observer might have\r\nconsidered that Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s manner to her children betokened far\r\nmore love to Fanny than to John. But such a one would have been deeply\r\nmistaken. The very daringness with which mother and son spoke out\r\nunpalatable truths, the one to the other, showed a reliance on the firm\r\ncentre of each other\xe2\x80\x99s souls, which the uneasy tenderness of Mrs.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s manner to her daughter, the shame with which she thought to\r\nhide the poverty of her child in all the grand qualities which she\r\nherself possessed unconsciously, and which she set so high a value upon\r\nin others--this shame, I say, betrayed the want of a secure\r\nresting-place for her affection. She never called her son by any name\r\nbut John; \xe2\x80\x9clove,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cdear,\xe2\x80\x9d and such like terms, were reserved for\r\nFanny.
