But her heart gave thanks for him day and night; and she walked\r\nproudly among women for his sake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFanny dear! I shall have horses to the carriage to-day, to go and call\r\non these Hales. Should not you go and see nurse? It\xe2\x80\x99s in the same\r\ndirection, and she\xe2\x80\x99s always so glad to see you. You could go on there\r\nwhile I am at Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! mamma, it\xe2\x80\x99s such a long way, and I am so tired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith what?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Thornton, her brow slightly contracting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know--the weather, I think. It is so relaxing. Couldn\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nbring nurse here, mamma? The carriage could fetch her, and she could\r\nspend the rest of the day here, which I know she would like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton did not speak; but she laid her work on the table, and\r\nseemed to think.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be a long way for her to walk back at night!\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked, at\r\nlast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but I will send her home in a cab. I never thought of her walking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this point, Mr. Thornton came in, just before going to the mill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother! I need hardly say, that if there is any little thing that could\r\nserve Mrs. Hale as an invalid, you will offer it, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I can find it out, I will. But I have never been ill myself, so I am\r\nnot much up to invalids\xe2\x80\x99 fancies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! here is Fanny then, who is seldom without an ailment. She will be\r\nable to suggest something, perhaps--won\xe2\x80\x99t you, Fan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not always an ailment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, pettishly; \xe2\x80\x9cand I am not\r\ngoing with mamma. I have a headache to-day, and I shan\xe2\x80\x99t go out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton looked annoyed. His mother\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were bent on her work, at\r\nwhich she was now stitching away busily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFanny! I wish you to go,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, authoritatively. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will do you\r\ngood, instead of harm. You will oblige me by going, without my saying\r\nanything more about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went abruptly out of the room after saying this.\r\n\r\nIf he had stayed a minute longer, Fanny would have cried at his tone of\r\ncommand, even when he used the words, \xe2\x80\x9cYou will oblige me.\xe2\x80\x9d As it was,\r\nshe grumbled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn always speaks as if I fancied I was ill, and I am sure I never do\r\nfancy any such thing. Who are these Hales that he makes such a fuss\r\nabout?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFanny, don\xe2\x80\x99t speak so of your brother. He has good reasons of some kind\r\nor other, or he would not wish us to go. Make haste and put your things\r\non.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the little altercation between her son and her daughter did not\r\nincline Mrs. Thornton more favourably towards \xe2\x80\x9cthese Hales.\xe2\x80\x9d Her jealous\r\nheart repeated her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s question, \xe2\x80\x9cWho are they, that he is so\r\nanxious we should pay them all this attention?\xe2\x80\x9d It came up like a burden\r\nto a song, long after Fanny had forgotten all about it in the pleasant\r\nexcitement of seeing the effect of a new bonnet in the looking-glass.\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton was shy. It was only of late years that she had had\r\nleisure enough in her life to go into society; and as society she did\r\nnot enjoy it. As dinner-giving, and as criticising other people\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndinners, she took satisfaction in it. But this going to make\r\nacquaintance with strangers was a very different thing. She was ill at\r\nease, and looked more than usually stern and forbidding as she entered\r\nthe Hales\xe2\x80\x99 little drawing-room.\r\n\r\nMargaret was busy embroidering a small piece of cambric for some little\r\narticle of dress for Edith\xe2\x80\x99s expected baby--\xe2\x80\x9cFlimsy, useless work,\xe2\x80\x9d as\r\nMrs. Thornton observed to herself. She liked Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s double knitting\r\nfar better; that was sensible of its kind. The room altogether was full\r\nof knick-knacks, which must take a long time to dust; and time to people\r\nof limited income was money.\r\n\r\nShe made all these reflections as she was talking in her stately way to\r\nMrs. Hale, and uttering all the stereotyped commonplaces that most\r\npeople can find to say with their senses blindfolded. Mrs. Hale was\r\nmaking rather more exertion in her answers, captivated by some real old\r\nlace which Mrs. Thornton wore; \xe2\x80\x9clace,\xe2\x80\x9d as she afterwards observed to\r\nDixon, \xe2\x80\x9cof that old English point which has not been made for this\r\nseventy years, and which cannot be bought. It must have been an\r\nheir-loom, and shows that she had ancestors.\xe2\x80\x9d So the owner of the\r\nancestral lace became worthy of something more than the languid exertion\r\nto be agreeable to a visitor, by which Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s efforts at\r\nconversation would have been otherwise bounded. And presently, Margaret,\r\nracking her brain to talk to Fanny, heard her mother and Mrs. Thornton\r\nplunge into the interminable subject of servants.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you are not musical,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, \xe2\x80\x9cas I see no piano.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am fond of hearing good music; I cannot play well myself; and papa\r\nand mamma don\xe2\x80\x99t care much about it; so we sold our old piano when we\r\ncame here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder how you can exist without one. It almost seems to me a\r\nnecessary of life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifteen shillings a week, and three saved out of them!\xe2\x80\x9d thought\r\nMargaret to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cBut she must have been very young. She probably\r\nhas forgotten her own personal experience. But she must know of those\r\ndays.\xe2\x80\x9d Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s manner had an extra tinge of coldness in it when she\r\nnext spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have good concerts here, I believe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes! Delicious! Too crowded, that is the worst. The directors admit\r\nso indiscriminately. But one is sure to hear the newest music there. I\r\nalways have a large order to give to Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s, the day after a\r\nconcert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you like new music simply for its newness, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh; one knows it is the fashion in London, or else the singers would\r\nnot bring it down here. You have been in London, of course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cI have lived there for several years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! London and the Alhambra are the two places I long to see!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLondon and the Alhambra!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! ever since I read the Tales of the Alhambra. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think I do. But surely, it is a very easy journey to London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but somehow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, lowering her voice, \xe2\x80\x9cmamma has never\r\nbeen to London herself, and can\xe2\x80\x99t understand my longing. She is very\r\nproud of Milton; dirty, smoky place as I feel it to be. I believe she\r\nadmires it the more for those very qualities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it has been Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s home for some years, I can well\r\nunderstand her loving it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, in her clear, bell-like voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you saying about me, Miss Hale? May I inquire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret had not the words ready for an answer to this question, which\r\ntook her a little by surprise, so Miss Thornton replied:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mamma! we are only trying to account for your being so fond of\r\nMilton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not feel that my very natural\r\nliking for the place where I was born and brought up,--and which has\r\nsince been my residence for some years, requires any accounting for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was vexed. As Fanny had put it, it did seem as if they had been\r\nimpertinently discussing Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s feelings; but she also rose up\r\nagainst that lady\xe2\x80\x99s manner of showing that she was offended.\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton went on after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know anything of Milton, Miss Hale? Have you seen any of our\r\nfactories? our magnificent warehouses?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cI have not seen anything of that description as\r\nyet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen she felt that, by concealing her utter indifference to all such\r\nplaces, she was hardly speaking with truth; so she went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say, papa would have taken me before now if I had cared. But I\r\nreally do not find much pleasure in going over manufactories.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are very curious places,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, \xe2\x80\x9cbut there is so much\r\nnoise and dirt always. I remember once going in a lilac silk to see\r\ncandles made, and my gown was utterly ruined.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery probably,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton, in a short displeased manner. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nmerely thought, that as strangers newly come to reside in a town which\r\nhas risen to eminence in the country, from the character and progress of\r\nits peculiar business, you might have cared to visit some of the places\r\nwhere it is carried on; places unique in the kingdom, I am informed. If\r\nMiss Hale changes her mind and condescends to be curious as to the\r\nmanufactures of Milton, I can only say I shall be glad to procure her\r\nadmission to print-works, or reed-making, or the more simple operations\r\nof spinning carried on in my son\xe2\x80\x99s mill. Every improvement of machinery\r\nis, I believe, to be seen there, in its highest perfection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so glad you don\xe2\x80\x99t like mills and manufactories, and all those kind\r\nof things,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, in a half-whisper, as she rose to accompany her\r\nmother, who was taking leave of Mrs. Hale with rustling dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I should like to know all about them, if I were you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nMargaret quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFanny!\xe2\x80\x9d said her mother, as they drove away, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will be civil to these\r\nHales: but don\xe2\x80\x99t form one of your hasty friendships with the daughter.\r\nShe will do you no good, I see. The mother looks very ill, and seems a\r\nnice, quiet kind of person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to form any friendship with Miss Hale, mamma,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny,\r\npouting. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought I was doing my duty by talking to her, and trying to\r\namuse her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! at any rate John must be satisfied now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII.\r\n\r\nSOFT BREEZE IN A SULTRY PLACE.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThat doubt and trouble, fear and pain,\r\n    And anguish, all, are shadows vain,\r\n    That death itself shall not remain;\r\n\r\n    That weary deserts we may tread,\r\n    A dreary labyrinth may thread.\r\n    Thro\xe2\x80\x99 dark ways underground be led;\r\n\r\n    Yet, if we will one Guide obey,\r\n    The dreariest path, the darkest way\r\n    Shall issue out in heavenly day;\r\n\r\n    And we, on divers shores now cast,\r\n    Shall meet, our perilous voyage past,\r\n    All in our Father\xe2\x80\x99s house at last!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              R. C. TRENCH.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret flew up stairs as soon as their visitors were gone, and put on\r\nher bonnet and shawl, to run and inquire how Betsy Higgins was, and sit\r\nwith her as long as she could before dinner. As she went along the\r\ncrowded narrow streets, she felt how much of interest they had gained by\r\nthe simple fact of her having learnt to care for a dweller in them.\r\n\r\nMary Higgins, the slatternly younger sister, had endeavoured as well as\r\nshe could to tidy up the house for the expected visit. There had been\r\nrough-stoning done in the middle of the floor, while the flags under the\r\nchairs and table and round the walls retained their dark unwashed\r\nappearance. Although the day was hot, there burnt a large fire in the\r\ngrate, making the whole place feel like an oven; Margaret did not\r\nunderstand that the lavishness of coals was a sign of hospitable welcome\r\nto her on Mary\xe2\x80\x99s part, and thought that perhaps the oppressive heat was\r\nnecessary for Bessy. Bessy herself lay on a squab, or short sofa, placed\r\nunder the window. She was very much more feeble than on the previous\r\nday, and tired with raising herself at every step to look out and see if\r\nit was Margaret coming. And now that Margaret was there, and had taken a\r\nchair by her, Bessy lay back silent, and content to look at Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface, and touch her articles of dress, with a childish admiration of\r\ntheir fineness of texture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never knew why folk in the Bible cared for soft raiment afore. But it\r\nmust be nice to go dressed as yo\xe2\x80\x99 do. It\xe2\x80\x99s different fro\xe2\x80\x99 common. Most\r\nfine folk tire my eyes out wi\xe2\x80\x99 their colours; but some how yours rest\r\nme. Where did ye get this frock?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn London,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, much amused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLondon! Have yo\xe2\x80\x99 been in London?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! I lived there for some years. But my home was in a forest; in the\r\ncountry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessy. \xe2\x80\x9cI like to hear speak of the country,\r\nand trees, and such like things.\xe2\x80\x9d She leant back, and shut her eyes,\r\nand crossed her hands over her breast, lying at perfect rest, as if to\r\nreceive all the ideas Margaret could suggest.\r\n\r\nMargaret had never spoken of Helstone since she left it, except just\r\nnaming the place incidentally. She saw it in dreams more vivid than\r\nlife, and as she fell away to slumber at nights her memory wandered in\r\nall its pleasant places. But her heart was opened to this girl: \xe2\x80\x9cOh,\r\nBessy, I loved the home we have left so dearly! I wish you could see it.\r\nI cannot tell you half its beauty. There are great trees standing all\r\nabout it, with their branches stretching long and level, and making a\r\ndeep shade of rest even at noonday. And yet, though every leaf may seem\r\nstill, there is a continual rushing sound of movement all around--not\r\nclose at hand. Then sometimes the turf is as soft and fine as velvet;\r\nand sometimes quite lush with the perpetual moisture of a little,\r\nhidden, tinkling brook near at hand. And then in other parts there are\r\nbillowy ferns--whole stretches of fern; some in the green shadow; some\r\nwith long streaks of golden sunlight lying on them--just like the sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have never seen the sea,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Bessy. \xe2\x80\x9cBut go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen here and there, there are wide commons, high up as if above the\r\nvery tops of the trees--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad of that. I felt smothered like down below. When I have gone\r\nfor an out, I\xe2\x80\x99ve always wanted to get high up and see far away, and take\r\na deep breath o\xe2\x80\x99 fulness in that air. I get smothered enough in Milton,\r\nand I think the sound yo\xe2\x80\x99 speak of among the trees, going on for ever\r\nand ever, would send me dazed; it\xe2\x80\x99s that made my head ache so in the\r\nmill. Now on these commons, I reckon, there is but little noise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret; \xe2\x80\x9cnothing but here and there a lark high in the air.\r\nSometimes I used to hear a farmer speaking sharp and loud to his\r\nservants; but it was so far away that it only reminded me pleasantly\r\nthat other people were hard at work in some distant place, while I just\r\nsat on the heather and did nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI used to think once that if I could have a day of doing nothing, to\r\nrest me--a day in some quiet place like that yo\xe2\x80\x99 speak on--it would\r\nmaybe set me up. But now I\xe2\x80\x99ve had many days o\xe2\x80\x99 idleness, and I\xe2\x80\x99m just as\r\nweary \xe2\x80\x99o them as I was o\xe2\x80\x99 my work. Sometimes I\xe2\x80\x99m so tired out I think I\r\ncannot enjoy heaven without a piece of rest first. I\xe2\x80\x99m rather afeard o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ngoing straight there without getting a good sleep in the grave to set me\r\nup.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, laying her hand on the girl\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand; \xe2\x80\x9cGod can give you more perfect rest than even idleness on earth,\r\nor the dead sleep of the grave can do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy moved uneasily; then she said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish father would not speak to me as he does. He means well, as I\r\ntelled yo\xe2\x80\x99 yesterday, and tell yo\xe2\x80\x99 again and again. But yo\xe2\x80\x99 see, though\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe him a bit by day, yet by night--when I\xe2\x80\x99m in a fever,\r\nhalf asleep and half awake--it comes back upon me--oh! so bad! And I\r\nthink, if this should be th\xe2\x80\x99 end of all, and if all I\xe2\x80\x99ve been born for\r\nis just to work my heart and my life away, and to sicken i\xe2\x80\x99 this dree\r\nplace, wi\xe2\x80\x99 them mill-noises in my ears for ever, until I could scream\r\nout for them to stop, and let me have a little piece o\xe2\x80\x99 quiet--and wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthe fluff filling my lungs, until I thirst to death for one long deep\r\nbreath o\xe2\x80\x99 the clear air yo\xe2\x80\x99 speak on--and my mother gone, and I never\r\nable to tell her again how I loved her, and o\xe2\x80\x99 all my troubles--I think\r\nif this life is th\xe2\x80\x99 end, and there\xe2\x80\x99s no God to wipe away all tears from\r\nall eyes--yo\xe2\x80\x99 wench, yo\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, sitting up, and clutching\r\nviolently, almost fiercely, at Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s hand, \xe2\x80\x9cI could go mad, and\r\nkill yo, I could.\xe2\x80\x9d She fell back completely worn out with her passion.\r\nMargaret knelt down by her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBessy--we have a Father in Heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it! I know it,\xe2\x80\x9d moaned she, turning her head uneasily from side\r\nto side. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m very wicked. I\xe2\x80\x99ve spoken very wickedly. Oh! don\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nfrightened by me and never come again. I would not harm a hair of your\r\nhead. And,\xe2\x80\x9d opening her eyes, and looking earnestly at Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nbelieve, perhaps, more than yo\xe2\x80\x99 do o\xe2\x80\x99 what\xe2\x80\x99s to come. I read the book o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nRevelations until I know it off by heart, and I never doubt when I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nwaking, and in my senses, of all the glory I\xe2\x80\x99m to come to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t let us talk of what fancies come into your head when you are\r\nfeverish. I would rather hear something about what you used to do when\r\nyou were well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I was well when mother died, but I have never been rightly\r\nstrong sin\xe2\x80\x99 somewhere about that time. I began to work in a carding-room\r\nsoon after, and the fluff got into my lungs, and poisoned me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFluff?\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, inquiringly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFluff,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Bessy. \xe2\x80\x9cLittle bits, as fly off fro\xe2\x80\x99 the cotton, when\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99re carding it, and fill the air till it looks all fine white dust.\r\nThey say it winds rounds the lungs, and tightens them up. Anyhow,\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s many a one as works in a carding-room, that falls into a waste,\r\ncoughing and spitting blood, because they\xe2\x80\x99re just poisoned by the\r\nfluff.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut can\xe2\x80\x99t it be helped?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dunno. Some folk have a great wheel at one end o\xe2\x80\x99 their carding-rooms\r\nto make a draught, and carry off th\xe2\x80\x99 dust; but that wheel costs a deal\r\nof money--five or six hundred pounds, maybe, and brings in no profit; so\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s but a few of th\xe2\x80\x99 masters as will put \xe2\x80\x99em up; and I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard tell o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmen who didn\xe2\x80\x99t like working in places where there was a wheel, because\r\nthey said as how it made \xe2\x80\x99em hungry, at after they\xe2\x80\x99d been long used to\r\nswallowing fluff, to go without it, and that their wages ought to be\r\nraised if they were to work in such places. So between masters and men\r\nth\xe2\x80\x99 wheels fall through. I know I wish there\xe2\x80\x99d been a wheel in our\r\nplace, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid not your father know about it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! And he was sorry. But our factory were a good one on the whole;\r\nand a steady likely set o\xe2\x80\x99 people; and father was afeard of letting me\r\ngo to a strange place, for though yo\xe2\x80\x99 would na think it now, many a one\r\nthen used to call me a gradely lass enough. And I did na like to be\r\nreckoned nesh and soft, and Mary\xe2\x80\x99s schooling were to be kept up, mother\r\nsaid, and father he were always liking to buy books, and go to lectures\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 one kind and another--all which took money--so I just worked on till\r\nI shall ne\xe2\x80\x99er get the whirr out o\xe2\x80\x99 my ears, or the fluff out o\xe2\x80\x99 my\r\nthroat i\xe2\x80\x99 this world. That\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow old are you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNineteen, come July.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I too am nineteen.\xe2\x80\x9d She thought more sorrowfully than Bessy did, of\r\nthe contrast between them. She could not speak for a moment or two for\r\nthe emotion she was trying to keep down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout Mary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessy. \xe2\x80\x9cI wanted to ask yo\xe2\x80\x99 to be a friend to her.\r\nShe\xe2\x80\x99s seventeen, but she\xe2\x80\x99s th\xe2\x80\x99 last on us. And I don\xe2\x80\x99t want her to go to\r\nth\xe2\x80\x99 mill, and yet I dunno what she\xe2\x80\x99s fit for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe could not do\xe2\x80\x9d--Margaret glanced unconsciously at the uncleaned\r\ncorners of the room--\xe2\x80\x9cShe could hardly undertake a servant\xe2\x80\x99s place,\r\ncould she? We have an old faithful servant, almost a friend, who wants\r\nhelp, but who is very particular; and it would not be right to plague\r\nher with giving her any assistance that would really be an annoyance and\r\nan irritation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I see. I reckon yo\xe2\x80\x99re right. Our Mary\xe2\x80\x99s a good wench; but who has\r\nshe had to teach her what to do about a house? No mother, and me at the\r\nmill till I was good for nothing but scolding her for doing badly what I\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t know how to do a bit. But I wish she could ha\xe2\x80\x99 lived wi\xe2\x80\x99 yo\xe2\x80\x99, for\r\nall that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut even though she may not be exactly fitted to come and live with us\r\nas a servant--and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know about that--I will always try to be a\r\nfriend to her for your sake, Bessy. And now I must go. I will come again\r\nas soon as I can; but if it should not be to-morrow, or the next day, or\r\neven a week or a fortnight hence, don\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten you. I may\r\nbe busy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll know yo\xe2\x80\x99 won\xe2\x80\x99t forget me again. I\xe2\x80\x99ll not mistrust yo\xe2\x80\x99 no more. But\r\nremember, in a week or a fortnight I may be dead and buried!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll come again as soon as I can, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, squeezing her\r\nhand tight. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you\xe2\x80\x99ll let me know if you get worse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, that will I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessy, returning the pressure.\r\n\r\nFrom that day forwards Mrs. Hale became more and more of a suffering\r\ninvalid. It was now drawing near to the anniversary of Edith\xe2\x80\x99s marriage,\r\nand looking back upon the year\xe2\x80\x99s accumulated heap of troubles, Margaret\r\nwondered how they had been borne. If she could have anticipated them,\r\nhow she would have shrunk away and hid herself from the coming time! And\r\nyet day by day had, of itself, and by itself, been very\r\nendurable--small, keen, bright little spots of positive enjoyment having\r\ncome sparkling into the very middle of sorrows. A year ago, or when she\r\nfirst went to Helstone, and first became silently conscious of the\r\nquerulousness in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s temper, she would have groaned bitterly\r\nover the idea of a long illness to be borne in a strange, desolate,\r\nnoisy, busy place, with diminished comforts on every side of the home\r\nlife. But with the increase of serious and just ground of complaint, a\r\nnew kind of patience had sprung up in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s mind. She was gentle\r\nand quiet in intense bodily suffering, almost in proportion as she had\r\nbeen restless and depressed when there had been no real cause for grief.\r\nMr. Hale was in exactly that stage of apprehension which, in men of his\r\nstamp, takes the shape of wilful blindness. He was more irritated than\r\nMargaret had ever known him at his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s expressed anxiety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, Margaret, you are growing fanciful! God knows I should be the\r\nfirst to take the alarm if your mother were really ill; we always saw\r\nwhen she had her headaches at Helstone, even without her telling us. She\r\nlooks quite pale and white when she is ill; and now she has a bright\r\nhealthy colour in her cheeks, just as she used to have when I first knew\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, with hesitation, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know I think that is\r\nthe flush of pain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, Margaret. I tell you, you are too fanciful. You are the\r\nperson not well, I think. Send for the doctor to-morrow for yourself;\r\nand then, if it will make your mind easier, he can see your mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, dear papa. It will make me happier, indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d And she went up\r\nto him to kiss him. But he pushed her away--gently enough, but still as\r\nif she had suggested unpleasant ideas, which he should be glad to get\r\nrid of as readily as he could of her presence. He walked uneasily up and\r\ndown the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Maria!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, half soliloquising, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish one could do right\r\nwithout sacrificing others. I shall hate this town, and myself too, if\r\nshe----. Pray, Margaret, does your mother often talk to you of the old\r\nplaces: of Helstone, I mean.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, you see, she can\xe2\x80\x99t be fretting after them, eh? It has always been\r\na comfort to me to think that your mother was so simple and open that I\r\nknew every little grievance she had. She never would conceal anything\r\nseriously affecting her health from me: would she, eh, Margaret? I am\r\nquite sure she would not. So don\xe2\x80\x99t let me hear of these foolish morbid\r\nideas. Come, give me a kiss, and run off to bed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut she heard him pacing about (racooning, as she and Edith used to call\r\nit) long after her slow and languid undressing was finished--long after\r\nas she began to listen as she lay in bed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIV.\r\n\r\nTHE MEETING.\r\n\r\n                        \xe2\x80\x9cI was used\r\n    To sleep at nights as sweetly as a child,--\r\n    Now if the wind blew rough, it made me start,\r\n    And think of my poor boy tossing about\r\n    Upon the roaring seas. And then I seemed\r\n    To feel that it was hard to take him from me\r\n    For such a little fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                      SOUTHEY.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was a comfort to Margaret about this time, to find that her mother\r\ndrew more tenderly and intimately towards her than she had ever done\r\nsince the days of her childhood. She took her to her heart as a\r\nconfidential friend--the post Margaret had always longed to fill, and\r\nhad envied Dixon for being preferred to. Margaret took pains to respond\r\nto every call made upon her for sympathy--and they were many--even when\r\nthey bore relation to trifles which she would no more have noticed or\r\nregarded herself than the elephant would perceive the little pin at his\r\nfeet, which yet he lifts carefully up at the bidding of his keeper. All\r\nunconsciously Margaret drew near to a reward.\r\n\r\nOne evening, Mr. Hale being absent, her mother began to talk to her\r\nabout her brother Frederick, the very subject on which Margaret had\r\nlonged to ask questions, and almost the only one on which her timidity\r\novercame her natural openness. The more she wanted to hear about him,\r\nthe less likely she was to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Margaret, it was so windy last night! It came howling down the\r\nchimney in our room! I could not sleep. I never can when there is such a\r\nterrible wind. I got into a wakeful habit when poor Frederick was at\r\nsea; and now, even if I don\xe2\x80\x99t waken all at once, I dream of him in some\r\nstormy sea, with great, clear, glass-green walls of waves on either side\r\nhis ship, but far higher than her very masts, curling over her with that\r\ncruel, terrible white foam, like some gigantic crested serpent. It is an\r\nold dream, but it always comes back on windy nights, till I am thankful\r\nto waken, sitting straight and stiff up in bed with my terror. Poor\r\nFrederick! He is on land now, so wind can do him no harm. Though I did\r\nthink it might shake down some of those tall chimneys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Frederick now, mamma? Our letters are directed to the care of\r\nMessrs. Barbour, at Cadiz. I know: but where is he himself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t remember the name of the place, but he is not called Hale; you\r\nmust remember that, Margaret. Notice the F. D. in every corner of the\r\nletters. He has taken the name of Dickenson. I wanted him to have been\r\ncalled Beresford, to which he had a kind of right, but your father\r\nthought he had better not. He might be recognised, you know, if he were\r\ncalled by my name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cI was at Aunt Shaw\xe2\x80\x99s when it all happened; and\r\nI suppose I was not old enough to be told plainly about it. But I should\r\nlike to know now, if I may--if it does not give you too much pain to\r\nspeak about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPain! No,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mrs. Hale, her cheek flushing. \xe2\x80\x9cYet it is pain to\r\nthink that perhaps I may never see my darling boy again. Or else he did\r\nright, Margaret. They may say what they like, but I have his own letters\r\nto show, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll believe him, though he is my son, sooner than any\r\ncourt-martial on earth. Go to my little japan cabinet, dear, and in the\r\nsecond left-hand drawer you will find a packet of letters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret went. There were the yellow, sea-stained letters, with the\r\npeculiar fragrance which ocean letters have. Margaret carried them back\r\nto her mother, who untied the silken string with trembling fingers, and,\r\nexamining their dates, she gave them to Margaret to read, making her\r\nhurried, anxious remarks on their contents, almost before her daughter\r\ncould have understood what they were.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, Margaret, how from the very first he disliked Captain Reid. He\r\nwas second lieutenant in the ship--the Orion--in which Frederick sailed\r\nthe very first time. Poor little fellow, how well he looked in his\r\nmidshipman\xe2\x80\x99s dress, with his dirk in his hand, cutting open all the\r\nnewspapers with it as if it were a paper-knife! But this Mr. Reid, as he\r\nwas then, seemed to take a dislike to Frederick from the very beginning.\r\nAnd then--stay! these are the letters he wrote on board the Russell.\r\nWhen he was appointed to her, and found his old enemy Captain Reid in\r\ncommand, he did mean to bear all his tyranny patiently. Look! this is\r\nthe letter. Just read it, Margaret. Where is it he says--Stop--\xe2\x80\x98my\r\nfather may rely upon me, that I will bear with all proper patience\r\neverything that one officer and gentleman can take from another. But\r\nfrom my former knowledge of my present captain, I confess I look forward\r\nwith apprehension to a long course of tyranny on board the Russell.\xe2\x80\x99 You\r\nsee, he promises to bear patiently, and I am sure he did, for he was the\r\nsweetest-tempered boy, when he was not vexed, that could possibly be. Is\r\nthat the letter in which he speaks of Captain Reid\xe2\x80\x99s impatience with the\r\nmen, for not going through the ship\xe2\x80\x99s man\xc5\x93uvres as quickly as the\r\nAvenger? You see, he says that they had many new hands on board the\r\nRussell, while the Avenger had been nearly three years on the station,\r\nwith nothing to do but to keep slavers off, and work her men, till they\r\nran up and down the rigging like rats or monkeys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret slowly read the letter, half illegible through the fading of\r\nthe ink. It might be--it probably was--a statement of Captain Reid\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimperiousness in trifles, very much exaggerated by the narrator, who had\r\nwritten it while fresh and warm from the scene of altercation. Some\r\nsailors being aloft in the main-topsail rigging, the captain had ordered\r\nthem to race down, threatening the hindmost with the cat-of-nine tails.\r\nHe who was the farthest on the spar, feeling the impossibility of\r\npassing his companions, and yet passionately dreading the disgrace of\r\nthe flogging, threw himself desperately down to catch a rope\r\nconsiderably lower, failed, and fell senseless on the deck. He only\r\nsurvived for a few hours afterwards, and the indignation of the ship\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncrew was at boiling point when young Hale wrote.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut we did not receive this letter till long, long after we heard of\r\nthe mutiny. Poor Fred! I dare say it was a comfort to him to write it,\r\neven though he could not have known how to send it, poor fellow! And\r\nthen we saw a report in the papers--that\xe2\x80\x99s to say, long before Fred\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nletter reached us--of an atrocious mutiny having broken out on board the\r\nRussell, and that the mutineers had remained in possession of the ship,\r\nwhich had gone off, it was supposed, to be a pirate; and that Captain\r\nReid was sent adrift in a boat with some men--officers or\r\nsomething--whose names were all given, for they were picked up by a West\r\nIndian steamer. Oh, Margaret! how your father and I turned sick over\r\nthat list, when there was no name of Frederick Hale. We thought it must\r\nbe some mistake; for poor Fred was such a fine fellow, only perhaps\r\nrather too passionate; and we hoped that the name of Carr, which was in\r\nthe list, was a misprint for that of Hale--newspapers are so careless.\r\nAnd towards post-time the next day, papa set off to walk to Southampton\r\nto get the papers; and I could not stop at home, so I went to meet him.\r\nHe was very late--much later than I thought he would have been; and I\r\nsat down under the hedge to wait for him. He came at last, his arms\r\nhanging loose down, his head sunk, and walking heavily along, as if\r\nevery step was a labour and a trouble. Margaret, I see him now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t go on, mamma. I can understand it all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, leaning up\r\ncaressingly against her mother\xe2\x80\x99s side, and kissing her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you can\xe2\x80\x99t, Margaret. No one can who did not see him then. I could\r\nhardly lift myself up to go and meet him--everything seemed so to reel\r\naround me all at once. And when I got to him, he did not speak, or seem\r\nsurprised to see me there, more than three miles from home, beside the\r\nOldham beech-tree; but he put my arm in his, and kept stroking my hand,\r\nas if he wanted to soothe me to be very quiet under some great heavy\r\nblow; and when I trembled so all over that I could not speak, he took me\r\nin his arms, and stooped down his head on mine, and began to shake and\r\nto cry in a strange muffled, groaning voice, till I, for very fright,\r\nstood quite still, and only begging him to tell me what he had heard.\r\nAnd then, with his hand jerking, as if some one else moved it against\r\nhis will, he gave me a wicked newspaper to read, calling our Frederick a\r\n\xe2\x80\x98traitor of the blackest dye,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98a base, ungrateful disgrace to his\r\nprofession.\xe2\x80\x99 Oh! I cannot tell what bad words they did not use. I took\r\nthe paper in my hands as soon as I had read it--I tore it up to little\r\nbits--I tore it--oh! I believe, Margaret, I tore it with my teeth. I did\r\nnot cry. I could not. My cheeks were as hot as fire, and my very eyes\r\nburnt in my head. I saw your father looking grave at me. I said it was a\r\nlie, and so it was. Months after, this letter came, and you see what\r\nprovocation Frederick had. It was not for himself, or his own injuries,\r\nhe rebelled; but he would speak his mind to Captain Reid, and so it\r\nwent on from bad to worse; and you see, most of the sailors stuck by\r\nFrederick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think, Margaret,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, after a pause, in a weak, trembling,\r\nexhausted voice, \xe2\x80\x9cI am glad of it--I am prouder of Frederick standing up\r\nagainst injustice, than if he had been simply a good officer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, in a firm, decided tone. \xe2\x80\x9cLoyalty and\r\nobedience to wisdom and justice are fine; but it is still finer to defy\r\narbitrary power, unjustly and cruelly used--not on behalf of ourselves,\r\nbut on behalf of others more helpless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor all that, I wish I could see Frederick once more--just once. He was\r\nmy first baby, Margaret.\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Hale spoke wistfully, and almost as if\r\napologising for the yearning, craving wish, as though it were a\r\ndepreciation of her remaining child. But such an idea never crossed\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s mind. She was thinking how her mother\xe2\x80\x99s desire could be\r\nfulfilled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is six or seven years ago--would they still prosecute him, mother.\r\nIf he came and stood his trial, what would be the punishment? Surely, he\r\nmight bring evidence of his great provocation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would do no good,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mrs. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cSome of the sailors who\r\naccompanied Frederick were taken, and there was a court-martial held on\r\nthem on board the Amicia; I believed all they said in their defence,\r\npoor fellows, because it just agreed with Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s story--but it was\r\nof no use,--\xe2\x80\x9d and for the first time during the conversation Mrs. Hale\r\nbegan to cry; yet something possessed Margaret to force the information\r\nshe foresaw, yet dreaded, from her mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat happened to them, mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d asked she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were hung at the yard-arm,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, solemnly. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the\r\nworst was that the court, in condemning them to death, said they had\r\nsuffered themselves to be led astray from their duty by their superior\r\nofficers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were silent for a long time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Frederick was in South America for several years, was he not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. And now he is in Spain. At Cadiz, or somewhere near it. If he\r\ncomes to England he will be hung. I shall never see his face again--for\r\nif he comes to England he will be hung.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no comfort to be given. Mrs. Hale turned her face to the wall,\r\nand lay perfectly still in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s despair. Nothing could be said\r\nto console her. She took her hand out of Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s with a little\r\nimpatient movement, as if she would fain be left alone with the\r\nrecollection of her son. When Mr. Hale came in, Margaret went out,\r\noppressed with gloom, and seeing no promise of brightness on any side of\r\nthe horizon.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XV\r\n\r\nMASTERS AND MEN.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThought fights with thought; out springs a spark of truth\r\n    From the collision of the sword and shield.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              W. S. LANDOR.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret,\xe2\x80\x9d said her father, the next day, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must return Mrs.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s call. Your mother is not very well, and thinks she cannot\r\nwalk so far; but you and I will go this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs they went, Mr. Hale began about his wife\xe2\x80\x99s health, with a kind of\r\nveiled anxiety, which Margaret was glad to see awakened at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you consult the doctor, Margaret? Did you send for him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, papa, you spoke of his coming to see me. Now I was well. But if I\r\nonly knew of some good doctor, I would go this afternoon, and ask him to\r\ncome, for I am sure mamma is seriously indisposed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe put the truth thus plainly and strongly because her father had so\r\ncompletely shut his mind against the idea, when she had last named her\r\nfears. But now the case was changed. He answered in a despondent tone:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think she has any hidden complaint? Do you think she is really\r\nvery ill? Has Dixon said anything? Oh, Margaret! I am haunted by the\r\nfear that our coming to Milton has killed her. My poor Maria!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, papa! don\xe2\x80\x99t imagine such things,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, shocked. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is\r\nnot well, that is all. Many a one is not well for a time; and with good\r\nadvice gets better and stronger than ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut has Dixon said anything about her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! You know Dixon enjoys making a mystery out of trifles; and she has\r\nbeen a little mysterious about mamma\xe2\x80\x99s health, which has alarmed me\r\nrather, that is all. Without any reason I dare say. You know, papa, you\r\nsaid the other day I was getting fanciful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope and trust you are. But don\xe2\x80\x99t think of what I said then. I like\r\nyou to be fanciful about your mother\xe2\x80\x99s health! Don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid of\r\ntelling me your fancies. I like to hear them, though I dare say, I spoke\r\nas if I was annoyed. But we will ask Mrs. Thornton if she can tell us of\r\na good doctor. We won\xe2\x80\x99t throw away our money on any but some one\r\nfirst-rate. Stay, we turn up this street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe street did not look as if it could contain any house large enough\r\nfor Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s habitation. Her son\xe2\x80\x99s presence never gave any\r\nimpression as to the kind of house he lived in; but, unconsciously,\r\nMargaret had imagined that tall, massive, handsomely dressed Mrs.\r\nThornton must live in a house of the same character as herself. Now\r\nMarlborough Street consisted of long rows of small houses, with a blank\r\nwall here and there; at least that was all they could see from the point\r\nat which they entered it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe told me he lived in Marlborough Street, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale,\r\nwith a much perplexed air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps it is one of the economies he still practises, to live in a\r\nvery small house. But here are plenty of people about; let me ask.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe accordingly inquired of a passer-by, and was informed that Mr.\r\nThornton lived close to the mill, and had the factory lodge-door pointed\r\nout to her, at the end of the long dead wall they had noticed.\r\n\r\nThe lodge-door was like a common garden-door; on one side of it were\r\ngreat closed gates for the ingress and egress of lorries and wagons. The\r\nlodge-keeper admitted them into a great oblong yard, on one side of\r\nwhich were offices for the transaction of business; on the opposite, an\r\nimmense many-windowed mill, whence proceeded the continual clank of\r\nmachinery and the long groaning roar of the steam-engine, enough to\r\ndeafen those who lived within the enclosure. Opposite to the wall, along\r\nwhich the street ran, on one of the narrow sides of the oblong, was a\r\nhandsome stone-coped house,--blackened, to be sure, by the smoke, but\r\nwith paint, windows, and steps kept scrupulously clean. It was evidently\r\na house which had been built some fifty or sixty years. The stone\r\nfacings--the long, narrow windows, and the number of them--the flights\r\nof steps up to the front door, ascending from either side, and guarded\r\nby railing--all witnessed to its age. Margaret only wondered why people\r\nwho could afford to live in so good a house, and keep it in such perfect\r\norder, did not prefer a much smaller dwelling in the country, or even\r\nsome suburb; not in the continual whirl and din of the factory. Her\r\nunaccustomed ears could hardly catch her father\xe2\x80\x99s voice, as they stood\r\non the steps awaiting the opening of the door. The yard, too, with the\r\ngreat doors in the dead wall as a boundary, was but a dismal look-out\r\nfor the sitting-rooms of the house--as Margaret found when they had\r\nmounted the old-fashioned stairs, and been ushered into the\r\ndrawing-room, the three windows of which went over the front door and\r\nthe room on the right-hand side of the entrance. There was no one in the\r\ndrawing-room. It seemed as though no one had been in it since the day\r\nwhen the furniture was bagged up with as much care as if the house was\r\nto be overwhelmed with lava, and discovered a thousand years hence. The\r\nwalls were pink and gold; the pattern on the carpet represented bunches\r\nof flowers on a light ground, but it was carefully covered up in the\r\ncentre by a linen drugget, glazed and colourless. The window-curtains\r\nwere lace; each chair and sofa had its own particular veil of netting or\r\nknitting. Great alabaster groups occupied every flat surface, safe from\r\ndust under their glass shades. In the middle of the room, right under\r\nthe bagged-up chandelier, was a large circular table, with smartly-bound\r\nbooks arranged at regular intervals round the circumference of its\r\npolished surface, like gaily coloured spokes of a wheel. Everything\r\nreflected light, nothing absorbed it. The whole room had a painfully\r\nspotted, spangled, speckled look about it, which impressed Margaret so\r\nunpleasantly that she was hardly conscious of the peculiar cleanliness\r\nrequired to keep everything so white and pure in such an atmosphere, or\r\nof the trouble that must be willingly expended to secure that effect of\r\nicy, snowy discomfort. Wherever she looked there was evidence of care\r\nand labour, but not care and labour to procure ease, to help on habits\r\nof tranquil home employment; solely to ornament and then to preserve\r\nornament from dirt or destruction.\r\n\r\nThey had leisure to observe, and to speak to each other in low voices,\r\nbefore Mrs. Thornton appeared. They were talking of what all the world\r\nmight hear; but it is a common effect of such a room as this to make\r\npeople speak low, as if unwilling to awaken the unused echoes.\r\n\r\nAt last Mrs. Thornton came in, rustling in handsome black silk, as was\r\nher wont; her muslins and laces rivalling, not excelling, the pure\r\nwhiteness of the muslins and netting of the room. Margaret explained how\r\nit was that her mother could not accompany them to return Mrs.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s call; but in her anxiety not to bring back her father\xe2\x80\x99s fears\r\ntoo vividly, she gave but a bungling account, and left the impression on\r\nMrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s mind that Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s was some temporary or fanciful\r\nfine-ladyish indisposition, which might have been put aside had there\r\nbeen a strong enough motive; or that if it was too severe to allow her\r\nto come out that day, the call might have been deferred. Remembering,\r\ntoo, the horses to her carriage, hired for her own visit to the Hales,\r\nand how Fanny had been ordered to go by Mr. Thornton, in order to pay\r\nevery respect to them, Mrs. Thornton drew up slightly offended, and gave\r\nMargaret no sympathy--indeed, hardly any credit for the statement of her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s indisposition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is Mr. Thornton?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cI was afraid he was not well,\r\nfrom his hurried note yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy son is rarely ill; and when he is, he never speaks about it, or\r\nmakes it an excuse for not doing anything. He told me he could not get\r\nleisure to read with you last night, sir. He regretted it, I am sure; he\r\nvalues the hours spent with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure they are equally agreeable to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cIt makes\r\nme feel young again to see his enjoyment and appreciation of all that is\r\nfine in classical literature.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no doubt that classics are very desirable for people who have\r\nleisure. But I confess, it was against my judgment that my son renewed\r\nhis study of them. The time and place in which he lives, seem to me to\r\nrequire all his energy and attention. Classics may do very well for men\r\nwho loiter away their lives in the country or in colleges; but Milton\r\nmen ought to have their thoughts and powers absorbed in the work of\r\nto-day. At least, that is my opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d This last clause she gave out\r\nwith \xe2\x80\x9cthe pride that apes humility.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, surely, if the mind is too long directed to one object only, it\r\nwill get stiff and rigid, and unable to take in many interests,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMargaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not quite understand what you mean by a mind getting stiff and\r\nrigid. Nor do I admire those whirligig characters that are full of this\r\nthing to-day, to be utterly forgetful of it in their new interest\r\nto-morrow. Having many interests does not suit the life of a Milton\r\nmanufacturer. It is or ought to be enough for him to have one great\r\ndesire, and to bring all the purposes of his life to bear on the\r\nfulfilment of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is--?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\nHer sallow cheek flushed, and her eye lightened, as she answered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo hold and maintain a high, honourable place among the merchants of\r\nhis country--the men of his town. Such a place my son has earned for\r\nhimself. Go where you will--I don\xe2\x80\x99t say in England only, but in\r\nEurope--the name of John Thornton of Milton is known and respected\r\namongst all men of business. Of course, it is unknown in the fashionable\r\ncircles,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued scornfully. \xe2\x80\x9cIdle gentlemen and ladies are not\r\nlikely to know much of a Milton manufacturer, unless he gets into\r\nparliament, or marries a lord\xe2\x80\x99s daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth Mr. Hale and Margaret had an uneasy, ludicrous consciousness that\r\nthey had never heard of this great name, until Mr. Bell had written them\r\nword that Mr. Thornton would be a good friend to have in Milton. The\r\nproud mother\xe2\x80\x99s world was not their world of Harley street gentilities on\r\nthe one hand, or country clergymen and Hampshire squires on the other.\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s face, in spite of all her endeavours to keep it simply\r\nlistening in its expression, told the sensitive Mrs. Thornton this\r\nfeeling of hers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think you never heard of this wonderful son of mine, Miss Hale. You\r\nthink I\xe2\x80\x99m an old woman whose ideas are hounded by Milton, and whose own\r\ncrow is the whitest ever seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, with some spirit. \xe2\x80\x9cIt may be true that I was\r\nthinking I had hardly heard Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s name before I came to Milton.\r\nBut since I have come here, I have heard enough to make me respect and\r\nadmire him, and to feel how much justice and truth there is in what you\r\nhave said of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho spoke to you of him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Thornton, a little mollified, yet\r\njealous lest any one else\xe2\x80\x99s words should not have done him full justice.\r\n\r\nMargaret hesitated before she replied. She did not like this\r\nauthoritative questioning. Mr. Hale came in, as he thought, to the\r\nrescue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was what Mr. Thornton said himself, that made us know the kind of\r\nman he was. Was it not, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton drew herself up, and said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy son is not the one to tell of his own doings. May I again ask you,\r\nMiss Hale, from whose account you formed your favourable opinion of him?\r\nA mother is curious and greedy of commendation of her children, you\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret replied, \xe2\x80\x9cIt was as much from what Mr. Thornton withheld of\r\nthat which we had been told of his previous life by Mr. Bell,--it was\r\nmore that than what he said, that made us all feel what reason you have\r\nto be proud of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bell! What can he know of John? He, living a lazy life in a drowsy\r\ncollege. But I\xe2\x80\x99m obliged to you, Miss Hale. Many a missy young lady\r\nwould have shrunk from giving an old woman the pleasure of hearing that\r\nher son was well spoken of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret, looking straight at Mrs. Thornton, in\r\nbewilderment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy! because I suppose they might have consciences that told them how\r\nsurely they were making the old mother into an advocate for them, in\r\ncase they had any plans on the son\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe smiled a grim smile, for she had been pleased by Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfrankness; and perhaps she felt that she had been asking questions too\r\nmuch as if she had a right to catechise. Margaret laughed outright at\r\nthe notion presented to her; laughed so merrily that it grated on Mrs.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s ear, as if the words that called forth that laugh, must have\r\nbeen utterly and entirely ludicrous.\r\n\r\nMargaret stopped her merriment as soon as she saw Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nannoyed look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, madam. But I really am very much obliged to you for\r\nexonerating me from making any plans on Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYoung ladies have, before now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton, stiffly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope Miss Thornton is well,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Mr. Hale, desirous of changing\r\nthe current of the conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is as well as she ever is. She is not strong,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mrs.\r\nThornton, shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Mr. Thornton? I suppose I may hope to see him on Thursday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot answer for my son\xe2\x80\x99s engagements. There is some uncomfortable\r\nwork going on in the town; a threatening of a strike. If so, his\r\nexperience and judgment will make him much consulted by his friends. But\r\nI should think he could come on Thursday. At any rate, I am sure he will\r\nlet you know if he cannot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA strike!\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat for? What are they going to strike\r\nfor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the mastership and ownership of other people\xe2\x80\x99s property,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nThornton, with a fierce snort. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is what they always strike for. If\r\nmy son\xe2\x80\x99s work-people strike, I will only say they are a pack of\r\nungrateful hounds. But I have no doubt they will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are wanting higher wages, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the face of the thing. But the truth is, they want to be\r\nmasters, and make the masters into slaves on their own ground. They are\r\nalways trying at it; they always have it in their minds; and every five\r\nor six years, there comes a struggle between masters and men. They\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nfind themselves mistaken this time, I fancy,--a little out of their\r\nreckoning. If they turn out, they mayn\xe2\x80\x99t find it so easy to go in again.\r\nI believe, the masters have a thing or two in their heads which will\r\nteach the men not to strike again in a hurry, if they try it this time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes it make the town very rough?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course it does. But surely you are not a coward, are you? Milton is\r\nnot the place for cowards. I have known the time when I have had to\r\nthread my way through a crowd of white, angry men, all swearing they\r\nwould have Makinson\xe2\x80\x99s blood as soon as he ventured to show his nose out\r\nof his factory; and he, knowing nothing of it, some one had to go and\r\ntell him, or he was a dead man; and it needed to be a woman,--so I went.\r\nAnd when I got in, I could not get out. It was as much as my life was\r\nworth. So I went up to the roof, where there were stones piled ready to\r\ndrop on the heads of the crowd, if they tried to force the factory\r\ndoors. And I would have lifted those heavy stones, and dropped them with\r\nas good an aim as the best man there, but that I fainted with the heat I\r\nhad gone through. If you live in Milton, you must learn to have a brave\r\nheart, Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would do my best,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret rather pale. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not know whether\r\nI am brave or not till I am tried; but I am afraid I should be a\r\ncoward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSouth country people are often frightened by what our Darkshire men and\r\nwomen only call living and struggling. But when you\xe2\x80\x99ve been ten years\r\namong a people who are always owing their betters a grudge, and only\r\nwaiting for an opportunity to pay it off, you\xe2\x80\x99ll know whether you are a\r\ncoward or not, take my word for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton came that evening to Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s. He was shown up into the\r\ndrawing-room, where Mr. Hale was reading aloud to his wife and daughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am come partly to bring you a note from my mother, and partly to\r\napologise for not keeping to my time yesterday. The note contains the\r\naddress you asked for; Dr. Donaldson.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, hastily, holding out her hand to take the\r\nnote, for she did not wish her mother to hear that they had been making\r\nany inquiry about a doctor. She was pleased that Mr. Thornton seemed\r\nimmediately to understand her feeling; he gave her the note without\r\nanother word of explanation.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale began to talk about the strike. Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s face assumed a\r\nlikeness to his mother\xe2\x80\x99s worst expression, which immediately repelled\r\nthe watching Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; the fools will have a strike. Let them. It suits us well enough.\r\nBut we gave them a chance. They think trade is flourishing as it was\r\nlast year. We see the storm on the horizon and draw in our sails. But\r\nbecause we don\xe2\x80\x99t explain our reasons, they won\xe2\x80\x99t believe we\xe2\x80\x99re acting\r\nreasonably. We must give them line and letter for the way we choose to\r\nspend or save our money. Henderson tried a dodge with his men, out at\r\nAshley, and failed. He rather wanted a strike; it would have suited his\r\nbook well enough. So when the men came to ask for the five per cent.\r\nthey are claiming, he told \xe2\x80\x99em he\xe2\x80\x99d think about it, and give them his\r\nanswer on the pay day; knowing all the while what his answer would be,\r\nof course, but thinking he\xe2\x80\x99d strengthen their conceit of their own way.\r\nHowever, they were too deep for him, and heard something about the bad\r\nprospects of trade. So in they came on the Friday, and drew back their\r\nclaim, and now he\xe2\x80\x99s obliged to go on working. But we Milton masters have\r\nto-day sent in our decision. We won\xe2\x80\x99t advance a penny. We tell them we\r\nmay have to lower wages; but can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to raise. So here we stand,\r\nwaiting for their next attack.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what will that be?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI conjecture a simultaneous strike. You will see Milton without smoke\r\nin a few days, I imagine, Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why,\xe2\x80\x9d asked she, \xe2\x80\x9ccould you not explain what good reason you had\r\nfor expecting a bad trade? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether I use the right words,\r\nbut you will understand what I mean.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you give your servants reasons for your expenditure, or your economy\r\nin the use of your own money? We, the owners of capital, have a right to\r\nchoose what we will do with it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA human right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, very low.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, I did not hear what you said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather not repeat it,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cit related to a feeling which\r\nI do not think you would share.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you try me?\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded he; his thoughts suddenly bent upon learning\r\nwhat she had said. She was displeased with his pertinacity, but did not\r\nchoose to affix too much importance to her words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said you had a human right. I meant that there seemed no reason but\r\nreligious ones, why you should not do what you like with your own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know we differ in our religious opinions; but don\xe2\x80\x99t you give me\r\ncredit for having some, though not the same as yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was speaking in a subdued voice, as if to her alone. She did not wish\r\nto be so exclusively addressed. She replied out in her usual tone:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think that I have any occasion to consider your special\r\nreligious opinions in the affair. All I meant to say is, that there is\r\nno human law to prevent the employers from utterly wasting or throwing\r\naway all their money, if they choose; but that there are passages in the\r\nBible which would rather imply--to me at least--that they neglected\r\ntheir duties as stewards if they did so. However, I know so little about\r\nstrikes and rate of wages, and capital, and labour, that I had better\r\nnot talk to a political economist like you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, the more reason,\xe2\x80\x9d said he eagerly. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall only be too glad to\r\nexplain to you all that may seem anomalous or mysterious to a stranger;\r\nespecially at a time like this, when our doings are sure to be canvassed\r\nby every scribbler who can hold a pen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, coldly. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course, I shall apply to my\r\nfather in the first instance for any information he can give me, if I\r\nget puzzled with living here amongst this strange society.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think it strange. Why?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know--I suppose because, on the very face of it, I see two\r\nclasses dependent on each other in every possible way, yet each\r\nevidently regarding the interests of the other as opposed to their own:\r\nI never lived in a place before where there were two sets of people\r\nalways running each other down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho have you heard running the masters down? I don\xe2\x80\x99t ask who you have\r\nheard abusing the men; for I see you persist in misunderstanding what I\r\nsaid the other day. But who have you heard abusing the masters?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret reddened; then smiled as she said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not fond of being catechised. I refuse to answer your question.\r\nBesides, it has nothing to do with the fact. You must take my word for\r\nit, that I have heard some people, or, it may be, only some one of the\r\nworkpeople speak as though it were the interest of the employers to keep\r\nthem from acquiring money--that it would make them too independent if\r\nthey had a sum in the savings\xe2\x80\x99 bank.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say it was that man Higgins who told you all this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nHale. Mr. Thornton did not appear to hear what Margaret evidently did\r\nnot wish him to know. But he caught it nevertheless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI heard, moreover, that it was considered to the advantage of the\r\nmasters to have ignorant workmen--not hedge-lawyers, as Captain Lennox\r\nused to call those men in his company who questioned and would know the\r\nreason for every order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis latter part of her sentence she addressed rather to her father than\r\nto Mr. Thornton. Who is Captain Lennox? asked Mr. Thornton of himself,\r\nwith a strange kind of displeasure, that prevented him for the moment\r\nfrom replying to her! Her father took up the conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou never were fond of schools, Margaret, or you would have seen and\r\nknown before this how much is being done for education in Milton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with sudden meekness. \xe2\x80\x9cI know I do not care enough about\r\nschools. But the knowledge and the ignorance of which I was speaking did\r\nnot relate to reading and writing,--the teaching or information one can\r\ngive to a child. I am sure, that what was meant was ignorance of the\r\nwisdom that shall guide men and women. I hardly know what that is. But\r\nhe--that is my informant--spoke as if the masters would like their hands\r\nto be merely tall, large children--living in the present moment--with a\r\nblind unreasoning kind of obedience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn short, Miss Hale, it is very evident that your informant found a\r\npretty ready listener to all the slander he chose to utter against the\r\nmasters,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton, in an offended tone.\r\n\r\nMargaret did not reply. She was displeased at the personal character Mr.\r\nThornton affixed to what she had said.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale spoke next:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must confess that, although I have not become so intimately\r\nacquainted with any workmen as Margaret has, I am very much struck by\r\nthe antagonism between the employer and the employed, on the very\r\nsurface of things. I even gather this impression from what you yourself\r\nhave from time to time said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton paused awhile before he spoke. Margaret had just left the\r\nroom, and he was vexed at the state of feeling between himself and her.\r\nHowever, the little annoyance, by making him cooler and more thoughtful,\r\ngave a greater dignity to what he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy theory is, that my interests are identical with those of my\r\nworkpeople, and vice-versa. Miss Hale, I know, does not like to hear men\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x98hands,\xe2\x80\x99 so I won\xe2\x80\x99t use that word, though it comes most readily\r\nto my lips as the technical term, whose origin, whatever it was, dates\r\nbefore my time. On some future day--in some millennium--in Utopia, this\r\nunity may be brought into practice--just as I can fancy a republic the\r\nmost perfect form of government.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will read Plato\xe2\x80\x99s Republic as soon as we have finished Homer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, in the Platonic year, it may fall out that we are all--men,\r\nwomen, and children--fit for a republic; but give me a constitutional\r\nmonarchy in our present state of morals and intelligence. In our infancy\r\nwe require a wise despotism to govern us. Indeed, long past infancy,\r\nchildren and young people are the happiest under the unfailing laws of a\r\ndiscreet firm authority. I agree with Miss Hale so far as to consider\r\nour people in the condition of children, while I deny that we, the\r\nmasters, have anything to do with the making or keeping them so. I\r\nmaintain that despotism is the best kind of government for them; so that\r\nin the hours in which I come in contact with them I must necessarily be\r\nan autocrat. I will use my best discretion--from no humbug or\r\nphilanthropic feeling, of which we have had rather too much in the\r\nNorth--to make wise laws and come to just decisions in the conduct of my\r\nbusiness--laws and decisions which work for my own good in the first\r\ninstance--for theirs in the second; but I will neither be forced to give\r\nmy reasons, nor flinch from what I have once declared to be my\r\nresolution. Let them turn out! I shall suffer as well as they: but in\r\nthe end they will find I have not bated nor altered one jot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret had re-entered the room and was sitting at her work; but she\r\ndid not speak. Mr. Hale answered--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say I am talking in great ignorance; but from the little I know,\r\nI should say that the masses were already passing rapidly into the\r\ntroublesome stage which intervenes between childhood and manhood, in the\r\nlife of the multitude as well as that of the individual. Now, the error\r\nwhich many parents commit in the treatment of the individual at this\r\ntime is, insisting on the same unreasoning obedience as when all he had\r\nto do in the way of duty was, to obey the simple laws of \xe2\x80\x98Come when\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re called,\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98Do as you\xe2\x80\x99re bid!\xe2\x80\x99 But a wise parent humours the\r\ndesire for independent action, so as to become the friend and adviser\r\nwhen his absolute rule shall cease. If I get wrong in my reasoning,\r\nrecollect, it is you who adopted the analogy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery lately,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cI heard a story of what happened in\r\nNuremberg only three or four years ago. A rich man there lived alone in\r\none of the immense mansions which were formerly both dwellings and\r\nwarehouses. It was reported that he had a child, but no one knew of it\r\nfor certain. For forty years this rumour kept rising and falling--never\r\nutterly dying away. After his death it was found to be true. He had a\r\nson--an overgrown man, with the unexercised intellect of a child, whom\r\nhe had kept up in that strange way, in order to save him from temptation\r\nand error. But, of course, when this great old child was turned loose in\r\nthe world, every bad counsellor had power over him. He did not know good\r\nfrom evil. His father had made the blunder of bringing him up in\r\nignorance and taking it for innocence; and after fourteen months of\r\nriotous living, the city authorities had to take charge of him, in order\r\nto save him from starvation. He could not even use words effectively\r\nenough to be a successful beggar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI used the comparison (suggested by Miss Hale) of the position of the\r\nmaster to that of a parent, so I ought not to complain of your turning\r\nthe simile into a weapon against me. But, Mr. Hale, when you were\r\nsetting up a wise parent as a model for us, you said he humoured his\r\nchildren in their desire for independent action. Now certainly, the time\r\nis not come for the hands to have any independent action during business\r\nhours; I hardly know what you would mean by it then. And I say, that the\r\nmasters would be trenching on the independence of their hands, in a way\r\nthat I, for one, should not feel justified in doing, if we interfered\r\ntoo much with the life they lead out of the mills. Because they labour\r\nten hours a-day for us, I do not see that we have any right to impose\r\nleading-strings upon them for the rest of their time. I value my own\r\nindependence so highly that I can fancy no degradation greater than that\r\nof having another man perpetually directing and advising and lecturing\r\nme, or even planning too closely in any way about my actions. He might\r\nbe the wisest of men or the most powerful--I should equally rebel and\r\nresent his interference. I imagine this is a stronger feeling in the\r\nNorth of England than in the South.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, but is not that because there has been none of the\r\nequality of friendship between the adviser and advised classes? Because\r\nevery man has had to stand in an unchristian and isolated position,\r\napart from and jealous of his brother-man: constantly afraid of his\r\nrights being trenched upon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only state the fact. I am sorry to say, I have an appointment at\r\neight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and I must just take facts as I find them to-night,\r\nwithout trying to account for them; which, indeed, would make no\r\ndifference in determining how to act as things stand--the facts must be\r\ngranted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems to me that it makes all\r\nthe difference in the world--.\xe2\x80\x9d Her father made a sign to her to be\r\nsilent, and allow Mr. Thornton to finish what he had to say. He was\r\nalready standing up and preparing to go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must grant me this one point. Given a strong feeling of\r\nindependence in every Darkshire man, have I any right to obtrude my\r\nviews, of the manner in which he shall act, upon another (hating it as\r\nI should do most vehemently myself), merely because he has labour to\r\nsell and I capital to buy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot in the least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, determined to say just this one\r\nthing; \xe2\x80\x9cnot in the least because of your labour and capital positions,\r\nwhatever they are, but because you are a man, dealing with a set of men\r\nover whom you have, whether you reject the use of it or not, immense\r\npower, just because your lives and your welfare are so constantly and\r\nintimately interwoven. God has made us so that we must be mutually\r\ndependent. We may ignore our own dependence, or refuse to acknowledge\r\nthat others depend upon us in more respects than the payment of weekly\r\nwages; but the thing must be, nevertheless. Neither you nor any other\r\nmaster can help yourselves. The most proudly independent man depends on\r\nthose around him for their insensible influence on his character--his\r\nlife. And the most isolated of all your Darkshire Egos has dependants\r\nclinging to him on all sides; he cannot shake them off, any more than\r\nthe great rock he resembles can shake off--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t go into similes, Margaret; you have led us off once\r\nalready,\xe2\x80\x9d said her father, smiling, yet uneasy at the thought that they\r\nwere detaining Mr. Thornton against his will, which was a mistake; for\r\nhe rather liked it, as long as Margaret would talk, although what she\r\nsaid only irritated him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust tell me, Miss Hale, are you yourself ever influenced--no, that is\r\nnot a fair way of putting it;--but if you are ever conscious of being\r\ninfluenced by others, and not by circumstances, have those others been\r\nworking directly or indirectly? Have they been labouring to exhort, to\r\nenjoin, to act rightly for the sake of example, or have they been\r\nsimple, true men, taking up their duty, and doing it unflinchingly,\r\nwithout a thought of how their actions were to make this man\r\nindustrious, that man saving? Why, if I were a workman, I should be\r\ntwenty times more impressed by the knowledge that my master was honest,\r\npunctual, quick, resolute in all his doings (and hands are keener spies\r\neven than valets), than by any amount of interference, however kindly\r\nmeant, with my ways of going on out of work-hours. I do not choose to\r\nthink too closely on what I am myself; but, I believe, I rely on the\r\nstraightforward honesty of my hands, and the open nature of their\r\nopposition, in contra-distinction to the way in which the turn-out will\r\nbe managed in some mills, just because they know I scorn to take a\r\nsingle dishonourable advantage, or do an underhand thing myself. It goes\r\nfarther than a whole course of lectures on \xe2\x80\x98Honesty is the Best\r\nPolicy\xe2\x80\x99--life diluted into words. No, no! What the master is, that will\r\nthe men be, without over-much taking thought on his part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a great admission,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I see men\r\nviolent and obstinate, in pursuit of their rights, I may safely infer\r\nthat the master is the same; that he is a little ignorant of that spirit\r\nwhich suffereth long, and is kind, and seeketh not her own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are just like all strangers who don\xe2\x80\x99t understand the working of our\r\nsystem, Miss Hale,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, hastily. \xe2\x80\x9cYou suppose that our men are\r\npuppets of dough, ready to be moulded into any amiable form we please.\r\nYou forget we have only to do with them for less than a third of their\r\nlives; and you seem not to perceive that the duties of a manufacturer\r\nare far larger and wider than those merely of an employer of labour: we\r\nhave a wide commercial character to maintain, which makes us into the\r\ngreat pioneers of civilisation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt strikes me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you might pioneer a\r\nlittle at home. They are a rough, heathenish set of fellows, these\r\nMilton men of yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Thornton. \xe2\x80\x9cRose-water surgery won\xe2\x80\x99t do for\r\nthem. Cromwell would have made a capital mill-owner, Miss Hale. I wish\r\nwe had him to put down this strike for us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCromwell is no hero of mine,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, coldly. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I am trying to\r\nreconcile your admiration of despotism with your respect for other men\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nindependence of character.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe reddened at her tone. \xe2\x80\x9cI choose to be the unquestioned and\r\nirresponsible master of my hands, during the hours they labour for me.\r\nBut those hours past, our relation ceases; and then comes in the same\r\nrespect for their independence that I myself exact.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe did not speak again for a minute, he was too much vexed. But he shook\r\nit off, and bade Mr. and Mrs. Hale good night.
