Then, drawing near to\r\nMargaret, he said in a lower voice--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI spoke hastily to you once this evening, and I am afraid, rather\r\nrudely. But you know I am but an uncouth Milton manufacturer; will you\r\nforgive me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, smiling up in his face, the expression of which\r\nwas somewhat anxious and oppressed, and hardly cleared away as he met\r\nher sweet sunny countenance, out of which all the north-wind effect of\r\ntheir discussion had entirely vanished. But she did not put out her hand\r\nto him, and again he felt the omission, and set it down to pride.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI.\r\n\r\nTHE SHADOW OF DEATH.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cTrust in that veiled hand, which leads\r\n    None by the path that he would go;\r\n    And always be for change prepared,\r\n    For the world\xe2\x80\x99s law is ebb and flow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              FROM THE ARABIC.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next afternoon Dr. Donaldson came to pay his first visit to Mrs.\r\nHale. The mystery that Margaret hoped their late habits of intimacy had\r\nbroken through was resumed. She was excluded from the room, while Dixon\r\nwas admitted. Margaret was not a ready lover, but where she loved she\r\nloved passionately, and with no small degree of jealousy.\r\n\r\nShe went into her mother\xe2\x80\x99s bed-room, just behind the drawing-room, and\r\npaced it up and down, while awaiting the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s coming out. Every now\r\nand then she stopped to listen; she fancied she heard a moan. She\r\nclenched her hands tight, and held her breath. She was sure she heard a\r\nmoan. Then all was still for a few minutes more; and then there was the\r\nmoving of chairs, the raised voices, all the little disturbances of\r\nleave-taking.\r\n\r\nWhen she heard the door open, she went quickly out of the bedroom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father is from home, Dr. Donaldson; he has to attend a pupil at this\r\nhour. May I trouble you to come into his room downstairs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe saw, and triumphed over all the obstacles which Dixon threw in her\r\nway; assuming her rightful position as daughter of the house in\r\nsomething of the spirit of the Elder Brother, which quelled the old\r\nservant\xe2\x80\x99s officiousness very effectually. Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s conscious\r\nassumption of this unusual dignity of demeanour towards Dixon, gave her\r\nan instant\xe2\x80\x99s amusement in the midst of her anxiety. She knew, from the\r\nsurprised expression on Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s face, how ridiculously grand she herself\r\nmust be looking; and the idea carried her downstairs into the room; it\r\ngave her that length of oblivion from the keen sharpness of the\r\nrecollection of the actual business in hand. Now, that came back, and\r\nseemed to take away her breath. It was a moment or two before she could\r\nutter a word.\r\n\r\nBut she spoke with an air of command, as she asked--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter with mamma? You will oblige me by telling the simple\r\ntruth.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, seeing a slight hesitation on the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s part, she\r\nadded--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am the only child she has--here, I mean. My father is not\r\nsufficiently alarmed, I fear: and, therefore, if there is any serious\r\napprehension, it must be broken to him gently. I can do this. I can\r\nnurse my mother. Pray, speak, sir; to see your face, and not be able to\r\nread it, gives me a worse dread than I trust any words of yours will\r\njustify.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear young lady, your mother seems to have a most attentive and\r\nefficient servant, who is more like her friend----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am her daughter, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut when I tell you she expressly desired that you might not be\r\ntold----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not good or patient enough to submit to the prohibition. Besides,\r\nI am sure, you are too wise--too experienced to have promised to keep\r\nthe secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, half-smiling, though sadly enough, \xe2\x80\x9cthere you are\r\nright. I did not promise. In fact, I fear, the secret will be known soon\r\nenough without my revealing it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused. Margaret then went very white, and compressed her lips a\r\nlittle more. Otherwise not a feature moved. With the quick insight into\r\ncharacter, without which no medical man can rise to the eminence of Dr.\r\nDonaldson, he saw that she would exact the full truth; that she would\r\nknow if one iota was withheld; and that the withholding would be torture\r\nmore acute than the knowledge of it. He spoke two short sentences in a\r\nlow voice, watching her all the time; for the pupils of her eyes dilated\r\ninto a black horror, and the whiteness of her complexion became livid.\r\nHe ceased speaking. He waited for that look to go off,--for her gasping\r\nbreath to come. Then she said:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you most truly, sir, for your confidence. That dread has\r\nhaunted me for many weeks. It is a true, real agony. My poor, poor\r\nmother!\xe2\x80\x9d Her lips now began to quiver, and he let her have the relief of\r\ntears, sure of her power of self-control to check them.\r\n\r\nA few tears--those were all she shed, before she recollected the many\r\nquestions she longed to ask.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill there be much suffering?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe shook his head. \xe2\x80\x9cThat we cannot tell. It depends on constitution; on\r\na thousand things. But the late discoveries of medical science have\r\ngiven us large power of alleviation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, trembling all over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know Mr. Hale. I mean, it is difficult to give advice. But I\r\nshould say, bear on, with the knowledge you have forced me to give you\r\nso abruptly, till the fact which I could not withhold has become in some\r\ndegree familiar to you, so that you may without too great an effort, be\r\nable to give what comfort you can to your father. Before then,--my\r\nvisits, which of course, I shall repeat from time to time, although I\r\nfear I can do nothing but alleviate,--a thousand little circumstances\r\nwill have occurred to awaken his alarm, to deepen it--so that he will be\r\nall the better prepared.--Nay, my dear young lady--nay, my dear--I saw\r\nMr. Thornton, and I honour your father for the sacrifice he has made,\r\nhowever mistaken I may believe him to be.--Well, this once, if it will\r\nplease you, my dear. Only remember, when I come again, I come as a\r\nfriend. And you must learn to look upon me as such, because seeing each\r\nother--getting to know each other at such times as these, is worth years\r\nof morning calls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret could not speak for crying; but she wrang his hand at parting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I call a fine girl!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Dr. Donaldson, when he was\r\nseated in his carriage, and had time to examine his ringed hand, which\r\nhad slightly suffered from her pressure. \xe2\x80\x9cWho would have thought that\r\nlittle hand could have given such a squeeze? But the bones were well put\r\ntogether, and that gives immense power. What a queen she is! With her\r\nhead thrown back at first, to force me into speaking the truth; and then\r\nbent so eagerly forward to listen. Poor thing! I must see she does not\r\noverstrain herself. Though it\xe2\x80\x99s astonishing how much these thorough-bred\r\ncreatures can do and suffer. That girl\xe2\x80\x99s game to the back-bone. Another,\r\nwho had gone that deadly colour, could never have come round without\r\neither fainting or hysterics. But she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do either--not she! And\r\nthe very force of her will brought her round. Such a girl as that would\r\nwin my heart, if I were thirty years younger. It\xe2\x80\x99s too late now. Ah;\r\nhere we are at the Archers\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d So out he jumped, with thought, wisdom,\r\nexperience, sympathy, and ready to attend to any of the calls made upon\r\nthem by this family, just as if there were none other in the world.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, Margaret had returned into her father\xe2\x80\x99s study for a moment,\r\nto recover strength before going upstairs into her mother\xe2\x80\x99s presence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God! but this is terrible. How shall I bear it? Such a\r\ndeadly disease! no hope! Oh, mamma, mamma, I wish I had never gone to\r\naunt Shaw\xe2\x80\x99s, and been all those precious years away from you! Poor\r\nmamma! how much she must have borne! Oh, pray thee, my God, that her\r\nsufferings may not be too acute, too dreadful. How shall I bear to see\r\nthem? How can I bear papa\xe2\x80\x99s agony? He must not be told yet; not all at\r\nonce. It would kill him. But I won\xe2\x80\x99t lose another moment of my own dear,\r\nprecious mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe ran upstairs. Dixon was not in the room. Mrs. Hale lay back in an\r\neasy chair, with a soft white shawl wrapped around her, and a becoming\r\ncap put on, in expectation of the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s visit. Her face had a little\r\nfaint colour in it, and the very exhaustion after the examination gave\r\nit a peaceful look. Margaret was surprised to see her look so calm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Margaret, how strange you look! What is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d And then, as\r\nthe idea stole into her mind of what was indeed the real state of the\r\ncase, she added, as if a little displeased: \xe2\x80\x9cyou have not been seeing\r\nDr. Donaldson, and asking him any questions--have you child?\xe2\x80\x9d Margaret\r\ndid not reply--only looked wistfully towards her. Mrs. Hale became more\r\ndispleased. \xe2\x80\x9cHe would not surely break his word to me, and\xe2\x80\x9d--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, mamma, he did. I made him. It was I--blame me.\xe2\x80\x9d She knelt down\r\nby her mother\xe2\x80\x99s side, and caught her hand--she would not let it go,\r\nthough Mrs. Hale tried to pull it away. She kept kissing it, and the hot\r\ntears she shed bathed it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret, it was very wrong of you. You knew I did not wish you to\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d But, as if tired with the contest, she left her hand in\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s clasp, and by-and-by she returned the pressure faintly. That\r\nencouraged Margaret to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mamma! let me be your nurse. I will learn anything Dixon can teach\r\nme. But you know I am your child, and I do think I have a right to do\r\neverything for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know what you are asking,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, with a shudder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I do. I know a great deal more than you are aware of. Let me be\r\nyour nurse. Let me try, at any rate. No one has ever, shall ever try so\r\nhard as I will do. It will be such a comfort, mamma.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy poor child! Well, you shall try. Do you know, Margaret, Dixon and I\r\nthought you would quite shrink from me if you knew--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDixon thought!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, her lip curling. \xe2\x80\x9cDixon could not give\r\nme credit for enough true love--for as much as herself! She thought, I\r\nsuppose, that I was one of those poor sickly women who like to lie on\r\nrose leaves, and be fanned all day. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s fancies come any\r\nmore between you and me, mamma. Don\xe2\x80\x99t please!\xe2\x80\x9d implored she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be angry with Dixon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, anxiously. Margaret\r\nrecovered herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! I won\xe2\x80\x99t. I will try and be humble, and learn her ways, if you will\r\nonly let me do all I can for you. Let me be in the first place,\r\nmother--I am greedy of that. I used to fancy you would forget me while I\r\nwas away at aunt Shaw\xe2\x80\x99s, and cry myself to sleep at nights with that\r\nnotion in my head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I used to think, how will Margaret bear our make-shift poverty\r\nafter the thorough comfort and luxury in Harley Street, till I have many\r\na time been more ashamed of your seeing our contrivances at Helstone\r\nthan of any stranger finding them out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mamma! and I did so enjoy them. They were so much more amusing than\r\nall the jog-trot Harley Street ways. The wardrobe shelf with handles\r\nthat served as a supper-tray on grand occasions! And the old tea-chests\r\nstuffed and covered for ottomans! I think what you call the make-shift\r\ncontrivances at dear Helstone were a charming part of the life there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall never see Helstone again, Margaret,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, the tears\r\nwelling up into her eyes. Margaret could not reply. Mrs. Hale went on.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile I was there, I was for ever wanting to leave it. Every place\r\nseemed pleasanter. And now I shall die far away from it. I am rightly\r\npunished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must not talk so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cHe said you might\r\nlive for years. Oh, mother! we will have you back at Helstone yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, never! That I must take as a just penance. But,\r\nMargaret--Frederick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the mention of that one word, she suddenly cried out loud, as in some\r\nsharp agony. It seemed as if the thought of him upset all her composure,\r\ndestroyed the calm, overcame the exhaustion. Wild passionate cry\r\nsucceeded to cry--\xe2\x80\x9cFrederick! Frederick! Come to me. I am dying. Little\r\nfirst-born child, come to me once again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was in violent hysterics. Margaret went and called Dixon in terror.\r\nDixon came in a huff, and accused Margaret of having over-excited her\r\nmother. Margaret bore all meekly, only trusting that her father might\r\nnot return. In spite of her alarm, which was even greater than the\r\noccasion warranted, she obeyed all Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s directions promptly and well\r\nwithout a word of self-justification. By so doing she mollified her\r\naccuser. They put her mother to bed, and Margaret sate by her till she\r\nfell asleep, and afterwards till Dixon beckoned her out of the room,\r\nand, with a sour face, as if doing something against the grain, she bade\r\nher drink a cup of coffee which she had prepared for her in the\r\ndrawing-room, and stood over her in a commanding attitude as she did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been so curious, Miss, and then you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\nneeded to fret before your time. It would have come soon enough. And\r\nnow, I suppose, you\xe2\x80\x99ll tell master, and a pretty household I shall have\r\nof you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Dixon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, sorrowfully, \xe2\x80\x9cI will not tell papa. He could\r\nnot bear it as I can.\xe2\x80\x9d And by way of proving how well she bore it, she\r\nburst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy! I knew how it would be. Now you\xe2\x80\x99ll waken your mamma, just after\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s gone to sleep so quietly. Miss Margaret my dear, I\xe2\x80\x99ve had to keep\r\nit down this many a week: and though I don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend I can love her as\r\nyou do, yet I loved her better than any other man, woman, or child--no\r\none but Master Frederick ever came near her in my mind. Ever since Lady\r\nBeresford\xe2\x80\x99s maid first took me in to see her dressed out in white crape,\r\nand corn-ears, and scarlet poppies, and I ran a needle down into my\r\nfinger, and broke it in, and she tore up her worked pocket-handkerchief,\r\nafter they\xe2\x80\x99d cut it out, and came in to wet the bandages again with\r\nlotion when she returned from the ball--where she\xe2\x80\x99d been the prettiest\r\nyoung lady of all--I\xe2\x80\x99ve never loved any one like her. I little thought\r\nthen that I should live to see her brought so low. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean no\r\nreproach to nobody. Many a one calls you pretty and handsome, and what\r\nnot. Even in this smoky place, enough to blind one\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, the owls can\r\nsee that. But you\xe2\x80\x99ll never be like your mother for beauty--never; not if\r\nyou live to be a hundred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma is very pretty still. Poor mamma!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow don\xe2\x80\x99t ye set off again, or I shall give way at last\xe2\x80\x9d (whimpering).\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll never stand master\xe2\x80\x99s coming home, and questioning, at this rate.\r\nGo out and take a walk, and come in something like. Many\xe2\x80\x99s the time I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nlonged to walk it off--the thought of what was the matter with her, and\r\nhow it must all end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Dixon!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9chow often I\xe2\x80\x99ve been cross with you, not\r\nknowing what a terrible secret you had to bear!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless you, child! I like to see you showing a bit of a spirit. It\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\ngood old Beresford blood. Why, the last Sir John but two shot his\r\nsteward down, there where he stood, for just telling him that he racked\r\nthe tenants, and he\xe2\x80\x99d racked the tenants till he could get no more money\r\noff them than he could get skin off a flint.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Dixon, I won\xe2\x80\x99t shoot you, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll try not to be cross again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou never have. If I\xe2\x80\x99ve said it at times, it has always been to myself,\r\njust in private, by way of making a little agreeable conversation, for\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s no one here fit to talk to. And when you fire up you\xe2\x80\x99re the very\r\nimage of Master Frederick. I could find in my heart to put you in a\r\npassion any day just to see his stormy look coming like a great cloud\r\nover your face. But now you go out, Miss. I\xe2\x80\x99ll watch over Missus; and as\r\nfor master, his books are company enough for him, if he should come in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. She hung about Dixon for a minute or so, as\r\nif afraid and irresolute; then, suddenly kissing her, she went quickly\r\nout of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless her!\xe2\x80\x9d said Dixon. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s as sweet as a nut. There are three\r\npeople I love; its Missus, Master Frederick, and her. Just them three.\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s all. The rest be hanged, for I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what they\xe2\x80\x99re in the\r\nworld for. Master was born, I suppose, for to marry missus. If I thought\r\nhe loved her properly, I might get to love him in time. But he should\r\nha\xe2\x80\x99 made a deal more on her, and not been always reading, reading,\r\nthinking, thinking. See what it has brought him to. Many a one who never\r\nreads or thinks either, gets to be Rector, and Dean, and what not; and I\r\ndaresay master might, if he\xe2\x80\x99d just minded missus, and let the weary\r\nreading and thinking alone.--There she goes\xe2\x80\x9d (looking out of the window\r\nas she heard the front door shut). \xe2\x80\x9cPoor young lady! her clothes look\r\nshabby to what they did when she came to Helstone a year ago. Then she\r\nhadn\xe2\x80\x99t so much as a darned stocking or a cleaned pair of gloves in all\r\nher wardrobe. And now--!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII.\r\n\r\nWHAT IS A STRIKE?\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThere are briars besetting every path,\r\n      Which call for patient care;\r\n    There is a cross in every lot,\r\n      And an earnest need for prayer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              ANON.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret went out heavily and unwillingly enough. But the length of a\r\nstreet--yes, the air of a Milton Street--cheered her young blood before\r\nshe reached her first turning. Her step grew lighter, her lip redder.\r\nShe began to take notice, instead of having her thoughts turned so\r\nexclusively inward. She saw unusual loiterers in the streets: men with\r\ntheir hands in their pockets sauntering along; loud-laughing and\r\nloud-spoken girls clustered together, apparently excited to high\r\nspirits, and a boisterous independence of temper and behaviour. The more\r\nill-looking of the men--the discreditable minority--hung about on the\r\nsteps of the beer-houses and gin-shops, smoking, and commenting pretty\r\nfreely on every passer-by. Margaret disliked the prospect of the long\r\nwalk through these streets, before she came to the fields which she had\r\nplanned to reach. Instead, she would go and see Bessy Higgins. It would\r\nnot be so refreshing as a quiet country walk, but still it would perhaps\r\nbe doing the kinder thing.\r\n\r\nNicholas Higgins was sitting by the fire smoking, as she went in. Bessy\r\nwas rocking herself on the other side.\r\n\r\nNicholas took the pipe out of his mouth, and standing up, pushed his\r\nchair towards Margaret; he leant against the chimney-piece in a lounging\r\nattitude, while she asked Bessy how she was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoo\xe2\x80\x99s rather down i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 mouth in regard to spirits, but hoo\xe2\x80\x99s better\r\nin health. Hoo doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like this strike. Hoo\xe2\x80\x99s a deal too much set on\r\npiece and quietness at any price.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is th\xe2\x80\x99 third strike I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, sighing, as if that was\r\nanswer and explanation enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, third time pays for all. See if we don\xe2\x80\x99t dang th\xe2\x80\x99 masters this\r\ntime. See if they don\xe2\x80\x99t come and beg us to come back at our own price.\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s all. We\xe2\x80\x99ve missed it afore time, I grant yo\xe2\x80\x99; but this time we\xe2\x80\x99n\r\nlaid our plans desperate deep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you strike?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cStriking is leaving off work till\r\nyou get your own rate of wages, is it not? You must not wonder at my\r\nignorance; where I come from I never heard of a strike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I were there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessie, wearily. \xe2\x80\x9cBut it\xe2\x80\x99s not for me to get\r\nsick and tired o\xe2\x80\x99 strikes. This is the last I\xe2\x80\x99ll see. Before it\xe2\x80\x99s ended\r\nI shall be in the Great City--the Holy Jerusalem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoo\xe2\x80\x99s so full of th\xe2\x80\x99 life to come, hoo cannot think of th\xe2\x80\x99 present. Now\r\nI, yo see, am bound to do the best I can here. I think a bird i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhand is worth two i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 bush. So them\xe2\x80\x99s the different views we take on\r\nth\xe2\x80\x99 strike question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cif the people struck, as you call it, where I\r\ncome from, as they are mostly all field labourers, the seed would not be\r\nsown, the hay got in, the corn reaped.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. He had resumed his pipe, and put his \xe2\x80\x9cwell\xe2\x80\x9d in the form\r\nof an interrogation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat would become of the farmers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe puffed away. \xe2\x80\x9cI reckon, they\xe2\x80\x99d have either to give up their farms, or\r\nto give fair rate of wage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose they could not, or would not do the last; they could not give\r\nup their farms all in a minute, however much they might wish to do so;\r\nbut they would have no hay, nor corn to sell that year; and where would\r\nthe money come from to pay the labourers\xe2\x80\x99 wages the next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill puffing away. At last he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nought of your ways down South. I have heerd they\xe2\x80\x99re a pack of\r\nspiritless, down-trodden men; welly clemmed to death; too dazed wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nclemming to know when they\xe2\x80\x99re put upon. Now, it\xe2\x80\x99s not so here. We known\r\nwhen we\xe2\x80\x99re put upon; and we\xe2\x80\x99en too much blood in us to stand it. We just\r\ntake our hands fro\xe2\x80\x99 our looms, and say, \xe2\x80\x98Yo\xe2\x80\x99 may clem us, but yo\xe2\x80\x99ll not\r\nput upon us, my masters!\xe2\x80\x99 And be danged to \xe2\x80\x99em, they shan\xe2\x80\x99t this time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wished I lived down South,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a deal to bear there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are sorrows to\r\nbear everywhere. There is very hard bodily labour to be gone through,\r\nwith very little food to give strength.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it\xe2\x80\x99s out of doors,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessy. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd away from the endless, endless\r\nnoise, and sickening heat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s sometimes in heavy rain, and sometimes in bitter cold. A young\r\nperson can stand it; but an old man gets racked with rheumatism, and\r\nbent and withered before his time; yet he must just work on the same, or\r\nelse go to the workhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought yo were so taken wi\xe2\x80\x99 the ways of the South country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, smiling a little, as she found herself thus\r\ncaught. \xe2\x80\x9cI only mean, Bessy, there\xe2\x80\x99s good and bad in everything in this\r\nworld; and as you felt the bad up here, I thought it was but fair you\r\nshould know the bad down there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yo say they never strike down there?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Nicholas abruptly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret; \xe2\x80\x9cI think they have too much sense.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn\xe2\x80\x99 I think,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, dashing the ashes out of his pipe with so\r\nmuch vehemence that it broke, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s not that they\xe2\x80\x99ve too much sense, but\r\nthat they\xe2\x80\x99ve too little spirit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, father!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessy, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat have ye gained by striking? Just think\r\nof that first strike when mother died--how we all had to clem--you the\r\nworst of all; and yet many a one went in every week at the same wage,\r\ntill all were gone in that there was work for; and some went beggars all\r\ntheir lives at after.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cThat there strike was badly managed. Folk got into th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmanagement of it, as were either fools or not true men. Yo\xe2\x80\x99ll see, it\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbe different this time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut all this time you\xe2\x80\x99ve not told me what you\xe2\x80\x99re striking for,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMargaret, again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yo see, there\xe2\x80\x99s five or six masters who have set themselves again\r\npaying the wages they\xe2\x80\x99ve been paying these two years past, and\r\nflourishing upon, and getting richer upon. And now they come to us, and\r\nsay we\xe2\x80\x99re to take less. And we won\xe2\x80\x99t. We\xe2\x80\x99ll just clem them to death\r\nfirst; and see who\xe2\x80\x99ll work for \xe2\x80\x99em then. They\xe2\x80\x99ll have killed the goose\r\nthat laid \xe2\x80\x99em the golden eggs, I reckon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so you plan dying, in order to be revenged upon them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI dunnot. I just look forward to the chance of dying at\r\nmy post sooner than yield. That\xe2\x80\x99s what folk call fine and honourable in\r\na soldier, and why not in a poor weaver-chap?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9ca soldier dies in the cause of the Nation--in the\r\ncause of others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe laughed grimly. \xe2\x80\x9cMy lass,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyo\xe2\x80\x99re but a young wench, but\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t yo think I can keep three people--that\xe2\x80\x99s Bessy, and Mary, and\r\nme--on sixteen shillings a week? Dun yo think it\xe2\x80\x99s for mysel\xe2\x80\x99 I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nstriking work at this time? It is just as much in the cause of others as\r\nyon soldier--only m\xe2\x80\x99appen, the cause he dies for is just that of\r\nsomebody he never clapt eyes on, nor heerd on all his born days, while I\r\ntake up John Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s cause, as lives next door but one, wi\xe2\x80\x99 a sickly\r\nwife, and eight childer, none on \xe2\x80\x99em factory age; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t take up\r\nhis cause only, though he\xe2\x80\x99s a poor good-for-nought, as can only manage\r\ntwo looms at a time, but I take up th\xe2\x80\x99 cause o\xe2\x80\x99 justice. Why are we to\r\nhave less wage now, I ask, than two year ago?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t ask me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret; \xe2\x80\x9cI am very ignorant. Ask some of your\r\nmasters. Surely they will give you a reason for it. It is not merely an\r\narbitrary decision of theirs, come to without reason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99re just a foreigner, and nothing more,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, contemptuously.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch yo know about it. Ask th\xe2\x80\x99 masters! They\xe2\x80\x99d tell us to mind our own\r\nbusiness, and they\xe2\x80\x99d mind theirs. Our business being, yo understand, to\r\ntake the bated wage, and be thankful; and their business to bate us down\r\nto clemming point, to swell their profits. That\xe2\x80\x99s what it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, determined not to give way, although she saw she\r\nwas irritating him, \xe2\x80\x9cthe state of trade may be such as not to enable\r\nthem to give you the same remuneration.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cState o\xe2\x80\x99 trade! That\xe2\x80\x99s just a piece o\xe2\x80\x99 masters\xe2\x80\x99 humbug. It\xe2\x80\x99s rate o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwages I was talking of. Th\xe2\x80\x99 masters keep th\xe2\x80\x99 state o\xe2\x80\x99 trade in their own\r\nhands; and just walk it forward like a black bug-a-boo, to frighten\r\nnaughty children with into being good. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you it\xe2\x80\x99s their\r\npart,--their cue, as some folks call it,--to beat us down, to swell\r\ntheir fortunes; and it\xe2\x80\x99s ours to stand up and fight hard,--not for\r\nourselves alone, but for them round about us--for justice and fair play.\r\nWe help to make their profits, and we ought to help spend \xe2\x80\x99em. It\xe2\x80\x99s not\r\nthat we want their brass so much this time, as we\xe2\x80\x99ve done many a time\r\nafore. We\xe2\x80\x99n getten money laid by; and we\xe2\x80\x99re resolved to stand and fall\r\ntogether; not a man on us will go in for less wage than th\xe2\x80\x99 Union says\r\nis our due. So I say, \xe2\x80\x98hooray for the strike,\xe2\x80\x99 and let Thornton, and\r\nSlickson, and Hamper, and their set look to it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThornton!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton of Marlborough Street?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye! Thornton o\xe2\x80\x99 Marlborough Mill, as we call him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is one of the masters you are striving with, is he not? What sort of\r\na master is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid yo\xe2\x80\x99 ever see a bulldog? Set a bulldog on hind legs, and dress him\r\nup in coat and breeches, and yo\xe2\x80\x99n just getten John Thornton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cI deny that. Mr. Thornton is plain\r\nenough, but he\xe2\x80\x99s not like a bulldog, with its short broad nose, and\r\nsnarling upper lip.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! not in look, I grant yo. But let John Thornton get hold on a\r\nnotion, and he\xe2\x80\x99ll stick to it like a bulldog; yo might pull him away wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\na pitchfork ere he\xe2\x80\x99d leave go. He\xe2\x80\x99s worth fighting wi\xe2\x80\x99, is John\r\nThornton. As for Slickson, I take it, some o\xe2\x80\x99 these days he\xe2\x80\x99ll wheedle\r\nhis men back wi\xe2\x80\x99 fair promises; that they\xe2\x80\x99ll just get cheated out of as\r\nsoon as they\xe2\x80\x99re in his power again. He\xe2\x80\x99ll work his fines well out on\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em, I\xe2\x80\x99ll warrant. He\xe2\x80\x99s as slippery as an eel, he is. He\xe2\x80\x99s like a\r\ncat,--as sleek, and cunning, and fierce. It\xe2\x80\x99ll never be an honest up and\r\ndown fight wi\xe2\x80\x99 him, as it will be wi\xe2\x80\x99 Thornton. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s as dour as a\r\ndoor-nail; an obstinate chap, every inch on him,--th\xe2\x80\x99 oud bulldog!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Bessy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, turning round to her. \xe2\x80\x9cYou sigh over it\r\nall. You don\xe2\x80\x99t like struggling and fighting as your father does, do\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, heavily. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sick on it. I could have wished to have\r\nhad other talk about me in my latter days, than just the clashing and\r\nclanging and clattering that has ever wearied a\xe2\x80\x99 my life long, about\r\nwork and wages, and masters, and hands, and knobsticks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor wench! latter days be farred! Thou\xe2\x80\x99rt looking a sight better\r\nalready for a little stir and change. Beside, I shall be a deal here to\r\nmake it more lively for thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTobacco-smoke chokes me!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, querulously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I\xe2\x80\x99ll never smoke no more i\xe2\x80\x99 the house!\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, tenderly. \xe2\x80\x9cBut\r\nwhy didst thou not tell me afore, thou foolish wench?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe did not speak for a while, and then so low that only Margaret heard\r\nher:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI reckon, he\xe2\x80\x99ll want a\xe2\x80\x99 the comfort he can get out o\xe2\x80\x99 either pipe or\r\ndrink afore he\xe2\x80\x99s done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer father went out of doors, evidently to finish his pipe.\r\n\r\nBessy said passionately,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow am not I a fool,--am I not, Miss?--there, I knew I ought for to\r\nkeep father at home, and away fro\xe2\x80\x99 the folk that are always ready for to\r\ntempt a man, in time o\xe2\x80\x99 strike, to go drink,--and there my tongue must\r\nneeds quarrel with this pipe o\xe2\x80\x99 his\xe2\x80\x99n--and he\xe2\x80\x99ll go off, I know he\r\nwill,--as often as he wants to smoke--and nobody knows where it\xe2\x80\x99ll end.\r\nI wish I\xe2\x80\x99d letten myself be choked first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut does your father drink?\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo--not to say drink,\xe2\x80\x9d replied she, still in the same wild excited\r\ntone. \xe2\x80\x9cBut what win ye have? There are days wi\xe2\x80\x99 you as wi\xe2\x80\x99 other folk, I\r\nsuppose, when yo\xe2\x80\x99 get up and go through th\xe2\x80\x99 hours, just longing for a\r\nbit of a change--a bit of a fillip, as it were. I know I ha\xe2\x80\x99 gone and\r\nbought a four-pounder out o\xe2\x80\x99 another baker\xe2\x80\x99s shop to common on such\r\ndays, just because I sickened at the thought of going on for ever wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthe same sight in my eyes, and the same sound in my ears, and the same\r\ntaste i\xe2\x80\x99 my mouth, and the same thought (or no thought, for that matter)\r\nin my head, day after day, for ever. I\xe2\x80\x99ve longed for to be a man to go\r\nspreeing, even if it were only a tramp to some new place in search o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwork. And father--all men--have it stronger in \xe2\x80\x99em than me to get tired\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 sameness and work for ever. And what is \xe2\x80\x99em to do? It\xe2\x80\x99s little blame\r\nto them if they do go into th\xe2\x80\x99 gin-shop for to make their blood flow\r\nquicker, and more lively, and see things they never see at no other\r\ntime--pictures, and looking-glass, and such like. But father never was a\r\ndrunkard, though maybe, he\xe2\x80\x99s got worse for drink, now and then. Only yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsee,\xe2\x80\x9d and now her voice took a mournful, pleading tone, \xe2\x80\x9cat times o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nstrike there\xe2\x80\x99s much to knock a man down, for all they start so\r\nhopefully; and where\xe2\x80\x99s the comfort to come fro\xe2\x80\x99? He\xe2\x80\x99ll get angry and\r\nmad--they all do--and then they get tired out wi\xe2\x80\x99 being angry and mad,\r\nand maybe ha\xe2\x80\x99 done things in their passion they\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to forget.\r\nBless yo\xe2\x80\x99r sweet pitiful face! but yo\xe2\x80\x99 dunnot know what a strike is\r\nyet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Bessy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t say you\xe2\x80\x99re exaggerating, because\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t know enough about it: but, perhaps, as you\xe2\x80\x99re not well, you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nonly looking on one side, and there is another and a brighter to be\r\nlooked to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all well enough for yo\xe2\x80\x99 to say so, who have lived in pleasant\r\ngreen places all your life long, and never known want or care, or\r\nwickedness either, for that matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, her cheek flushing, and her eye lightening,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chow you judge, Bessy. I shall go home to my mother, who is so ill--so\r\nill, Bessy, that there\xe2\x80\x99s no outlet but death for her out of prison of\r\nher great suffering; and yet I must speak cheerfully to my father, who\r\nhas no notion of her real state, and to whom the knowledge must come\r\ngradually. The only person--the only one who could sympathise with me\r\nand help me--whose presence could comfort my mother more than any other\r\nearthly thing--is falsely accused--would run the risk of death if he\r\ncame to see his dying mother. This I tell you--only you, Bessy. You must\r\nnot mention it. No other person in Milton--hardly any other person in\r\nEngland knows. Have I not care? Do I not know anxiety, though I go about\r\nwell-dressed, and have food enough? Oh, Bessy, God is just, and our lots\r\nare well portioned out by Him, although none but He knows the bitterness\r\nof our souls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ask your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bessy, humbly. \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes, when I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nthought o\xe2\x80\x99 my life, and the little pleasure I\xe2\x80\x99ve had in it, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbelieved that, maybe, I was one of those doomed to die by the falling of\r\na star from heaven; \xe2\x80\x98And the name of the star is called Wormwood; and\r\nthe third part of the waters became wormwood; and men died of the\r\nwaters, because they were made bitter.\xe2\x80\x99 One can bear pain and sorrow\r\nbetter if one thinks it has been prophesied long before for one:\r\nsomehow, then it seems as if my pain was needed for the fulfilment;\r\notherways it seems all sent for nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, Bessy--think!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cGod does not willingly inflict.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t dwell so much on the prophecies, but read the clearer parts of the\r\nBible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say it would be wiser; but where would I hear such grand words\r\nof promise--hear tell o\xe2\x80\x99 anything so far different fro\xe2\x80\x99 this dreary\r\nworld, and this town above a\xe2\x80\x99 as in Revelations? Many\xe2\x80\x99s the time I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nrepeated the verses in the seventh chapter to myself, just for the\r\nsound. It\xe2\x80\x99s as good as an organ, and as different from every day, too.\r\nNo, I cannot give up Revelations. It gives me more comfort than any\r\nother book i\xe2\x80\x99 the Bible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me come and read you some of my favourite chapters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said she greedily, \xe2\x80\x9ccome. Father will maybe hear yo.\xe2\x80\x99 He\xe2\x80\x99s deaved\r\nwi\xe2\x80\x99 my talking; he says it\xe2\x80\x99s all nought to do with the things o\xe2\x80\x99 to-day,\r\nand that\xe2\x80\x99s his business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is your sister?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone fustian cutting. I were loth to let her go; but somehow we must\r\nlive; and th\xe2\x80\x99 Union can\xe2\x80\x99t afford us much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I must go. You have done me good, Bessy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI done you good!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I came here very sad, and rather too apt to think my own cause for\r\ngrief was the only one in the world. And now I hear how you have had to\r\nbear for years, and that makes me stronger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless yo\xe2\x80\x99! I thought a\xe2\x80\x99 the good-doing was on the side of gentlefolk. I\r\nshall get proud if I think I can do good to yo\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t do it if you think about it. But you\xe2\x80\x99ll only puzzle yourself\r\nif you do, that\xe2\x80\x99s one comfort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not like no one I ever seed. I dunno what to make of yo\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor I of myself. Good-bye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy stilled her rocking to gaze after her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder if there are many folk like her down South. She\xe2\x80\x99s like a\r\nbreath of country air, somehow. She freshens me up above a bit. Who\xe2\x80\x99d a\r\nthought that face--as bright and as strong as the angel I dream\r\nof--could have known the sorrow she speaks on? I wonder how she\xe2\x80\x99ll sin.\r\nAll on us must sin. I think a deal on her, for sure. But father does the\r\nlike, I see. And Mary even. It\xe2\x80\x99s not often hoo\xe2\x80\x99s stirred up to notice\r\nmuch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVIII.\r\n\r\nLIKES AND DISLIKES.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cMy heart revolts within me, and two voices\r\n    Make themselves audible within my bosom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              WALLENSTEIN.\r\n\r\n\r\nOn Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s return home she found two letters on the table: one was a\r\nnote for her mother,--the other, which had come by the post, was\r\nevidently from her aunt Shaw--covered with foreign post-marks--thin,\r\nsilvery, and rustling. She took up the other, and was examining it, when\r\nher father came in suddenly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo your mother is tired, and gone to bed early! I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, such a\r\nthundery day was not the best in the world for the doctor to see her.\r\nWhat did he say? Dixon tells me he spoke to you about her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret hesitated. Her father\xe2\x80\x99s looks became more grave and anxious:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe does not think her seriously ill?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at present; she needs care, he says; he was very kind, and he said\r\nhe would call again, and see how his medicines worked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly care?--he did not recommend change of air?--he did not say this\r\nsmoky town was doing her any harm, did he, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! not a word,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, gravely. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was anxious, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoctors have that anxious manner; its professional,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nMargaret saw, in her father\xe2\x80\x99s nervous ways, that the first impression of\r\npossible danger was made upon his mind, in spite of all his making light\r\nof what she told him. He could not forget the subject,--could not pass\r\nfrom it to other things; he kept recurring to it through the evening,\r\nwith an unwillingness to receive even the slightest unfavourable idea,\r\nwhich made Margaret inexpressibly sad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis letter is from Aunt Shaw, papa. She has got to Naples, and finds\r\nit too hot, so she has taken apartments at Sorrento. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\nshe likes Italy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did not say anything about diet, did he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was to be nourishing, and digestible. Mamma\xe2\x80\x99s appetite is pretty\r\ngood, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! and that makes it all the more strange he should have thought of\r\nspeaking about diet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI asked him, papa.\xe2\x80\x9d Another pause. Then Margaret went on: \xe2\x80\x9cAunt Shaw\r\nsays she has sent me some coral ornaments, papa: but,\xe2\x80\x9d added Margaret,\r\nhalf smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s afraid the Milton dissenters won\xe2\x80\x99t appreciate them.\r\nShe has got all her ideas of Dissenters from the Quakers, has she not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf ever you hear or notice that your mother wishes for anything, be\r\nsure you let me know. I am so afraid she does not tell me always what\r\nshe would like. Pray, see after that girl Mrs. Thornton named. If we had\r\na good, efficient house-servant, Dixon could be constantly with her, and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d answer for it we\xe2\x80\x99d soon set her up amongst us, if care will do it.\r\nShe\xe2\x80\x99s been very much tired of late, with the hot weather, and the\r\ndifficulty of getting a servant. A little rest will put her quite to\r\nrights--eh, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret,--but so sadly, that her father took notice\r\nof it. He pinched her cheek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome; if you look so pale as this, I must rouge you up a little. Take\r\ncare of yourself, child, or you\xe2\x80\x99ll be wanting the doctor next.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he could not settle to anything that evening. He was continually\r\ngoing backwards and forwards, on laborious tiptoe, to see if his wife\r\nwas still asleep. Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart ached at his restlessness--his trying\r\nto stifle and strangle the hideous fear that was looming out of the dark\r\nplaces of his heart.\r\n\r\nHe came back at last, somewhat comforted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s awake now, Margaret. She quite smiled as she saw me standing by\r\nher. Just her old smile. And she says she feels refreshed, and ready for\r\ntea. Where\xe2\x80\x99s the note for her? She want\xe2\x80\x99s to see it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll read it to her\r\nwhile you make tea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe note proved to be a formal invitation from Mrs. Thornton, to Mr.,\r\nMrs., and Miss Hale to dinner, on the twenty-first instant. Margaret was\r\nsurprised to find an acceptance contemplated, after all she had learnt\r\nof sad probabilities during the day. But so it was. The idea of her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s and daughter\xe2\x80\x99s going to this dinner had quite captivated Mrs.\r\nHale\xe2\x80\x99s fancy, even before Margaret had heard the contents of the note.\r\nIt was an event to diversify the monotony of the invalid\xe2\x80\x99s life; and she\r\nclung to the idea of their going, with even fretful pertinacity, when\r\nMargaret objected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, Margaret: if she wishes it, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure we\xe2\x80\x99ll both go willingly. She\r\nnever would wish it unless she felt herself really stronger--really\r\nbetter than we thought she was, eh, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, anxiously,\r\nas she prepared to write the note of acceptance, the next day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh! Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d questioned he, with a nervous motion of his hands. It\r\nseemed cruel to refuse him the comfort he craved for. And besides, his\r\npassionate refusal to admit the existence of fear, almost inspired\r\nMargaret herself with hope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do think she is better since last night,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cHer eyes look\r\nbrighter, and her complexion clearer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you,\xe2\x80\x9d said her father earnestly. \xe2\x80\x9cBut is it true? Yesterday\r\nwas so sultry every one felt ill. It was a most unlucky day for Mr.\r\nDonaldson to see her on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo he went away to his day\xe2\x80\x99s duties, now increased by the preparation of\r\nsome lectures he had promised to deliver to the working people at a\r\nneighbouring Lyceum. He had chosen Ecclesiastical Architecture as his\r\nsubject, rather more in accordance with his own taste and knowledge than\r\nas falling in with the character of the place or the desire for\r\nparticular kinds of information among those to whom he was to lecture.\r\nAnd the institution itself, being in debt, was only too glad to get a\r\ngratis course from an educated and accomplished man like Mr. Hale, let\r\nthe subject be what it might.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Thornton that night, \xe2\x80\x9cwho have accepted your\r\ninvitations for the twenty-first?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFanny, where are the notes? The Slicksons accept, Collingbrooks accept,\r\nStephenses accept, Browns decline. Hales--father and daughter\r\ncome--mother too great an invalid--Macphersons come, and Mr. Horsfall,\r\nand Mr. Young. I was thinking of asking the Porters, as the Browns can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good. Do you know, I\xe2\x80\x99m really afraid Mrs. Hale is very far from\r\nwell, from what Dr. Donaldson says.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s strange of them to accept a dinner-invitation if she\xe2\x80\x99s very ill,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Fanny.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t say very ill,\xe2\x80\x9d said her brother, rather sharply. \xe2\x80\x9cI only said\r\nfar from well. They may not know it either.\xe2\x80\x9d And then he suddenly\r\nremembered that, from what Dr. Donaldson had told him, Margaret, at any\r\nrate, must be aware of the exact state of the case.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery probably they are quite aware of what you said yesterday, John--of\r\nthe great advantage it would be to them--to Mr. Hale, I mean, to be\r\nintroduced to such people as the Stephenses and the Collingbrooks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure that motive would not influence them. No! I think I understand\r\nhow it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, laughing in her little, weak, nervous way. \xe2\x80\x9cHow you\r\nprofess to understand these Hales, and how you never will allow that we\r\ncan know anything about them. Are they really so very different to most\r\npeople one meets with?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe did not mean to vex him; but if she had intended it, she could not\r\nhave done it more thoroughly. He chafed in silence, however, not\r\ndeigning to reply to her question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey do not seem to me out of the common way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\nappears a worthy kind of man enough; rather too simple for trade--so\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s perhaps as well he should have been a clergyman first, and now a\r\nteacher. She\xe2\x80\x99s a bit of a fine lady, with her invalidism; and as for the\r\ngirl--she\xe2\x80\x99s the only one who puzzles me when I think about her,--which I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t often do. She seems to have a great notion of giving herself airs;\r\nand I can\xe2\x80\x99t make out why. I could almost fancy she thinks herself too\r\ngood for her company at times. And yet they\xe2\x80\x99re not rich; from all I can\r\nhear they never have been.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she\xe2\x80\x99s not accomplished, mamma. She can\xe2\x80\x99t play.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, Fanny. What else; does she want to bring her up to your\r\nstandard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay! John,\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother, \xe2\x80\x9cthat speech of Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s did no harm. I\r\nmyself heard Miss Hale say she could not play. If you would let us\r\nalone, we could perhaps like her, and see her merits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure I never could!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Fanny, protected by her mother. Mr.\r\nThornton heard, but did not care to reply. He was walking up and down\r\nthe dining-room, wishing that his mother would order candles, and allow\r\nhim to set to work at either reading or writing, and so put a stop to\r\nthe conversation. But he never thought of interfering in any of the\r\nsmall domestic regulations that Mrs. Thornton observed, in habitual\r\nremembrance of her old economies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, stopping, and bravely speaking out the truth, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish\r\nyou would like Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d asked she, startled by his earnest, yet tender manner. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nnever thinking of marrying her?--a girl without a penny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe would never have me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with a short laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think she would,\xe2\x80\x9d answered his mother. \xe2\x80\x9cShe laughed in my\r\nface, when I praised her for speaking out something Mr. Bell had said in\r\nyour favour. I liked the girl for doing so frankly, for it made me sure\r\nshe had no thought of you; and the next minute she vexed me so by\r\nseeming to think---- Well, never mind! Only you\xe2\x80\x99re right in saying she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntoo good an opinion of herself to think of you! The saucy jade! I should\r\nlike to know where she\xe2\x80\x99d find a better!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, as I\xe2\x80\x99m just as much convinced of the truth of what you have been\r\nsaying as you can be; and as I have no thought or expectation of ever\r\nasking her to be my wife, you\xe2\x80\x99ll believe me for the future that I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nquite disinterested in speaking about her. I foresee trouble for that\r\ngirl--perhaps, want of motherly care--and I only wish you to be ready to\r\nbe a friend to her, in case she needs one. Now, Fanny,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ntrust you have delicacy enough to understand, that it is as great an\r\ninjury to Miss Hale as to me--in fact, she would think it a greater--to\r\nsuppose that I have any reason, more than I now give, for begging you\r\nand my mother to show her every kindly attention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot forgive her her pride,\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother; \xe2\x80\x9cI will befriend her,\r\nif there is need, for your asking, John. I would befriend Jezebel\r\nherself if you asked me. But this girl, who turns up her nose at us\r\nall--who turns up her nose at you----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, mother; I have never yet put myself, and I mean never to put\r\nmyself, within reach of her contempt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cContempt, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d--(One of Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s expressive snorts.)--\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngo on speaking of Miss Hale, John, if I\xe2\x80\x99ve to be kind to her. When I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nwith her, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know if I like or dislike her most; but when I think\r\nof her, and hear you talk of her, I hate her. I can see she\xe2\x80\x99s given\r\nherself airs to you as well as if you\xe2\x80\x99d told me out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if she has,\xe2\x80\x9d said he--and then he paused for a moment--then went\r\non: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not a lad, to be cowed by a proud look from a woman, or to care\r\nfor her misunderstanding me and my position. I can laugh at it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure! and at her too, with her fine notions, and haughty tosses!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only wonder why you talk so much about her, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsure, I\xe2\x80\x99m tired enough of the subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said her brother, with a shade of bitterness. \xe2\x80\x9cSuppose we find\r\nsome more agreeable subject. What do you say to a strike, by way of\r\nsomething pleasant to talk about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave the hands actually turned out?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Thornton, with vivid\r\ninterest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHamper\xe2\x80\x99s men are actually out. Mine are working out their week, through\r\nfear of being prosecuted for breach of contract. I\xe2\x80\x99d have had every one\r\nof them up and punished for it, that left his work before his time was\r\nout.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe law expenses would have been more than the hands themselves were\r\nworth--a set of ungrateful naughts!\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure. But I\xe2\x80\x99d have shown them how to keep my word, and how I mean\r\nthem to keep their\xe2\x80\x99s. They know me by this time. Slickson\xe2\x80\x99s men are\r\noff--pretty certain he won\xe2\x80\x99t spend money in getting them punished. We\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nin for a turn-out, mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope there are not many orders in hand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course there are. They know that well enough. But they don\xe2\x80\x99t quite\r\nunderstand all, though they think they do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, John?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCandles had been brought, and Fanny had taken up her interminable piece\r\nof worsted-work, over which she was yawning; throwing herself back in\r\nher chair, from time to time to gaze at vacancy, and think of nothing at\r\nher ease.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Americans are getting their yarns so into the\r\ngeneral market, that our only chance is producing them at a lower rate.\r\nIf we can\xe2\x80\x99t, we may shut up shop at once, and hands and masters alike go\r\non tramp. Yet these fools go back to the prices paid three years\r\nago--nay, some of their leaders quote Dickinson\xe2\x80\x99s price now--though they\r\nknow as well as we do that, what with fines pressed out of their wages,\r\nas no honourable man would extort them, the real rate of wage paid at\r\nDickinson\xe2\x80\x99s is less than at ours. Upon my word, mother, I wish the old\r\ncombination laws were in force. It is too bad to find out that\r\nfools--ignorant, wayward men like these--just by uniting their silly\r\nheads, are to rule over the fortunes of those who bring all the wisdom\r\nthat knowledge and experience, and often painful thought and anxiety,\r\ncan give. The next thing will be--indeed, we\xe2\x80\x99ve all but come to it\r\nnow--that we shall have to go and ask--stand hat in hand--and humbly ask\r\nthe secretary of the Spinner\xe2\x80\x99s Union to be so kind as to furnish us with\r\nlabour at their own price. That\xe2\x80\x99s what they want--they, who haven\xe2\x80\x99t the\r\nsense to see that, if we don\xe2\x80\x99t get a fair share of the profits to\r\ncompensate us for our wear and tear here in England, we can move off to\r\nsome other country; and that, what with home and foreign competition, we\r\nare none of us likely to make above a fair share, and may be thankful\r\nenough if we can get that, in an average number of years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you get hands from Ireland? I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t keep these fellows a day.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d teach them that I was master, and could employ what servants I\r\nliked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! to be sure, I can; and will, too, if they go on long. It will be\r\ntrouble and expense, and I fear there will be some danger; but I will do\r\nit, rather than give in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf there is to be all this extra expense, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry we\xe2\x80\x99re giving a\r\ndinner just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo am I,--not because of the expense, but because I shall have much to\r\nthink about, and many unexpected calls on my time. But we must have had\r\nMr. Horsfall, and he does not stay in Milton long. And as for the\r\nothers, we owe them dinners, and it\xe2\x80\x99s all one trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe kept on with his restless walk--not speaking any more, but drawing a\r\ndeep breath from time to time, as if endeavouring to throw off some\r\nannoying thought. Fanny asked her mother numerous small questions, all\r\nhaving nothing to do with the subject, which a wiser person would have\r\nperceived was occupying her attention. Consequently, she received many\r\nshort answers. She was not sorry when, at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the servants\r\nfiled in to prayers. These her mother always read,--first reading a\r\nchapter. They were now working steadily through the Old Testament. When\r\nprayers were ended, and his mother had wished him good-night, with that\r\nlong steady look of hers which conveyed no expression of the tenderness\r\nthat was in her heart, but yet had the intensity of a blessing, Mr.\r\nThornton continued his walk. All his business plans had received a\r\ncheck, a sudden pull-up, from this approaching turn-out. The forethought\r\nof many anxious hours was thrown away, utterly wasted by their insane\r\nfolly, which would injure themselves even more than him, though no one\r\ncould set any limit to the mischief they were doing. And these were the\r\nmen who thought themselves fitted to direct the masters in the disposal\r\nof their capital; Hamper had said, only this very day, that if he were\r\nruined by the strike, he would start life again, comforted by the\r\nconviction that those who had brought it on were in a worse predicament\r\nthan he himself,--for he had head as well as hands, while they had only\r\nhands; and if they drove away their market, they could not follow it,\r\nnor turn to anything else. But this thought was no consolation to Mr.\r\nThornton. It might be that revenge gave him no pleasure; it might be\r\nthat he valued the position he had earned with the sweat of his brow, so\r\nmuch that he keenly felt its being endangered by the ignorance or folly\r\nof others,--so keenly that he had no thoughts to spare for what would be\r\nthe consequences of their conduct to themselves. He paced up and down,\r\nsetting his teeth now and then. At last it struck two. The candles were\r\nflickering in their sockets. He lighted his own, muttering to himself:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce for all they shall know whom they have got to deal with. I can\r\ngive them a fortnight,--no more. If they don\xe2\x80\x99t see their madness before\r\nthe end of that time, I must have hands from Ireland. I believe it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nSlickson\xe2\x80\x99s doing,--confound him and his dodges! He thought he was\r\noverstocked; so he seemed to yield at first, when the deputation came to\r\nhim,--and of course, he only confirmed them in their folly, as he meant\r\nto do. That\xe2\x80\x99s where it spread from.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIX.\r\n\r\nANGEL VISITS.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cAs angels in some brighter dreams\r\n       Call to the soul when man doth sleep,\r\n     So some strange thoughts transcend our wonted themes,\r\n       And into glory peep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                                   HENRY VAUGHAN.\r\n\r\n\r\nMrs. Hale was curiously amused and interested by the idea of the\r\nThornton dinner party. She kept wondering about the details, with\r\nsomething of the simplicity of a little child, who wants to have all its\r\nanticipated pleasure described beforehand. But the monotonous life led\r\nby invalids often makes them like children, inasmuch as they have\r\nneither of them any sense of proportion in events, and seem each to\r\nbelieve that the walls and curtains which shut in their world, and shut\r\nout everything else, must of necessity be larger than anything hidden\r\nbeyond. Besides Mrs. Hale had had her vanities as a girl; had perhaps\r\nunduly felt their mortification when she became a poor clergyman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwife;--they had been smothered and kept down; but they were not extinct;\r\nand she liked to think of seeing Margaret dressed for a party, and\r\ndiscussed what she should wear, with an unsettled anxiety that amused\r\nMargaret, who had been more accustomed to society in her one year in\r\nHarley Street than her mother in five and twenty years of Helstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you think you shall wear your white silk. Are you sure it will\r\nfit? It\xe2\x80\x99s nearly a year since Edith was married!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, mamma! Mrs. Murray made it, and it\xe2\x80\x99s sure to be right; it may\r\nbe a straw\xe2\x80\x99s breadth shorter or longer-waisted, according to my having\r\ngrown fat or thin. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99ve altered in the least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHadn\xe2\x80\x99t you better let Dixon see it? It may have gone yellow with lying\r\nby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you like, mamma. But if the worst comes to the worst, I\xe2\x80\x99ve a very\r\nnice pink gauze which Aunt Shaw gave me, only two or three months before\r\nEdith was married. That can\xe2\x80\x99t have gone yellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! but it may have faded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! then I\xe2\x80\x99ve a green silk. I feel more as if it was the\r\nembarrassment of riches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I knew what you ought to wear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, nervously.\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s manner changed instantly. \xe2\x80\x9cShall I go and put them on one\r\nafter another, mamma, and then you could see which you liked best?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut--yes! perhaps that will be best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo off Margaret went. She was very much inclined to play some pranks\r\nwhen she was dressed up at such an unusual hour; to make her rich white\r\nsilk balloon out into a cheese, to retreat backwards from her mother as\r\nif she were the queen; but when she found that these freaks of hers were\r\nregarded as interruptions to the serious business, and as such annoyed\r\nher mother, she became grave and sedate. What had possessed the world\r\n(her world) to fidget so about her dress, she could not understand; but\r\nthat very afternoon, on naming her engagement to Bessy Higgins (apropos\r\nof the servant that Mrs. Thornton had promised to enquire about), Bessy\r\nquite roused up at the intelligence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear! and are you going to dine at Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s at Marlborough Mills?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Bessy. Why are you so surprised?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I dunno. But they visit wi\xe2\x80\x99 a\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 first folk in Milton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you don\xe2\x80\x99t think we\xe2\x80\x99re quite the first folk in Milton, eh, Bessy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy\xe2\x80\x99s cheeks flushed a little at her thought being thus easily read.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyo\xe2\x80\x99 see, they thinken a deal o\xe2\x80\x99 money here; and I\r\nreckon yo\xe2\x80\x99ve not getten much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s very true. But we are educated people, and\r\nhave lived amongst educated people. Is there anything so wonderful, in\r\nour being asked out to dinner by a man who owns himself inferior to my\r\nfather by coming to him to be instructed? I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to blame Mr.\r\nThornton. Few drapers\xe2\x80\x99 assistants, as he was once, could have made\r\nthemselves what he is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut can yo\xe2\x80\x99 give dinners back, in yo\xe2\x80\x99re small house? Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s house\r\nis three times as big.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I think we could manage to give Mr. Thornton a dinner back, as\r\nyou call it. I shall look to\r\nsee you on the twenty-first, if you\xe2\x80\x99re well enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe medicines and treatment which Dr. Donaldson had ordered for Mrs.\r\nHale, did her so much good at first that not only she herself, but\r\nMargaret, began to hope that he might have been mistaken, and that she\r\ncould recover permanently. As for Mr. Hale, although he had never had an\r\nidea of the serious nature of their apprehensions, he triumphed over\r\ntheir fears with an evident relief, which proved how much his glimpse\r\ninto the nature of them had affected him. Only Dixon croaked for ever\r\ninto Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s ear. However, Margaret defied the raven, and would hope.\r\n\r\nThey needed this gleam of brightness in-doors, for out-of-doors, even to\r\ntheir uninstructed eyes, there was a gloomy brooding appearance of\r\ndiscontent. Mr. Hale had his own acquaintances among the working men,\r\nand was depressed with their earnestly-told tales of suffering and\r\nlong-endurance. They would have scorned to speak of what they had to\r\nbear to any one who might, from his position, have understood it without\r\ntheir words. But here was this man, from a distant county, who was\r\nperplexed by the workings of a system into the midst of which he was\r\nthrown, and each was eager to make him a judge, and to bring witness of\r\nhis own causes for irritation. Then Mr. Hale brought all his budget of\r\ngrievances, and laid it before Mr. Thornton, for him, with his\r\nexperience as a master, to arrange them, and explain their origin; which\r\nhe always did, on sound economical principles; showing that, as trade\r\nwas conducted, there must always be a waxing and waning of commercial\r\nprosperity; and that in the waning a certain number of masters, as well\r\nas of men, must go down into ruin, and be no more seen among the ranks\r\nof the happy and prosperous. He spoke as if this consequence were so\r\nentirely logical, that neither employers nor employed had any right to\r\ncomplain if it became their fate: the employer to turn aside from the\r\nrace he could no longer run, with a bitter sense of incompetency and\r\nfailure--wounded in the struggle--trampled down by his fellows in their\r\nhaste to get rich--slighted where he was once honoured--humbly asking\r\nfor, instead of bestowing, employment with a lordly hand. Of course,\r\nspeaking so of the fate that, as a master, might be his own in the\r\nfluctuations of commerce, he was not likely to have more sympathy with\r\nthat of the workmen, who were passed by in the swift merciless\r\nimprovement or alteration; who would fain lie down and quietly die out\r\nof the world that needed them not, but felt as they could never rest in\r\ntheir graves for the clinging cries of the beloved and helpless they\r\nwould leave behind; who envied the power of the wild bird, that can feed\r\nher young with her very heart\xe2\x80\x99s blood. Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s whole soul rose up\r\nagainst him while he reasoned in this way--as if commerce were\r\neverything and humanity nothing. She could hardly thank him for the\r\nindividual kindness, which brought him that very evening to offer\r\nher--for the delicacy which made him understand that he must offer her\r\nprivately--every convenience for illness that his own wealth or his\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s foresight had caused them to accumulate in their household, and\r\nwhich, as he learnt from Dr. Donaldson, Mrs. Hale might possibly\r\nrequire. His presence, after the way he had spoken--his bringing before\r\nher the doom, which she was vainly trying to persuade herself might yet\r\nbe averted from her mother--all conspired to set Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s teeth on\r\nedge, as she looked at him, and listened to him. What business had he to\r\nbe the only person, except Dr. Donaldson and Dixon, admitted to the\r\nawful secret, which she held shut up in the most dark and sacred recess\r\nof her heart--not daring to look at it, unless she invoked heavenly\r\nstrength to bear the sight--that, some day soon, she should cry aloud\r\nfor her mother, and no answer would come out of the blank, dumb\r\ndarkness? Yet he knew all. She saw it in his pitying eyes. She heard it\r\nin his grave and tremulous voice. How reconcile those eyes, that voice,\r\nwith the hard, reasoning, dry, merciless way in which he laid down\r\naxioms of trade, and serenely followed them out to their full\r\nconsequences? The discord jarred upon her inexpressibly. The more\r\nbecause of the gathering woe of which she heard from Bessy. To be sure,\r\nNicholas Higgins, the father, spoke differently. He had been appointed a\r\ncommittee-man, and said that he knew secrets of which the exoteric knew\r\nnothing. He said this more expressly and particularly, on the very day\r\nbefore Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s dinner-party. When Margaret, going in to speak to\r\nBessy, found him arguing the point with Boucher, the neighbour of whom\r\nshe had frequently heard mention, as by turns exciting Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncompassion, as an unskilful workman with a large family depending upon\r\nhim for support, and at other times enraging his more energetic and\r\nsanguine neighbour by his want of what the latter called spirit. It was\r\nvery evident that Higgins was in a passion when Margaret entered.\r\nBoucher stood, with both hands on the rather high mantelpiece, swaying\r\nhimself a little on the support which his arms, thus placed, gave him,\r\nand looking wildly into the fire, with a kind of despair that irritated\r\nHiggins, even while it went to his heart. Bessy was rocking herself\r\nviolently backwards and forwards, as was her wont (Margaret knew by this\r\ntime) when she was agitated. Her sister Mary was tying on her bonnet (in\r\ngreat clumsy bows, as suited her great clumsy fingers), to go to her\r\nfustian-cutting, blubbering out loud the while, and evidently longing to\r\nbe away from a scene that distressed her.\r\n\r\nMargaret came in upon this scene. She stood for a moment at the\r\ndoor--then, her finger on her lips, she stole to a seat on the squab\r\nnear Bessy. Nicholas saw her come in, and greeted her with a gruff, but\r\nnot unfriendly nod. It was only John Boucher that took no notice whatever who came\r\nin and who went out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no use, Higgins. Hoo cannot live long a\xe2\x80\x99 this\xe2\x80\x99n. Thy lile Jack shall na\xe2\x80\x99 clem. I ha\xe2\x80\x99 gotten brass, and\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll go buy the chap a sup o\xe2\x80\x99 milk an\xe2\x80\x99 a good four-pounder this very\r\nminute. What\xe2\x80\x99s mine\xe2\x80\x99s thine, sure enough, i\xe2\x80\x99 thou\xe2\x80\x99st i\xe2\x80\x99 want. Only,\r\ndunnot lose heart, man!\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, as he fumbled in a tea-pot for\r\nwhat money he had. \xe2\x80\x9cI lay yo my heart and soul we\xe2\x80\x99ll win for a\xe2\x80\x99 this:\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s but bearing on one more week, and yo\xe2\x80\x99 just see th\xe2\x80\x99 way th\xe2\x80\x99 masters\r\n\xe2\x80\x99ll come round, praying on us to come back to our mills. An\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\nUnion--that\xe2\x80\x99s to say, I--will take care yo\xe2\x80\x99ve enough for th\xe2\x80\x99 childer and\r\nth\xe2\x80\x99 missus. So dunnot turn faint-heart, and go to th\xe2\x80\x99 tyrants a-seeking\r\nwork.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man turned round at these words,--turned round a face so white, and\r\ngaunt, and tear-furrowed, and hopeless, that its very calm forced\r\nMargaret to weep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99 know well, that a worser tyrant than e\xe2\x80\x99er th\xe2\x80\x99 masters were says,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Clem to death, and see \xe2\x80\x99em a\xe2\x80\x99 clem to death, ere yo\xe2\x80\x99 dare go again th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nUnion.\xe2\x80\x99 Yo\xe2\x80\x99 know it well, Nicholas, for a\xe2\x80\x99 yo\xe2\x80\x99re one on e\xe2\x80\x99m. Yo\xe2\x80\x99 may be\r\nkind hearts, each separate; but once banded together, yo\xe2\x80\x99ve no more pity\r\nfor a man than a wild hunger-maddened wolf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNicholas had his hand on the lock of the door--he stopped and turned\r\nround on Boucher, close following:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo help me God! man alive--if I think not I\xe2\x80\x99m doing best for thee, and\r\nfor all on us. If I\xe2\x80\x99m going wrong when I think I\xe2\x80\x99m going right, it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntheir sin, who ha\xe2\x80\x99 left me where I am, in my ignorance. I ha\xe2\x80\x99 thought\r\ntill my brains ached,--Beli\xe2\x80\x99 me, John, I have. An\xe2\x80\x99 I say again, there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nno help for us but having faith i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 Union. They\xe2\x80\x99ll win the day, see\r\nif they dunnot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNot one word had Margaret or Bessy spoken. They had hardly uttered the\r\nsighing, that the eyes of each called to the other to bring up from the\r\ndepths of her heart. At last Bessy said,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never thought to hear father call on God again. But yo\xe2\x80\x99 heard him\r\nsay, \xe2\x80\x98So help me God!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me bring you what money I can spare,--let me\r\nbring you a little food for that poor man\xe2\x80\x99s children. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let them\r\nknow it comes from any one but your father. It will be but little.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy lay back without taking any notice of what Margaret said. She did\r\nnot cry--she only quivered up her breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy heart\xe2\x80\x99s drained dry o\xe2\x80\x99 tears,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cBoucher\xe2\x80\x99s been in these\r\ndays past, a telling me of his fears and his troubles. He\xe2\x80\x99s but a weak\r\nkind of chap, I know, but he\xe2\x80\x99s a man for a\xe2\x80\x99 that; and tho\xe2\x80\x99 I\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\nangry, many a time afore now, wi\xe2\x80\x99 him an\xe2\x80\x99 his wife, as knew no more nor\r\nhim how to manage, yet yo\xe2\x80\x99 see, all folks isn\xe2\x80\x99t wise, yet God lets \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nlive--ay, an\xe2\x80\x99 gives \xe2\x80\x99em some one to love, and be loved by, just as good\r\nas Solomon. An\xe2\x80\x99 if sorrow comes to them they love, it hurts \xe2\x80\x99em as sore\r\nas e\xe2\x80\x99er it did Solomon. I can\xe2\x80\x99t make it out. Perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s as well such a\r\none as Boucher has th\xe2\x80\x99 Union to see after him. But I\xe2\x80\x99d just like for to\r\nsee th\xe2\x80\x99 men as make th\xe2\x80\x99 Union, and put \xe2\x80\x99em one by one face to face wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nBoucher. I reckon, if they heard him, the\xe2\x80\x99d tell him (if I cotched \xe2\x80\x99em\r\none by one), he might go back and get what he could for his work, even\r\nif it weren\xe2\x80\x99t so much as they ordered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret sat utterly silent. How was she ever to go away into comfort\r\nand forget that man\xe2\x80\x99s voice, with the tone of unutterable agony, telling\r\nmore by far than his words of what he had to suffer? She took out her\r\npurse; she had not much in it of what she could call her own, but what\r\nshe had she put into Bessy\xe2\x80\x99s hands without speaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank yo\xe2\x80\x99. There\xe2\x80\x99s many on \xe2\x80\x99em gets no more, and is not so bad\r\noff,--leastways does not show it as he does. But father won\xe2\x80\x99t let \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nwant, now he knows. Yo\xe2\x80\x99 see, Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s been pulled down wi\xe2\x80\x99 his\r\nchilder,--and her being so cranky, and a\xe2\x80\x99 they could pawn has gone this\r\nlast twelvemonth. Yo\xe2\x80\x99re not to think we\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 letten \xe2\x80\x99em clem, for all\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99re a bit pressed oursel\xe2\x80\x99; if neighbours doesn\xe2\x80\x99t see after neighbours,\r\nI dunno who will.\xe2\x80\x9d Bessy seemed almost afraid lest Margaret should think\r\nthey had not the will, and, to a certain degree, the power of helping\r\none whom she evidently regarded as having a claim upon them. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe went on, \xe2\x80\x9cfather is sure and positive the masters must give in\r\nwithin these next few days,--that they canna hould on much longer.
