But I\r\nthank yo\xe2\x80\x99 all the same,--I thank yo\xe2\x80\x99 for mysel\xe2\x80\x99, as much as for Boucher,\r\nfor it jus makes my heart warm to yo\xe2\x80\x99 more and more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy seemed much quieter to-day, but fearfully languid and exhausted.\r\nAs she finished speaking, she looked so faint and weary that Margaret\r\nbecame alarmed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s nout,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessy. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not death yet. I had a fearfu\xe2\x80\x99 night wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndreams--or somewhat like dreams, for I were wide awake--and I\xe2\x80\x99m all in a\r\nswounding daze to-day,--only yon poor chap made me alive again. No! it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnot death yet, but death is not far off. Ay. Cover me up, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll may\r\nbe sleep, if th\xe2\x80\x99 cough will let me. Good night--good afternoon, m\xe2\x80\x99appen\r\nI should say--but th\xe2\x80\x99 light is dim an\xe2\x80\x99 misty to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XX.\r\n\r\nMEN AND GENTLEMEN.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cOld and young, boy, let \xe2\x80\x99em all eat, I have it;\r\n    Let \xe2\x80\x99em have ten tire of teeth a-piece, I care not.\r\n              ROLLO, DUKE OF NORMANDY.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret went home so painfully occupied with what she had heard and\r\nseen that she hardly knew how to rouse herself up to the duties which\r\nawaited her; the necessity for keeping up a constant flow of cheerful\r\nconversation for her mother, who, now that she was unable to go out,\r\nalways looked to Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s return from the shortest walk as bringing in\r\nsome news.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd can your factory friend come on Thursday to see you dressed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was so ill I never thought of asking her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret,\r\ndolefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear! Everybody is ill now, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, with a little of\r\nthe jealousy which one invalid is apt to feel of another. \xe2\x80\x9cBut it must\r\nbe very sad to be ill in one of those little back streets.\xe2\x80\x9d (Her kindly\r\nnature prevailing, and the old Helstone habits of thought returning.)\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s bad enough here. What could you do for her, Margaret? Mr. Thornton\r\nhas sent me some of his old port wine since you went out. Would a bottle\r\nof that do her good, think you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, mamma! I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe they are very poor,--at least, they don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nspeak as if they were; and, at any rate, Bessy\xe2\x80\x99s illness is\r\nconsumption--she won\xe2\x80\x99t want wine. Perhaps, I might take her a little\r\npreserve, made of our dear Helstone fruit. No! there\xe2\x80\x99s another family to\r\nwhom I should like to give--Oh mamma, mamma! how am I to dress up in my\r\nfinery, and go off and away to smart parties, after the sorrow I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen\r\nto-day?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Margaret, bursting the bounds she had preordained for\r\nherself before she came in, and telling her mother what she had seen and\r\nheard at Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s cottage.\r\n\r\nIt distressed Mrs. Hale excessively. It made her restlessly irritated\r\ntill she could do something. She directed Margaret to pack up a basket\r\nin the very drawing-room, to be sent there and then to the family; and\r\nwas almost angry with her for saying, that it would not signify if it\r\ndid not go till morning, as she knew Higgins had provided for their\r\nimmediate wants, and she herself had left money with Bessy. Mrs. Hale\r\ncalled her unfeeling for saying this; and never gave herself\r\nbreathing-time till the basket was sent out of the house. Then she said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter all, we may have been doing wrong. It was only the last time Mr.\r\nThornton was here that he said, those were no true friends who helped to\r\nprolong the struggle by assisting the turn-outs. And this Boucher-man\r\nwas a turn-out, was he not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe question was referred to Mr. Hale by his wife, when he came\r\nupstairs, fresh from giving a lesson to Mr. Thornton, which had ended in\r\nconversation, as was their wont. Margaret did not care if their gifts\r\nhad prolonged the strife; she did not think far enough for that, in her\r\npresent excited state.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale listened, and tried to be as calm as a judge; he recalled all\r\nthat had seemed so clear not half-an-hour before, as it came out of Mr.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s lips; and then he made an unsatisfactory compromise. His wife\r\nand daughter had not only done quite right in this instance, but he did\r\nnot see for a moment how they could have done otherwise. Nevertheless,\r\nas a general rule, it was very true what Mr. Thornton said, that as the\r\nstrike, if prolonged, must end in the masters bringing hands from a\r\ndistance (if, indeed, the final result were not, as it had often been\r\nbefore, the invention of some machine which would diminish the need of\r\nhands at all), why, it was clear enough that the kindest thing was to\r\nrefuse all help which might bolster them up in their folly. But as to\r\nthis Boucher, he would go and see him the first thing in the morning,\r\nand try and find out what could be done for him.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale went the next morning, as he proposed. He did not find Boucher\r\nat home, but he had a long talk with his wife; promised to ask for an\r\nInfirmary order for; and, seeing the plenty provided by Mrs. Hale, and\r\nsomewhat lavishly used by the children, who were masters downstairs in\r\ntheir father\xe2\x80\x99s absence, he came back with a more consoling and cheerful\r\naccount than Margaret had dared to hope for; indeed, what she had said\r\nthe night before had prepared her father for so much worse a state of\r\nthings that, by a re-action of his imagination, he described all as\r\nbetter than it really was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I will go again, and see the man himself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cI hardly\r\nknow as yet how to compare one of these houses with our Helstone\r\ncottages. I see furniture here which our labourers would never have\r\nthought of buying, and food commonly used which they would consider\r\nluxuries; yet for these very families there seems no other resource now\r\nthat their weekly wages are stopped, but the pawn-shop. One had need to\r\nlearn a different standard, up here in Milton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy, too, was rather better this day. Still she was so weak that she\r\nseemed to have entirely forgotten her wish to see Margaret dressed--if,\r\nindeed, that had not been the feverish desire of a half delirious state.\r\n\r\nMargaret could not help comparing this strange dressing of hers, to go\r\nwhere she did not care to be--her heart heavy with various\r\nanxieties--with the old, merry, girlish toilettes that she and Edith had\r\nperformed scarcely more than a year ago. Her only pleasure now in\r\ndecking herself out was in thinking that her mother would take delight\r\nin seeing her dressed. She blushed when Dixon, throwing the drawing-room\r\ndoor open, made an appeal for admiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Hale looks well, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,--doesn\xe2\x80\x99t she? Mrs. Shaw\xe2\x80\x99s coral couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave come in better. It just gives the right touch of colour, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\r\nOtherwise, Miss Margaret, you would have been too pale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s black hair was too thick to be plaited; it needed rather to\r\nbe twisted round and round, and have its fine silkiness compressed into\r\nmassive coils, that encircled her head like a crown, and then were\r\ngathered into a large spiral knot behind. She kept its weight together\r\nby two large coral pins, like small arrows for length. Her white silk\r\nsleeves were looped up with strings of the same material, and on her\r\nneck, just below the base of her curved and milk-white throat, there lay\r\nheavy coral beads.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Margaret! how I should like to be going with you to one of the old\r\nBarrington assemblies,--taking you as Lady Beresford used to take me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret kissed her mother for this little burst of maternal vanity; but\r\nshe could hardly smile at it, she felt so much out of spirits.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather stay at home with you,--much rather, mamma.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, darling! Be sure you notice the dinner well. I shall like to\r\nhear how they manage these things in Milton. Particularly the second\r\ncourse, dear. Look what they have instead of game.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Hale would have been more than interested,--she would have been\r\nastonished, if she had seen the sumptuousness of the dinner-table and\r\nits appointments. Margaret, with her London cultivated taste, felt the\r\nnumber of delicacies to be oppressive; one half of the quantity would\r\nhave been enough, and the effect tighter and more elegant. But it was\r\none of Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s rigorous laws of hospitality, that of each\r\nseparate dainty enough should be provided for all the guests to partake,\r\nif they felt inclined. Careless to abstemiousness in her daily habits,\r\nit was part of her pride to set a feast before such of her guests as\r\ncared for it. Her son shared this feeling. He had never known--though he\r\nmight have imagined, and had the capability to relish--any kind of\r\nsociety but that which depended on an exchange of superb meals: and even\r\nnow, though he was denying himself the personal expenditure of an\r\nunnecessary sixpence, and had more than once regretted that the\r\ninvitations for this dinner had been sent out, still, as it was to be,\r\nhe was glad to see the old magnificence of preparation.\r\n\r\nMargaret and her father were the first to arrive. Mr. Hale was anxiously\r\npunctual to the time specified. There was no one upstairs in the\r\ndrawing-room but Mrs. Thornton and Fanny. Every cover was taken off, and\r\nthe apartment blazed forth in yellow silk damask and a brilliantly\r\nflowered carpet. Every corner seemed filled up with ornament, until it\r\nbecame a weariness to the eye, and presented a strange contrast to the\r\nbald ugliness of the look-out into the great mill-yard, where wide\r\nfolding gates were thrown open for the admission of carriages. The mill\r\nloomed high on the left-hand side of the windows, casting a shadow down\r\nfrom its many stories, which darkened the summer evening before its\r\ntime.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy son was engaged up to the last moment on business. He will be here\r\ndirectly, Mr. Hale. May I beg you to take a seat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale was standing at one of the windows as Mrs. Thornton spoke. He\r\nturned away, saying,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you find such close neighbourhood to the mill rather unpleasant\r\nat times?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe drew herself up:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever. I am not become so fine as to desire to forget the source of my\r\nson\xe2\x80\x99s wealth and power. Besides, there is not such another factory in\r\nMilton. One room alone is two hundred and twenty square yards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI meant that the smoke and the noise--the constant going out and coming\r\nin of the workpeople, might be annoying!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI agree with you, Mr. Hale!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is a continual smell of\r\nsteam and oily machinery--and the noise is perfectly deafening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard noise that was called music far more deafening. The\r\nengine-room is at the street-end of the factory; we hardly hear it,\r\nexcept in summer weather, when all the windows are open; and as for the\r\ncontinual murmur of the workpeople, it disturbs me no more than the\r\nhumming of a hive of bees. If I think of it at all, I connect it with my\r\nson, and feel how all belongs to him, and that his is the head that\r\ndirects it. Just now, there are no sounds to come from the mill; the\r\nhands have been ungrateful enough to turn out, as perhaps you have\r\nheard. But the very business (of which I spoke when you entered), had\r\nreference to the steps he is going to take to make them learn their\r\nplace.\xe2\x80\x9d The expression on her face, always stern, deepened into dark\r\nanger, as she said this. Nor did it clear away when Mr. Thornton entered\r\nthe room; for she saw in an instant, the weight of care and anxiety\r\nwhich he could not shake off, although his guests received from him a\r\ngreeting that appeared both cheerful and cordial. He shook hands with\r\nMargaret. He knew it was the first time their hands had met, though she\r\nwas perfectly unconscious of the fact. He inquired after Mrs. Hale, and\r\nheard Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s sanguine, hopeful account; and, glancing to Margaret,\r\nto understand how far she agreed with her father, he saw that no\r\ndissenting shadow crossed her face. And as he looked with this\r\nintention, he was struck anew with her great beauty. He had never seen\r\nher in such dress before; and yet now it appeared that such elegance of\r\nattire was so befitting her noble figure and lofty serenity of\r\ncountenance that she ought to go always thus apparelled. She was talking\r\nto Fanny; about what he could not hear; but he saw his sister\xe2\x80\x99s restless\r\nway of continually arranging some part of her gown, her wandering eyes,\r\nnow glancing here, now there, but without any purpose in her\r\nobservation; and he contrasted them uneasily with the large soft eyes\r\nthat looked forth steadily at one object, as if from out their light\r\nbeamed some gentle influence of repose: the curving lines of the red\r\nlips, just parted in the interest of listening to what her companion\r\nsaid--the head a little bent forwards, so as to make a long sweeping\r\nline from the summit, where the light caught on the glossy raven hair,\r\nto the smooth ivory tip of the shoulder; the round white arms, and taper\r\nhands, laid lightly across each other, but perfectly motionless in their\r\npretty attitude. Mr. Thornton sighed as he took in all this with one of\r\nhis sudden comprehensive glances. And then he turned his back to the\r\nyoung ladies, and threw himself, with an effort, but with all his heart\r\nand soul, into a conversation with Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\nMore people came--more and more. Fanny left Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s side and helped\r\nher mother to receive her guests. Mr. Thornton felt that in this influx\r\nno one was speaking to Margaret, and was restless under this apparent\r\nneglect. But he never went near her himself; he did not look at her.\r\nOnly, he knew what she was doing--or not doing--better than he knew the\r\nmovements of any one else in the room. Margaret was so unconscious of\r\nherself, and so much amused by watching other people, that she never\r\nthought whether she was left unnoticed or not. Somebody took her down to\r\ndinner; she did not catch the name; nor did he seem much inclined to\r\ntalk to her. There was a very animated conversation going on among the\r\ngentlemen; the ladies, for the most part, were silent, employing\r\nthemselves in taking notes of the dinner and criticising each other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndresses. Margaret caught the clue to the general conversation, grew\r\ninterested and listened attentively. Mr. Horsfall, the stranger, whose\r\nvisit to the town was the original germ of the party, was asking\r\nquestions relative to the trade and manufactures of the place; and the\r\nrest of the gentlemen--all Milton men--were giving him answers and\r\nexplanations. Some dispute arose, which was warmly contested; it was\r\nreferred to Mr. Thornton, who had hardly spoken before; but who now\r\ngave an opinion, the grounds of which were so clearly stated that even\r\nthe opponents yielded. Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s attention was thus called to her host;\r\nhis whole manner, as master of the house, and entertainer of his\r\nfriends, was so straightforward, yet simple and modest, as to be\r\nthoroughly dignified. Margaret thought she had never seen him to so much\r\nadvantage. When he had come to their house, there had been always\r\nsomething, either of over-eagerness or of that kind of vexed annoyance\r\nwhich seemed ready to pre-suppose that he was unjustly judged, and yet\r\nfelt too proud to try and make himself better understood. But now, among\r\nhis fellows, there was no uncertainty as to his position. He was\r\nregarded by them as a man of great force of character; of power in many\r\nways. There was no need to struggle for their respect. He had it, and he\r\nknew it; and the security of this gave a fine grand quietness to his\r\nvoice and ways, which Margaret had missed before.\r\n\r\nHe was not in the habit of talking to ladies; and what he did say was a\r\nlittle formal. To Margaret herself he hardly spoke at all. She was\r\nsurprised to think how much she enjoyed this dinner. She knew enough now\r\nto understand many local interests--nay, even some of the technical\r\nwords employed by the eager millowners. She silently took a very decided\r\npart in the question they were discussing. At any rate, they talked in\r\ndesperate earnest,--not in the used-up style that wearied her so in the\r\nold London parties. She wondered that, with all this dwelling on the\r\nmanufacturers and trade of the place, no allusion was made to the strike\r\nthen pending. She did not yet know how coolly such things were taken by\r\nthe masters, as having only one possible end. To be sure, the men were\r\ncutting their own throats, as they had done many a time before; but if\r\nthey would be fools, and put themselves into the hands of a rascally set\r\nof paid delegates, they must take the consequence. One or two thought\r\nThornton looked out of spirits; and, of course, he must lose by this\r\nturn-out. But it was an accident that might happen to themselves any\r\nday; and Thornton was as good to manage a strike as any one; for he was\r\nas iron a chap as any in Milton. The hands had mistaken their man in\r\ntrying that dodge on him. And they chuckled inwardly at the idea of the\r\nworkmen\xe2\x80\x99s discomfiture and defeat, in their attempt to alter one iota of\r\nwhat Thornton had decreed.\r\n\r\nIt was rather dull for Margaret after dinner. She was glad when the\r\ngentlemen came, not merely because she caught her father\xe2\x80\x99s eye to\r\nbrighten her sleepiness up; but because she could listen to something\r\nlarger and grander than the petty interests which the ladies had been\r\ntalking about. She liked the exultation in the sense of power which\r\nthese Milton men had. It might be rather rampant in its display, and\r\nsavour of boasting; but still they seemed to defy the old limits of\r\npossibility, in a kind of fine intoxication, caused by the recollection\r\nof what had been achieved, and what yet should be. If in her cooler\r\nmoments she might not approve of the spirit in all things, still there\r\nwas much to admire in their forgetfulness of themselves and the present,\r\nin their anticipated triumphs over all inanimate matter at some future\r\ntime which none of them would live to see. She was rather startled when\r\nMr. Thornton spoke to her close at her elbow:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could see you were on our side in our discussion at dinner,--were you\r\nnot, Miss Hale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. But then I know so little about it. I was surprised,\r\nhowever, to find from what Mr. Horsfall said, that there were others who\r\nthought in so diametrically opposite a manner, as the Mr. Morison he\r\nspoke about. He cannot be a gentleman--is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not quite the person to decide on another\xe2\x80\x99s gentlemanliness, Miss\r\nHale. I mean, I don\xe2\x80\x99t quite understand your application of the word. But\r\nI should say that this Morison is no true man. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know who he is; I\r\nmerely judge him from Mr. Horsfall\xe2\x80\x99s account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suspect my \xe2\x80\x98gentleman\xe2\x80\x99 includes your \xe2\x80\x98true man.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a great deal more, you would imply. I differ from you. A man is to\r\nme a higher and a completer being than a gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must understand the words\r\ndifferently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI take it that \xe2\x80\x98gentleman\xe2\x80\x99 is a term that only describes a person in\r\nhis relation to others; but when we speak of him as \xe2\x80\x98a man,\xe2\x80\x99 we consider\r\nhim not merely with regard to his fellow-men, but in relation to\r\nhimself,--to life--to time--to eternity. A cast-away lonely as Robinson\r\nCrusoe--a prisoner immured in a dungeon for life--nay, even a saint in\r\nPatmos, has his endurance, his strength, his faith, best described by\r\nbeing spoken of as \xe2\x80\x98a man.\xe2\x80\x99 I am rather weary of this word\r\n\xe2\x80\x98gentlemanly,\xe2\x80\x99 which seems to me to be often inappropriately used, and\r\noften, too, with such exaggerated distortion of meaning, while the full\r\nsimplicity of the noun \xe2\x80\x98man,\xe2\x80\x99 and the adjective \xe2\x80\x98manly\xe2\x80\x99 are\r\nacknowledged--that I am induced to class it with the cant of the day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret thought a moment--but before she could speak her slow\r\nconviction, he was called away by some of the eager manufacturers, whose\r\nspeeches she could not hear, though she could guess at their import by\r\nthe short clear answers Mr. Thornton gave, which came steady and firm as\r\nthe boom of a distant minute gun. They were evidently talking of the\r\nturn-out, and suggesting what course had best be pursued. She heard Mr.\r\nThornton say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat has been done.\xe2\x80\x9d Then came a hurried murmur, in which two or three\r\njoined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll those arrangements have been made.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSome doubts were implied, some difficulties named by Mr. Slickson, who\r\ntook hold of Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s arm, the better to impress his words. Mr.\r\nThornton moved slightly away, lifted his eyebrows a very little, and\r\nthen replied:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI take the risk. You need not join in it unless you choose.\xe2\x80\x9d Still some\r\nmore fears were urged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not afraid of anything so dastardly as incendiarism. We are open\r\nenemies; and I can protect myself from any violence that I apprehend.\r\nAnd I will assuredly protect all others who come to me for work. They\r\nknow my determination by this time, as well and as fully as you do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Horsfall took him a little on one side, as Margaret conjectured, to\r\nask him some other question about the strike; but, in truth, it was to\r\ninquire who she herself was--so quiet, so stately, and so beautiful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Milton lady?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, as the name was given.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! from the south of England--Hampshire, I believe,\xe2\x80\x9d was the cold,\r\nindifferent answer.\r\n\r\nMrs. Slickson was catechising Fanny on the same subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is that fine distinguished-looking girl? a sister of Mr.\r\nHorsfall\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear, no! That is Mr. Hale, her father, talking now to Mr. Stephens.\r\nHe gives lessons; that is to say, he reads with young men. My brother\r\nJohn goes to him twice a week, and so he begged mamma to ask them here,\r\nin hopes of getting him known. I believe we have some of their\r\nprospectuses, if you would like to have one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton! Does he really find time to read with a tutor, in the\r\nmidst of all his business,--and this abominable strike in hand as well?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFanny was not sure, from Mrs. Slickson\xe2\x80\x99s manner, whether she ought to be\r\nproud or ashamed of her brother\xe2\x80\x99s conduct; and, like all people who try\r\nand take other people\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cought\xe2\x80\x9d for the rule of their feelings, she was\r\ninclined to blush for any singularity of action. Her shame was\r\ninterrupted by the dispersion of the guests.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXI.\r\n\r\nTHE DARK NIGHT.\r\n\r\n              \xe2\x80\x9cOn earth is known to none\r\n    The smile that is not sister to a tear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                                ELLIOTT.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret and her father walked home. The night was fine, the streets\r\nclean, and with her pretty white silk, like Leezie Lindsay\xe2\x80\x99s gown o\xe2\x80\x99\r\ngreen satin, in the ballad, \xe2\x80\x9ckilted up to her knee,\xe2\x80\x9d she was off with\r\nher father--ready to dance along with the excitement of the cool, fresh\r\nnight air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI rather think Thornton is not quite easy in his mind about this\r\nstrike. He seemed very anxious to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should wonder if he were not. But he spoke with his usual coolness to\r\nthe others, when they suggested different things, just before we came\r\naway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo he did after dinner as well. It would take a good deal to stir him\r\nfrom his cool manner of speaking; but his face strikes me as anxious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should be, if I were he. He must know of the growing anger and hardly\r\nsmothered hatred of his workpeople, who all looked upon him as what the\r\nBible calls a \xe2\x80\x98hard man,\xe2\x80\x99--not so much unjust as unfeeling; clear in\r\njudgment, standing upon his \xe2\x80\x98rights\xe2\x80\x99 as no human being ought to stand,\r\nconsidering what we and all our petty rights are in the sight of the\r\nAlmighty. I am glad you think he looks anxious. When I remember\r\nBoucher\xe2\x80\x99s half mad words and ways, I cannot bear to think how coolly Mr.\r\nThornton spoke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place, I am not so convinced as you are about that man\r\nBoucher\xe2\x80\x99s utter distress; for the moment, he was badly off, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndoubt. But there is always a mysterious supply of money from these\r\nUnions; and, from what you said, it was evident the man was of a\r\npassionate, demonstrative nature, and gave strong expression to all he\r\nfelt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, papa!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! I only want you to do justice to Mr. Thornton, who is, I suspect,\r\nof an exactly opposite nature--a man who is far too proud to show his\r\nfeelings. Just the character I should have thought beforehand, you would\r\nhave admired, Margaret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I do--so I should; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel quite so sure as you do of the\r\nexistence of those feelings. He is a man of great strength of\r\ncharacter--of unusual intellect, considering the few advantages he has\r\nhad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so few. He has led a practical life from a very early age, has been\r\ncalled upon to exercise judgment and self-control. All that developes\r\none part of the intellect. To be sure, he needs some of the knowledge of\r\nthe past, which gives the truest basis for conjecture as to the future;\r\nbut he knows this need--he perceives it, and that is something. You are\r\nquite prejudiced against Mr. Thornton, Margaret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is the first specimen of a manufacturer--of a person engaged in\r\ntrade--that I had ever the opportunity of studying, papa. He is my first\r\nolive: let me make a face while I swallow it. I know he is good of his\r\nkind, and by and by I shall like the kind. I rather think I am already\r\nbeginning to do so. I was very much interested by what the gentlemen\r\nwere talking about, although I did not understand half of it. I was\r\nquite sorry when Miss Thornton came to take me to the other end of the\r\nroom, saying she was sure I should be uncomfortable at being the only\r\nlady among so many gentlemen. I had never thought about it, I was so\r\nbusy listening; and the ladies were so dull, papa--oh, so dull! Yet I\r\nthink it was clever too. It reminded me of our old game of having each\r\nso many nouns to introduce into a sentence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, child?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, they took nouns that were signs of things which gave evidence of\r\nwealth,--housekeepers, under-gardeners, extent of glass, valuable lace,\r\ndiamonds, and all such things; and each one formed her speech so as to\r\nbring them all in, in the prettiest accidental manner possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will be as proud of your one servant when you get her, if all is\r\ntrue about her that Mrs. Thornton says.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, I shall. I felt like a great hypocrite to-night, sitting\r\nthere in my white silk gown, with my idle hands before me, when I\r\nremembered all the good, thorough, house-work they had done to-day. They\r\ntook me for a fine lady, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven I was mistaken enough to think you looked like a lady, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mr. Hale, quietly smiling.\r\n\r\nBut smiles were changed to white and trembling looks when they saw\r\nDixon\xe2\x80\x99s face, as she opened the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, master!--Oh, Miss Margaret! Thank God you are come! Dr. Donaldson\r\nis here. The servant next door went for him, for the charwoman is gone\r\nhome. She\xe2\x80\x99s better now; but, oh sir! I thought she\xe2\x80\x99d have died an hour\r\nago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale caught Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s arm to steady himself from falling. He looked\r\nat her face, and saw an expression upon it of surprise and extremest\r\nsorrow, but not the agony of terror that contracted his own unprepared\r\nheart. She knew more than he did, and yet she listened with that\r\nhopeless expression of awed apprehension.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I should not have left her--wicked daughter that I am!\xe2\x80\x9d moaned\r\nforth Margaret, as she supported her trembling father\xe2\x80\x99s hasty steps\r\nupstairs. Dr. Donaldson met them on the landing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is better now,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered. \xe2\x80\x9cThe opiate has taken effect. The\r\nspasms were very bad: no wonder they frightened your maid; but she\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nrally this time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis time! Let me go to her!\xe2\x80\x9d Half an hour ago Mr. Hale was a\r\nmiddle-aged man; now his sight was dim, his senses wavering, his walk\r\ntottering, as if he were seventy years of age.\r\n\r\nDr. Donaldson took his arm, and led him into the bedroom. Margaret\r\nfollowed close. There lay her mother, with an unmistakeable look on her\r\nface. She might be better now; she was sleeping, but Death had signed\r\nher for his own, and it was clear that ere long he would return to take\r\npossession. Mr. Hale looked at her for some time without a word. Then he\r\nbegan to shake all over, and, turning away from Dr. Donaldson\xe2\x80\x99s anxious\r\ncare, he groped to find the door; he could not see it, although several\r\ncandles, brought in the sudden affright, were burning and flaring there.\r\nHe staggered into the drawing-room, and felt about for a chair. Dr.\r\nDonaldson wheeled one to him, and placed him in it. He felt his pulse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak to him, Miss Hale. We must rouse him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, with a crying voice that was wild with pain.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa! Speak to me!\xe2\x80\x9d The speculation came again into his eyes, and he\r\nmade a great effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret, did you know of this? Oh, it was cruel of you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir, it was not cruel!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dr. Donaldson, with quick decision.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Hale acted under my directions. There may have been a mistake, but\r\nit was not cruel. Your wife will be a different creature to-morrow, I\r\ntrust. She has had spasms, as I anticipated, though I did not tell Miss\r\nHale of my apprehensions. She has taken the opiate I brought with me;\r\nshe will have a good long sleep; and to-morrow that look which has\r\nalarmed you so much will have passed away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not the disease?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDr. Donaldson glanced at Margaret. Her bent head, her face raised with\r\nno appeal for a temporary reprieve, showed that quick observer of human\r\nnature that she thought it better that the whole truth should be told.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the disease. We cannot touch the disease, with all our poor vaunted\r\nskill. We can only delay its progress--alleviate the pain it causes. Be\r\na man, sir--a Christian. Have faith in the immortality of the soul,\r\nwhich no pain, no mortal disease, can assail or touch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut all the reply he got was in the choked words, \xe2\x80\x9cYou have never been\r\nmarried, Dr. Donaldson; you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it is,\xe2\x80\x9d and in the deep,\r\nmanly sobs, which went through the stillness of the night like heavy\r\npulses of agony.\r\n\r\nMargaret knelt by him, caressing him with tearful caresses. No one, not\r\neven Dr. Donaldson, knew how the time went by. Mr. Hale was the first to\r\ndare to speak of the necessities of the present moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat must we do?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he. \xe2\x80\x9cTell us both. Margaret is my staff--my\r\nright hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDr. Donaldson gave his clear, sensible directions. No fear for\r\nto-night--nay, even peace for to-morrow, and for many days yet. But no\r\nenduring hope of recovery. He advised Mr. Hale to go to bed, and leave\r\nonly one to watch the slumber, which he hoped would be undisturbed. He\r\npromised to come again early in the morning. And, with a warm and kindly\r\nshake of the hand, he left them.\r\n\r\nThey spoke but few words; they were too much exhausted by their terror\r\nto do more than decide upon the immediate course of action. Mr. Hale was\r\nresolved to sit up through the night, and all that Margaret could do was\r\nto prevail upon him to rest on the drawing-room sofa. Dixon stoutly and\r\nbluntly refused to go to bed; and, as for Margaret, it was simply\r\nimpossible that she should leave her mother, let all the doctors in the\r\nworld speak of \xe2\x80\x9chusbanding resources,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cone watcher only being\r\nrequired.\xe2\x80\x9d So, Dixon sat, and stared, and winked, and drooped, and\r\npicked herself up again with a jerk, and finally gave up the battle, and\r\nfairly snored. Margaret had taken off her gown and tossed it aside with\r\na sort of impatient disgust, and put on her dressing-gown. She felt as\r\nif she never could sleep again; as if her whole senses were acutely\r\nvital, and all endued with double keenness, for the purpose of watching.\r\nEvery sight and sound--nay, even every thought, touched some nerve to\r\nthe very quick. For more than two hours, she heard her father\xe2\x80\x99s restless\r\nmovements in the next room. He came perpetually to the door of her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s chamber, pausing there to listen, till she, not hearing his\r\nclose unseen presence, went and opened it to tell him how all went on,\r\nin reply to the questions his baked lips could hardly form. At last he,\r\ntoo, fell asleep, and all the house was still. Margaret sat behind the\r\ncurtain thinking. Far away in time, far away in space, seemed all the\r\ninterests of past days. Not more than thirty-six hours ago, she cared\r\nfor Bessy Higgins and her father, and her heart was wrung for Boucher;\r\nnow, that was all like a dreaming memory of some former\r\nlife;--everything that had passed out of doors seemed dissevered from\r\nher mother, and therefore unreal. Even Harley Street appeared more\r\ndistinct; there she remembered, as if it were yesterday, how she had\r\npleased herself with tracing out her mother\xe2\x80\x99s features in her Aunt\r\nShaw\xe2\x80\x99s face,--and how letters had come, making her dwell on the thoughs\r\nof home with all the longing of love. Helstone, itself, was in the dim\r\npast. The dull gray days of the preceding winter and spring, so\r\nuneventless and monotonous, seemed more associated with what she cared\r\nfor now above all price. She would fain have caught at the skirts of\r\nthat departing time, and prayed it to return, and give her back what she\r\nhad too little valued while it was yet in her possession. What a vain\r\nshow Life seemed! How unsubstantial, and flickering, and flitting! It\r\nwas as if from some a\xc3\xabrial belfry, high up above the stir and jar of the\r\nearth, there was a bell continually tolling, \xe2\x80\x9cAll are shadows!--all are\r\npassing!--all is past!\xe2\x80\x9d And when the morning dawned, cool and gray, like\r\nmany a happier morning before--when Margaret looked one by one at the\r\nsleepers, it seemed as if the terrible night were unreal as a dream; it,\r\ntoo, was a shadow. It, too, was past.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hale herself was not aware when she awoke, how ill she had been the\r\nnight before. She was rather surprised at Dr. Donaldson\xe2\x80\x99s early visit,\r\nand perplexed by the anxious faces of husband and child. She consented\r\nto remain in bed that day, saying she certainly was tired; but, the\r\nnext, she insisted on getting up; and Dr. Donaldson gave his consent to\r\nher returning into the drawing-room. She was restless and uncomfortable\r\nin every position, and before night she became very feverish. Mr. Hale\r\nwas utterly listless, and incapable of deciding on anything.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can we do to spare mamma such another night?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret on\r\nthe third day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is to a certain degree, the reaction after the powerful opiates I\r\nhave been obliged to use. It is more painful for you to see than for her\r\nto bear, I believe. But, I think, if we could get a water-bed it might\r\nbe a good thing. Not but what she will be better to-morrow; pretty much\r\nlike herself as she was before this attack. Still, I should like her to\r\nhave a water-bed. Mrs. Thornton has one, I know. I\xe2\x80\x99ll try and call there\r\nthis afternoon. Stay,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, his eye catching on Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s face,\r\nblanched with watching in a sick room, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not sure whether I can go;\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve a long round to take. It would do you no harm to have a brisk walk\r\nto Marlborough Street, and ask Mrs. Thornton if she can spare it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cI could go while mamma is asleep this\r\nafternoon. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure Mrs. Thornton would lend it to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDr. Donaldson\xe2\x80\x99s experience told him rightly. Mrs. Hale seemed to shake\r\noff the consequences of her attack, and looked brighter and better this\r\nafternoon than Margaret had ever hoped to see her again. Her daughter\r\nleft her after dinner, sitting in her easy chair, with her hand lying in\r\nher husband\xe2\x80\x99s, who looked more worn and suffering than she by far.\r\nStill, he could smile now--rather slowly, rather faintly, it is true;\r\nbut a day or two before, Margaret never thought to see him smile again.\r\n\r\nIt was about two miles from their house in Crampton Crescent to\r\nMarlborough Street. It was too hot to walk very quickly. An August sun\r\nbeat straight down into the street at three o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon.\r\nMargaret went along, without noticing anything very different from usual\r\nin the first mile and a half of her journey; she was absorbed in her own\r\nthoughts, and had learnt by this time to thread her way through the\r\nirregular stream of human beings that flowed through Milton streets.\r\nBut, by and by, she was struck with an unusual heaving among the mass of\r\npeople in the crowded road on which she was entering. They did not\r\nappear to be moving on, so much as talking, and listening, and buzzing\r\nwith excitement without much stirring from the spot where they might\r\nhappen to be. Still, as they made way for her, and, wrapt up in the\r\npurpose of her errand, and the necessities that suggested it, she was\r\nless quick of observation than she might have been, if her mind had been\r\nat ease. She had got into Marlborough Street before the full conviction\r\nforced itself upon her, that there was a restless, oppressive sense of\r\nirritation abroad among the people; a thunderous atmosphere, morally as\r\nwell as physically, around her. From every narrow lane opening out on\r\nMarlborough Street came up a low distant roar, as of myriads of fierce\r\nindignant voices. The inhabitants of each poor squalid dwelling were\r\ngathered round the doors and windows, if indeed they were not actually\r\nstanding in the middle of the narrow ways--all with looks intent towards\r\none point. Marlborough Street itself was the focus of all those human\r\neyes, that betrayed intensest interest of various kinds; some fierce\r\nwith anger, some lowering with relentless threats! some dilated with\r\nfear, or imploring entreaty; and as Margaret reached the small\r\nside-entrance by the folding doors, in the great dead wall of\r\nMarlborough mill-yard, and waited the porter\xe2\x80\x99s answer to the bell, she\r\nlooked round and heard the first long far-off roll of the tempest;--saw\r\nthe first slow-surging wave of the dark crowd come, with its threatening\r\ncrest, tumble over, and retreat, at the far end of the street, which a\r\nmoment ago seemed so full of repressed noise, but which now was\r\nominously still; all these circumstances forced themselves on Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnotice, but did not sink down into her pre-occupied heart. She did not\r\nknow what they meant--what was their deep significance; while she did\r\nknow, did feel the keen sharp pressure of the knife that was soon to\r\nstab her through and through by leaving her motherless. She was trying\r\nto realise that, in order that, when it came, she might be ready to\r\ncomfort her father.\r\n\r\nThe porter opened the door cautiously, not nearly wide enough to admit\r\nher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s you, is it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, drawing a long breath, and widening\r\nthe entrance, but still not opening it fully. Margaret went in. He\r\nhastily bolted it behind her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTh\xe2\x80\x99 folk are all coming up here, I reckon?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. Something unusual seemed going on; but this street is\r\nquite empty, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe went across the yard and put up the steps to the house door. There\r\nwas no near sound,--no steam engine at work with beat and pant,--no\r\nclick of machinery, no mingling and clashing of many sharp voices; but\r\nfar away, the ominous gathering roar, deep-clamouring.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXII.\r\n\r\nA BLOW AND ITS CONSEQUENCES.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cBut work grew scarce, while bread grew dear,\r\n       And wages lessened, too;\r\n     For Irish hordes were bidders here,\r\n       Our half-paid work to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                       CORN LAW RHYMES.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret was shown into the drawing-room. It had returned into its\r\nnormal state of bag and covering. The windows were half open because of\r\nthe heat, and the Venetian blinds covered the glass,--so that a gray\r\ngrim light, reflected from the pavement below, threw all the shadows\r\nwrong, and combined with the green-tinged upper light to make even\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s own face, as she caught it in the mirrors, look ghastly and\r\nwan. She sat and waited; no one came. Every now and then, the wind\r\nseemed to bear the distant multitudinous sound nearer; and yet there was\r\nno wind! It died away into profound stillness between whiles.\r\n\r\nFanny came in at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma will come directly, Miss Hale. She desired me to apologise to you\r\nas it is. Perhaps you know my brother has imported hands from Ireland,\r\nand it has irritated the Milton people excessively--as if he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a\r\nright to get labour where he could; and the stupid wretches here\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t work for him; and now they\xe2\x80\x99ve frightened these poor Irish\r\nstarvelings so with their threats, that we daren\xe2\x80\x99t let them out. You may\r\nsee them huddled in that top room in the mill,--and they\xe2\x80\x99re to sleep\r\nthere, to keep them safe from those brutes, who will neither work or let\r\nthem work. And mamma is seeing about their food, and John is speaking to\r\nthem, for some of the women are crying to go back. Ah! here\xe2\x80\x99s mamma!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton came in with a look of black sternness on her face, which\r\nmade Margaret feel she had arrived at a bad time to trouble her with her\r\nrequest. However, it was only in compliance with Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexpressed desire, that she would ask for whatever they might want in the\r\nprogress of her mother\xe2\x80\x99s illness. Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s brow contracted, and\r\nher mouth grew set, while Margaret spoke with gentle modesty of her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s restlessness, and Dr. Donaldson\xe2\x80\x99s wish that she should have the\r\nrelief of a water-bed. She ceased. Mrs. Thornton did not reply\r\nimmediately. Then she started up and exclaimed--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re at the gates! Call John, Fanny,--call him in from the mill!\r\nThey\xe2\x80\x99re at the gates! They\xe2\x80\x99ll batter them in! Call John, I say!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd simultaneously, the gathering tramp--to which she had been\r\nlistening, instead of heeding Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s words--was heard just right\r\noutside the wall, and an increasing din of angry voices raged behind the\r\nwooden barrier, which shook as if the unseen maddened crowd made\r\nbattering rams of their bodies, and retreated a short space only to come\r\nwith more united steady impetus against it, till their great beats made\r\nthe strong gates quiver, like reeds before the wind.\r\n\r\nThe women gathered round the windows, fascinated to look on the scene\r\nwhich terrified them. Mrs. Thornton, the women-servants, Margaret,--all\r\nwere there. Fanny had returned, screaming upstairs as if pursued at\r\nevery step, and had thrown herself in hysterical sobbing on the sofa.\r\nMrs. Thornton watched for her son, who was still in the mill. He came\r\nout, looked up at them--the pale cluster of faces--and smiled good\r\ncourage to them, before he locked the factory door. Then he called to\r\none of the women to come down and undo his own door, which Fanny had\r\nfastened behind her in her mad flight. Mrs. Thornton herself went. And\r\nthe sound of his well-known and commanding voice, seemed to have been\r\nlike the taste of blood to the infuriated multitude outside. Hitherto\r\nthey had been voiceless, wordless, needing all their breath for their\r\nhard-laboured efforts to break down the gates. But now, hearing him\r\nspeak inside, they set up such a fierce, unearthly groan, that even Mrs.\r\nThornton was white with fear as she preceded him into the room. He came\r\nin a little flushed, but his eyes gleamed, as in answer to the\r\ntrumpet-call of danger, and with a proud look of defiance on his face,\r\nthat made him a noble, if not a handsome man. Margaret had always\r\ndreaded lest her courage should fail her in any emergency, and she\r\nshould be proved to be, what she dreaded lest she was--a coward. But\r\nnow, in this real great time of reasonable fear and nearness of terror,\r\nshe forgot herself, and felt only an intense sympathy--intense to\r\npainfulness--in the interests of the moment.\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton came frankly forwards:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry, Miss Hale, you have visited us at this unfortunate moment,\r\nwhen, I fear, you may be involved in whatever risk we have to bear.\r\nMother! hadn\xe2\x80\x99t you better go into the back rooms? I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure whether\r\nthey may not have made their way from Pinner\xe2\x80\x99s Lane into the\r\nstable-yard; but if not, you will be safer there than here. Go, Jane!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued he, addressing the upper-servant. And she went, followed by\r\nthe others.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI stop here!\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere you are, there I stay.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nindeed, retreat into the back rooms was of no avail; the crowd had\r\nsurrounded the outbuildings at the rear, and were sending forth their\r\nawful threatening roar behind. The servants retreated into the garrets,\r\nwith many a cry and shriek. Mr. Thornton smiled scornfully as he heard\r\nthem. He glanced at Margaret, standing all by herself at the window\r\nnearest the factory. Her eyes glittered, her colour was deepened on\r\ncheek and lip. As if she felt his look, she turned to him and asked a\r\nquestion that had been for some time in her mind:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are the poor imported workpeople? In the factory there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! I left them cowed up in a small room, at the head of a back flight\r\nof stairs; bidding them run all risks, and escape down there, if they\r\nheard any attack made on the mill doors. But it is not them--it is me\r\nthey want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen can the soldiers be here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked his mother, in a low but not\r\nunsteady voice.\r\n\r\nHe took out his watch with the same steady composure with which he did\r\neverything. He made some little calculation:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSupposing Williams got straight off when I told him, and hadn\xe2\x80\x99t to\r\ndodge about amongst them--it must be twenty minutes yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty minutes!\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother, for the first time showing her terror\r\nin the tones of her voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShut down the windows instantly, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed he: \xe2\x80\x9cthe gates\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t bear such another shock. Shut down that window, Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret shut down her window, and then went to assist Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntrembling fingers.\r\n\r\nFrom some cause or other, there was a pause of several minutes in the\r\nunseen street. Mrs. Thornton looked with wild anxiety at her son\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncountenance, as if to gain the interpretation of the sudden stillness\r\nfrom him. His face was set into rigid lines of contemptuous defiance;\r\nneither hope nor fear could be read there.\r\n\r\nFanny raised herself up:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre they gone?\xe2\x80\x9d asked she, in a whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone!\xe2\x80\x9d replied he. \xe2\x80\x9cListen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe did listen; they all could hear the one great straining breath; the\r\ncreak of wood slowly yielding; the wrench of iron; the mighty fall of\r\nthe ponderous gates. Fanny stood up tottering--made a step or two\r\ntowards her mother, and fell forwards into her arms in a fainting fit.\r\nMrs. Thornton lifted her up with a strength that was as much that of the\r\nwill as of the body, and carried her away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton, as he watched her out. \xe2\x80\x9cHad you not\r\nbetter go upstairs, Miss Hale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s lips formed a \xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d--but he could not hear her speak, for the\r\ntramp of innumerable steps right under the very wall of the house, and\r\nthe fierce growl of low deep angry voices that had a ferocious murmur of\r\nsatisfaction in them, more dreadful than their baffled cries not many\r\nminutes before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, thinking to encourage her. \xe2\x80\x9cI am very sorry that\r\nyou should have been entrapped into all this alarm; but it cannot last\r\nlong now; a few minutes more, and the soldiers will be here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Margaret, suddenly; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is Boucher. I know his face,\r\nthough he is livid with rage,--he is fighting to get to the front--look!\r\nlook!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is Boucher?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Thornton coolly, and coming close to the\r\nwindow to discover the man in whom Margaret took such an interest. As\r\nsoon as they saw Mr. Thornton, they set up a yell, to call it not human\r\nis nothing,--it was as the demoniac desire of some terrible wild beast\r\nfor the food that is withheld from his ravening. Even he drew back for a\r\nmoment, dismayed at the intensity of hatred he had provoked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet them yell!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cIn five minutes more--. I only hope my poor\r\nIrishmen are not terrified out of their wits by such a fiendlike noise.\r\nKeep up your courage for five minutes, Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid for me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said hastily. \xe2\x80\x9cBut what in five minutes?\r\nCan you do nothing to soothe these poor creatures? It is awful to see\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe soldiers will be here directly, and that will bring them to\r\nreason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo reason!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat kind of reason?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe only reason that does with men that make themselves into wild\r\nbeasts. By heaven! they\xe2\x80\x99ve turned to the mill-door!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, shaking all over with her passion, \xe2\x80\x9cgo\r\ndown this instant, if you are not a coward. Go down and face them like a\r\nman. Save these poor strangers, whom you have decoyed here. Speak to\r\nyour workmen as if they were human beings. Speak to them kindly. Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlet the soldiers come in and cut down poor creatures who are driven mad.\r\nI see one there who is. If you have any courage or noble quality in you,\r\ngo out and speak to them, man to man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned and looked at her while she spoke. A dark cloud came over his\r\nface while he listened. He set his teeth as he heard her words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go. Perhaps I may ask you to accompany me downstairs, and bar\r\nthe door behind me; my mother and sister will need that protection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! Mr. Thornton! I do not know--I may be wrong--only--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he was gone; he was downstairs in the hall; he had unbarred the\r\nfront door; all she could do, was to follow him quickly, and fasten it\r\nbehind him, and clamber up the stairs again with a sick heart and a\r\ndizzy head. Again she took her place by the farthest window. He was on\r\nthe steps below; she saw that by the direction of a thousand angry eyes;\r\nbut she could neither see nor hear anything save the savage satisfaction\r\nof the rolling angry murmur. See threw the window wide open. Many in the\r\ncrowd were mere boys; cruel and thoughtless,--cruel because they were\r\nthoughtless; some were men, gaunt as wolves, and mad for prey. She knew\r\nhow it was; they were like Boucher,--with starving children at\r\nhome--relying on ultimate success in their efforts to get higher wages,\r\nand enraged beyond measure at discovering that Irishmen were to be\r\nbrought in to rob their little ones of bread. Margaret knew it all; she\r\nread it in Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s face, forlornly desperate and livid with rage. If\r\nMr. Thornton would but say something to them--let them hear his voice\r\nonly--it seemed as if it would be better than this wild beating and\r\nraging against the stony silence that vouchsafed them no word, even of\r\nanger or reproach. But perhaps he was speaking now; there was a\r\nmomentary hush of their noise, inarticulate as that of a troop of\r\nanimals. She tore her bonnet off, and bent forward to hear. She could\r\nonly see; for if Mr. Thornton had indeed made the attempt to speak, the\r\nmomentary instinct to listen to him was past and gone, and the people\r\nwere raging worse than ever. He stood with his arms folded; still as a\r\nstatue; his face pale with repressed excitement. They were trying to\r\nintimidate him--to make him flinch; each was urging the other on to some\r\nimmediate act of personal violence. Margaret felt intuitively, that in\r\nan instant all would be uproar; the first touch would cause an\r\nexplosion, in which, among such hundreds of infuriated men and reckless\r\nboys, even Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s life would be unsafe,--that in another instant\r\nthe stormy passions would have passed their bounds, and swept away all\r\nbarriers of reason, or apprehension of consequence. Even while she\r\nlooked, she saw lads in the background stooping to take off their heavy\r\nwooden clogs--the readiest missile they could find; she saw it was the\r\nspark to the gunpowder, and, with a cry, which no one heard, she rushed\r\nout of the room, down stairs,--she had lifted the great iron bar of the\r\ndoor with an imperious force--had thrown the door open wide--and was\r\nthere, in face of that angry sea of men, her eyes smiting them with\r\nflaming arrows of reproach. The clogs were arrested in the hands that\r\nheld them--the countenances, so fell not a moment before, now looked\r\nirresolute, and as if asking what this meant. For she stood between them\r\nand their enemy. She could not speak, but held out her arms towards them\r\ntill she could recover breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do not use violence! He is one man, and you are many;\xe2\x80\x9d but her\r\nwords died away, for there was no tone in her voice; it was but a hoarse\r\nwhisper. Mr. Thornton stood a little on one side; he had moved away from\r\nbehind her, as if jealous of anything that should come between him and\r\ndanger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, once more (and now her voice was like a cry). \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nsoldiers are sent for--are coming. Go peaceably. Go away. You shall have\r\nrelief from your complaints, whatever they are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall them Irish blackguards be packed back again?\xe2\x80\x9d asked one from out\r\nthe crowd, with fierce threatening in his voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever, for your bidding!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Thornton. And instantly the\r\nstorm broke. The hootings rose and filled the air,--but Margaret did not\r\nhear them. Her eye was on the group of lads who had armed themselves\r\nwith their clogs some time before. She saw their gesture--she knew its\r\nmeaning--she read their aim. Another moment, and Mr. Thornton might be\r\nsmitten down,--he whom she had urged and goaded to come to this\r\nperilous place. She only thought how she could save him. She threw her\r\narms around him; she made her body into a shield from the fierce people\r\nbeyond. Still, with his arms folded, he shook her off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo away,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in his deep voice. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is no place for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cYou did not see what I saw.\xe2\x80\x9d If she thought her sex\r\nwould be a protection,--if, with shrinking eyes she had turned away from\r\nthe terrible anger of these men, in any hope that ere she looked again\r\nthey would have paused and reflected, and slunk away, and vanished,--she\r\nwas wrong. Their reckless passion had carried them too far to stop--at\r\nleast had carried some of them too far; for it is always the savage\r\nlads, with their love of cruel excitement, who head the riot--reckless\r\nto what bloodshed it may lead. A clog whizzed through the air.\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s fascinated eyes watched its progress; it missed its aim, and\r\nshe turned sick with affright, but changed not her position, only hid\r\nher face on Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s arm. Then she turned and spoke again:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake! do not damage your cause by this violence. You do not\r\nknow what you are doing.\xe2\x80\x9d She strove to make her words distinct.\r\n\r\nA sharp pebble flew by her, grazing forehead and cheek, and drawing a\r\nblinding sheet of light before her eyes. She lay like one dead on Mr.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder. Then he unfolded his arms, and held her encircled\r\nin one for an instant:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do well!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cYou come to oust the innocent stranger. You\r\nfall--you hundreds--on one man; and when a woman comes before you, to\r\nask you for your own sakes to be reasonable creatures, your cowardly\r\nwrath falls upon her! You do well!\xe2\x80\x9d They were silent while he spoke.\r\nThey were watching, open-eyed and open-mouthed, the thread of dark-red\r\nblood which wakened them up from their trance of passion. Those nearest\r\nthe gate stole out ashamed; there was a movement through all the\r\ncrowd--a retreating movement. Only one voice called out:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTh\xe2\x80\x99 stone was meant for thee; but thou wert sheltered behind a woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton quivered with rage. The blood-flowing had made Margaret\r\nconscious--dimly, vaguely conscious. He placed her gently on the\r\ndoor-step, her head leaning against the frame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you rest there?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. But without waiting for her answer, he\r\nwent slowly down the steps right into the middle of the crowd. \xe2\x80\x9cNow kill\r\nme, if it is your brutal will. There is no woman to shield me here. You\r\nmay beat me to death--you will never move me from what I have determined\r\nupon--not you!\xe2\x80\x9d He stood amongst them with his arms folded, in precisely\r\nthe same attitude as he had been in on the steps.\r\n\r\nBut the retrograde movement towards the gate had begun--as\r\nunreasoningly, perhaps as blindly, as the simultaneous anger. Or,\r\nperhaps, the idea of the approach of the soldiers, and the sight of that\r\npale, upturned face, with closed eyes, still and sad as marble, though\r\nthe tears welled out of the long entanglement of eyelashes, and dropped\r\ndown; and, heavier, slower plash than even tears, came the drip of blood\r\nfrom her wound. Even the most desperate--Boucher himself--drew back,\r\nfaltered away, scowled, and finally went off, muttering curses on the\r\nmaster, who stood in his unchanging attitude, looking after their\r\nretreat with defiant eyes. The moment that retreat had changed into a\r\nflight (as it was sure from its very character to do), he darted up the\r\nsteps to Margaret.\r\n\r\nShe tried to rise without his help.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a sickly smile. \xe2\x80\x9cThe skin is grazed, and\r\nI was stunned at the moment. Oh, I am so thankful they are gone!\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nshe cried without restraint.\r\n\r\nHe could not sympathise with her. His anger had not abated; it was\r\nrising the more as his sense of immediate danger was passing away. The\r\ndistant clank of the soldiers was heard: just five minutes too late to\r\nmake this vanished mob feel the power of authority and order. He hoped\r\nthey would see the troops, and be quelled by the thought of their narrow\r\nescape. While these thoughts crossed his mind, Margaret clung to the\r\ndoorpost to steady herself: but a film came over her eyes--he was only\r\njust in time to catch her. \xe2\x80\x9cMother--mother!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he; \xe2\x80\x9cCome down--they\r\nare gone, and Miss Hale is hurt!\xe2\x80\x9d He bore her into the dining-room, and\r\nlaid her on the sofa there; laid her down softly, and looking on her\r\npure white face, the sense of what she was to him came upon him so\r\nkeenly that he spoke it out in his pain:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my Margaret--my Margaret! no one can tell what you are to me!\r\nDead--cold as you lie there, you are the only woman I ever loved! Oh,\r\nMargaret--Margaret!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nInarticulately as he spoke, kneeling by her, and rather moaning than\r\nsaying the words, he started up, ashamed of himself, as his mother came\r\nin. She saw nothing, but her son a little paler, a little sterner than\r\nusual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Hale is hurt, mother. A stone has grazed her temple. She has lost\r\na good deal of blood, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe looks very seriously hurt,--I could almost fancy her dead,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMrs. Thornton, a good deal alarmed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is only a fainting-fit. She has spoken to me since.\xe2\x80\x9d But all the\r\nblood in his body seemed to rush inwards to his heart as he spoke, and\r\nhe absolutely trembled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo and call Jane,--she can find me the things I want; and do you go to\r\nyour Irish people, who are crying and shouting as if they were mad with\r\nfright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went. He went away as if weights were tied to every limb that bore\r\nhim from her. He called Jane; he called his sister. She should have all\r\nwomanly care, all gentle tendance. But every pulse beat in him as he\r\nremembered how she had come down and placed herself in foremost\r\ndanger--could it be to save him? At the time, he had pushed her aside,\r\nand spoken gruffly; he had seen nothing but the unnecessary danger she\r\nhad placed herself in. He went to his Irish people, with every nerve in\r\nhis body thrilling at the thought of her, and found it difficult to\r\nunderstand enough of what they were saying to soothe and comfort away\r\ntheir fears. There, they declared, they would not stop; they claimed to\r\nbe sent back.\r\n\r\nAnd so he had to think, and talk, and reason.\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton bathed Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s temples with eau de Cologne. As the\r\nspirit touched the wound, which till then neither Mrs. Thornton nor Jane\r\nhad perceived, Margaret opened her eyes; but it was evident she did not\r\nknow where she was, nor who they were. The dark circles deepened, the\r\nlips quivered and contracted, and she became insensible once more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has had a terrible blow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton. \xe2\x80\x9cIs there any one who\r\nwill go for a doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot me, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, if you please,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jane, shrinking back. \xe2\x80\x9cThem rabble\r\nmay be all about; I don\xe2\x80\x99t think the cut is so deep, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, as it looks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not run the chance. She was hurt in our house. If you are a\r\ncoward, Jane, I am not. I will go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, let me send one of the police. There\xe2\x80\x99s ever so many come\r\nup, and soldiers too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet you\xe2\x80\x99re afraid to go! I will not have their time taken up with\r\nour errands. They\xe2\x80\x99ll have enough to do to catch some of the mob. You\r\nwill not be afraid to stop in this house,\xe2\x80\x9d she asked contemptuously,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand go on bathing Miss Hale\xe2\x80\x99s forehead, shall you? I shall not be ten\r\nminutes away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t Hannah go, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy Hannah? Why any but you? No, Jane, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t go, I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton went first to the room in which she had left Fanny\r\nstretched on the bed. She started up as her mother entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mamma, how you terrified me! I thought you were a man that had got\r\ninto the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense! The men are all gone away. There are soldiers all round the\r\nplace, seeking for their work now it is too late. Miss Hale is lying on\r\nthe dining-room sofa badly hurt. I am going for the doctor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! don\xe2\x80\x99t, mamma! they\xe2\x80\x99ll murder you.\xe2\x80\x9d She clung to her mother\xe2\x80\x99s gown.\r\nMrs. Thornton wrenched it away with no gentle hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFind me some one else to go; but that girl must not bleed to death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBleed! oh, how horrid! How has she got hurt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,--I have no time to ask. Go down to her, Fanny, and do try\r\nto make yourself of use. Jane is with her; and I trust it looks worse\r\nthan it is. Jane has refused to leave the house, cowardly woman! And I\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t put myself in the way of any more refusals from my servants, so I\r\nam going myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, crying, and preparing to go down rather\r\nthan be left alone, with the thought of wounds and bloodshed in the very\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Jane!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, creeping into the dining-room, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the\r\nmatter? How white she looks! How did she get hurt? Did they throw stones\r\ninto the drawing-room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret did indeed look white and wan, although her senses were\r\nbeginning to return to her. But the sickly daze of the swoon made her\r\nstill miserably faint. She was conscious of movement around her, and of\r\nrefreshment from the eau de Cologne, and a craving for the bathing to go\r\non without intermission; but when they stopped to talk, she could no\r\nmore have opened her eyes, or spoken to ask for more bathing, than the\r\npeople who lie in death-like trance can move, or utter sound, to arrest\r\nthe awful preparations for their burial, while they are yet fully aware,\r\nnot merely of the actions of those around them, but of the idea that is\r\nthe motive for such actions.\r\n\r\nJane paused in her bathing, to reply to Miss Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99d have been safe enough, miss, if she\xe2\x80\x99d stayed in the drawing-room,\r\nor come up to us; we were in the front garret, and could see it all, out\r\nof harm\xe2\x80\x99s way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere was she then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, drawing nearer by slow degrees, as she\r\nbecame accustomed to the sight of Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s pale face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust before the front door--with master!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jane, significantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith John! with my brother! How did she get there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, miss, that\xe2\x80\x99s not for me to say,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Jane, with a slight toss\r\nof her head. \xe2\x80\x9cSarah did----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSarah what?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, with impatient curiosity.\r\n\r\nJane resumed her bathing, as if what Sarah did or said was not exactly\r\nthe thing she liked to repeat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSarah what?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Fanny, sharply. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t speak in these half\r\nsentences, or I can\xe2\x80\x99t understand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, miss, since you will have it--Sarah, you see, was in the best\r\nplace for seeing, being at the right-hand window; and she says, and said\r\nat the very time too, that she saw Miss Hale with her arms about\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s neck, hugging him before all the people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny. \xe2\x80\x9cI know she cares for my brother; any\r\none can see that; and I dare say, she\xe2\x80\x99d give her eyes if he\xe2\x80\x99d marry\r\nher,--which he never will, I can tell her. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe she\xe2\x80\x99d be\r\nso bold and forward as to put her arms round his neck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor young lady! she\xe2\x80\x99s paid for it dearly if she did. It\xe2\x80\x99s my belief,\r\nthat the blow has given her such an ascendancy of blood to the head as\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99ll never get the better from. She looks like a corpse now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I wish mamma would come!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny, wringing her hands. \xe2\x80\x9cI never\r\nwas in the room with a dead person before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, miss! She\xe2\x80\x99s not dead: her eye-lids are quivering, and here\xe2\x80\x99s wet\r\ntears a-coming down her cheeks. Speak to her, Miss Fanny!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you better now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Fanny, in a quavering voice.\r\n\r\nNo answer; no sign of recognition; but a faint pink colour returned to\r\nher lips, although the rest of her face was ashen pale.\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton came hurriedly in, with the nearest surgeon she could\r\nfind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is she? Are you better, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d as Margaret opened her filmy\r\neyes, and gazed dreamily at her. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is Mr. Lowe come to see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton spoke loudly and distinctly, as to a deaf person. Margaret\r\ntried to rise, and drew her ruffled, luxuriant hair instinctively over\r\nthe cut.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am better now,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, in a very low, faint voice. \xe2\x80\x9cI was a little\r\nsick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe let him take her hand and feel her pulse. The bright colour came for\r\na moment into her face, when he asked to examine the wound in her\r\nforehead; and she glanced up at Jane, as if shrinking from her\r\ninspection more than from the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not much, I think. I am better now. I must go home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot until I have applied some strips of plaster, and you have rested a\r\nlittle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe sat down hastily, without another word, and allowed it to be bound\r\nup.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, if you please,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI must go. Mamma will not see it, I\r\nthink. It is under the hair, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite; no one could tell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you must not go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton, impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are not fit\r\nto go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, decidedly. \xe2\x80\x9cThink of mamma. If they should\r\nhear---- Besides, I must go,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, vehemently. \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot stay here.\r\nMay I ask for a cab?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are quite flushed and feverish,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Mr. Lowe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is only with being here, when I do so want to go. The air--getting\r\naway, would do me more good than anything,\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI really believe it is as she says,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Lowe replied. \xe2\x80\x9cIf her mother\r\nis so ill as you told me on the way here, it may be very serious if she\r\nhears of this riot, and does not see her daughter back at the time she\r\nexpects. The injury is not deep. I will fetch a cab, if your servants\r\nare still afraid to go out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, thank you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will do me more good than anything.\r\nIt is the air of this room that makes me feel so miserable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe leant back on the sofa, and closed her eyes. Fanny beckoned her\r\nmother out of the room, and told her something that made her equally\r\nanxious with Margaret for the departure of the latter. Not that she\r\nfully believed Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s statement; but she credited enough to make her\r\nmanner to Margaret appear very much constrained, at wishing her\r\ngood-bye.\r\n\r\nMr. Lowe returned in the cab.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you will allow me, I will see you home, Miss Hale. The streets are\r\nnot very quiet yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts were quite alive enough to the present to make her\r\ndesirous of getting rid of both Mr. Lowe and the cab before she reached\r\nCrampton Crescent, for fear of alarming her father and mother. Beyond\r\nthat one aim she would not look. That ugly dream of insolent words\r\nspoken about herself, could never be forgotten--but could be put aside\r\ntill she was stronger--for, oh! she was very weak; and her mind sought\r\nfor some present fact to steady itself upon, and keep it from utterly\r\nlosing consciousness in another hideous, sickly swoon.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIII.\r\n\r\nMISTAKES.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cWhich when his mother saw, she in her mind\r\n    Was troubled sore, he wist well what to ween.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              SPENSER.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret had not been gone five minutes when Mr. Thornton came in, his\r\nface all a-glow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could not come sooner: the superintendent would---- Where is she?\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nlooked round the dining-room, and then almost fiercely at his mother,\r\nwho was quietly re-arranging the disturbed furniture, and did not\r\ninstantly reply. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Miss Hale?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone home,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, rather shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone home!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. She was a great deal better. Indeed, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it was so\r\nvery much of a hurt; only some people faint at the least thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry she has gone home,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, walking uneasily about. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\r\ncould not have been fit for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe said she was; and Mr. Lowe said she was. I went for him myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, mother.\xe2\x80\x9d He stopped, and partly held out his hand to give\r\nher a grateful shake. But she did not notice the movement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you done with your Irish people?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSent to the Dragon, for a good meal for them, poor wretches. And then,\r\nluckily, I caught Father Grady, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve asked him in to speak to them,\r\nand dissuade them from going off in a body. How did Miss Hale go home?\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m sure she could not walk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe had a cab. Everything was done properly, even to the paying. Let us\r\ntalk of something else. She has caused disturbance enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know where I should have been but for her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you become so helpless as to have to be defended by a girl?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nMrs. Thornton scornfully.\r\n\r\nHe reddened. \xe2\x80\x9cNot many girls would have taken the blows on herself\r\nwhich were meant for me;--meant with right down goodwill, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA girl in love will do a good deal,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mrs. Thornton, shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother!\xe2\x80\x9d He made a step forwards; stood still; heaved with passion.\r\n\r\nShe was a little startled at the evident force he used to keep himself\r\ncalm. She was not sure of the nature of the emotions she had provoked.\r\nIt was only their violence that was clear. Was it anger? His eyes\r\nglowed, his figure was dilated, his breath came thick and fast. It was a\r\nmixture of joy, of anger, of pride, of glad surprise, of panting doubt;\r\nbut she could not read it. Still it made her uneasy,--as the presence of\r\nall strong feeling, of which the cause is not fully understood or\r\nsympathised in, always has this effect. She went to the side-board,\r\nopened a drawer, and took out a duster, which she kept there for any\r\noccasional purpose. She had seen a drop of eau de Cologne on the\r\npolished arm of the sofa, and instinctively sought to wipe it off. But\r\nshe kept her back turned to her son much longer than was necessary; and\r\nwhen she spoke, her voice seemed unusual and constrained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have taken some steps about the rioters, I suppose? You don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\napprehend anymore violence, do you? Where were the police? Never at hand\r\nwhen they\xe2\x80\x99re wanted!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, I saw three or four of them, when the gates gave way,\r\nstruggling and beating about in fine fashion; and more came running up\r\njust when the yard was clearing.
