I might have given some of the fellows\r\nin charge then, if I had had my wits about me. But there will be no\r\ndifficulty, plenty of people can identify them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut won\xe2\x80\x99t they come back to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to see about a sufficient guard for the premises. I have\r\nappointed to meet Captain Hanbury in half an hour at the station.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must have some tea first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTea! Yes, I suppose I must. It\xe2\x80\x99s half-past six, and I may be out for\r\nsome time. Don\xe2\x80\x99t sit up for me, mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou expect me to go to bed before I have seen you safe, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, perhaps not.\xe2\x80\x9d He hesitated for a moment. \xe2\x80\x9cBut if I\xe2\x80\x99ve time, I\r\nshall go round by Crampton, after I\xe2\x80\x99ve arranged with the police and seen\r\nHamper and Clarkson.\xe2\x80\x9d Their eyes met; they looked at each other intently\r\nfor a minute. Then she asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you going round by Crampton?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo ask after Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will send. Williams must take the water-bed she came to ask for. He\r\nshall inquire how she is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must go myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot merely to ask how Miss Hale is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not merely for that. I want to thank her for the way in which she\r\nstood between me and the mob.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat made you go down at all? It was putting your head into the lion\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmouth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe glanced sharply at her; saw that she did not know what had passed\r\nbetween him and Margaret in the drawing-room: and replied by another\r\nquestion:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you be afraid to be left without me, until I can get some of the\r\npolice; or had we better send Williams for them now, and they could be\r\nhere by the time we have done tea? There\xe2\x80\x99s no time to be lost. I must be\r\noff in a quarter of an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton left the room. Her servants wondered at her directions,\r\nusually so sharply-cut and decided, now confused and uncertain. Mr.\r\nThornton remained in the dining-room, trying to think of the business he\r\nhad to do at the police-office, and in reality thinking of Margaret.\r\nEverything seemed dim and vague beyond--behind--besides the touch of her\r\narms round his neck--the soft clinging which made the dark colour come\r\nand go in his cheek as he thought of it.\r\n\r\nThe tea would have been very silent, but for Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s perpetual\r\ndescription of her own feelings; how she had been alarmed--and then\r\nthought they were gone--and then felt sick and faint and trembling in\r\nevery limb.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, that\xe2\x80\x99s enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said her brother, rising from the table. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nreality was enough for me.\xe2\x80\x9d He was going to leave the room, when his\r\nmother stopped him with her hand upon his arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will come back here before you go to the Hales\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, in a\r\nlow, anxious voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know what I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fanny to herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? Will it be too late to disturb them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn, come back to me for this one evening. It will be late for Mrs.\r\nHale. But that is not it. To-morrow, you will---- Come back to-night,\r\nJohn!\xe2\x80\x9d She had seldom pleaded with her son at all--she was too proud for\r\nthat; but she had never pleaded in vain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will return straight here after I have done my business. You will be\r\nsure to enquire after them?--after her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton was by no means a talkative companion to Fanny, nor yet a\r\ngood listener while her son was absent. But on his return, her eyes and\r\nears were keen to see and to listen to all the details which he could\r\ngive, as to the steps he had taken to secure himself, and those whom he\r\nchose to employ, from any repetition of the day\xe2\x80\x99s outrages. He clearly\r\nsaw his object. Punishment and suffering, were the natural consequences\r\nto those who had taken part in the riot. All that was necessary, in\r\norder that property should be protected, and that the will of the\r\nproprietor might cut to his end, clean and sharp as a sword.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother! You know what I have got to say to Miss Hale, to-morrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe question came upon her suddenly, during a pause in which she, at\r\nleast, had forgotten Margaret.\r\n\r\nShe looked up at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! I do. You can hardly do otherwise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo otherwise! I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that, after allowing her feelings so to overcome her, I consider\r\nyou bound in honour--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBound in honour,\xe2\x80\x9d said he scornfully. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid honour has nothing to\r\ndo with it. \xe2\x80\x98Her feelings overcome her!\xe2\x80\x99 What feelings do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, John, there is no need to be angry. Did she not rush down and\r\ncling to you to save you from danger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe did!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, stopping short in his\r\nwalk right in front of her. \xe2\x80\x9cI dare not hope. I never was faint-hearted\r\nbefore; but I cannot believe such a creature cares for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be foolish, John. Such a creature! Why, she might be a duke\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndaughter, to hear you speak. And what proof more would you have, I\r\nwonder, of her caring for you? I can believe she has had a struggle with\r\nher aristocratic way of viewing things; but I like her the better for\r\nseeing clearly at last. It is a good deal for me to say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nThornton, smiling slowly, while the tears stood in her eyes; \xe2\x80\x9cfor after\r\nto-night, I stand second. It was to have you to myself, all to myself, a\r\nfew hours longer, that I begged you not to go till to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDearest mother!\xe2\x80\x9d (Still love is selfish, and in an instant he reverted\r\nto his own hopes and fears in a way that drew the cold creeping shadow\r\nover Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s heart.) \xe2\x80\x9cBut I know she does not care for me. I\r\nshall put myself at her feet--I must. If it were but one chance in a\r\nthousand--or a million--I should do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t fear!\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother, crushing down her own personal\r\nmortification at the little notice he had taken of the rare ebullition\r\nof her maternal feelings--of the pang of jealousy that betrayed the\r\nintensity of her disregarded love. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, coldly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs far as love may go she may be worthy of you. It must have taken a\r\ngood deal to overcome her pride. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid, John,\xe2\x80\x9d said she,\r\nkissing him, as she wished him good-night. And she went slowly and\r\nmajestically out of the room. But when she got into her own, she locked\r\nthe door, and sate down to cry unwonted tears.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMargaret entered the room (where her father and mother still sat,\r\nholding low conversation together), looking very pale and white. She\r\ncame close up to them before she could trust herself to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Thornton will send the water-bed, mamma.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear, how tired you look! Is it very hot, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery hot, and the streets are rather rough with the strike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s colour came back vivid and bright as ever; but it faded away\r\ninstantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere has been a message from Bessy Higgins, asking you to go to her,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mrs. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you look too tired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cI am tired, I cannot go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was very silent and trembling while she made tea. She was thankful\r\nto see her father so much occupied with her mother as not to notice her\r\nlooks. Even after her mother went to bed, he was not content to be\r\nabsent from her, but undertook to read her to sleep. Margaret was alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I will think of it--now I will remember it all. I could not\r\nbefore--I dared not.\xe2\x80\x9d She sat still in her chair, her hands clasped on\r\nher knees, her lips compressed, her eyes fixed as one who sees a vision.\r\nShe drew a deep breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, who hate scenes--I, who have despised people for showing\r\nemotion--who have thought them wanting in self-control--I went down and\r\nmust needs throw myself into the mel\xc3\xa9e, like a romantic fool! Did I do\r\nany good? They would have gone away without me, I dare say.\xe2\x80\x9d But this\r\nwas overleaping the rational conclusion,--as in an instant her\r\nwell-poised judgment felt. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, perhaps they would not. I did some good.\r\nBut what possessed me to defend that man as if he were a helpless child!\r\nAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, clenching her hands together, \xe2\x80\x9cit is no wonder those\r\npeople thought I was in love with him, after disgracing myself in that\r\nway. I in love--and with him too!\xe2\x80\x9d Her pale cheeks suddenly became one\r\nflame of fire; and she covered her face with her hands. When she took\r\nthem away, her palms were wet with scalding tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh how low I am fallen that they should say that of me! I could not\r\nhave been so brave for any one else, just because he was so utterly\r\nindifferent to me--if, indeed, I do not positively dislike him. It made\r\nme the more anxious that there should be fair play on each side; and I\r\ncould see what fair play was. It was not fair,\xe2\x80\x9d said she vehemently,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat he should stand there--sheltered, awaiting the soldiers, who might\r\ncatch those poor maddened creatures as in a trap--without an effort on\r\nhis part, to bring them to reason. And it was worse than unfair for them\r\nto set on him as they threatened. I would do it again, let who will say\r\nwhat they like of me. If I saved one blow, one cruel, angry action that\r\nmight otherwise have been committed, I did a woman\xe2\x80\x99s work. Let them\r\ninsult my maiden pride as they will--I walk pure before God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked up, and a noble peace seemed to descend and calm her face,\r\ntill it was \xe2\x80\x9cstiller than chiselled marble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDixon came in:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, Miss Margaret, here\xe2\x80\x99s the water-bed from Mrs.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s. It\xe2\x80\x99s too late for to-night, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, for missus is nearly\r\nasleep: but it will do nicely for to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must send our best thanks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDixon left the room for a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, Miss Margaret, he says he\xe2\x80\x99s to ask particular how you\r\nare. I think he must mean missus; but he says his last words were, to\r\nask how Miss Hale was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, drawing herself up. \xe2\x80\x9cI am quite well. Tell him I am\r\nperfectly well.\xe2\x80\x9d But her complexion was as deadly white as her\r\nhandkerchief; and her head ached intensely.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale now came in. He had left his sleeping wife; and wanted, as\r\nMargaret saw, to be amused and interested by something that she was to\r\ntell him. With sweet patience did she bear her pain, without a word of\r\ncomplaint; and rummaged up numberless small subjects for\r\nconversation--all except the riot, and that she never named once. It\r\nturned her sick to think of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night, Margaret. I have every chance of a good night myself, and\r\nyou are looking very pale with your watching. I shall call Dixon if your\r\nmother needs anything. Do you go to bed and sleep like a top; for I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsure you need it, poor child!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night, papa!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe let her colour go--the false smile fade away--the eyes grow dull\r\nwith heavy pain. She released her strong will from its laborious task.\r\nTill morning she might feel ill and weary.\r\n\r\nShe lay down and never stirred. To move hand or foot, or even so much as\r\none finger, would have been beyond the powers of either volition or\r\nmotion. She was so tired, so stunned, that she thought she never slept\r\nat all; her feverish thoughts passed and repassed the boundary between\r\nsleeping and waking, and kept their own miserable identity. She could\r\nnot be alone, prostrate, powerless as she was,--a cloud of faces looked\r\nup at her, giving her no idea of fierce vivid anger, or of personal\r\ndanger, but a deep sense of shame that she should thus be the object of\r\nuniversal regard--a sense of shame so acute that it seemed as if she\r\nwould fain have burrowed into the earth to hide herself, and yet she\r\ncould not escape out of that unwinking glare of many eyes.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIV.\r\n\r\nMISTAKES CLEARED UP.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYour beauty was the first that won the place\r\n    And scal\xe2\x80\x99d the walls of my undaunted heart,\r\n      Which, captive now, pines in a caitive case,\r\n    Unkindly met with rigour for desert:--\r\n      Yet not the less your servant shall abide,\r\n      In spite of rude repulse or silent pride.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              WILLIAM FOWLER.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next morning, Margaret dragged herself up, thankful that the night\r\nwas over,--unrefreshed, yet rested. All had gone well through the house;\r\nher mother had only wakened once. A little breeze was stirring in the\r\nhot air, and though there were no trees to show the playful tossing\r\nmovement caused by the wind among the leaves, Margaret knew how,\r\nsomewhere or another, by wayside, in copses, or in thick green woods,\r\nthere was a pleasant, murmuring dancing sound,--a rushing and falling\r\nnoise, the very thought of which was an echo of distinct gladness in her\r\nheart.\r\n\r\nShe sat at her work in Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s room. As soon as that forenoon\r\nslumber was over, she would help her mother to dress; after dinner, she\r\nwould go and see Bessy Higgins. She would banish all recollection of the\r\nThornton family--no need to think of them till they absolutely stood\r\nbefore her in flesh and blood. But, of course, the effort not to think\r\nof them brought them only the more strongly before her; and from time to\r\ntime, the hot flush came over her pale face sweeping it into colour, as\r\na sunbeam from between watery clouds comes swiftly moving over the sea.\r\n\r\nDixon opened the door very softly, and stole on tiptoe up to Margaret,\r\nsitting by the shaded window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton, Miss Margaret. He is in the drawing-room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret dropped her sewing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he ask for me? Isn\xe2\x80\x99t papa come in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe asked for you, miss; and master is out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, I will come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, quietly. But she lingered\r\nstrangely.\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton stood by one of the windows, with his back to the door\r\napparently absorbed in watching something in the street. But, in truth,\r\nhe was afraid of himself. His heart beat thick at the thought of her\r\ncoming. He could not forget the touch of her arms around his neck,\r\nimpatiently felt as it had been at the time; but now the recollection of\r\nher clinging defence of him, seemed to thrill him through and\r\nthrough,--to melt away every resolution, all power of self-control, as\r\nif it were wax before a fire. He dreaded lest he should go forwards to\r\nmeet her, with his arms held out in mute entreaty that she would come\r\nand nestle there, as she had done, all unheeded, the day before, but\r\nnever unheeded again. His heart throbbed loud and quick. Strong man as\r\nhe was, he trembled at the anticipation of what he had to say, and how\r\nit might be received. She might droop, and flush, and flutter to his\r\narms, as to her natural home and resting-place. One moment he glowed\r\nwith impatience at the thought that she might do this,--the next he\r\nfeared a passionate rejection, the idea of which withered up his future\r\nwith so deadly a blight that he refused to think of it. He was startled\r\nby the sense of the presence of some one else in the room. He turned\r\nround. She had come in so gently, that he had never heard her; the\r\nstreet noises had been more distinct to his inattentive ear than her\r\nslow movements, in her soft muslin gown.\r\n\r\nShe stood by the table, not offering to sit down. Her eyelids were\r\ndropped half over her eyes; her teeth were shut, not compressed; her\r\nlips were just parted over them, allowing the white line to be seen\r\nbetween their curve. Her slow deep breathings dilated her chin and\r\nbeautiful nostrils; it was the only motion visible on her countenance.\r\nThe fine-grained skin, the oval cheek, the rich outline of her mouth,\r\nits corners deep set in dimples,--were all wan and pale to-day; the loss\r\nof their usual natural healthy colour being made more evident by the\r\nheavy shadow of the dark hair, brought down upon her temples, to hide\r\nall sign of the blow she had received. Her head, for all its drooping\r\neyes, was thrown a little back, in the old proud attitude. Her long arms\r\nhung motionless by her sides. Altogether she looked like some prisoner,\r\nfalsely accused of a crime that she loathed and despised, and from which\r\nshe was too indignant to justify herself.\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton made a hasty step or two forwards; recovered himself, and\r\nwent with quiet firmness to the door (which she had left open), and shut\r\nit. Then he came back, and stood opposite to her for a moment, receiving\r\nthe general impression of her beautiful presence, before he dared to\r\ndisturb it, perhaps to repel it, by what he had to say.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Hale, I was very ungrateful yesterday--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had nothing to be grateful for,\xe2\x80\x9d said she raising her eyes, and\r\nlooking full and straight at him. \xe2\x80\x9cYou mean, I suppose, that you believe\r\nyou ought to thank me for what I did.\xe2\x80\x9d In spite of herself--in defiance\r\nof her anger--the thick blushes came all over her face, and burnt into\r\nher very eyes; which fell not nevertheless from their grave and steady\r\nlook. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was only a natural instinct; any woman would have done just\r\nthe same. We all feel the sanctity of our sex as a high privilege when\r\nwe see danger. I ought rather,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, hastily, \xe2\x80\x9cto apologise to you,\r\nfor having said thoughtless words which sent you down into the danger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not your words; it was the truth they conveyed, pungently as it\r\nwas expressed. But you shall not drive me off upon that, and so escape\r\nthe expression of my deep gratitude, my--\xe2\x80\x9d he was on the verge now; he\r\nwould not speak in the haste of his hot passion; he would weigh each\r\nword. He would; and his will was triumphant. He stopped in mid career.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not try to escape from anything,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI simply say, that\r\nyou owe me no gratitude; and I may add, that any expression of it will\r\nbe painful to me, because I do not feel that I deserve it. Still, if it\r\nwill relieve you from even a fancied obligation, speak on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not want to be relieved from any obligation,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, goaded by\r\nher calm manner. \xe2\x80\x9cFancied, or not fancied--I question not myself to know\r\nwhich--I choose to believe that I owe my very life to you--ay--smile,\r\nand think it an exaggeration if you will. I believe it, because it adds\r\na value to that life to think--oh, Miss Hale!\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, lowering\r\nhis voice to such a tender intensity of passion that she shivered and\r\ntrembled before him, \xe2\x80\x9cto think circumstances so wrought, that whenever I\r\nexult in existence henceforward, I may say to myself, \xe2\x80\x98All this gladness\r\nin life, all honest pride in doing my work in the world, all this keen\r\nsense of being, I owe to her!\xe2\x80\x99 And it doubles the gladness, it makes the\r\npride glow, it sharpens the sense of existence till I hardly know if it\r\nis pain or pleasure to think that I owe it to one--nay, you must, you\r\nshall hear,\xe2\x80\x9d--said he, stepping forward with stern determination--\xe2\x80\x9cto\r\none whom I love, as I do not believe man ever loved woman before.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nheld her hand tight in his. He panted as he listened for what should\r\ncome. He threw the hand away with indignation, as he heard her icy\r\ntone; for icy it was, though the words came faltering out, as if she\r\nknew not where to find them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour way of speaking shocks me. It is blasphemous. I cannot help it, if\r\nthat is my first feeling. It might not be so, I dare say, if I\r\nunderstood the kind of feeling you describe. I do not want to vex you;\r\nand besides, we must speak gently, for mamma is asleep; but your whole\r\nmanner offends me--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed he. \xe2\x80\x9cOffends you! I am indeed most unfortunate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d said she with recovered dignity. \xe2\x80\x9cI do feel offended; and, I\r\nthink, justly. You seem to fancy that my conduct of yesterday\xe2\x80\x9d--again\r\nthe deep carnation blush, but this time with eyes kindling with\r\nindignation rather than shame--\xe2\x80\x9cwas a personal act between you and me;\r\nand that you may come and thank me for it, instead of perceiving, as a\r\ngentleman would--yes! a gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated, in allusion to their\r\nformer conversation about that word, \xe2\x80\x9cthat any woman, worthy of the name\r\nof woman, would come forward to shield, with her reverenced\r\nhelplessness, a man in danger from the violence of numbers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the gentleman thus rescued is forbidden the relief of thanks!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nbroke in contemptuously. \xe2\x80\x9cI am a man. I claim the right of expressing my\r\nfeelings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I yielded to the right; simply saying that you gave me pain by\r\ninsisting upon it,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, proudly. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you seem to have\r\nimagined, that I was not merely guided by womanly instinct, but\xe2\x80\x9d--and\r\nhere the passionate tears (kept down for long--struggled with\r\nvehemently) came up into her eyes and choked her voice--\xe2\x80\x9cbut that I was\r\nprompted by some particular feeling for you--you! Why, there was not a\r\nman--not a poor desperate man in all that crowd--for whom I had not more\r\nsympathy--for whom I should not have done what little I could more\r\nheartily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may speak on, Miss Hale. I am aware of these misplaced sympathies\r\nof yours. I now believe that it was only your innate sense of\r\noppression--(yes; I, though a master, may be oppressed)--that made you\r\nact so nobly as you did. I know you despise me; allow me to say, it is\r\nbecause you do not understand me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not care to understand,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, taking hold of the table to\r\nsteady herself; for she thought him cruel--as, indeed, he was--and she\r\nwas weak with her indignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I see you do not. You are unfair and unjust.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret compressed her lips. She would not speak in answer to such\r\naccusations. But, for all that--for all his savage words, he could have\r\nthrown himself at her feet, and kissed the hem of her garment. She did\r\nnot speak; she did not move. The tears of wounded pride fell hot and\r\nfast. He waited awhile, longing for her to say something, even a taunt,\r\nto which he might reply. But she was silent. He took up his hat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word more. You look as if you thought it tainted you to be loved by\r\nme. You cannot avoid it. Nay, I, if I would, cannot cleanse you from it.\r\nBut I would not if I could. I have never loved any woman before: my\r\nlife has been too busy, my thoughts too much absorbed with other things.\r\nNow I love, and will love. But do not be afraid of too much expression\r\non my part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, lifting herself straight up. \xe2\x80\x9cNo one yet\r\nhas ever dared to be impertinent to me, and no one ever shall. But, Mr.\r\nThornton, you have been very kind to my father,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, changing her\r\nwhole tone and bearing to a most womanly softness. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t let us go on\r\nmaking each other angry. Pray don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d He took no notice of her words; he\r\noccupied himself in smoothing the nap of his hat with his coat-sleeve,\r\nfor half a minute or so; and then, rejecting her offered hand, and\r\nmaking as if he did not see her grave look of regret, he turned abruptly\r\naway, and left the room. Margaret caught one glance at his face before\r\nhe went.\r\n\r\nWhen he was gone she thought she had seen the gleam of washed tears in\r\nhis eyes; and that turned her proud dislike into something different and\r\nkinder, if nearly as painful--self-reproach for having caused such\r\nmortification to any one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how could I help it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked she of herself. \xe2\x80\x9cI never liked him. I\r\nwas civil; but I took no trouble to conceal my indifference. Indeed, I\r\nnever thought about myself or him, so my manners must have shown the\r\ntruth. All that yesterday, he might mistake. But that is his fault, not\r\nmine. I would do it again, if need were, though it does lead me into all\r\nthis shame and trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXV.\r\n\r\nFREDERICK.\r\n\r\n            \xe2\x80\x9cRevenge may have her own;\r\n    Roused discipline aloud proclaims their cause,\r\n    And injured navies urge their broken laws.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              BYRON.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret began to wonder whether all offers were as unexpected\r\nbeforehand,--as distressing at the time of their occurrence, as the two\r\nshe had had. An involuntary comparison between Mr. Lennox and Mr.\r\nThornton arose in her mind. She had been sorry, that an expression of\r\nany other feeling than friendship had been lured out by circumstances\r\nfrom Henry Lennox. That regret was the predominant feeling, on the first\r\noccasion of her receiving a proposal. She had not felt so stunned--so\r\nimpressed as she did now, when echoes of Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s voice yet\r\nlingered about the room. In Lennox\xe2\x80\x99s case, he seemed for a moment to\r\nhave slid over the boundary between friendship and love; and the instant\r\nafterwards, to regret it nearly as much as she did, although for\r\ndifferent reasons. In Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s case, as far as Margaret knew,\r\nthere was no intervening stage of friendship. Their intercourse had been\r\none continued series of opposition. Their opinions clashed; and indeed,\r\nshe had never perceived that he had cared for her opinions, as belonging\r\nto her, the individual. As far as they defied his rock-like power of\r\ncharacter, his passion-strength, he seemed to throw them off from him\r\nwith contempt, until she felt the weariness of the exertion of making\r\nuseless protests; and now, he had come, in this strange wild passionate\r\nway, to make known his love! For, although at first it had struck her,\r\nthat his offer was forced and goaded out of him by sharp compassion for\r\nthe exposure she had made of herself,--which he, like others, might\r\nmisunderstand--yet, even before he left the room,--and certainly not\r\nfive minutes after, the clear conviction dawned upon her, shined bright\r\nupon her, that he did love her; that he had loved her; that he would\r\nlove her. And she shrank and shuddered as under the fascination of some\r\ngreat power, repugnant to her whole previous life. She crept away, and\r\nhid from his idea. But it was of no use. To parody a line out of\r\nFairfax\xe2\x80\x99s Tasso--\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cHis strong idea wandered through her thought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe disliked him the more for having mastered her inner will. How dared\r\nhe say that he would love her still, even though she shook him off with\r\ncontempt? She wished she had spoken more--stronger. Sharp, decisive\r\nspeeches came thronging into her mind, now that it was too late to utter\r\nthem. The deep impression made by the interview, was like that of a\r\nhorror in a dream; that will not leave the room although we waken up,\r\nand rub our eyes, and force a stiff rigid smile upon our lips. It is\r\nthere--there, cowering and gibbering, with fixed ghastly eyes, in some\r\ncorner of the chamber, listening to hear whether we dare to breathe of\r\nits presence to any one. And we dare not; poor cowards that we are!\r\n\r\nAnd so she shuddered away from the threat of his enduring love. What did\r\nhe mean? Had she not the power to daunt him? She would see. It was more\r\ndaring than became a man to threaten her so. Did he ground it upon the\r\nmiserable yesterday? If need were, she would do the same to-morrow,--by\r\na crippled beggar, willingly and gladly,--but by him, she would do it,\r\njust as bravely, in spite of his deductions, and the cold slime of\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s impertinence. She did it because it was right, and simple, and\r\ntrue to save where she could save; even to try to save. \xe2\x80\x9cFais ce que\r\ndois, advienne que pourra.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHitherto she had not stirred from where he had left her; no outward\r\ncircumstances had roused her out of the trance of thought in which she\r\nhad been plunged by his last words, and by the look of his deep intent\r\npassionate eyes, as their flames had made her own fall before them. She\r\nwent to the window, and threw it open, to dispel the oppression which\r\nhung around her. Then she went and opened the door, with a sort of\r\nimpetuous wish to shake off the recollection of the past hour, in the\r\ncompany of others, or in active exertion. But all was profoundly hushed\r\nin the noonday stillness of a house, where an invalid catches the\r\nunrefreshing sleep that is denied to the night-hours. Margaret would not\r\nbe alone. What should she do? \xe2\x80\x9cGo and see Bessy Higgins, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthought she, as the recollection of the message sent the night before\r\nflashed into her mind. And away she went.\r\n\r\nWhen she got there, she found Bessy lying on the settle, moved close to\r\nthe fire, though the day was sultry and oppressive. She was laid down\r\nquite flat, as if resting languidly after some paroxysm of pain.\r\nMargaret felt sure she ought to have the greater freedom of breathing\r\nwhich a more sitting posture would procure; and, without a word, she\r\nraised her up, and so arranged the pillows, that Bessy was more at ease,\r\nthough very languid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought I should na\xe2\x80\x99 ha\xe2\x80\x99 seen yo\xe2\x80\x99 again,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, at last, looking\r\nwistfully in Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid you\xe2\x80\x99re much worse. Let us ask him how best to do it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou promised, Margaret, not a quarter of an hour ago,--you said he\r\nshould come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so he shall, mamma; don\xe2\x80\x99t cry, my own dear mother. I\xe2\x80\x99ll write here,\r\nnow--you shall see me write--and it shall go by this very post; and if\r\npapa thinks fit he can write again when he comes in--it is only a day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndelay. Oh, mamma, don\xe2\x80\x99t cry so pitifully, it cuts me to the heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Hale could not stop her tears; they came hysterically; and, in\r\ntruth, she made no effort to control them, but rather called up all the\r\npictures of the happy past, and the probable future--painting the scene\r\nwhen she should lie a corpse, with the son she had longed to see in life\r\nweeping over her, and she unconscious of his presence--till she was\r\nmelted by self-pity into a state of sobbing and exhaustion that made\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart ache. But at last she was calm, and greedily watched\r\nher daughter, as she began her letter; wrote it with swift urgent\r\nentreaty; sealed it up hurriedly, for fear her mother should ask to see\r\nit: and then to make security most sure, at Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s own bidding,\r\ntook it herself to the post-office. She was coming home when her father\r\novertook her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where have you been, my pretty maid?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the post-office--with a letter; a letter to Frederick. Oh, papa,\r\nperhaps I have done wrong: but mamma was seized with such a passionate\r\nyearning to see him--she said it would make her well again--and then she\r\nsaid that she must see him before she died--I cannot tell you how urgent\r\nshe was! Did I do wrong?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale did not reply at first. Then he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should have waited till I came in, Margaret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tried to persuade her--\xe2\x80\x9d and then she was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, after a pause. \xe2\x80\x9cShe ought to see him if\r\nshe wishes it so much; for I believe it would do her much more good than\r\nall the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s medicine--and, perhaps, set her up altogether; but the\r\ndanger to him, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, is very great.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll these years since the mutiny, papa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; it is necessary, of course, for government to take very stringent\r\nmeasures for the repression of offences against authority, more\r\nparticularly in the navy, where a commanding officer needs to be\r\nsurrounded in his men\xe2\x80\x99s eyes with a vivid consciousness of all the power\r\nthere is at home to back him, and take up his cause, and avenge any\r\ninjuries offered to him, if need be. Ah! it\xe2\x80\x99s no matter to them how far\r\ntheir authorities have tyrannised--galled hasty tempers to madness--or,\r\nif that can be any excuse afterwards, it is never allowed for in the\r\nfirst instance; they spare no expense, they send out ships--they scour\r\nthe seas to lay hold of the offenders--the lapse of years does not wash\r\nout the memory of the offence--it is a fresh and vivid crime on the\r\nAdmiralty books till it is blotted out by blood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, papa, what have I done! And yet it seemed so right at the time. I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsure Frederick himself, would run the risk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo he would; so he should! Nay, Margaret, I\xe2\x80\x99m glad it is done, though I\r\ndurst not have done it myself. I\xe2\x80\x99m thankful it is as it is; I should\r\nhave hesitated till, perhaps, it might have been too late to do any\r\ngood. Dear Margaret, you have done what is right about it; and the end\r\nis beyond our control.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was all very well; but her father\xe2\x80\x99s account of the relentless manner\r\nin which mutinies were punished made Margaret shiver and creep. If she\r\nhad decoyed her brother home to blot out the memory of his error by his\r\nblood! She saw her father\xe2\x80\x99s anxiety lap deeper than the source of his\r\nlatter cheering words. She took his arm and walked home pensively and\r\nwearily by his side.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVI.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cI have found that holy place of rest\r\n    Still changeless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              MRS. HEMANS.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. Thornton had left the house that morning he was almost blinded\r\nby his baffled passion. He was as dizzy as if Margaret, instead of\r\nlooking, and speaking, and moving like a tender graceful woman, had been\r\na sturdy fish-wife, and given him a sound blow with her fists. He had\r\npositive bodily pain--a violent headache, and a throbbing intermittent\r\npulse. He could not bear the noise, the garish light, the continued\r\nrumble and movement of the street. He called himself a fool for\r\nsuffering so; and yet he could not, at the moment, recollect the cause\r\nof his suffering, and whether it was adequate to the consequences it had\r\nproduced. It would have been a relief to him, if he could have sat down\r\nand cried on a door-step by a little child, who was raging and storming,\r\nthrough his passionate tears, at some injury he had received. He said to\r\nhimself, that he hated Margaret, but a wild, sharp sensation of love\r\ncleft his dull, thunderous feeling like lightning, even as he shaped the\r\nwords expressive of hatred. His greatest comfort was in hugging his\r\ntorment and in feeling, as he had indeed said to her, that though she\r\nmight despise him, contemn him, treat him with her proud sovereign\r\nindifference, he did not change one whit. She could not make him change.\r\nHe loved her, and would love her; and defy her, and this miserable\r\nbodily pain.\r\n\r\nHe stood still for a moment, to make this resolution firm and clear.\r\nThere was an omnibus passing--going into the country; the conductor\r\nthought he was wishing for a place, and stopped near the pavement. It\r\nwas too much trouble to apologise and explain; so he mounted upon it,\r\nand was borne away--past long rows of houses--then past detached villas\r\nwith trim gardens, till they came to real country hedge-rows, and,\r\nby-and-by, to a small country town. Then everybody got down; and so did\r\nMr. Thornton, and because they walked away he did so too. He went into\r\nthe fields, walking briskly, because the sharp motion relieved his mind.\r\nHe could remember all about it now; the pitiful figure he must have cut;\r\nthe absurd way in which he had gone and done the very thing he had so\r\noften agreed with himself in thinking would be the most foolish thing in\r\nthe world; and had met with exactly the consequences which, in these\r\nwise moods, he had always foretold were certain to follow, if he ever\r\ndid make such a fool of himself. Was he bewitched by those beautiful\r\neyes, that soft, half-open, sighing mouth which lay so close upon his\r\nshoulder only yesterday? He could not even shake off the recollection\r\nthat she had been there; that her arms had been round him, once--if\r\nnever again. He only caught glimpses of her; he did not understand her\r\naltogether. At one time she was so brave, and at another so timid; now\r\nso tender, and then so haughty and regal proud. And then he thought\r\nover every time he had ever seen her once again, by way of finally\r\nforgetting her. He saw her in every dress, in every mood, and did not\r\nknow which became her best. Even this morning how magnificent she had\r\nlooked--her eyes flashing out upon him at the idea that, because she had\r\nshared his danger yesterday, she had cared for him the least!\r\n\r\nIf Mr. Thornton was a fool in the morning, as he assured himself at\r\nleast twenty times he was, he did not grow much wiser in the afternoon.\r\nAll that he gained for his sixpenny omnibus ride, was a more vivid\r\nconviction that there never was, never could be, any one like Margaret;\r\nthat she did not love him and never would; but that she--no! nor the\r\nwhole world--should never hinder him from loving her. And so he returned\r\nto the little market-place, and remounted the omnibus to return to\r\nMilton.\r\n\r\nIt was late in the afternoon when he was set down, near his warehouse.\r\nThe accustomed places brought back the accustomed habits and trains of\r\nthought. He knew how much he had to do--more than his usual work, owing\r\nto the commotion of the day before. He had to see his brother\r\nmagistrates; he had to complete the arrangements, only half made in the\r\nmorning, for the comfort and safety of his newly imported Irish hands;\r\nhe had to secure them from all chance of communication with the\r\ndiscontented workpeople of Milton. Last of all, he had to go home and\r\nencounter his mother.\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton had sat in the dining-room all day, every moment expecting\r\nthe news of her son\xe2\x80\x99s acceptance by Miss Hale. She had braced herself up\r\nmany and many a time, at some sudden noise in the house; had caught up\r\nthe half-dropped work, and begun to ply her needle diligently, though\r\nthrough dimmed spectacles, and with an unsteady hand! and many times had\r\nthe door opened, and some indifferent person entered on some\r\ninsignificant errand. Then her rigid face unstiffened from its gray\r\nfrost-bound expression, and the features dropped into the relaxed look\r\nof despondency, so unusual to their sternness. She wrenched herself away\r\nfrom the contemplation of all the dreary changes that would be brought\r\nabout to herself by her son\xe2\x80\x99s marriage; she forced her thoughts into the\r\naccustomed household grooves. The newly-married couple-to-be would need\r\nfresh household stocks of linen: and Mrs. Thornton had clothes-basket\r\nupon clothes-basket, full of table-cloths and napkins, brought in, and\r\nbegan to reckon up the store. There was some confusion between what was\r\nhers, and consequently marked G. H. T. (for George and Hannah Thornton),\r\nand what was her son\xe2\x80\x99s--bought with his money, marked with his initials.\r\nSome of those marked G. H. T. were Dutch damask of the old kind,\r\nexquisitely fine; none were like them now. Mrs. Thornton stood looking\r\nat them long,--they had been her pride when she was first married. Then\r\nshe knit her brows, and pinched and compressed her lips tight, and\r\ncarefully unpicked the G.H. She went so far as to search for the\r\nTurkey-red marking-thread to put in the new initials; but it was all\r\nused,--and she had no heart to send for any more just yet. So she looked\r\nfixedly at vacancy; a series of visions passing before her, in all of\r\nwhich her son was the principal, the sole object,--her son, her pride,\r\nher property. Still he did not come. Doubtless he was with Miss Hale.\r\nThe new love was displacing her already from her place as first in his\r\nheart. A terrible pain--a pang of vain jealousy--shot through her: she\r\nhardly knew whether it was more physical or mental; but it forced her to\r\nsit down. In a moment, she was up again as straight as ever,--a grim\r\nsmile upon her face for the first time that day, ready for the door\r\nopening, and the rejoicing triumphant one, who should never know the\r\nsore regret his mother felt at his marriage. In all this, there was\r\nlittle thought enough of the future daughter-in-law as an individual.\r\nShe was to be John\xe2\x80\x99s wife. To take Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s place as mistress of\r\nthe house, was only one of the rich consequences which decked out the\r\nsupreme glory: all household plenty and comfort, all purple and fine\r\nlinen, honour, love, obedience, troops of friends, would all come as\r\nnaturally as jewels on a king\xe2\x80\x99s robe, and be as little thought of for\r\ntheir separate value. To be chosen by John, would separate a\r\nkitchen-wench from the rest of the world. And Miss Hale was not so bad.\r\nIf she had been a Milton lass, Mrs. Thornton would have positively liked\r\nher. She was pungent, and had taste, and spirit, and flavour in her.\r\nTrue, she was sadly prejudiced, and very ignorant; but that was to be\r\nexpected from her southern breeding. A strange sort of mortified\r\ncomparison of Fanny with her, went on in Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s mind; and for\r\nonce she spoke harshly to her daughter; abused her roundly; and then, by\r\nway of penance, she took up Henry\xe2\x80\x99s Commentaries, and tried to fix her\r\nattention on it, instead of pursuing the employment she took pride in,\r\nand continuing her inspection of the table-linen.\r\n\r\n_His_ step at last! She heard him, even while she thought she was\r\nfinishing a sentence; while her eye did pass over it, and her memory\r\ncould mechanically have repeated it word for word, she heard him come in\r\nat the hall-door. Her quickened sense could interpret every sound of\r\nmotion: now he was at the hat-stand--now at the very room-door. Why did\r\nhe pause? Let her know the worst.\r\n\r\nYet her head was down over the book; she did not look up. He came close\r\nto the table, and stood still there, waiting till she should have\r\nfinished the paragraph which apparently absorbed her. By an effort she\r\nlooked up. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, John?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe knew what that little speech meant. But he had steeled himself. He\r\nlonged to reply with a jest; the bitterness of his heart could have\r\nuttered one, but his mother deserved better of him. He came round behind\r\nher, so that she could not see his looks, and, bending back her gray,\r\nstony face, he kissed it, murmuring:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one loves me,--no one cares for me, but you, mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned away and stood leaning his head against the mantelpiece, tears\r\nforcing themselves into his manly eyes. She stood up,--she tottered. For\r\nthe first time in her life, the strong woman tottered. She put her hands\r\non his shoulders; she was a tall woman. She looked into his face: she\r\nmade him look at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother\xe2\x80\x99s love is given by God, John. It holds fast for ever and ever.\r\nA girl\xe2\x80\x99s love is like a puff of smoke,--it changes with every wind. And\r\nshe would not have you, my own lad, would not she?\xe2\x80\x9d She set her teeth;\r\nshe showed them like a dog for the whole length of her mouth. He shook\r\nhis head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not fit for her, mother; I knew I was not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe ground out words between her closed teeth. He could not hear what\r\nshe said; but the look in her eyes interpreted it to be a curse,--if not\r\nas coarsely worded, as fell in intent as ever was uttered. And yet her\r\nheart leapt up light, to know he was her own again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, hurriedly, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot hear a word against her. Spare\r\nme,--spare me! I am very weak in my sore heart;--I love her yet; I love\r\nher more than ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I hate her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton, in a low fierce voice. \xe2\x80\x9cI tried\r\nnot to hate her, when she stood between you and me, because,--I said to\r\nmyself,--she will make him happy; and I would give my heart\xe2\x80\x99s blood to\r\ndo that. But now, I hate her for your misery\xe2\x80\x99s sake. Yes, John, it\xe2\x80\x99s no\r\nuse hiding up your aching heart from me. I am the mother that bore you,\r\nand your sorrow is my agony; and if you don\xe2\x80\x99t hate her, I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, mother, you make me love her more. She is unjustly treated by\r\nyou, and I must make the balance even. But why do we talk of love or\r\nhatred? She does not care for me, and that is enough, too much. Let us\r\nnever name the subject again. It is the only thing you can do for me in\r\nthe matter. Let us never name her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith all my heart. I only wish that she, and all belonging to her, were\r\nswept back to the place they came from.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stood still, gazing into the fire for a minute or two longer. Her dry\r\ndim eyes filled with unwonted tears as she looked at him; but she seemed\r\njust as grim and quiet as usual when he next spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWarrants are out against three men for conspiracy, mother. The riot\r\nyesterday helped to knock up the strike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s name was no more mentioned between Mrs. Thornton and her\r\nson. They fell back into their usual mode of talk,--about facts, not\r\nopinions, far less feelings. Their voices and tones were calm and cold;\r\na stranger might have gone away and thought that he had never seen such\r\nfrigid indifference of demeanour between such near relations.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVII.\r\n\r\nFRUIT-PIECE.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cFor never any thing can be amiss\r\n     When simpleness and duty tender it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                MIDSUMMER NIGHT\xe2\x80\x99S DREAM.\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton went straight and clear into all the interests of the\r\nfollowing day. There was a slight demand for finished goods; and as it\r\naffected his branch of the trade, he took advantage of it, and drove\r\nhard bargains. He was sharp to the hour at the meeting of his brother\r\nmagistrates,--giving them the best assistance of his strong sense, and\r\nhis power of seeing consequences at a glance, and so coming to a rapid\r\ndecision. Older men, men of long standing in the town, men of far\r\ngreater wealth--realised and turned into land, while his was all\r\nfloating capital, engaged in his trade--looked to him for prompt, ready\r\nwisdom. He was the one deputed to see and arrange with the police--to\r\nlead in all the requisite steps. And he cared for their unconscious\r\ndeference no more than for the soft west wind, that scarcely made the\r\nsmoke from the great tall chimneys swerve in its straight upward course.\r\nHe was not aware of the silent respect paid to him. If it had been\r\notherwise, he would have felt it as an obstacle in his progress to the\r\nobject he had in view. As it was, he looked to the speedy accomplishment\r\nof that alone. It was his mother\xe2\x80\x99s greedy ears that sucked in, from the\r\nwomenkind of these magistrates and wealthy men, how highly Mr. This or\r\nMr. That thought of Mr. Thornton: that if he had not been there, things\r\nwould have gone on very differently,--very badly, indeed. He swept off\r\nhis business right and left that day. It seemed as though his deep\r\nmortification of yesterday, and the stunned purposeless course of the\r\nhours afterwards, had cleared away all the mists from his intellect. He\r\nfelt his power and revelled in it. He could almost defy his heart. If he\r\nhad known it, he could have sang the song of the miller who lived by the\r\nriver Dee:--\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cI care for nobody--\r\n    Nobody cares for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe evidence against Boucher, and other ring-leaders of the riot, was\r\ntaken before him: that against the three others, for conspiracy, failed.\r\nBut he sternly charged the police to be on the watch; for the swift\r\nright arm of the law should be in readiness to strike, as soon as they\r\ncould prove a fault. And then he left the hot reeking room in the\r\nborough court, and went out into the fresher, but still sultry street.\r\nIt seemed as though he gave way all at once; he was so languid that he\r\ncould not control his thoughts; they would wander to her: they would\r\nbring back the scene,--not of his repulse and rejection the day before,\r\nbut the looks, the actions of the day before that. He went along the\r\ncrowded streets mechanically, winding in and out among the people, but\r\nnever seeing them,--almost sick with longing for that one\r\nhalf-hour--that one brief space of time when she clung to him, and her\r\nheart beat against his--to come once again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Mr. Thornton! you\xe2\x80\x99re cutting me very coolly, I must say. And how\r\nis Mrs. Thornton? Brave weather this! We doctors don\xe2\x80\x99t like it, I can\r\ntell you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, Dr. Donaldson. I really didn\xe2\x80\x99t see you. My mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nquite well, thank you. It is a fine day, and good for the harvest, I\r\nhope. If the wheat is well got in, we shall have a brisk trade next\r\nyear, whatever you doctors have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay. Each man for himself. Your bad weather, and your bad times, are\r\nmy good ones. When trade is bad, there\xe2\x80\x99s more undermining of health, and\r\npreparation for death, going on among you Milton men than you\xe2\x80\x99re aware\r\nof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot with me, Doctor. I\xe2\x80\x99m made of iron. The news of the very worst bad\r\ndebt I ever had, never made my pulse vary. This strike, which affects me\r\nmore than any one else in Milton,--more than Hamper,--never comes near\r\nmy appetite. You must go elsewhere for a patient, Doctor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way, you\xe2\x80\x99ve recommended me a good patient, poor lady! Not to go\r\non talking in this heartless way, I seriously believe that Mrs.\r\nHale--that lady in Crampton, you know--hasn\xe2\x80\x99t many weeks to live. I\r\nnever had any hope of cure, as I think I told you; but I\xe2\x80\x99ve been seeing\r\nher to-day, and I think very badly of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton was silent. The vaunted steadiness of pulse failed him for\r\nan instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I do anything, Doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, in an altered voice. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nknow--you would see, that money is not very plentiful, are there any\r\ncomforts or dainties she ought to have?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Doctor, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x9cShe craves for fruit,--she\r\nhas a constant fever on her; but jargonelle pears will do as well as\r\nanything, and there are quantities of them in the market.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will tell me if there is anything I can do, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr.\r\nThornton. \xe2\x80\x9cI rely upon you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! never fear! I\xe2\x80\x99ll not spare your purse,--I know it\xe2\x80\x99s deep enough. I\r\nwish you\xe2\x80\x99d give me a carte-blanche for all my patients, and all their\r\nwants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Mr. Thornton had no general benevolence,--no universal philanthropy;\r\nfew even would have given him credit for strong affections. But he went\r\nstraight to the first fruit-shop in Milton, and chose out the bunch of\r\npurple grapes with the most delicate bloom upon them,--the\r\nrichest-coloured peaches,--the freshest vine-leaves. They were packed\r\ninto a basket, and the shopman awaited the answer to his inquiry, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\r\nshall we send them to, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no reply. \xe2\x80\x9cTo Marlborough Mills, I suppose, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Thornton said. \xe2\x80\x9cGive the basket to me,--I\xe2\x80\x99ll take it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt took up both his hands to carry it; and he had to pass through the\r\nbusiest part of the town for feminine shopping. Many a young lady of his\r\nacquaintance turned to look after him, and thought it strange to see him\r\noccupied just like a porter or an errand-boy.\r\n\r\nHe was thinking, \xe2\x80\x9cI will not be daunted from doing as I choose by the\r\nthought of her. I like to take this fruit to the poor mother, and it is\r\nsimply right that I should. She shall never scorn me out of doing what I\r\nplease. A pretty joke, indeed, if, for fear of a haughty girl, I failed\r\nin doing a kindness to a man I liked! I do it for Mr. Hale; I do it in\r\ndefiance of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went at an unusual pace, and was soon at Crampton. He went upstairs\r\ntwo steps at a time, and entered the drawing-room before Dixon could\r\nannounce him,--his face flushed, his eyes shining with kindly\r\nearnestness. Mrs. Hale lay on the sofa, heated with fever. Mr. Hale was\r\nreading aloud. Margaret was working on a low stool by her mother\xe2\x80\x99s side.\r\nHer heart fluttered, if his did not at this interview. But he took no\r\nnotice of her,--hardly of Mr. Hale himself; he went up straight with his\r\nbasket to Mrs. Hale, and said, in that subdued and gentle tone, which is\r\nso touching when used by a robust man in full health, speaking to a\r\nfeeble invalid,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI met Dr. Donaldson, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, and as he said fruit would be good for you,\r\nI have taken the liberty--the great liberty--of bringing you some that\r\nseemed to me fine.\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs. Hale was excessively pleased; quite in a\r\ntremble of eagerness. Mr. Hale with fewer words expressed a deeper\r\ngratitude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFetch a plate, Margaret--a basket--anything.\xe2\x80\x9d Margaret stood up by the\r\ntable, half afraid of moving or making any noise to arouse Mr. Thornton\r\ninto a consciousness of her being in the room. She thought it would be\r\nawkward for both to be brought into conscious collision: and fancied\r\nthat, from her being on a low seat at first, and now standing behind her\r\nfather, he had overlooked her in his haste. As if he did not feel the\r\nconsciousness of her presence all over, though his eyes had never rested\r\non her!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must go,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot stay. If you will forgive this\r\nliberty,--my rough ways,--too abrupt, I fear--but I will be more gentle\r\nnext time. You will allow me the pleasure of bringing you some fruit\r\nagain, if I should see any that is tempting. Good afternoon, Mr. Hale.\r\nGood-bye, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was gone. Not one word: not one look to Margaret. She believed that\r\nhe had not seen her. She went for a plate in silence, and lifted the\r\nfruit out tenderly, with the points of her delicate taper fingers. It\r\nwas good of him to bring it; and after yesterday too!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! it is so delicious!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, in a feeble voice. \xe2\x80\x9cHow kind\r\nof him to think of me! Margaret love, only taste these grapes! Was it\r\nnot good of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, rather querulously, \xe2\x80\x9cyou won\xe2\x80\x99t like anything\r\nMr. Thornton does. I never saw anybody so prejudiced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale had been peeling a peach for his wife; and, cutting off a small\r\npiece for himself, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I had any prejudices, the gift of such delicious fruit as this would\r\nmelt them away. I have not tasted such fruit--no! not even in\r\nHampshire--since I was a boy; and, to boys, I fancy, all fruit is good.\r\nI remember eating sloes and crabs with a relish. Do you remember the\r\nmatted-up currant bushes, Margaret, at the corner of the west-wall at\r\nthe garden at home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDid she not? Did she not remember every weather-stain on the old stone\r\nwall; the gray and yellow lichens that marked it like a map; the little\r\ncrane\xe2\x80\x99s-bill that grew in the crevices? She had been shaken by the\r\nevents of the last two days; her whole life just now was a strain upon\r\nher fortitude; and, somehow, these careless words of her father\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\ntouching on the remembrance of the sunny times of old, made her start\r\nup, and, dropping her sewing on the ground, she went hastily out of the\r\nroom into her own little chamber. She had hardly given way to the first\r\nchoking sob, when she became aware of Dixon standing at her drawers, and\r\nevidently searching for something.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless me, miss! How you startled me! Missus is not worse, is she? Is\r\nanything the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, nothing. Only I\xe2\x80\x99m silly, Dixon, and want a glass of water. What are\r\nyou looking for? I keep my muslins in that drawer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDixon did not speak, but went on rummaging. The scent of lavender came\r\nout and perfumed the room.\r\n\r\nAt last Dixon found what she wanted; what it was Margaret could not see.\r\nDixon faced round, and spoke to her:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I don\xe2\x80\x99t like telling what I wanted, because you\xe2\x80\x99ve fretting enough\r\nto go through, and I know you\xe2\x80\x99ll fret about this. I meant to have kept\r\nit from you till night, may be, or such times as that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter? Pray, tell me, Dixon, at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat young woman you go to see--Higgins I mean.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! she died this morning, and her sister is here--come to beg a\r\nstrange thing. It seems, the young woman who died had a fancy for being\r\nburied in something of yours, and so the sister\xe2\x80\x99s come to ask for\r\nit,--and I was looking for a night-cap that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t too good to give\r\naway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! let me find one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, in the midst of her tears. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor\r\nBessy! I never thought I should not see her again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that\xe2\x80\x99s another thing. This girl downstairs wanted me to ask you,\r\nif you would like to see her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she\xe2\x80\x99s dead!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, turning a little pale. \xe2\x80\x9cI never saw a\r\ndead person. No! I would rather not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should never have asked you, if you hadn\xe2\x80\x99t come in. I told her you\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go down and speak to her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, afraid lest Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nharshness of manner might wound the poor girl. So, taking the cap in her\r\nhand, she went to the kitchen. Mary\xe2\x80\x99s face was all swollen with crying,\r\nand she burst out afresh when she saw Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, she loved yo\xe2\x80\x99, she loved yo\xe2\x80\x99, she did indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d And for a\r\nlong time, Margaret could not get her to say anything more than this. At\r\nlast, her sympathy, and Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s scolding, forced out a few facts.\r\nNicholas Higgins had gone out in the morning, leaving Bessy as well as\r\non the day before. But in an hour she was taken worse; some neighbour\r\nran to the room where Mary was working; they did not know where to find\r\nher father; Mary had only come in a few minutes before she died.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt were a day or two ago she axed to be buried in somewhat o\xe2\x80\x99 yourn.\r\nShe were never tired o\xe2\x80\x99 talking o\xe2\x80\x99 yo\xe2\x80\x99. She used to say yo\xe2\x80\x99 were the\r\nprettiest thing she ever clapped eyes on. She loved yo\xe2\x80\x99 dearly. Her last\r\nwords were \xe2\x80\x98Give her my affectionate respects; and keep father fro\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndrink.\xe2\x80\x99 Yo\xe2\x80\x99ll come and see her ma\xe2\x80\x99am. She would ha\xe2\x80\x99 thought it a great\r\ncompliment, I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret shrank a little from answering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, perhaps I may. Yes, I will. I\xe2\x80\x99ll come before tea. But where\xe2\x80\x99s your\r\nfather, Mary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMary shook her head, and stood up to be going.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Hale,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dixon, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere\xe2\x80\x99s the use o\xe2\x80\x99 your going\r\nto see the poor thing laid out? I\xe2\x80\x99d never say a word against it, if it\r\ncould do the girl any good; and I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind a bit going myself, if\r\nthat would satisfy her. They\xe2\x80\x99ve just a notion, these common folks, of\r\nits being a respect to the departed. Here,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, turning sharply\r\nround, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll come and see your sister. Miss Hale is busy, and she can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncome, or else she would.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl looked wistfully at Margaret. Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s coming might be a\r\ncompliment, but it was not the same thing to the poor sister, who had\r\nhad her little pangs of jealousy, during Bessy\xe2\x80\x99s lifetime, at the\r\nintimacy between her and the young lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Dixon!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret with decision. \xe2\x80\x9cI will go. Mary, you shall\r\nsee me this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d And for fear of her own cowardice, she went\r\naway, in order to take from herself any chance of changing her\r\ndetermination.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVIII.\r\n\r\nCOMFORT IN SORROW.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThrough cross to crown!--And though thy spirit\xe2\x80\x99s life\r\n      Trials untold assail with giant strength,\r\n    Good cheer! good cheer! Soon ends the bitter strife,\r\n      And thou shalt reign in peace with Christ at length.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              KOSEGARTEN.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cAy sooth, we feel too strong in weal, to need Thee on that road;\r\n    But woe being come, the soul is dumb, that crieth not on \xe2\x80\x98God.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              MRS. BROWNING.\r\n\r\n\r\nThat afternoon she walked swiftly to the Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s house. Mary was\r\nlooking out for her, with a half-distrustful face. Margaret smiled into\r\nher eyes to re-assure her. They passed quickly through the house-place,\r\nupstairs, and into the quiet presence of the dead. Then Margaret was\r\nglad that she had come. The face, so often weary with pain, so restless\r\nwith troublous thoughts, had now the faint soft smile of eternal rest\r\nupon it. The slow tears gathered into Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, but a deep calm\r\nentered into her soul. And that was death! It looked more peaceful than\r\nlife. All beautiful scriptures came into her mind. \xe2\x80\x9cThey rest from their\r\nlabours.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThe weary are at rest.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cHe giveth his beloved sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSlowly, slowly Margaret turned away from the bed. Mary was humbly\r\nsobbing in the back-ground. They went downstairs without a word.\r\n\r\nResting his hand upon the house-table, Nicholas Higgins stood in the\r\nmidst of the floor; his great eyes startled open by the news he had\r\nheard, as he came along the court, from many busy tongues. His eyes were\r\ndry and fierce; studying the reality of her death; bringing himself to\r\nunderstand that her place should know her no more. For she had been\r\nsickly, dying so long, that he had persuaded himself she would not die;\r\nthat she would \xe2\x80\x9cpull through.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret felt as if she had no business to be there, familiarly\r\nacquainting herself with the surroundings of death, which he, the\r\nfather, had only just learnt. There had been a pause of an instant on\r\nthe steep crooked stair, when she first saw him; but now she tried to\r\nsteal past his abstracted gaze, and to leave him in the solemn circle of\r\nhis household misery.\r\n\r\nMary sat down on the first chair she came to, and throwing her apron\r\nover her head, began to cry.\r\n\r\nThe noise appeared to rouse him. He took sudden hold of Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s arm,\r\nand held her till he could gather words to speak. His throat seemed dry;\r\nthey came up thick, and choked, and hoarse:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere yo\xe2\x80\x99 with her? Did yo\xe2\x80\x99 see her die?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Margaret, standing still with the utmost patience, now she\r\nfound herself perceived. It was some time before he spoke again, but he\r\nkept his hold on her arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll men must die,\xe2\x80\x9d said he at last, with a strange sort of gravity,\r\nwhich first suggested to Margaret the idea that he had been\r\ndrinking--not enough to intoxicate himself, but enough to make his\r\nthoughts bewildered. \xe2\x80\x9cBut she were younger than me.\xe2\x80\x9d Still he pondered\r\nover the event, not looking at Margaret, though he grasped her tight.\r\nSuddenly, he looked up at her with a wild searching inquiry in his\r\nglance. \xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99re sure and certain she\xe2\x80\x99s dead--not in a dwam, a faint?\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s been so before, often.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is dead,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Margaret. She felt no fear in speaking to him,\r\nthough he hurt her arm with his gripe, and wild gleams came across the\r\nstupidity of his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is dead!\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nHe looked at her still with that searching look, which seemed to fade\r\nout of his eyes as he gazed. Then he suddenly let go his hold of\r\nMargaret, and, throwing his body half across the table, he shook it and\r\nevery piece of furniture in the room, with his violent sobs. Mary came\r\ntrembling towards him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet thee gone!--get thee gone!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, striking wildly and blindly\r\nat her. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I care for thee?\xe2\x80\x9d Margaret took her hand and held it\r\nsoftly in hers. He tore his hair, he beat his head against the hard\r\nwood, then he lay exhausted and stupid. Still his daughter and Margaret\r\ndid not move. Mary trembled from head to foot.\r\n\r\nAt last--it might have been a quarter of an hour, it might have been an\r\nhour--he lifted himself up. His eyes were swollen and bloodshot, and he\r\nseemed to have forgotten that any one was by; he scowled at the watchers\r\nwhen he saw them. He shook himself heavily, gave them one more sullen\r\nlook, spoke never a word, but made for the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, father, father!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary, throwing herself upon his arm,--\xe2\x80\x9cnot\r\nto-night! Any night but to-night. Oh, help me! he\xe2\x80\x99s going out to drink\r\nagain! Father, I\xe2\x80\x99ll not leave yo\xe2\x80\x99. Yo\xe2\x80\x99 may strike, but I\xe2\x80\x99ll not leave\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99. She told me last of all to keep yo\xe2\x80\x99 fro\xe2\x80\x99 drink!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Margaret stood in the doorway, silent yet commanding. He looked up\r\nat her defyingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s my own house. Stand out o\xe2\x80\x99 the way, wench, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll make yo\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nhad shaken off Mary with violence; he looked ready to strike Margaret.\r\nBut she never moved a feature--never took her deep, serious eyes off\r\nhim. He stared back on her with gloomy fierceness. If she had stirred\r\nhand or foot, he would have thrust her aside with even more violence\r\nthan he had used to his own daughter, whose face was bleeding from her\r\nfall against a chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are yo\xe2\x80\x99 looking at me in that way for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he at last, daunted\r\nand awed by her severe calm. \xe2\x80\x9cIf yo\xe2\x80\x99 think for to keep me from going\r\nwhat gait I choose, because she loved yo\xe2\x80\x99--and in my own house, too,\r\nwhere I never asked yo\xe2\x80\x99 to come, yo\xe2\x80\x99re mista\xe2\x80\x99en. It\xe2\x80\x99s very hard upon a\r\nman that he can\xe2\x80\x99t go to the only comfort left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret felt that he acknowledged her power. What could she do next? He\r\nhad seated himself on a chair, close to the door; half-conquered\r\nhalf-resenting; intending to go out as soon as she left her position,\r\nbut unwilling to use the violence he had threatened not five minutes\r\nbefore. Margaret laid her hand on his arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome with me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cCome and see her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice in which she spoke was very low and solemn; but there was no\r\nfear or doubt expressed in it, either of him or of his compliance. He\r\nsullenly rose up. He stood uncertain, with dogged irresolution upon his\r\nface. She waited him there; quietly and patiently waited for his time to\r\nmove. He had a strange pleasure in making her wait; but at last he moved\r\ntowards the stairs.\r\n\r\nShe and he stood by the corpse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer last words to Mary were, \xe2\x80\x98Keep my father fro\xe2\x80\x99 drink.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt canna hurt her now,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered he. \xe2\x80\x9cNought can hurt her now.\xe2\x80\x9d Then,\r\nraising his voice to a wailing cry, he went on: \xe2\x80\x9cWe may quarrel and fall\r\nout--we may make peace and be friends--we may clem to skin and bone--and\r\nnought o\xe2\x80\x99 all our griefs will ever touch her more. Hoo\xe2\x80\x99s had her portion\r\non \xe2\x80\x99em. What wi\xe2\x80\x99 hard work first, and sickness at last, hoo\xe2\x80\x99 led the\r\nlife of a dog. And to die without knowing one good piece o\xe2\x80\x99 rejoicing in\r\nall her days! Nay, wench, whatever hoo said, hoo can know nought about\r\nit now, and I mun ha\xe2\x80\x99 a sup o\xe2\x80\x99 drink just to steady me again sorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, softening with his softened manner. \xe2\x80\x9cYou shall not.\r\nIf her life has been what you say, at any rate she did not fear death as\r\nsome do. Oh, you should have heard her speak of the life to come--the\r\nlife hidden with God, that she is now gone to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe shook his head, glancing sideways up at Margaret as he did so. His\r\npale haggard face struck her painfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are sorely tried. Where have you been all day--not at work?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at work, sure enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with a short, grim laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cNot at\r\nwhat you call work. I were at the Committee, till I were sickened out\r\nwi\xe2\x80\x99 trying to make fools hear reason. I were fetched to Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s wife\r\nafore seven this morning. She\xe2\x80\x99s bed-fast, but she were raving and raging\r\nto know where her dunner-headed brute of a chap was, as if I\xe2\x80\x99d to keep\r\nhim--as if he were fit to be ruled by me. And I\xe2\x80\x99ve walked my feet sore wi\xe2\x80\x99 going about for\r\nto see men who wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be seen, now the law is raised against us. And I\r\nwere sore-hearted, too, which is worse than sore-footed; and if I did\r\nsee a friend who ossed to treat me, I never knew hoo lay a-dying here.\r\nBess, lass, thou\xe2\x80\x99d believe me, thou wouldst--wouldstn\xe2\x80\x99t thou?\xe2\x80\x9d turning\r\nto the poor dumb form with wild appeal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cI am sure you did not know; it was quite\r\nsudden. In fact, where was he to look for comfort?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome home with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said she at last, with a bold venture, half\r\ntrembling at her own proposal as she made it. \xe2\x80\x9cAt least you shall have\r\nsome comfortable food, which I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you need.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99r father\xe2\x80\x99s a parson?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, with a sudden turn in his ideas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go and take a dish o\xe2\x80\x99 tea with him, since yo\xe2\x80\x99ve asked me. I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nmany a thing I often wished to say to a parson, and I\xe2\x80\x99m not particular\r\nas to whether he\xe2\x80\x99s preaching now, or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was perplexed; his drinking tea with her father, who would be\r\ntotally unprepared for his visitor--her mother so ill--seemed utterly\r\nout of the question; and yet, if she drew back now, it would be worse\r\nthan ever--sure to drive him to the gin-shop. She thought that if she\r\ncould only get him to their own house, it was so great a step gained\r\nthat she would trust to the chapter of accidents for the next.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, ou\xe2\x80\x99d wench! We\xe2\x80\x99ve parted company at last, we have! But\r\nthou\xe2\x80\x99st been a blessin\xe2\x80\x99 to thy father ever sin\xe2\x80\x99 thou wert born. Bless\r\nthy white lips, lass,--they\xe2\x80\x99ve a smile on \xe2\x80\x99em now! and I\xe2\x80\x99m glad to see\r\nit once again, though I\xe2\x80\x99m lone and forlorn for evermore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stooped down and fondly kissed his daughter; covered up her face, and\r\nturned to follow Margaret. She had hastily gone down stairs to tell\r\nMary of the arrangement; to say it was the only place she could think of\r\nto keep him from the gin-palace; to urge Mary to come too, for her heart\r\nsmote her at the idea of leaving the poor affectionate girl alone. But\r\nMary had friends amongst the neighbours, she said, who would come in and\r\nsit a bit with her; it was all right; but father--\r\n\r\nHe was there by them or she would have spoken more. He had shaken off\r\nhis emotion, as if he was ashamed of having ever given way to it; and\r\nhad even o\xe2\x80\x99erleaped himself so much that he assumed a sort of bitter\r\nmirth, like the crackling of thorns under a pot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to take my tea wi\xe2\x80\x99 her father, I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he slouched his cap low down over his brow as he went out into the\r\nstreet, and looked neither to the right nor to the left, while he\r\ntramped along by Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s side; he feared being upset by the words,\r\nstill more the looks, of sympathising neighbours. She met Dixon on the landing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is mamma?--where is papa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMissus was tired, and gone into her own room. She had wanted to go to\r\nbed, but Dixon had persuaded her to lie down on the sofa, and have her\r\ntea brought to her there; it would be better than getting restless by\r\nbeing too long in bed.\r\n\r\nSo far, so good. But where was Mr. Hale? In the drawing-room. Margaret\r\nwent in half breathless with the hurried story she had to tell. Of\r\ncourse, she told it incompletely; and her father was rather \xe2\x80\x9ctaken\r\naback\xe2\x80\x9d by the idea of the drunken weaver awaiting him in his quiet\r\nstudy, with whom he was expected to drink tea, and on whose behalf\r\nMargaret was anxiously pleading. She wondered how her father and Higgins had got on.\r\n\r\nIn the first place, the decorous, kind-hearted, simple, old-fashioned\r\ngentleman, had unconsciously called out, by his own refinement and\r\ncourteousness of manner, all the latent courtesy in the other.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale treated all his fellow-creatures alike: it never entered into\r\nhis head to make any difference because of their rank. The workmen\xe2\x80\x99s calculations were based\r\n(like too many of the masters\xe2\x80\x99) on false premises. They reckoned on\r\ntheir fellow-men as if they possessed the calculable powers of machines,\r\nno more, no less; no allowance for human passions getting the better of\r\nreason, as in the case of Boucher and the rioters; and believing that\r\nthe representations of their injuries would have the same effect on\r\nstrangers far away, as the injuries (fancied or real) had upon\r\nthemselves. I can make nought on\xe2\x80\x99t. Afore\r\nHamper and me had this split, th\xe2\x80\x99 overlooker telled him I were stirring\r\nup th\xe2\x80\x99 men to ask for higher wages; and Hamper met me one day in th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyard. He\xe2\x80\x99d a thin book i\xe2\x80\x99 his hand, and says he, \xe2\x80\x98Higgins, I\xe2\x80\x99m told\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re one o\xe2\x80\x99 those damned fools that think you can get higher wages for\r\nasking for \xe2\x80\x99em; ay, and keep \xe2\x80\x99em up too, when you\xe2\x80\x99ve forced \xe2\x80\x99em up.
