Now,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll give yo\xe2\x80\x99 a chance and try if yo\xe2\x80\x99ve any sense in yo.\xe2\x80\x99 Here\xe2\x80\x99s a book\r\nwritten by a friend o\xe2\x80\x99 mine, and if yo\xe2\x80\x99ll read it yo\xe2\x80\x99ll see how wages\r\nfind their own level, without either masters or men having aught to do\r\nwith them; except the men cut their own throats wi\xe2\x80\x99 striking, like the\r\nconfounded noodles they are.\xe2\x80\x99 Well, now, sir, I put it to yo,\xe2\x80\x99 being a\r\nparson, and having been in th\xe2\x80\x99 preaching line, and having had to try and\r\nbring folk o\xe2\x80\x99er to what yo\xe2\x80\x99 thought was a right way o\xe2\x80\x99 thinking--did yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\nbegin by calling \xe2\x80\x99em fools and such like, or didn\xe2\x80\x99t yo\xe2\x80\x99 rayther give \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nsuch kind words at first, to make \xe2\x80\x99em ready for to listen and be\r\nconvinced, if they could; and in yo\xe2\x80\x99r preaching, did yo\xe2\x80\x99 stop every now\r\nand then, and say, half to them and half to yo\xe2\x80\x99rsel,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98But yo\xe2\x80\x99r such a\r\npack o\xe2\x80\x99 fools, that I\xe2\x80\x99ve a strong notion it\xe2\x80\x99s no use my trying to put\r\nsense into yo\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x99 I were not i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 best state, I\xe2\x80\x99ll own, for taking in\r\nwhat Hamper\xe2\x80\x99s friend had to say--I were so vexed at the way it were put\r\nto me;--but I thought, \xe2\x80\x98Come, I\xe2\x80\x99ll see what these chaps has got to say,\r\nand try if it\xe2\x80\x99s them or me as is th\xe2\x80\x99 noodle.\xe2\x80\x99 So I took th\xe2\x80\x99 book and\r\ntugged at it; but, Lord bless yo\xe2\x80\x99, it went on about capital and labour,\r\nand labour and capital, till it fair sent me off to sleep. I ne\xe2\x80\x99er could\r\nrightly fix i\xe2\x80\x99 my mind which was which; and it spoke on \xe2\x80\x99em as if they\r\nwas vartues or vices; and what I wanted for to know were the rights o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmen, whether they were rich or poor--so be they only were men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut for all that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, \xe2\x80\x9cand granting to the full the\r\noffensiveness, the folly, the unchristianness of Mr. Hamper\xe2\x80\x99s way of\r\nspeaking to you in recommending his friend\xe2\x80\x99s book, yet if it told you\r\nwhat he said it did, that wages find their own level, and that the most\r\nsuccessful strike can only force them up for a moment, to sink in far\r\ngreater proportion afterwards, in consequence of that very strike, the\r\nbook would have told you the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Higgins, rather doggedly; \xe2\x80\x9cit might, or it might not.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s two opinions go to settling that point. But suppose it was truth\r\ndouble strong, it were no truth to me if I couldna take it in. I daresay\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s great truth in yon Latin book on your shelves; but it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngibberish and not truth to me, unless I know the meaning o\xe2\x80\x99 the words.\r\nIf yo\xe2\x80\x99, sir, or any other knowledgable, patient man comes to me, and\r\nsays he\xe2\x80\x99ll larn me what the words mean, and not blow me up if I\xe2\x80\x99m a bit\r\nstupid, or forget how one thing hangs on another--why, in time I may get\r\nto see the truth of it; or I may not. I\xe2\x80\x99ll not be bound to say I shall\r\nend in thinking the same as any man. And I\xe2\x80\x99m not one who think truth can\r\nbe shaped out in words, all neat and clean, as th\xe2\x80\x99 men at th\xe2\x80\x99 foundry\r\ncut out sheet-iron. Same bones won\xe2\x80\x99t go down wi\xe2\x80\x99 every one. It\xe2\x80\x99ll stick\r\nhere i\xe2\x80\x99 this man\xe2\x80\x99s throat, and there i\xe2\x80\x99 t\xe2\x80\x99others. Let alone that, when\r\ndown, it may be too strong for this one, too weak for that. Folk who\r\nsets up to doctor th\xe2\x80\x99 world wi\xe2\x80\x99 their truth, mun suit different for\r\ndifferent minds; and be a bit tender i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 way of giving it too, or the\r\npoor sick fools may spit it out i\xe2\x80\x99 their faces. Now Hamper first gi\xe2\x80\x99es\r\nme a box on my ear, and then he throws his big bolus at me, and says he\r\nreckons it\xe2\x80\x99ll do me no good, I\xe2\x80\x99m such a fool, but there it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish some of the kindest and wisest of the masters would meet some of\r\nyou men, and have a good talk on these things; it would, surely, be the\r\nbest way of getting over your difficulties, which, I do believe, arise\r\nfrom your ignorance--excuse me, Mr. Higgins--on subjects which it is for\r\nthe mutual interests of both masters and men should be well understood\r\nby both. I wonder\xe2\x80\x9d--(half to his daughter), \xe2\x80\x9cif Mr. Thornton might not\r\nbe induced to do such thing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember, papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said she in a very low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat he said one\r\nday,--about governments, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d She was unwilling to make any\r\nclearer allusion to the conversation they had held on the mode of\r\ngoverning work-people--by giving men intelligence enough to rule\r\nthemselves, or by a wise despotism on the part of the master--for she\r\nsaw that Higgins had caught Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s name, if not the whole of the\r\nspeech: indeed, he began to speak of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThornton! He\xe2\x80\x99s the chap as wrote off at once for these Irishers; and\r\nled to th\xe2\x80\x99 riot that ruined th\xe2\x80\x99 strike. Even Hamper wi\xe2\x80\x99 all his\r\nbullying, would ha\xe2\x80\x99 waited a while--but it\xe2\x80\x99s a word and a blow wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThornton. And, now, when th\xe2\x80\x99 Union would ha\xe2\x80\x99 thanked him for following\r\nup th\xe2\x80\x99 chase after Boucher, and them chaps as went right again our\r\ncommands, it\xe2\x80\x99s Thornton who steps forrard and coolly says that, as th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nstrike\xe2\x80\x99s at an end, he, as party injured, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to press the\r\ncharge again the rioters. I thought he\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 carried his point, and had\r\nhis revenge in an open way; but says he (one in court telled me his very\r\nwords) \xe2\x80\x98they are well known; they will find the natural punishment of\r\ntheir conduct, in the difficulty they will meet wi\xe2\x80\x99 in getting\r\nemployment. That will be severe enough.\xe2\x80\x99 I only wish they\xe2\x80\x99d cotched\r\nBoucher, and had him up before Hamper. I see th\xe2\x80\x99 oud tiger setting on\r\nhim! would he ha\xe2\x80\x99 let him off? Not he!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton was right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are angry against Boucher,\r\nNicholas; or else you would be the first to see, that where the natural\r\npunishment would be severe enough for the offence, any farther\r\npunishment would be something like revenge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter is no great friend of Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale,\r\nsmiling at Margaret; while she, as red as any carnation, began to work\r\nwith double diligence, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I believe what she says is the truth. I like\r\nhim for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, this strike has been a weary bit o\xe2\x80\x99 business to me; and\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99ll not wonder if I\xe2\x80\x99m a bit put out wi\xe2\x80\x99 seeing it fail, just for a few\r\nmen who would na suffer in silence, and aou\xe2\x80\x99d out, brave and firm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou forget!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know much of Boucher; but the only\r\ntime I saw him it was not his own sufferings he spoke of, but those of\r\nhis sick wife--his little children.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue! but he were not made of iron himsel\xe2\x80\x99. He\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 cried out for his\r\nown sorrows, next. He were not one to bear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow came he into the Union?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret innocently. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t seem\r\nto have much respect for him; nor gained much good from having him in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHiggins\xe2\x80\x99s brow clouded. He was silent for a minute or two. Then he said,\r\nshortly enough:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not for me to speak o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 Union. What they does they does. Them\r\nthat is of a trade mun hang together; and if they\xe2\x80\x99re not willing to take\r\ntheir chance along wi\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 rest, th\xe2\x80\x99 Union has ways and means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale saw that Higgins was vexed at the turn the conversation had\r\ntaken, and was silent. Not so Margaret, though she saw Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s feeling\r\nas clearly as he did. By instinct she felt that if he could but be\r\nbrought to express himself in plain words, something clear would be\r\ngained on which to argue for the right and the just.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what are the Union\xe2\x80\x99s ways and means?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked up at her, as if on the point of dogged resistance to her\r\nwish for information. But her calm face, fixed on his, patient and\r\ntrustful, compelled him to answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! If a man doesn\xe2\x80\x99t belong to th\xe2\x80\x99 Union, them as works next looms as\r\norders not to speak to him--if he\xe2\x80\x99s sorry or ill it\xe2\x80\x99s a\xe2\x80\x99 the same; he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nout o\xe2\x80\x99 bounds; he\xe2\x80\x99s none o\xe2\x80\x99 us; he comes among us, he works among us,\r\nbut he\xe2\x80\x99s none o\xe2\x80\x99 us. I\xe2\x80\x99 some places them\xe2\x80\x99s fined who speaks to him. Yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\ntry that, miss; try living a year or two among them as looks away if yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\nlook at \xe2\x80\x99em; try working within two yards o\xe2\x80\x99 crowds o\xe2\x80\x99 men, who, yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\nknow, have a grinding grudge at yo\xe2\x80\x99 in their hearts--to whom if yo\xe2\x80\x99 say\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99r glad, not an eye brightens, nor a lip moves,--to whom if your\r\nheart\xe2\x80\x99s heavy, yo\xe2\x80\x99 can never say nought, because they\xe2\x80\x99ll ne\xe2\x80\x99er take\r\nnotice on your sighs or sad looks (and a man\xe2\x80\x99s no man who\xe2\x80\x99ll groan out\r\nloud \xe2\x80\x99bout folk asking him what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?)--just yo\xe2\x80\x99 try that,\r\nmiss--ten hours for three hundred days, and yo\xe2\x80\x99ll know a bit what the\r\nUnion is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat tyranny this is! Nay, Higgins, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care\r\none straw for your anger. I know you can\xe2\x80\x99t be angry with me if you\r\nwould, and I must tell you the truth: that I never read, in all the\r\nhistory I have read, of a more slow, lingering torture than this. And\r\nyou belong to the Union! And you talk of the tyranny of the masters!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Higgins, \xe2\x80\x9cyo\xe2\x80\x99 may say what yo\xe2\x80\x99 like. The dead stand between\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99 and every angry word o\xe2\x80\x99 mine. D\xe2\x80\x99ye think I forget who\xe2\x80\x99s lying\r\n_there_, and how hoo loved yo\xe2\x80\x99? And it\xe2\x80\x99s th\xe2\x80\x99 masters as has made us sin,\r\nif th\xe2\x80\x99 Union is a sin. Not this generation maybe, but their fathers.\r\nTheir fathers ground our fathers to the very dust; ground us to powder!\r\nParson! I reckon I\xe2\x80\x99ve heerd my mother read out a text, \xe2\x80\x98The fathers have\r\neaten sour grapes, and th\xe2\x80\x99 chidren\xe2\x80\x99s teeth are set on edge.\xe2\x80\x99 Its so wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthem. In those days of sore oppression th\xe2\x80\x99 Unions began; it were a\r\nnecessity. It\xe2\x80\x99s a necessity now, according to me. It\xe2\x80\x99s a withstanding of\r\ninjustice, past, present, or to come. It may be like war; along wi\xe2\x80\x99 it\r\ncome crimes; but I think it were a greater crime to let it alone. Our\r\nonly chance is binding men together in one common interest; and if some\r\nare cowards and some are fools, they mun come along and join the great\r\nmarch, whose only strength is in numbers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, sighing, \xe2\x80\x9cyour Union in itself would be beautiful,\r\nglorious--it would be Christianity itself--if it were but for an end\r\nwhich affected the good of all, instead of that of merely one class as\r\nopposed to another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI reckon it\xe2\x80\x99s time for me to be going, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Higgins, as the clock\r\nstruck ten.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHome?\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret very softly. He understood her, and took her\r\noffered hand. \xe2\x80\x9cHome, miss. Yo\xe2\x80\x99 may trust me, tho\xe2\x80\x99 I am one o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nUnion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do trust you most thoroughly, Nicholas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, hurrying to the bookshelves. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Higgins! I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsure you\xe2\x80\x99ll join us in family prayer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHiggins looked at Margaret, doubtfully. Her grave sweet eyes met his;\r\nthere was no compulsion, only deep interest in them. He did not speak,\r\nbut he kept his place.\r\n\r\nMargaret the Churchwoman, her father the Dissenter, Higgins the Infidel,\r\nknelt down together. It did them no harm.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIX.\r\n\r\nA RAY OF SUNSHINE.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cSome wishes crossed my mind and dimly cheered it,\r\n    And one or two poor melancholy pleasures,\r\n    Each in the pale unwarming light of hope,\r\n    Silvering its flimsy wing, flew silent by--\r\n    Moths in the moonbeam!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              COLERIDGE.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next morning brought Margaret a letter from Edith. It was\r\naffectionate and inconsequent like the writer. But the affection was\r\ncharming to Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s own affectionate nature; and she had grown up\r\nwith the inconsequence, so she did not perceive it. It was as follows:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Margaret, it is worth a journey from England to see my boy! He is a\r\nsuperb little fellow, especially in his caps, and most especially in the\r\none you sent him, you good, dainty-fingered, persevering little lady!\r\nHaving made all the mothers here envious, I want to show him to somebody\r\nnew, and hear a fresh set of admiring expressions; perhaps, that\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nthe reason; perhaps it is not--nay, possibly, there is just a little\r\ncousinly love mixed with it; but I do want you so much to come here,\r\nMargaret! I\xe2\x80\x99m sure it would be the very best thing for Aunt Hale\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhealth; everybody here is young and well, and our skies are always blue,\r\nand our sun always shines, and the band plays deliciously from morning\r\ntill night; and, to come back to the burden of my ditty, my baby always\r\nsmiles. I am constantly wanting you to draw him from me, Margaret. It\r\ndoes not signify what he is doing; that very thing is prettiest,\r\ngracefullest, best. I think I love him a great deal better than my\r\nhusband, who is getting stout, and grumpy--what he calls \xe2\x80\x98busy.\xe2\x80\x99 No! he\r\nis not. He has just come in with news of such a charming pic-nic, given\r\nby the officers of the Hazard, at anchor in the bay below. Because he\r\nhas brought in such a pleasant piece of news, I retract all I said just\r\nnow. Did not somebody burn his hand for having said or done something he\r\nwas sorry for? Well, I can\xe2\x80\x99t burn mine, because it would hurt me, and\r\nthe scar would be ugly; but I\xe2\x80\x99ll retract all I said as fast as I can.\r\nCosmo is quite as great a darling as baby, and not a bit stout, and as\r\nungrumpy as ever husband was; only, sometimes he is very, very busy. I\r\nmay say that without love--wifely duty--- where was I?--I had something\r\nvery particular to say, I know, once. Oh, it is this--Dearest\r\nMargaret!--you must come and see me; it would do Aunt Hale good, as I\r\nsaid before. Get the doctor to order it for her. Tell him that it\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nsmoke of Milton that does her harm. I have no doubt it is that, really.\r\nThree months (you must not come for less) of this delicious climate--all\r\nsunshine, and grapes as common as blackberries, would quite cure her. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t ask my uncle\xe2\x80\x9d--(Here the letter became more constrained, and\r\nbetter written. Mr. Hale was in the corner, like a naughty child, for\r\nhaving given up his living.)--\xe2\x80\x9cbecause, I dare say, he disapproves of\r\nwar, soldiers, and bands of music; at least, I know that many Dissenters\r\nare members of the Peace Society, and I am afraid he would not like to\r\ncome; but, if he would, dear, pray say that Cosmo and I will do our best\r\nto make him happy; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll hide up Cosmo\xe2\x80\x99s red coat and sword, and make\r\nthe band play all sorts of grave, solemn things; or, if they do play\r\npomps and vanities, it shall be in double slow time. Dear Margaret, if\r\nhe would like to accompany you and Aunt Hale, we will try and make it\r\npleasant, though I\xe2\x80\x99m rather afraid of any one who has done anything for\r\nconscience\xe2\x80\x99 sake. You never did, I hope. Tell Aunt Hale not to bring any\r\nwarm clothes, though I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid it will be late in the year before you\r\ncan come. But you have no idea of the heat here! I tried to wear my\r\ngreat beauty Indian shawl at a pic-nic. I kept myself up with proverbs\r\nas long as I could; \xe2\x80\x98Pride must abide,\xe2\x80\x99--and such wholesome pieces of\r\npith; but it was no use. I was like mamma\xe2\x80\x99s little dog Tiny with an\r\nelephant\xe2\x80\x99s trappings on; smothered, hidden, killed with my finery; so I\r\nmade it into a capital carpet for us all to sit down upon. Here\xe2\x80\x99s this\r\nboy of mine, Margaret--if you don\xe2\x80\x99t pack up your things as soon as you\r\nget this letter, and come straight off to see him, I shall think you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\ndescended from King Herod!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret did long for a day of Edith\xe2\x80\x99s life--her freedom from care, her\r\ncheerful home, her sunny skies. If a wish could have transported her,\r\nshe would have gone off; just for one day. She yearned for the strength\r\nwhich such a change would give--even for a few hours to be in the midst\r\nof that bright life, and to feel young again. Not yet twenty! and she\r\nhad had to bear up against such hard pressure that she felt quite old.\r\nThat was her first feeling after reading Edith\xe2\x80\x99s letter. Then she read\r\nit again, and, forgetting herself, was amused at its likeness to Edith\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nself, and was laughing merrily over it when Mrs. Hale came into the\r\ndrawing-room, leaning on Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s arm. Margaret flew to adjust the\r\npillows. Her mother seemed more than usually feeble.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat were you laughing at, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d asked she, as soon as she had\r\nrecovered from the exertion of settling herself on the sofa.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA letter I have had this morning from Edith. Shall I read it to you,\r\nmamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe read it aloud, and for a time it seemed to interest her mother, who\r\nkept wondering what name Edith had given to her boy, and suggesting all\r\nprobable names, and all possible reasons why each and all of these names\r\nshould be given. Into the very midst of these wonders Mr. Thornton came,\r\nbringing another offering of fruit for Mrs. Hale. He could not--say\r\nrather, he would not--deny himself the chance of the pleasure of seeing\r\nMargaret. He had no end in this but the present gratification. It was\r\nthe sturdy wilfulness of a man usually most reasonable and\r\nself-controlled. He entered the room, taking in at a glance the fact of\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s presence; but after the first cold distant bow, he never\r\nseemed to let his eyes fall on her again. He only stayed to present his\r\npeaches--to speak some gentle kindly words--and then his cold offended\r\neyes met Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s with a grave farewell, as he left the room. She sat\r\ndown silent and pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, Margaret, I really begin to like Mr. Thornton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo answer at first. Then Margaret forced out an icy \xe2\x80\x9cDo you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! I think he is really getting quite polished in his manners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s voice was more in order now. She replied,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is very kind and attentive--there is no doubt of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder Mrs. Thornton never calls. She must know I am ill, because of\r\nthe water-bed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say, she hears how you are from her son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill, I should like to see her. You have so few friends here,\r\nMargaret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret felt what was in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts--a tender craving to\r\nbespeak the kindness of some woman towards the daughter that might soon\r\nbe left motherless. But she could not speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, after a pause, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you could go and\r\nask Mrs. Thornton to come and see me? Only once--I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be\r\ntroublesome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do anything, if you wish it, mamma--but if--but when Frederick\r\ncomes----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, to be sure! we must keep our doors shut--we must let no one in. I\r\nhardly know whether I dare wish him to come or not. Sometimes I think I\r\nwould rather not. Sometimes I have such frightful dreams about him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mamma! we\xe2\x80\x99ll take good care. I will put my arm in the bolt sooner\r\nthan he should come to the slightest harm. Trust the care of him to me,\r\nmamma. I will watch over him like a lioness over her young.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen can we hear from him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot for a week yet, certainly--perhaps more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must send Martha away in good time. It would never do to have her\r\nhere when he comes, and then send her off in a hurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDixon is sure to remind us of that. I was thinking that, if we wanted\r\nany help in the house while he is here, we could perhaps get Mary\r\nHiggins. She is very slack of work, and is a good girl, and would take\r\npains to do her best, I am sure, and would sleep at home, and need never\r\ncome upstairs, so as to know who is in the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you please. As Dixon pleases. But, Margaret, don\xe2\x80\x99t get to use these\r\nhorrid Milton words. \xe2\x80\x98Slack of work:\xe2\x80\x99 it is a provincialism. What will\r\nyour aunt Shaw say, if she hears you use it on her return?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mamma! don\xe2\x80\x99t try and make a bugbear of aunt Shaw,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret,\r\nlaughing. \xe2\x80\x9cEdith picked up all sorts of military slang from Captain\r\nLennox, and aunt Shaw never took any notice of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut yours is factory slang.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I live in a factory town, I must speak factory language when I\r\nwant it. Why, mamma, I could astonish you with a great many words you\r\nnever heard in your life. I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe you know what a knobstick is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I, child. I only know it has a very vulgar sound; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nto hear you using it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, dearest mother, I won\xe2\x80\x99t. Only I shall have to use a whole\r\nexplanatory sentence instead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like this Milton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cEdith is right enough in\r\nsaying it\xe2\x80\x99s the smoke that has made me so ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret started up as her mother said this. Her father had just entered\r\nthe room, and she was most anxious that the faint impression she had\r\nseen on his mind that the Milton air had injured her mother\xe2\x80\x99s health,\r\nshould not be deepened--should not receive any confirmation. She could\r\nnot tell whether he had heard what Mrs. Hale had said or not; but she\r\nbegan speaking hurriedly of other things, unaware that Mr. Thornton was\r\nfollowing him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMamma is accusing me of having picked up a great deal of vulgarity\r\nsince we came to Milton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cvulgarity\xe2\x80\x9d Margaret spoke of, referred purely to the use of local\r\nwords, and the expression arose out of the conversation they had just\r\nbeen holding. But Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s brow darkened; and Margaret suddenly\r\nfelt how her speech might be misunderstood by him; so, in the natural\r\nsweet desire to avoid giving unnecessary pain, she forced herself to go\r\nforwards with a little greeting, and continue what she was saying,\r\naddressing herself to him expressly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Mr. Thornton, though \xe2\x80\x98knobstick\xe2\x80\x99 has not a very pretty sound, is\r\nit not expressive? Could I do without it, in speaking of the thing it\r\nrepresents? If using local words is vulgar, I was very vulgar in the\r\nForest,--was I not, mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was unusual with Margaret to obtrude her own subject of conversation\r\non others; but, in this case, she was so anxious to prevent Mr. Thornton\r\nfrom feeling annoyance at the words he had accidentally overheard, that\r\nit was not until she had done speaking that she coloured all over with\r\nconsciousness, more especially as Mr. Thornton seemed hardly to\r\nunderstand the exact gist or bearing of what she was saying, but passed\r\nher by, with a cold reserve of ceremonious movement, to speak to Mrs.\r\nHale.\r\n\r\nThe sight of him reminded her of the wish to see his mother, and commend\r\nMargaret to her care. Margaret, sitting in burning silence, vexed and\r\nashamed of her difficulty in keeping her right place, and her calm\r\nunconsciousness of heart, when Mr. Thornton was by, heard her mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nslow entreaty that Mrs. Thornton would come and see her; see her soon;\r\nto-morrow, if it were possible. Mr. Thornton promised that she\r\nshould--conversed a little, and then took his leave; and Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmovements and voice seemed at once released from some invisible chains.\r\nHe never looked at her; and yet, the careful avoidance of his eyes\r\nbetokened that in some way he knew exactly where, if they fell by\r\nchance, they would rest on her. If she spoke, he gave no sign of\r\nattention, and yet his next speech to any one else was modified by what\r\nshe had said; sometimes there was an express answer to what she had\r\nremarked, but given to another person as though unsuggested by her. It\r\nwas not the bad manners of ignorance; it was the wilful bad manners\r\narising from deep offence. It was wilful at the time; repented of\r\nafterwards. But no deep plan, no careful cunning could have stood him in\r\nsuch good stead. Margaret thought about him more than she had ever done\r\nbefore; not with any tinge of what is called love, but with regret that\r\nshe had wounded him so deeply,--and with a gentle, patient striving to\r\nreturn to their former position of antagonistic friendship; for a\r\nfriend\xe2\x80\x99s position was what she found that he had held in her regard, as\r\nwell as in that of the rest of the family. There was a pretty humility\r\nin her behaviour to him, as if mutely apologising for the over-strong\r\nwords which were the reaction from the deeds of the day of the riot.\r\n\r\nBut he resented those words bitterly. They rung in his ears; and he was\r\nproud of the sense of justice which made him go in every kindness he\r\ncould offer to her parents. He exulted in the power he showed in\r\ncompelling himself to face her, whenever he could think of any action\r\nwhich might give her father or mother pleasure. He thought that he\r\ndisliked seeing one who had mortified him so keenly; but he was\r\nmistaken. It was a stinging pleasure to be in the room with her, and\r\nfeel her presence. But he was no great analyser of his own motives and\r\nwas mistaken, as I have said.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXX.\r\n\r\nHOME AT LAST.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThe saddest birds a season find to sing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              SOUTHWELL.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cNever to fold the robe o\xe2\x80\x99er secret pain,\r\n    Never, weighed down by memory\xe2\x80\x99s clouds again,\r\n    To bow thy head! Thou art gone home!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              MRS. HEMANS.\r\n\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton came to see Mrs. Hale the next morning. She was much\r\nworse. One of those sudden changes--those great visible strides towards\r\ndeath, had been taken in the night, and her own family were startled by\r\nthe gray sunken look her features had assumed in that one twelve hours\r\nof suffering. Mrs. Thornton--who had not seen her for weeks--was\r\nsoftened all at once. She had come because her son asked it from her as\r\na personal favour, but with all the proud bitter feelings of her nature\r\nin arms against that family of which Margaret formed one. She doubted\r\nthe reality of Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s illness; she doubted any want beyond a\r\nmomentary fancy on that lady\xe2\x80\x99s part, which should take her out of her\r\npreviously settled course of employment for the day. She told her son\r\nthat she wished they had never come near the place; that he had never\r\ngot acquainted with them; that there had been no such useless languages\r\nas Latin and Greek ever invented. He bore all this pretty silently; but\r\nwhen she had ended her invective against the dead languages, he quietly\r\nreturned to the short, curt, decided expression of his wish that she\r\nshould go and see Mrs. Hale at the time appointed, as most likely to be\r\nconvenient to the invalid. Mrs. Thornton submitted with as bad a grace\r\nas she could to her son\xe2\x80\x99s desire, all the time liking him the better for\r\nhaving it; and exaggerating in her own mind the same notion that he had\r\nof extraordinary goodness on his part in so perseveringly keeping up\r\nwith the Hales.\r\n\r\nHis goodness verging on weakness (as all the softer virtues did in her\r\nmind), and her own contempt for Mr. and Mrs. Hale, and positive dislike\r\nto Margaret, were the ideas which occupied Mrs. Thornton, till she was\r\nstruck into nothingness before the dark shadow of the wings of the angel\r\nof death. There lay Mrs. Hale--a mother like herself--a much younger\r\nwoman than she was,--on the bed from which there was no sign of hope\r\nthat she might ever rise again. No more variety of light and shade for\r\nher in that darkened room; no power of action, scarcely change of\r\nmovement; faint alternations of whispered sound and studious silence;\r\nand yet that monotonous life seemed almost too much! When Mrs. Thornton,\r\nstrong and prosperous with life, came in, Mrs. Hale lay still, although\r\nfrom the look on her face she was evidently conscious of who it was. But\r\nshe did not even open her eyes for a minute or two. The heavy moisture\r\nof tears stood on her eyelashes before she looked up; then, with her\r\nhand groping feebly over the bed-clothes, for the touch of Mrs.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s large firm fingers, she said, scarcely above her\r\nbreath.--Mrs. Thornton had to stoop from her erectness to listen,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret--you have a daughter--my sister is in Italy. My child will be\r\nwithout a mother;--in a strange place,--if I die---- will you\xe2\x80\x9d----\r\n\r\nAnd her filmy wandering eyes fixed themselves with an intensity of\r\nwistfulness on Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s face. For a minute there was no change in\r\nits rigidness; it was stern and unmoved;--nay, but that the eyes of the\r\nsick woman were growing dim with the slow-gathering tears, she might\r\nhave seen a dark cloud cross the cold features. And it was no thought of\r\nher son, or of her living daughter Fanny, that stirred her heart at\r\nlast; but a sudden remembrance, suggested by something in the\r\narrangement of the room,--of a little daughter--dead in infancy--long\r\nyears ago--that, like a sudden sunbeam, melted the icy crust, behind\r\nwhich there was a real tender woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wish me to be a friend to Miss Hale,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton, in her\r\nmeasured voice, that would not soften with her heart, but came out\r\ndistinct and clear.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hale, her eyes still fixed on Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s face, pressed the\r\nhand that lay below hers on the coverlet. She could not speak. Mrs.\r\nThornton sighed, \xe2\x80\x9cI will be a true friend, if circumstances require it.\r\nNot a tender friend. That I cannot be,\xe2\x80\x9d--(\xe2\x80\x9cto her,\xe2\x80\x9d she was on the\r\npoint of adding, but she relented at the sight of that poor, anxious\r\nface.)--\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not my nature to show affection even where I feel it, nor\r\ndo I volunteer advice in general. Still, at your request,--if it will be\r\nany comfort to you, I will promise you.\xe2\x80\x9d Then came a pause. Mrs.\r\nThornton was too conscientious to promise what she did not mean to\r\nperform; and to perform anything in the way of kindness on behalf of\r\nMargaret, more disliked at this moment than ever, was difficult; almost\r\nimpossible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, with grave severity; which, after all, inspired\r\nthe dying woman with faith as in something more stable than life\r\nitself,--flickering, flittering, wavering life! \xe2\x80\x9cI promise that in any\r\ndifficulty in which Miss Hale\xe2\x80\x9d----\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall her Margaret!\xe2\x80\x9d gasped Mrs. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn which she comes to me for help, I will help her with every power I\r\nhave, as if she were my own daughter. I also promise that if ever I see\r\nher doing what I think is wrong\xe2\x80\x9d----\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Margaret never does wrong--not wilfully wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded Mrs. Hale.\r\nMrs. Thornton went on as before; as if she had not heard:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf ever I see her doing what I believe to be wrong--such wrong not\r\ntouching me or mine, in which case I might be supposed to have an\r\ninterested motive--I will tell her of it, faithfully and plainly, as I\r\nshould wish my own daughter to be told.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a long pause. Mrs. Hale felt that this promise did not include\r\nall; and yet it was much. It had reservations in it which she did not\r\nunderstand: but then she was weak, dizzy, and tired. Mrs. Thornton was\r\nreviewing all the probable cases in which she had pledged herself to\r\nact. She had a fierce pleasure in the idea of telling Margaret unwelcome\r\ntruths, in the shape of performance of duty. Mrs. Hale began to speak:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you. I pray God to bless you. I shall never see you again in\r\nthis world. But my last words are, I thank you for your promise of\r\nkindness to my child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot kindness!\xe2\x80\x9d testified Mrs. Thornton, ungraciously truthful to the\r\nlast. But having eased her conscience by saying these words, she was not\r\nsorry that they were not heard. She pressed Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s soft languid\r\nhand; and rose up and went her way out of the house without seeing a\r\ncreature.\r\n\r\nDuring the time that Mrs. Thornton was having this interview with Mrs.\r\nHale, Margaret and Dixon were laying their heads together and consulting\r\nhow they should keep Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s coming a profound secret to all out of\r\nthe house. A letter from him might now be expected any day; and he would\r\nassuredly follow quickly on its heels. Martha must be sent away on her\r\nholiday; Dixon must keep stern guard on the front door, only admitting\r\nthe few visitors that ever came to the house into Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s room down\r\nstairs--Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s extreme illness giving her a good excuse for this.\r\nIf Mary Higgins was required as a help to Dixon in the kitchen, she was\r\nto hear and see as little of Frederick as possible; and he was, if\r\nnecessary, to be spoken of to her under the name of Mr. Dickinson. But\r\nher sluggish and incurious nature was the greatest safeguard of all.\r\n\r\nThey resolved that Martha should leave them that very afternoon for this\r\nvisit to her mother. Margaret wished that she had been sent away on the\r\nprevious day, as she fancied it might be thought strange to give a\r\nservant a holiday when her mistress\xe2\x80\x99s state required so much attendance.\r\n\r\nPoor Margaret! All that afternoon she had to act the part of a Roman\r\ndaughter, and give strength out of her own scanty stock to her father.\r\nMr. Hale would hope, would not despair, between the attacks of his\r\nwife\xe2\x80\x99s malady; he buoyed himself up in every respite from her pain, and\r\nbelieved that it was the beginning of ultimate recovery. And so, when\r\nthe paroxysms came on, each more severe than the last, they were fresh\r\nagonies, and greater disappointments to him. This afternoon, he sat in\r\nthe drawing-room, unable to bear the solitude of his study, or to employ\r\nhimself in any way. He buried his head in his arms, which lay folded on\r\nthe table. Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart ached to see him; yet, as he did not speak,\r\nshe did not like to volunteer any attempt at comfort. Martha was gone.\r\nDixon sat with Mrs. Hale while she slept. The house was very still and\r\nquiet, and darkness came on, without any movement to procure candles.\r\nMargaret sat at the window, looking out at the lamps and the street, but\r\nseeing nothing,--only alive to her father\xe2\x80\x99s heavy sighs. She did not\r\nlike to go down for lights, lest the tacit restraint of her presence\r\nbeing withdrawn, he might give way to more violent emotion, without her\r\nbeing at hand to comfort him. Yet she was just thinking that she ought\r\nto go and see after the well-doing of the kitchen fire, which there was\r\nnobody but herself to attend to, when she heard the muffled door-bell\r\nring with so violent a pull, that the wires jingled all through the\r\nhouse, though the positive sound was not great. She started up, passed\r\nher father, who had never moved at the veiled, dull sound,--returned,\r\nand kissed him tenderly. And still he never moved, nor took any notice\r\nof her fond embrace. Then she went down softly, through the dark, to the\r\ndoor. Dixon would have put the chain on before she opened it, but\r\nMargaret had not a thought of fear in her pre-occupied mind. A man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntall figure stood between her and the luminous street. He was looking\r\naway; but at the sound of the latch he turned quickly round.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in a clear, full, delicate voice.\r\n\r\nMargaret trembled all over; at first she did not answer. In a moment she\r\nsighed out,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrederick!\xe2\x80\x9d and stretched out both her hands to catch his, and draw him\r\nin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Margaret!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, holding her off by her shoulders, after they\r\nhad kissed each other, as if even in that darkness he could see her\r\nface, and read in its expression a quicker answer to his question than\r\nwords could give,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother! is she alive!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, she is alive, dear, dear brother! She--as ill as she can be she\r\nis; but alive! She is alive!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa is utterly prostrate with this great grief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou expect me, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, we have had no letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I have come before it. But my mother knows I am coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! we all knew you would come. But wait a little! Step in here. Give\r\nme your hand. What is this? Oh! your carpet-bag. Dixon has shut the\r\nshutters; but this is papa\xe2\x80\x99s study, and I can take you to a chair to\r\nrest yourself for a few minutes; while I go and tell him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe groped her way to the taper and the lucifer matches. She suddenly\r\nfelt shy when the little feeble light made them visible. All she could\r\nsee was, that her brother\xe2\x80\x99s face was unusually dark in complexion, and\r\nshe caught the stealthy look of a pair of remarkably long-cut blue eyes,\r\nthat suddenly twinkled up with a droll consciousness of their mutual\r\npurpose of inspecting each other. But though the brother and sister had\r\nan instant of sympathy in their reciprocal glances, they did not\r\nexchange a word; only, Margaret felt sure that she should like her\r\nbrother as a companion as much as she already loved him as a near\r\nrelation. Her heart was wonderfully lighter as she went up stairs; the\r\nsorrow was no less in reality, but it became less oppressive from having\r\nsome one in precisely the same relation to it as that in which she\r\nstood. Not her father\xe2\x80\x99s desponding attitude had power to damp her now.\r\nHe lay across the table, helpless as ever; but she had the spell by\r\nwhich to rouse him. She used it perhaps too violently in her own great\r\nrelief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, throwing her arms fondly round his neck; pulling his\r\nweary head up in fact with her gentle violence, till it rested in her\r\narms, and she could look into his eyes, and let them gain strength and\r\nassurance from hers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa! guess who is here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at her; she saw the idea of the truth glimmer into their filmy\r\nsadness, and be dismissed thence as a wild imagination.\r\n\r\nHe threw himself forward, and hid his face once more in his\r\nstretched-out arms, resting upon the table as heretofore. She heard him\r\nwhisper; she bent tenderly down to listen. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know; don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me\r\nit is Frederick--not Frederick. I cannot bear it,--I am too weak. And\r\nhis mother is dying!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe began to cry and wail like a child. It was so different to all which\r\nMargaret had hoped and expected, that she turned sick with\r\ndisappointment, and was silent for an instant. Then she spoke\r\nagain--very differently--not so exultingly, far more tenderly and\r\ncarefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, it is Frederick! Think of mamma, how glad she will be! And oh,\r\nfor her sake, how glad we ought to be! For his sake, too,--our poor,\r\npoor boy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer father did not change his attitude, but he seemed to be trying to\r\nunderstand the fact.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he at last, his face still hidden in his prostrate\r\narms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn your study, quite alone. I lighted the taper, and ran up to tell\r\nyou. He is quite alone, and will be wondering why--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go to him,\xe2\x80\x9d broke in her father; and he lifted himself up and\r\nleant on her arm as on that of a guide.\r\n\r\nMargaret led him to the study door, but her spirits were so agitated\r\nthat she felt she could not bear to see the meeting. She turned away,\r\nand ran up stairs, and cried most heartily. It was the first time she\r\nhad dared to allow herself this relief for days. The strain had been\r\nterrible, as she now felt. But Frederick was come! He, the one precious\r\nbrother, was there, safe, amongst them again! She could hardly believe\r\nit. She stopped her crying, and opened her bedroom door. She heard no\r\nsound of voices, and almost feared she might have dreamt. She went down\r\nstairs, and listened at the study door. She heard the buzz of voices;\r\nand that was enough. She went into the kitchen, and stirred up the fire,\r\nand lighted the house, and prepared for the wanderer\xe2\x80\x99s refreshment. How\r\nfortunate it was that her mother slept! She knew that she did, from the\r\ncandle-lighter thrust through the keyhole of her bedroom door. The\r\ntraveller could be refreshed and bright, and the first excitement of the\r\nmeeting with his father all be over, before her mother became aware of\r\nanything unusual.\r\n\r\nWhen all was ready, Margaret opened the study door, and went in like a\r\nserving-maiden, with a heavy tray held in her extended arms. She was\r\nproud of serving Frederick. But he, when he saw her, sprang up in a\r\nminute, and relieved her of her burden. It was a type, a sign, of all\r\nthe coming relief which his presence would bring. The brother and sister\r\narranged the table together, saying little, but their hands touching,\r\nand their eyes speaking the natural language of expression, so\r\nintelligible to those of the same blood. The fire had gone out; and\r\nMargaret applied herself to light it, for the evenings had begun to be\r\nchilly; and yet it was desirable to make all noises as distant as\r\npossible from Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDixon says it is a gift to light a fire; not an art to be acquired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoeta nascitur, non fit,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mr. Hale; and Margaret was glad to\r\nhear a quotation once more, however languidly given.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear old Dixon! How we shall kiss each other!\xe2\x80\x9d said Frederick. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\r\nused to kiss me, and then look in my face to be sure I was the right\r\nperson, and then set to again! But, Margaret, what a bungler you are! I\r\nnever saw such a little awkward, good-for-nothing pair of hands. Run\r\naway, and wash them, ready to cut bread-and-butter for me, and leave the\r\nfire. I\xe2\x80\x99ll manage it. Lighting fires is one of my natural\r\naccomplishments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo Margaret went away; and returned; and passed in and out of the room,\r\nin a glad restlessness that could not be satisfied with sitting still.\r\nThe more wants Frederick had, the better she was pleased; and he\r\nunderstood all this by instinct. It was a joy snatched in the house of\r\nmourning, and the zest of it was all the more pungent, because they\r\nknew in the depth of their hearts what irremediable sorrow awaited them.\r\n\r\nIn the middle, they heard Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s foot on the stairs. Mr. Hale started\r\nfrom his languid posture in his great arm-chair, from which he had been\r\nwatching his children in a dreamy way, as if they were acting some drama\r\nof happiness, which it was pretty to look at, but which was distinct\r\nfrom reality, and in which he had no part. He stood up, and faced the\r\ndoor, showing such a strange, sudden anxiety to conceal Frederick from\r\nthe sight of any person entering, even though it were the faithful\r\nDixon, that a shiver came over Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart: it reminded her of the\r\nnew fear in their lives. She caught at Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and clutched it\r\ntight, while a stern thought compressed her brow, and caused her to set\r\nher teeth. And yet they knew it was only Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s measured tread. They\r\nheard her walk the length of the passage,--into the kitchen. Margaret\r\nrose up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go to her, and tell her. And I shall hear how mamma is.\xe2\x80\x9d Mrs.\r\nHale was awake. She rambled at first; but after they had given her some\r\ntea she was refreshed, though not disposed to talk. It was better that\r\nthe night should pass over before she was told of her son\xe2\x80\x99s arrival. Dr.\r\nDonaldson\xe2\x80\x99s appointed visit would bring nervous excitement enough for\r\nthe evening; and he might tell them how to prepare her for seeing\r\nFrederick. He was there, in the house; could be summoned at any moment.\r\n\r\nMargaret could not sit still. It was a relief to her to aid Dixon in all\r\nher preparations for \xe2\x80\x9cMaster Frederick.\xe2\x80\x9d It seemed as though she never\r\ncould be tired again. Each glimpse into the room where he sate by his\r\nfather, conversing with him, about, she knew not what, nor cared to\r\nknow,--was increase of strength to her. Her own time for talking and\r\nhearing would come at last, and she was too certain of this to feel in a\r\nhurry to grasp it now. She took in his appearance and liked it. He had\r\ndelicate features, redeemed from effeminacy by the swarthiness of his\r\ncomplexion, and his quick intensity of expression. His eyes were\r\ngenerally merry-looking, but at times they and his mouth so suddenly\r\nchanged, and gave her such an idea of latent passion, that it almost\r\nmade her afraid. But this look was only for an instant; and had in it no\r\ndoggedness, no vindictiveness; it was rather the instantaneous ferocity\r\nof expression that comes over the countenances of all natives of wild or\r\nsouthern countries--a ferocity which enhances the charm of the childlike\r\nsoftness into which such a look may melt away. Margaret might fear the\r\nviolence of the impulsive nature thus occasionally betrayed, but there\r\nwas nothing in it to make her distrust, or recoil in the least, from the\r\nnew-found brother. On the contrary, all their intercourse was peculiarly\r\ncharming to her from the very first. She knew then how much\r\nresponsibility she had had to bear, from the exquisite sensation of\r\nrelief which she felt in Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s presence. He understood his father\r\nand mother--their characters and their weaknesses, and went along with a\r\ncareless freedom, which was yet most delicately careful not to hurt or\r\nwound any of their feelings. He seemed to know instinctively when a\r\nlittle of the natural brilliancy of his manner and conversation would\r\nnot jar on the deep depression of his father, or might relieve his\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s pain. Whenever it would have been out of tune, and out of time,\r\nhis patient devotion and watchfulness came into play, and made him an\r\nadmirable nurse. Then Margaret was almost touched into tears by the\r\nallusions which he often made to their childish days in the New Forest;\r\nhe had never forgotten her--or Helstone either--all the time he had been\r\nroaming among distant countries and foreign people. She might talk to\r\nhim of the old spot, and never feared tiring him. She had been afraid of\r\nhim before he came, even while she had longed for his coming; seven or\r\neight years had, she felt, produced such great changes in herself that,\r\nforgetting how much of the original Margaret was left, she had reasoned\r\nthat if her tastes and feelings had so materially altered, even in her\r\nstay-at-home life, his wild career, with which she was but imperfectly\r\nacquainted, must have almost substituted another Frederick for the tall\r\nstripling in his middy\xe2\x80\x99s uniform, whom she remembered looking up to with\r\nsuch admiring awe. But in their absence they had grown nearer to each\r\nother in age, as well as in many other things. And so it was that the\r\nweight, this sorrowful time, was lightened to Margaret. Other light than\r\nthat of Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s presence she had none. For a few hours, the mother\r\nrallied on seeing her son. She sate with his hand in hers; she would not\r\npart with it even while she slept; and Margaret had to feed him like a\r\nbaby, rather than he should disturb her mother by removing a finger.\r\nMrs. Hale wakened while they were thus engaged; she slowly moved her\r\nhead round on the pillow, and smiled at her children, as she understood\r\nwhat they were doing, and why it was done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very selfish,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it will not be for long.\xe2\x80\x9d Frederick\r\nbent down and kissed the feeble hand that imprisoned his.\r\n\r\nThis state of tranquility could not endure for many days, nor perhaps\r\nfor many hours; so Dr. Donaldson assured Margaret. After the kind doctor\r\nhad gone away, she stole down to Frederick, who, during the visit, had\r\nbeen adjured to remain quietly concealed in the back parlour, usually\r\nDixon\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom, but now given up to him.\r\n\r\nMargaret told him what Dr. Donaldson said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is very ill; she may be\r\ndangerously ill, and in immediate danger, too; but I can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine that\r\nshe could be as she is, if she were on the point of death. Margaret! she\r\nshould have some other advice--some London doctor. Have you never\r\nthought of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cmore than once. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe it would do\r\nany good. And, you know, we have not the money to bring any great London\r\nsurgeon down, and I am sure Dr. Donaldson is only second in skill to the\r\nvery best,--if, indeed, he is to them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrederick began to walk up and down the room impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have credit in Cadiz,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut none here, owing to this\r\nwretched change of name. Why did my father leave Helstone? That was the\r\nblunder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was no blunder,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret gloomily. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd above all possible\r\nchances, avoid letting papa hear anything like what you have just been\r\nsaying. I can see that he is tormenting himself already with the idea\r\nthat mamma would never have been ill if we had stayed at Helstone, and\r\nyou don\xe2\x80\x99t know papa\xe2\x80\x99s agonising power of self-reproach!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrederick walked away as if he were on the quarter-deck. At last he\r\nstopped right opposite to Margaret, and looked at her drooping and\r\ndesponding attitude for an instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy little Margaret!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, caressing her. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us hope as long as we\r\ncan. Poor little woman! what! is this face all wet with tears? I will\r\nhope. I will, in spite of a thousand doctors. Bear up, Margaret, and be\r\nbrave enough to hope!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret choked in trying to speak, and when she did it was very low.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must try to be meek enough to trust. Oh, Frederick! mamma was getting\r\nto love me so! And I was getting to understand her. And now comes death\r\nto snap us asunder!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, come! Let us go upstairs, and do something, rather than\r\nwaste time that may be so precious. Thinking has, many a time, made me\r\nsad, darling; but doing never did in all my life. My theory is a sort of\r\nparody on the maxim of \xe2\x80\x98Get money, my son, honestly if you can; but get\r\nmoney.\xe2\x80\x99 My precept is, \xe2\x80\x98Do something my sister, do good if you can; but,\r\nat any rate, do something.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot excluding mischief,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, smiling faintly through her\r\ntears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means. What I do exclude is the remorse afterwards. Blot your\r\nmisdeeds out (if you are particularly conscientious), by a good deed, as\r\nsoon as you can; just as we did a correct sum at school on the slate,\r\nwhere an incorrect one was only half rubbed out. It was better than\r\nwetting our sponge with our tears; both less loss of time where tears\r\nhad to be waited for, and a better effect at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf Margaret thought Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s theory rather a rough one at first, she\r\nsaw how he worked it out into continual production of kindness in fact.\r\nAfter a bad night with his mother (for he insisted on taking his turn as\r\na sitter-up) he was busy next morning before breakfast, contriving a\r\nleg-rest for Dixon, who was beginning to feel the fatigues of watching.\r\nAt breakfast-time, he interested Mr. Hale with vivid, graphic, rattling\r\naccounts of the wild life he had led in Mexico, South America, and\r\nelsewhere. Margaret would have given up the effort in despair to rouse\r\nMr. Hale out of his dejection; it would even have affected herself and\r\nrendered her incapable of talking at all. But Fred, true to his theory,\r\ndid something perpetually; and talking was the only thing to be done,\r\nbesides eating, at breakfast.\r\n\r\nBefore the night of that day, Dr. Donaldson\xe2\x80\x99s opinion was proved to be\r\ntoo well founded. Convulsions came on; and when they ceased, Mrs. Hale\r\nwas unconscious. Her husband might lie by her shaking the bed with his\r\nsobs; her son\xe2\x80\x99s strong arms might lift her tenderly up into a\r\ncomfortable position; her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s hands might bathe her face; but she\r\nknew them not. She would never recognise them again, till they met in\r\nHeaven.\r\n\r\nBefore the morning came all was over.\r\n\r\nThen Margaret rose from her trembling and despondency, and became as a\r\nstrong angel of comfort to her father and brother. For Frederick had\r\nbroken down now, and all his theories were of no use to him. He cried so\r\nviolently when shut up in his little room at night, that Margaret and\r\nDixon came down in affright to warn him to be quiet: for the house\r\npartitions were but thin, and the next door neighbours might easily hear\r\nhis youthful passionate sobs, so different from the slower trembling\r\nagony of after-life, when we become inured to grief, and dare not be\r\nrebellious against the inexorable doom, knowing who it is that decrees.\r\n\r\nMargaret sate with her father in the room of the dead. If he had cried,\r\nshe would have been thankful. But he sate by the bed quite quietly;\r\nonly, from time to time, he uncovered the face, and stroked it gently,\r\nmaking a kind of soft inarticulate noise, like that of some\r\nmother-animal caressing her young. He took no notice of Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npresence. Once or twice she came up to kiss him; and he submitted to it,\r\ngiving her a little push away when she had done, as if her affection\r\ndisturbed him from his absorption in the dead. He started when he heard\r\nFrederick\xe2\x80\x99s cries, and shook his head:--\xe2\x80\x9cPoor boy! poor boy!\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\nand then took no more notice. Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart ached within her. She\r\ncould not think of her own loss in thinking of her father\xe2\x80\x99s case. The\r\nnight was wearing away, and the day was at hand, when, without a word of\r\npreparation, Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s voice broke upon the stillness of the room, with\r\na clearness of sound that startled even herself: \xe2\x80\x9cLet not your heart be\r\ntroubled,\xe2\x80\x9d it said; and she went steadily on through all that chapter of\r\nunspeakable consolation.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXI.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSHOULD AULD ACQUAINTANCE BE FORGOT.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cShow not that manner, and these features all,\r\n     The serpent\xe2\x80\x99s cunning, and the sinner\xe2\x80\x99s fall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                          CRABBE.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe chill, shivery October morning came; not the October morning of the\r\ncountry, with soft, silvery mists, clearing off before the sunbeams that\r\nbring out all the gorgeous beauty of colouring, but the October morning\r\nof Milton, whose silvery mists were heavy fogs, and where the sun could\r\nonly show long dusky streets when he did break through and shine.\r\nMargaret went languidly about, assisting Dixon in her task of arranging\r\nthe house. Her eyes were continually blinded by tears, but she had no\r\ntime to give way to regular crying. The father and brother depended\r\nupon her; while they were giving way to grief, she must be working,\r\nplanning, considering. Even the necessary arrangements for the funeral\r\nseemed to devolve upon her.\r\n\r\nWhen the fire was bright and crackling--when everything was ready for\r\nbreakfast, and the tea-kettle was singing away, Margaret gave a last\r\nlook round the room before going to summon Mr. Hale and Frederick. She\r\nwanted everything to look as cheerful as possible; and yet, when it did\r\nso, the contrast between it and her own thoughts forced her into sudden\r\nweeping. She was kneeling by the sofa, hiding her face in the cushions\r\nthat no one might hear her cry, when she was touched on the shoulder by\r\nDixon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Miss Hale--come, my dear! You must not give way, or where shall\r\nwe all be? There is not another person in the house fit to give a\r\ndirection of any kind, and there is so much to be done. There\xe2\x80\x99s who\xe2\x80\x99s to\r\nmanage the funeral; and who\xe2\x80\x99s to come to it; and where it\xe2\x80\x99s to be; and\r\nall to be settled: and Master Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s like one crazed with crying,\r\nand master never was a good one for settling; and, poor gentleman, he\r\ngoes about now as if he was lost. It\xe2\x80\x99s bad enough, my dear, I know; but\r\ndeath comes to us all; and you\xe2\x80\x99re well off never to have lost any friend\r\ntill now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPerhaps so. But this seemed a loss by itself; not to bear comparison\r\nwith any other event in the world. Margaret did not take any comfort\r\nfrom what Dixon said, but the unusual tenderness of the prim old\r\nservant\xe2\x80\x99s manner touched her to the heart; and, more from a desire to\r\nshow her gratitude for this than for any other reason, she roused\r\nherself up, and smiled in answer to Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s anxious look at her; and\r\nwent to tell her father and brother that breakfast was ready.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale came--as if in a dream, or rather with the unconscious motion\r\nof a sleep-walker, whose eyes and mind perceive other things than what\r\nare present. Frederick came briskly in, with a forced cheerfulness,\r\ngrasped her hand, looked into her eyes and burst into tears. She had to\r\ntry and think of little nothings to say all breakfast-time, in order to\r\nprevent the recurrence of her companions\xe2\x80\x99 thoughts too strongly to the\r\nlast meal they had taken together, when there had been a continual\r\nstrained listening for some sound or signal from the sick-room.\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast, she resolved to speak to her father about the funeral.\r\nHe shook his head, and assented to all she proposed, though many of her\r\npropositions absolutely contradicted one another. Margaret gained no\r\nreal decision from him; and was leaving the room languidly, to have a\r\nconsultation with Dixon, when Mr. Hale motioned her back to his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk Mr. Bell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a hollow voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bell!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, a little surprised. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bell of Oxford?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bell,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cYes. He was my groom\xe2\x80\x99s-man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret understood the association.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will write to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. He sank again into listlessness. All\r\nmorning she toiled on, longing for rest, but in a continual whirl of\r\nmelancholy business.\r\n\r\nTowards evening Dixon said to her:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve done it, miss. I was really afraid for master, that he\xe2\x80\x99d have a\r\nstroke with grief. He\xe2\x80\x99s been all this day with poor missus; and when\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve listened at the door, I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard him talking to her, and talking to\r\nher, as if she was alive. When I went in he would be quite quiet, but\r\nall in a maze like. So I thought to myself, he ought to be roused; and\r\nif it gives him a shock at first, it will, maybe, be the better for him\r\nafterwards. So I\xe2\x80\x99ve been and told him, that I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it\xe2\x80\x99s safe for\r\nMaster Frederick to be here. And I don\xe2\x80\x99t. It was only on Tuesday, when I\r\nwas out, that I met a Southampton man--the first I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen since I came\r\nto Milton; they don\xe2\x80\x99t make their way much up here, I think. Well, it was\r\nyoung Leonards, old Leonards the draper\xe2\x80\x99s son, as great a scamp as ever\r\nlived--who plagued his father almost to death, and then ran off to sea.\r\nI never could abide him. He was in the Orion at the same time as\r\nFrederick, I know; though I don\xe2\x80\x99t recollect if he was there at the\r\nmutiny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he know you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that\xe2\x80\x99s the worst of it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe he would have known me but\r\nfor my being such a fool as to call out his name. He were a Southampton\r\nman, in a strange place, or else I should never have been so ready to\r\ncall cousins with him, a nasty, good-for-nothing-fellow. Says he, \xe2\x80\x98Miss\r\nDixon! who would ha\xe2\x80\x99 thought of seeing you here? But perhaps I mistake,\r\nand you\xe2\x80\x99re Miss Dixon no longer?\xe2\x80\x99 So I told him he might still address\r\nme as an unmarried lady, though if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been so particular, I\xe2\x80\x99d had\r\ngood chances of matrimony. He was polite enough: \xe2\x80\x98He couldn\xe2\x80\x99t look at me\r\nand doubt me.\xe2\x80\x99 But I were not to be caught with such chaff from such a\r\nfellow as him, and so I told him; and, by way of being even, I asked him\r\nafter his father (who I knew had turned him out of doors), as if they\r\nwere the best friends as ever was. So then, to spite me--for you see we\r\nwere getting savage, for all we were so civil to each other--he began to\r\ninquire after Master Frederick, and said, what a scrape he\xe2\x80\x99d got into\r\n(as if Master Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s scrapes would ever wash George Leonards white,\r\nor make \xe2\x80\x99em look otherwise than nasty, dirty black), and how he\xe2\x80\x99d be\r\nhung for mutiny if ever he were caught, and how a hundred pound reward\r\nhad been offered for catching him, and what a disgrace he had been to\r\nhis family--all to spite me, you see, my dear, because before now I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nhelped old Mr. Leonards to give George a good rating, down in\r\nSouthampton. So I said, there were other families as I knew, who had far\r\nmore cause to blush for their sons, and to be thankful if they could\r\nthink they were earning an honest living far away from home. To which he\r\nmade answer, like the impudent chap he is, that he were in a\r\nconfidential situation, and if I knew of any young man who had been so\r\nunfortunate as to lead vicious courses, and wanted to turn steady, he\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nhave no objection to lend him his patronage. He, indeed! Why, he\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ncorrupt a saint. I\xe2\x80\x99ve not felt so bad myself for years as when I were\r\nstanding talking to him the other day. I could have cried to think I\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t spite him better, for he kept smiling in my face, as if he took\r\nall my compliments for earnest; and I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t see that he minded what I\r\nsaid in the least, while I was mad with all his speeches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you did not tell him anything about us--about Frederick?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dixon. \xe2\x80\x9cHe had never the grace to ask where I was staying;\r\nand I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have told him if he had asked. Nor did I ask him what\r\nhis precious situation was. He was waiting for a bus, and just then it\r\ndrove up, and he hailed it. But, to plague me to the last, he turned\r\nback before he got in, and said, \xe2\x80\x98If you can help me to trap Lieutenant\r\nHale, Miss Dixon, we\xe2\x80\x99ll go partners in the reward. I know you\xe2\x80\x99d like to\r\nbe my partner, now wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you? Don\xe2\x80\x99t be shy, but say yes.\xe2\x80\x99 And he\r\njumped on the bus, and I saw his ugly face leering at me with a wicked\r\nsmile to think how he\xe2\x80\x99d had the last word of plaguing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was made very uncomfortable by this account of Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you told Frederick?\xe2\x80\x9d asked she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dixon. \xe2\x80\x9cI were uneasy in my mind at knowing that bad Leonards\r\nwas in town; but there was so much else to think about that I did not\r\ndwell on it all. But when I saw master sitting so stiff, and with his\r\neyes so glazed and sad, I thought it might rouse him to have to think of\r\nMaster Frederick in hiding, he would have to go, poor fellow, before Mr.\r\nBell came.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99m not afraid of Mr. Bell; but I am afraid of this Leonards. I\r\nmust tell Frederick. What did Leonards look like?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA bad-looking fellow, I can assure you, miss. Whiskers such as I should\r\nbe ashamed to wear--they are so red. And for all he said he\xe2\x80\x99d got a\r\nconfidential situation, he was dressed in fustian just like a\r\nworking-man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was evident that Frederick must go. Go, too, when he had so\r\ncompletely vaulted into his place in the family, and promised to be such\r\na stay and staff to his father and sister. Go, when his cares for the\r\nliving mother, and sorrow for the dead, seemed to make him one of those\r\npeculiar people who are bound to us by a fellow-love for them that are\r\ntaken away. Just as Margaret was thinking all this, sitting over the\r\ndrawing-room fire--her father restless and uneasy under the pressure of\r\nthis newly-aroused fear, of which he had not as yet spoken--Frederick\r\ncame in, his brightness dimmed, but the extreme violence of his grief\r\npassed away. He came up to Margaret, and kissed her forehead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow wan you look, Margaret!\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a low voice. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have been\r\nthinking of everybody, and no one has thought of you. Lie on this\r\nsofa--there is nothing for you to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the worst,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, in a sad whisper. But she went and\r\nlay down, and her brother covered her feet with a shawl and then sate on\r\nthe ground by her side; and the two began to talk together in a subdued\r\ntone.\r\n\r\nMargaret told him all that Dixon had related of her interview with\r\nyoung Leonards. Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s lips closed with a long whew of dismay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should just like to have it out with that young fellow. A worse\r\nsailor was never on board ship--nor a much worse man either. I declare,\r\nMargaret--you know the circumstances of the whole affair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, mamma told me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, when all the sailors who were good for anything were indignant\r\nwith our captain, this fellow to curry favour--pah! And to think of his\r\nbeing here! Oh, if he\xe2\x80\x99d a notion I was within twenty miles of him, he\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nferret me out to pay all old grudges. I\xe2\x80\x99d rather anybody had the hundred\r\npounds they think I am worth than that rascal. What a pity poor old\r\nDixon could not be persuaded to give me up, and make a provision for her\r\nold age!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Frederick, hush! Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale came towards them, eager and trembling. He had overheard what\r\nthey were saying. He took Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s hand in both of his:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy boy, you must go. It is very bad--but I see you must. You have done\r\nall you could--you have been a comfort to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, papa, must he go?\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, pleading against her own\r\nconviction of necessity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI declare, I\xe2\x80\x99ve a good mind to face it out, and stand my trial. If I\r\ncould only pick up my evidence! I cannot endure the thought of being in\r\nthe power of such a blackguard as Leonards. I could almost have\r\nenjoyed--in other circumstances--this stolen visit: it has had all the\r\ncharm which the Frenchwoman attributed to forbidden pleasures.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the earliest things I can remember,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cwas your\r\nbeing in some great disgrace, Fred, for stealing apples. We had plenty\r\nof our own--trees loaded with them; but some one had told you that\r\nstolen fruit tasted sweetest, which you took au pied de la lettre, and\r\noff you went a-robbing. You have not changed your feelings much since\r\nthen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes--you must go,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mr. Hale, answering Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s question,\r\nwhich she had asked some time ago. His thoughts were fixed on one\r\nsubject, and it was an effort to him to follow the zigzag remarks of his\r\nchildren--an effort which he did not make.\r\n\r\nMargaret and Frederick looked at each other. That quick momentary\r\nsympathy would be theirs no longer if he went away. So much was\r\nunderstood through eyes that could not be put into words. Both coursed\r\nthe same thought till it was lost in sadness. Frederick shook it off\r\nfirst:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, Margaret, I was very nearly giving both Dixon and myself a\r\ngood fright this afternoon. I was in my bedroom; I had heard a ring at\r\nthe front door, but I thought the ringer must have done his business and\r\ngone away long ago; so I was on the point of making my appearance in the\r\npassage, when, as I opened my room door, I saw Dixon coming downstairs;\r\nand she frowned and kicked me into hiding again. I kept the door open,\r\nand heard a message given to some man that was in my father\xe2\x80\x99s study, and\r\nthat then went away. What could it have been? Some of the shopmen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery likely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret indifferently. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was a little quiet\r\nman who came up for orders about two o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this was not a little man--a great powerful fellow; and it was past\r\nfour when he was here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was Mr. Thornton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. They were glad to have drawn him\r\ninto the conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, a little surprised. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, little one, what did you think?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Frederick, as she did not\r\nfinish her sentence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, only,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, reddening and looking straight at him, \xe2\x80\x9cI fancied\r\nyou meant some one of a different class, not a gentleman; somebody come\r\non an errand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe looked like someone of that kind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Frederick, carelessly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ntook him for a shopman, and he turns out a manufacturer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was silent. She remembered how at first, before she knew his\r\ncharacter, she had spoken and thought of him just as Frederick was\r\ndoing. It was but a natural impression that was made upon him, and yet\r\nshe was a little annoyed by it. She was unwilling to speak; she wanted\r\nto make Frederick understand what kind of person Mr. Thornton was--but\r\nshe was tongue-tied.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale went on. \xe2\x80\x9cHe came to offer any assistance in his power, I\r\nbelieve. But I could not see him. I told Dixon to ask him if he would\r\nlike to see you--I think I asked her to find you, and you would go to\r\nhim. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has been a very agreeable acquaintance, has he not?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nFrederick, throwing the question like a ball for any one to catch who\r\nchose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA very kind friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, when her father did not answer.\r\n\r\nFrederick was silent for a time. At last he spoke:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret, it is painful to think I can never thank those who have shown\r\nyou kindness. Your acquaintances and mine must be separate. Unless,\r\nindeed, I run the chances of a court-martial, or unless you and my\r\nfather would come to Spain.\xe2\x80\x9d He threw out this last suggestion as a kind\r\nof feeler; and then suddenly made the plunge. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know how I wish\r\nyou would. I have a good position--the chance of a better,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nhe, reddening like a girl. \xe2\x80\x9cThat Dolores Barbour that I was telling you\r\nof, Margaret--I only wish you knew her; I am sure you would like--no,\r\nlove is the right word, like is so poor--you would love her, father, if\r\nyou knew her. She is not eighteen; but if she is in the same mind\r\nanother year, she is to be my wife. Mr. Barbour won\xe2\x80\x99t let us call it an\r\nengagement. But if you would come you would find friends everywhere,\r\nbesides Dolores. Think of it, father. Margaret be on my side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo--no more removals for me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cOne has cost me my wife.\r\nNo more removals in this life. She will be here; and here will I stay\r\nout my appointed time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Frederick,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9ctell us more about her. I never thought\r\nof this; but I am so glad. You will have some one to love and care for\r\nyou out there. Tell us all about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place, she is a Roman Catholic. That\xe2\x80\x99s the only objection\r\nI anticipated. But my father\xe2\x80\x99s change of opinion--nay, Margaret, don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsigh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret had reason to sigh a little more before the conversation ended.\r\nFrederick himself was Roman Catholic in fact, though not in profession\r\nas yet. This was, then, the reason why his sympathy in her extreme\r\ndistress at her father\xe2\x80\x99s leaving the church had been so faintly\r\nexpressed in his letters. She had thought it was the carelessness of a\r\nsailor; but the truth was, that even then he was himself inclined to\r\ngive up the form of religion into which had been baptized, only that his\r\nopinions were tending in exactly the opposite direction to those of his\r\nfather. How much love had to do with this change not even Frederick\r\nhimself could have told. Margaret gave up talking about this branch of\r\nthe subject at last; and, returning to the fact of the engagement, she\r\nbegan to consider it in some fresh light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut for her sake, Fred, you surely will try and clear yourself of the\r\nexaggerated charges brought against you, even if the charge of mutiny\r\nitself be true. If there were to be a court-martial, and you could find\r\nyour witnesses, you might, at any rate, show your disobedience to\r\nauthority was because that authority was unworthily exercised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale roused himself up to listen to his son\xe2\x80\x99s answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place, Margaret, who is to hunt up my witnesses? All of\r\nthem are sailors, drafted off to other ships, except those whose\r\nevidence would go for very little, as they took part or sympathised in\r\nthe affair. In the next place allow me to tell you, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\r\na court-martial is, and consider it as an assembly where justice is\r\nadministered, instead of what it really is--a court where authority\r\nweighs nine-tenths in the balance, and evidence forms only the other\r\ntenth. In such cases, evidence itself can hardly escape being influenced\r\nby the prestige of authority.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut is it not worth trying, to see how much evidence might be\r\ndiscovered and arrayed on your behalf? At present, all those who knew\r\nyou formerly, believe you guilty without any shadow of excuse. You have\r\nnever tried to justify yourself, and we have never known where to seek\r\nfor proofs of your justification.
