They both were reminded of their\r\nrecent loss, by a strange kind of shyness in their new habiliments, and\r\nin the fact that it was the first time, for many weeks, that they had\r\ndeliberately gone out together. They drew very close to each other in\r\nunspoken sympathy.\r\n\r\nNicholas was sitting by the fire-side in his accustomed corner; but he\r\nhad not his accustomed pipe. He was leaning his head upon his hand, his\r\narm resting on his knee. He did not get up when he saw them, though\r\nMargaret could read the welcome in his eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit ye down, sit ye down. Fire\xe2\x80\x99s welly out,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, giving it a\r\nvigorous poke, as if to turn attention away from himself. He was rather\r\ndisorderly, to be sure, with a black unshaven beard of several days\xe2\x80\x99\r\ngrowth, making his pale face look yet paler, and a jacket which would\r\nhave been all the better for patching.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe thought we should have a good chance of finding you, just after\r\ndinner-time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have had our sorrows too, since we saw you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay. Sorrows is more plentiful than dinners just now; I reckon, my\r\ndinner hour stretches all o\xe2\x80\x99er the day; yo\xe2\x80\x99re pretty sure of finding\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you out of work?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied shortly. What was he?\r\n\r\nGathering, gathering along the narrow street, came a hollow, measured\r\nsound; now forcing itself on their attention. Many voices were hushed\r\nand low: many steps were heard, not moving onwards, at least not with\r\nany rapidity or steadiness of motion, but as if circling round one spot.\r\nYes, there was one distinct, slow tramp of feet, which made itself a\r\nclear path through the air, and reached their ears; the measured\r\nlaboured walk of men carrying a heavy burden. He might----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t blame him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cHe felt it deeply, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillto\xe2\x80\x99 hold thy din, and let me hear the lady speak!\xe2\x80\x9d addressing\r\nherself, in no very gentle voice, to a little urchin of about a year\r\nold. She apologetically continued to Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s always mithering me\r\nfor \xe2\x80\x98daddy\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98butty\xe2\x80\x99; and I ha\xe2\x80\x99 no butties to give him, and daddy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naway, and forgotten us a\xe2\x80\x99, I think. He\xe2\x80\x99s his father\xe2\x80\x99s darling, he is,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid she, with a sudden turn of mood, and, dragging the child up to her\r\nknee, she began kissing it fondly.\r\n\r\nMargaret laid her hand on the woman\xe2\x80\x99s arm to arrest her attention. Their\r\neyes met.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor little fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, slowly; \xe2\x80\x9che _was_ his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndarling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe _is_ his father\xe2\x80\x99s darling,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, rising hastily, and\r\nstanding face to face with Margaret. Neither of them spoke for a moment\r\nor two. Then Mrs. Boucher began in a low growling tone, gathering in\r\nwildness as she went on: \xe2\x80\x9cHe _is_ his father\xe2\x80\x99s darling, I say. Poor folk\r\ncan love their childer as well as rich. Why dunno yo\xe2\x80\x99 speak? Why dun yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\nstare at me wi\xe2\x80\x99 your great pitiful eyes? Where\xe2\x80\x99s John?\xe2\x80\x9d Weak as she was,\r\nshe shook Margaret to force out an answer. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d said she,\r\nunderstanding the meaning of that tearful look. She sank back into the\r\nchair. Margaret took up the child and put him into her arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe loved him,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, shaking her head, \xe2\x80\x9che loved us a\xe2\x80\x99. We had some one\r\nto love us once. It\xe2\x80\x99s a long time ago; but when he were in life and with\r\nus he did love us, he did. He loved this babby mappen the best on us;\r\nbut he loved me and I loved him, though I was calling him five minutes\r\nagone. Are yo\xe2\x80\x99 sure he\xe2\x80\x99s dead?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, trying to get up. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nonly that he\xe2\x80\x99s ill and like to die, they may bring him round yet. I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nbut an ailing creature mysel\xe2\x80\x99--I\xe2\x80\x99ve been ailing this long time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he is dead--he is drowned!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFolk are brought round after they\xe2\x80\x99re dead-drowned. Whatten was I\r\nthinking of, to sit still when I should be stirring mysel\xe2\x80\x99? Here, whisth\r\nthee, child--whisth thee! tak\xe2\x80\x99 this, tak\xe2\x80\x99 aught to play wi\xe2\x80\x99, but dunnot\r\ncry while my heart\xe2\x80\x99s breaking! Oh, where is my strength gone to? Oh\r\nJohn--husband!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret saved her from falling by catching her in her arms. She sate\r\ndown in the rocking chair, and held the woman upon her knees, her head\r\nlying on Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder. The other children, clustered together in\r\naffright, began to understand the mystery of the scene; but the ideas\r\ncame slowly, for their brains were dull and languid of perception. They\r\nset up such a cry of despair as they guessed the truth, that Margaret\r\nknew not how to bear it. Johnny\xe2\x80\x99s cry was loudest of them all, though he\r\nknew not why he cried, poor little fellow.\r\n\r\nThe mother quivered as she lay in Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s arms. Margaret heard a\r\nnoise at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOpen it. Open it quick,\xe2\x80\x9d said she to the eldest child. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s bolted;\r\nmake no noise--be very still. Oh, papa, let them go upstairs very softly\r\nand carefully, and perhaps she will not hear them. She has\r\nfainted--that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s as well for her, poor creature,\xe2\x80\x9d said a woman following in the\r\nwake of the bearers of the dead. \xe2\x80\x9cBut yo\xe2\x80\x99re not fit to hold her. Stay,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll run fetch a pillow, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll let her down easy on the floor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis helpful neighbour was a great relief to Margaret; she was evidently\r\na stranger to the house, a new-comer in the district, indeed; but she\r\nwas so kind and thoughtful that Margaret felt she was no longer needed;\r\nand that it would be better, perhaps, to set an example of clearing the\r\nhouse, which was filled with idle, if sympathising gazers.\r\n\r\nShe looked round for Nicholas Higgins. He was not there. So she spoke to\r\nthe woman who had taken the lead in placing Mrs. Boucher on the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you give all these people a hint that they had better leave in\r\nquietness? So that when she comes round, she could only find one or two\r\nthat she knows about her. Papa, will you speak to the men, and get them\r\nto go away. She cannot breathe, poor thing, with this crowd about her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was kneeling down by Mrs. Boucher and bathing her face with\r\nvinegar; but in a few minutes she was surprised at the gush of fresh\r\nair. She looked round, and saw a smile pass between her father and the\r\nwoman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly our good friend here,\xe2\x80\x9d replied her father, \xe2\x80\x9chit on a capital\r\nexpedient for clearing the place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did \xe2\x80\x99em begone, and each take a child with \xe2\x80\x99em, and to mind that they\r\nwere orphans, and their mother a widow. It was who could do most, and\r\nthe childer are sure of a bellyful to-day, and of kindness too. Does hoo\r\nknow how he died?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret; \xe2\x80\x9cI could not tell her all at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoo mun be told because of th\xe2\x80\x99 Inquest. See! Hoo\xe2\x80\x99s coming round; shall\r\nyou or I do it? or mappen your father would be best?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; you, you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret.\r\n\r\nThey awaited her perfect recovery in silence. Then the neighbour woman\r\nsat down on the floor, and took Mrs. Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s head and shoulders on her\r\nlap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeighbour,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyour man is dead. Guess yo\xe2\x80\x99 how he died?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe were drowned,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Boucher, feebly, beginning to cry for the\r\nfirst time, at this rough probing of her sorrows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe were found drowned. He were coming home very hopeless o\xe2\x80\x99 aught on\r\nearth. He thought God could na be harder than men; mappen not so hard;\r\nmappen as tender as a mother; mappen tenderer. I\xe2\x80\x99m not saying he did\r\nright, and I\xe2\x80\x99m not saying he did wrong. Who will take up\r\nyour cause?\xe2\x80\x9d The widow opened her eyes wide, and looked at the new\r\nspeaker, of whose presence she had not been aware till then.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho has promised to be a father to the fatherless?\xe2\x80\x9d continued he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x99ve getten six children, sir, and the eldest not eight years of\r\nage. I\xe2\x80\x99m not meaning for to doubt His power, sir,--only it needs a deal\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 trust\xe2\x80\x9d; and she began to cry afresh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoo\xe2\x80\x99ll be better able to talk to-morrow, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the neighbour.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBest comfort now would be the feel of a child at her heart. I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry\r\nthey took the babby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go for it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. And in a few minutes she returned,\r\ncarrying Johnnie, his face all smeared with eating, and his hands loaded\r\nwith treasures in the shape of shells, and bits of crystal, and the head\r\nof a plaster figure. She placed him on his mother\xe2\x80\x99s arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere!\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, \xe2\x80\x9cnow you go. They\xe2\x80\x99ll cry together, and comfort\r\ntogether, better nor any one but a child can do. I\xe2\x80\x99ll stop with her as\r\nlong as I\xe2\x80\x99m needed, and if you come to-morrow, you\xe2\x80\x99 can have a deal o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwise talk with her, that she\xe2\x80\x99s not up to to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Margaret and her father went slowly up the street, she paused at\r\nHiggins\xe2\x80\x99s closed door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we go in?\xe2\x80\x9d asked her father. \xe2\x80\x9cI was thinking of him too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey knocked. There was no answer, so they tried the door. It was\r\nbolted, but they thought they heard him moving within.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. There was no answer, and they might have gone\r\naway, believing the house to be empty, if there had not been some\r\naccidental fall, as of a book, within.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNicholas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret again. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is only us. Won\xe2\x80\x99t you let us come\r\nin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI spoke as plain as I could, \xe2\x80\x99bout using words, when I\r\nbolted th\xe2\x80\x99 door. Let me be, this day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale would have urged their desire, but Margaret placed her finger\r\non his lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t wonder at it,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI myself long to be alone. It seems\r\nthe only thing to do one good after a day like this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVII.\r\n\r\nLOOKING SOUTH.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cA spade! a rake! a hoe!\r\n      A pickaxe or a bill!\r\n    A hook to reap, or a scythe to mow,\r\n      A flail or what ye will--\r\n    And here\xe2\x80\x99s a ready hand\r\n      To ply the needful tool,\r\n    And skill\xe2\x80\x99d enough, by lessons rough,\r\n      In Labour\xe2\x80\x99s rugged school.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              HOOD.\r\n\r\n\r\nHiggins\xe2\x80\x99s door was locked the next day, when they went to pay their call\r\non the widow Boucher: but they learnt this time from an officious\r\nneighbour, that he was really from home. He had, however, been in to see\r\nMrs. Boucher, before starting on his day\xe2\x80\x99s business, whatever that was.\r\nIt was but an unsatisfactory visit to Mrs. Boucher; she considered\r\nherself an ill-used woman by her poor husband\xe2\x80\x99s suicide; and there was\r\nquite germ of truth enough in this idea to make it a very difficult one\r\nto refute. Still, it was unsatisfactory to see how completely her\r\nthoughts were turned upon herself and her own position, and this\r\nselfishness extended even to her relations with her children, whom she\r\nconsidered as incumbrances, even in the very midst of her somewhat\r\nanimal affection for them. Margaret tried to make acquaintances with one\r\nor two of them, while her father strove to raise the widow\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts\r\ninto some higher channel than that of mere helpless querulousness. She\r\nfound that the children were truer and simpler mourners than the widow.\r\nDaddy had been a kind daddy to them; each could tell, in their eager\r\nstammering way, of some tenderness shown, some indulgence granted by the\r\nlost father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs yon thing upstairs really him? it doesna look like him. I\xe2\x80\x99m feared\r\non it, and I never was feared o\xe2\x80\x99 daddy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart bled to hear that the mother, in her selfish\r\nrequirement of sympathy, had taken her children upstairs to see their\r\ndead disfigured father. It was intermingling the coarseness of horror\r\nwith the profoundness of natural grief. She tried to turn their thoughts\r\nin some other direction; on what they could do for mother; on what--for\r\nthis was a more efficacious way of putting it--what father would have\r\nwished them to do. Margaret was more successful than Mr. Hale in her\r\nefforts. The children seeing their little duties lie in action close\r\naround them, began to try each one to do something that she suggested\r\ntowards redding up the slatternly room. But her father set too high a\r\nstandard, and too abstract a view, before the indolent invalid. She\r\ncould not rouse her torpid mind into any vivid imagination of what her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s misery might have been, before he had resorted to the last\r\nterrible step; she could only look upon it as it affected herself; she\r\ncould not enter into the enduring mercy of the God who had not\r\nspecially interposed to prevent the water from drowning her prostrate\r\nhusband; and although she was secretly blaming her husband for having\r\nfallen into such drear despair, and denying that he had any excuse for\r\nhis last rash act, she was inveterate in her abuse of all who could by\r\nany possibility be supposed to have driven him to such desperation. The\r\nmasters--Mr. Thornton in particular, whose mill had been attacked by\r\nBoucher, and who, after the warrant had been issued for his apprehension\r\non the charge of rioting, had caused it to be withdrawn,--the Union, of\r\nwhich Higgins was a representative to the poor woman,--the children so\r\nnumerous, so hungry, and so noisy--all made up one great army of\r\npersonal enemies, whose fault it was that she was now a helpless widow.\r\n\r\nMargaret heard enough of this unreasonableness to dishearten her; and\r\nwhen they came away she found it impossible to cheer her father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the town life,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cTheir nerves are quickened by the\r\nhaste and bustle and speed of everything around them, to say nothing of\r\nthe confinement in these pent-up houses, which of itself is enough to\r\ninduce depression and worry of spirits. Now in the country, people live\r\nso much more out of doors, even children, and even in the winter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut people must live in towns. And in the country some get such\r\nstagnant habits of mind that they are almost fatalists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I acknowledge that. I suppose each mode of life produces its own\r\ntrials and its own temptations. The dweller in towns must find it as\r\ndifficult to be patient, as the country-bred man must find it to be\r\nactive, and equal to unwonted emergencies. Both must find it hard to\r\nrealise a future of any kind; the one because the present is so living\r\nand hurrying and close around him; the other because his life tempts him\r\nto revel in the mere sense of animal existence, not knowing of, and\r\nconsequently not caring for any pungency of pleasure, for the attainment\r\nof which he can plan, and deny himself and look forward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thus both the necessity for engrossment, and the stupid content in\r\nthe present, produce the same effects. But this poor Mrs. Boucher! how\r\nlittle we can do for her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet we dare not leave her without our efforts, although they may\r\nseem so useless. Oh papa! it\xe2\x80\x99s a hard world to live in!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it is, my child. We feel it so just now, at any rate; but we have\r\nbeen very happy, even in the midst of our sorrow. What a pleasure\r\nFrederick\xe2\x80\x99s visit was!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that it was,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, brightly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was such a charming,\r\nsnatched, forbidden thing.\xe2\x80\x9d But she suddenly stopped speaking. She had\r\nspoiled the remembrance of Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s visit to herself by her own\r\ncowardice. Of all faults the one she most despised in others was the\r\nwant of bravery; the meanness of heart which leads to untruth. And here\r\nhad she been guilty of it! Then came the thought of Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncognisance of her falsehood. She wondered if she should have minded\r\ndetection half so much from any one else. She tried herself in\r\nimagination with her Aunt Shaw and Edith; with her father; with Captain\r\nand Mr. Lennox; with Frederick. The thought of the last knowing what she\r\nhad done, even in his own behalf, was the most painful, for the brother\r\nand sister were in the first flush of their mutual regard and love; but\r\neven any fall in Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s opinion was as nothing to the shame, the\r\nshrinking shame she felt at the thought of meeting Mr. Thornton again.\r\nAnd yet she longed to see him, to get it over; to understand where she\r\nstood in his opinion. Her cheeks burnt as she recollected how proudly\r\nshe had implied an objection to trade (in the early days of their\r\nacquaintance), because it too often led to the deceit of passing off\r\ninferior for superior goods, in the one branch; of assuming credit for\r\nwealth and resources not possessed, in the other. She remembered Mr.\r\nThornton\xe2\x80\x99s look of calm disdain, as in few words he gave her to\r\nunderstand that, in the great scheme of commerce, all dishonourable ways\r\nof acting were sure to prove injurious in the long run, and that,\r\ntesting such actions simply according to the poor standard of success,\r\nthere was folly and not wisdom in all such, and every kind of deceit in\r\ntrade, as well as in other things. She remembered--she, then strong in\r\nher own untempted truth--asking him, if he did not think that buying in\r\nthe cheapest and selling in the dearest market proved some want of the\r\ntransparent justice which is so intimately connected with the idea of\r\ntruth: and she had used the word chivalric--and her father had corrected\r\nher with the higher word, Christian; and so drawn the argument upon\r\nhimself, while she sate silent by with a slight feeling of contempt.\r\n\r\nNo more contempt for her!--no more talk about the chivalric!\r\nHenceforward she must feel humiliated and disgraced in his sight. But\r\nwhen should she see him? Her heart leaped up in apprehension at every\r\nring of the door-bell; and yet, when it fell down to calmness, she felt\r\nstrangely saddened and sick at heart at each disappointment. It was very\r\nevident that her father expected to see him, and was surprised that he\r\ndid not come. The truth was, that there were points in their\r\nconversation the other night on which they had no time then to enlarge;\r\nbut it had been understood that if possible on the succeeding\r\nevening--if not then, at least the very first evening that Mr. Thornton\r\ncould command,--they should meet for further discussion. Mr. Hale had\r\nlooked forward to this meeting ever since they had parted. He had not\r\nyet resumed the instruction to his pupils, which he had relinquished at\r\nthe commencement of his wife\xe2\x80\x99s more serious illness, so he had fewer\r\noccupations than usual; and the great interest of the last day or so\r\n(Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s suicide) had driven him back with more eagerness than ever\r\nupon his speculations. He was restless all the evening. He kept saying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI quite expected to have seen Mr. Thornton. I think the messenger who\r\nbrought the book last night must have had some note, and forgot to\r\ndeliver it. Do you think there has been any message left to-day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go and inquire, papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, after the changes on these\r\nsentences had been rung once or twice, \xe2\x80\x9cStay, there\xe2\x80\x99s a ring!\xe2\x80\x9d She sat\r\ndown instantly, and bent her head attentively over her work. She heard a\r\nstep on the stairs, but it was only one, and she knew it was Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nShe lifted up her head and sighed, and believed she felt glad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s that Higgins, sir. He wants to see you, or else Miss Hale. Or it\r\nmight be Miss Hale first, and then you, sir; for he\xe2\x80\x99s in a strange kind\r\nof way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe had better come up here, Dixon; and then he can see us both, and\r\nchoose which he likes for his listener.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! very well, sir. I\xe2\x80\x99ve no wish to hear what he\xe2\x80\x99s got to say, I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsure; only, if you could see his shoes, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you\xe2\x80\x99d say the kitchen\r\nwas the fitter place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe can wipe them, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. So Dixon flung off, to bid\r\nhim walk up-stairs. She was a little mollified, however, when he looked\r\nat his feet with a hesitating air; and then, sitting down on the bottom\r\nstair, he took off the offending shoes, and without a word walked\r\nup-stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSarvant, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, slicking his hair down when he came into the\r\nroom: \xe2\x80\x9cIf hoo\xe2\x80\x99l excuse me (looking at Margaret) for being i\xe2\x80\x99 my\r\nstockings; I\xe2\x80\x99se been tramping a\xe2\x80\x99 day, and streets is none o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncleanest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret thought that fatigue might account for the change in his\r\nmanner, for he was unusually quiet and subdued; and he had evidently\r\nsome difficulty in saying what he came to say.\r\n\r\nMr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s ever-ready sympathy with anything of shyness or hesitation,\r\nor want of self-possession, made him come to his aid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall have tea up directly, and then you\xe2\x80\x99ll take a cup with us, Mr.\r\nHiggins. I am sure you are tired, if you\xe2\x80\x99ve been out much this wet\r\nrelaxing day. Margaret, my dear, can\xe2\x80\x99t you hasten tea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret could only hasten tea by taking the preparation of it into her\r\nown hands, and so offending Dixon, who was emerging out of her sorrow\r\nfor her late mistress into a very touchy, irritable state. But Martha,\r\nlike all who came in contact with Margaret--even Dixon herself, in the\r\nlong run--felt it a pleasure and an honour to forward any of her wishes;\r\nand her readiness, and Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s sweet forbearance, soon made Dixon\r\nashamed of herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy master and you must always be asking the lower classes up-stairs,\r\nsince we came to Milton, I cannot understand. Folk at Helstone were\r\nnever brought higher than the kitchen; and I\xe2\x80\x99ve let one or two of them\r\nknow before now that they might think it an honour to be even there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHiggins found it easier to unburden himself to one than to two. After\r\nMargaret left the room, he went to the door and assured himself that it\r\nwas shut. Then he came and stood close to Mr. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaster,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyo\xe2\x80\x99d not guess easy what I\xe2\x80\x99ve been tramping after\r\nto-day. Special if yo\xe2\x80\x99d remember my manner o\xe2\x80\x99 talk yesterday. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\na seeking work. I have,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI said to mysel\xe2\x80\x99, I\xe2\x80\x99d keep a civil\r\ntongue in my head, let who would say what \xe2\x80\x99em would. I\xe2\x80\x99d set my teeth\r\ninto my tongue sooner nor speak i\xe2\x80\x99 haste. For that man\xe2\x80\x99s sake--yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\nunderstand,\xe2\x80\x9d jerking his thumb back in some unknown direction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, seeing he waited for some kind of assent,\r\nand completely bewildered as to who \xe2\x80\x9cthat man\xe2\x80\x9d could be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat chap as lies theer,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with another jerk. \xe2\x80\x9cHim as went and\r\ndrownded himself, poor chap! I did na think he\xe2\x80\x99d got it in him to lie\r\nstill and let the water creep o\xe2\x80\x99er him till he died. Boucher, yo\xe2\x80\x99 know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cGo back to what you were saying:\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d not speak in haste----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor his sake. Yet not for his sake; for where\xe2\x80\x99er he is, and whate\xe2\x80\x99er,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99ll ne\xe2\x80\x99er know other clemming or cold again; but for the wife\xe2\x80\x99s sake,\r\nand the bits o\xe2\x80\x99 childer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, starting up; then, calming down, he\r\nsaid, breathlessly, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean? Tell me out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have telled yo\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d said Higgins, a little surprised at Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nagitation. \xe2\x80\x9cI would na ask for work for mysel\xe2\x80\x99; but them\xe2\x80\x99s left as a\r\ncharge on me. I reckon, I would ha guided Boucher to a better end; but I\r\nset him off o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 road, and so I mun answer for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale got hold of Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s hand and shook it heartily, without\r\nspeaking. Higgins looked awkward and ashamed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTheer, theer, master! Theer\xe2\x80\x99s ne\xe2\x80\x99er a man, to call a man, amongst us,\r\nbut what would do th\xe2\x80\x99 same; ay, and better too; for, belie\xe2\x80\x99 me, Is\xe2\x80\x99e\r\nne\xe2\x80\x99er got a stroke o\xe2\x80\x99 work, nor yet a sight of any. For all I telled\r\nHamper that, let alone his pledge--which I would not sign--no, I could\r\nna, not e\xe2\x80\x99en for this--he\xe2\x80\x99d ne\xe2\x80\x99er ha\xe2\x80\x99 such a worker on his mill as I\r\nwould be--he\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 none o\xe2\x80\x99 me--no more would none o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 others. I\xe2\x80\x99m a\r\npoor black feckless sheep--childer may clem for ought I can do, unless,\r\nparson, yo\xe2\x80\x99d help me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp you! How? I would do anything,--but what can I do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss there\xe2\x80\x9d--for Margaret had re-entered the room, and stood silent,\r\nlistening--\xe2\x80\x9chas often talked grand o\xe2\x80\x99 the South, and the ways down\r\nthere. I\xe2\x80\x99m not forty-five, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve a deal o\xe2\x80\x99 strength in\r\nme, measter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what kind of work could you do, my man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I reckon I could spade a bit----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd for that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, stepping forwards, \xe2\x80\x9cfor anything you\r\ncould do, Higgins, with the best will in the world, you would, may be,\r\nget nine shillings a week; may be ten, at the outside. Food is much the\r\nsame as here, except that you might have a little garden----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe childer could work at that,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sick o\xe2\x80\x99 Milton anyways,\r\nand Milton is sick o\xe2\x80\x99 me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must not go the South,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cfor all that. You could not\r\nstand it. You would have to be out all weathers. It would kill you with\r\nrheumatism. The mere bodily work at your time of life would break you\r\ndown. The fare is far different to what you have been accustomed to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99se nought particular about my meat,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as if offended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you\xe2\x80\x99ve reckoned on having butcher\xe2\x80\x99s meat once a day, if you\xe2\x80\x99re in\r\nwork; pay for that out of your ten shillings, and keep those poor\r\nchildren if you can. I owe it to you--since it\xe2\x80\x99s my way of talking that\r\nhas set you off on this idea--to put it all clear before you. You would\r\nnot bear the dulness of the life; you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it is; it would\r\neat you away like rust. Those that have lived there all their lives, are\r\nused to soaking in the stagnant waters. They labour on from day to day,\r\nin the great solitude of steaming fields--never speaking or lifting up\r\ntheir poor, bent, downcast heads. The hard spadework robs their brain of\r\nlife; the sameness of their toil deadens their imagination; they don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncare to meet to talk over thoughts and speculations, even of the\r\nweakest, wildest kind, after their work is done; they go home brutishly\r\ntired, poor creatures! caring for nothing but food and rest. You could\r\nnot stir them up into any companionship, which you get in a town as\r\nplentiful as the air you breathe, whether it be good or bad--and that I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know; but I do know, that you of all men are not one to bear a\r\nlife among such labourers. What would be peace to them, would be eternal\r\nfretting to you. Think no more of it, Nicholas, I beg. Besides, you\r\ncould never pay to get mother and children all there--that\xe2\x80\x99s one good\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve reckoned for that. One house mun do for us a\xe2\x80\x99, and the furniture\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 t\xe2\x80\x99other would go a good way. And men theer mun have their families to\r\nkeep--mappen six or seven childer. God help \xe2\x80\x99em!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, more\r\nconvinced by his own presentation of the facts than by all Margaret had\r\nsaid, and suddenly renouncing the idea, which had but recently formed\r\nitself in a brain worn out by the day\xe2\x80\x99s fatigue and anxiety. \xe2\x80\x9cGod help\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em! North an\xe2\x80\x99 South have each getten their own troubles. If work\xe2\x80\x99s sure\r\nand steady theer, labour\xe2\x80\x99s paid at starvation wages; while here we\xe2\x80\x99n\r\nrucks o\xe2\x80\x99 money coming in one quarter, and ne\xe2\x80\x99er a farthing th\xe2\x80\x99 next. For\r\nsure, th\xe2\x80\x99 world is in a confusion that passes me or any other man to\r\nunderstand; it needs fettling, and who\xe2\x80\x99s to fettle it if it\xe2\x80\x99s as yon\r\nfolks say, and there\xe2\x80\x99s nought but what we see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Hale was busy cutting bread and butter; Margaret was glad of this,\r\nfor she saw that Higgins was better left to himself: that if her father\r\nbegan to speak ever so mildly on the subject of Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts, the\r\nlatter would consider himself challenged to an argument, and would feel\r\nhimself bound to maintain his own ground. She and her father kept up an\r\nindifferent conversation until Higgins, scarcely aware whether he ate or\r\nnot, had made a very substantial meal. Then he pushed his chair away\r\nfrom the table, and tried to take an interest in what they were saying;\r\nbut it was of no use; and he fell back into dreamy gloom. Suddenly,\r\nMargaret said (she had been thinking of it for some time, but the words\r\nhad stuck in her throat), \xe2\x80\x9cHiggins have you been to Marlborough Mills to\r\nseek for work?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThornton\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he. \xe2\x80\x9cAy, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been at Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did he say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch a chap as me is not like to see the measter. Th\xe2\x80\x99 o\xe2\x80\x99erlooker bid me\r\ngo and be d----d.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you had seen Mr. Thornton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cHe might not have\r\ngiven you work, but he would not have used such language.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to th\xe2\x80\x99 language, I\xe2\x80\x99m welly used to it; it dunnot matter to me. I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nnot nesh mysel\xe2\x80\x99 when I\xe2\x80\x99m put out. It were th\xe2\x80\x99 fact that I were na wanted\r\ntheer, no more nor ony other place, as I minded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I wish you had seen Mr. Thornton,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cWould you go\r\nagain--it\xe2\x80\x99s a good deal to ask, I know--but would you go to-morrow and\r\ntry him? Those grave soft eyes of hers were difficult to\r\nresist. He gave a great sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would tax my pride above a bit; if it were for mysel\xe2\x80\x99, I could stand\r\na deal o\xe2\x80\x99 clemming first; I\xe2\x80\x99d sooner knock him down than ask a favour\r\nfrom him. I\xe2\x80\x99d a deal sooner be flogged mysel\xe2\x80\x99; but yo\xe2\x80\x99re not a common\r\nwench, axing yo\xe2\x80\x99r pardon, nor yet have yo\xe2\x80\x99 common ways about yo\xe2\x80\x99. That man has it in him to be burnt at the stake afore he\xe2\x80\x99ll give\r\nin. I\xe2\x80\x99ll do it for yo\xe2\x80\x99r sake, Miss Hale, and it\xe2\x80\x99s first time in my life\r\nas e\xe2\x80\x99er I give way to a woman. I\r\ndunnot stomach the notion of having favour curried for me, by one as\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t know the ins and outs of the quarrel. Meddling \xe2\x80\x99twixt master and\r\nman is liker meddling \xe2\x80\x99twixt husband and wife than aught else: it takes\r\na deal of wisdom to do ony good. I\xe2\x80\x99ll stand guard at the lodge door.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll stand there fro\xe2\x80\x99 six in the morning till I get speech on him. But\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d liefer sweep th\xe2\x80\x99 streets, if paupers had na\xe2\x80\x99 got hold on that work.\r\nDunna yo\xe2\x80\x99 hope, miss.
