I\r\nwonder what success he\xe2\x80\x99ll have to-morrow. If he and Mr. Thornton would\r\nspeak out together as man to man--if Higgins would forget that Mr.\r\nThornton was a master, and speak to him as he does to us--and if Mr.\r\nThornton would be patient enough to listen to him with his human heart,\r\nnot with his master\xe2\x80\x99s ears--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are getting to do Mr. Thornton justice at last, Margaret,\xe2\x80\x9d said her\r\nfather, pinching her ear.\r\n\r\nMargaret had a strange choking at her heart, which made her unable to\r\nanswer, \xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d thought she, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I were a man, that I could go and\r\nforce him to express his disapprobation, and tell him honestly that I\r\nknew I deserved it. It seems hard to lose him as a friend just when I\r\nhad begun to feel his value. How tender he was with dear mamma! If it\r\nwere only for her sake, I wish he would come, and then at least I should\r\nknow how much I was abased in his eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVIII.\r\n\r\nPROMISES FULFILLED.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThen proudly, proudly up she rose,\r\n       Tho\xe2\x80\x99 the tear was in her e\xe2\x80\x99e,\r\n     Whate\xe2\x80\x99er ye say, think what ye may,\r\n       Ye\xe2\x80\x99s get na word frae me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                   SCOTCH BALLAD.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was not merely that Margaret was known to Mr. Thornton to have spoken\r\nfalsely,--though she imagined that for this reason only was she so\r\nturned in his opinion,--but that this falsehood of hers bore a distinct\r\nreference in his mind to some other lover. He could not forget the fond\r\nand earnest look that had passed between her and some other man--the\r\nattitude of familiar confidence, if not of positive endearment. The\r\nthought of this perpetually stung him; it was a picture before his\r\neyes, wherever he went and whatever he was doing. In addition to this\r\n(and he ground his teeth as he remembered it), was the hour, dusky\r\ntwilight; the place, so far away from home, and comparatively\r\nunfrequented. His nobler self had said at first, that all this last\r\nmight be accidental, innocent, justifiable; but once allow her right to\r\nlove and be beloved (and had he any reason to deny her right?--had not\r\nher words been severely explicit when she cast his love away from her?),\r\nshe might easily have been beguiled into a longer walk, on to a later\r\nhour than she had anticipated. But that falsehood! which showed a fatal\r\nconsciousness of something wrong, and to be concealed, which was unlike\r\nher. He did her that justice, though all the time it would have been a\r\nrelief to believe her utterly unworthy of his esteem. It was this that\r\nmade the misery--that he passionately loved her, and thought her, even\r\nwith all her faults, more lovely and more excellent than any other\r\nwoman; yet he deemed her so attached to some other man, so led away by\r\nher affection for him, as to violate her truthful nature. The very\r\nfalsehood that stained her, was a proof how blindly she loved\r\nanother--this dark, slight, elegant, handsome man--while he himself was\r\nrough, and stern, and strongly made. He lashed himself into an agony of\r\nfierce jealousy. He thought of that look, that attitude!--how he would\r\nhave laid his life at her feet for such tender glances, such fond\r\ndetention! He mocked at himself, for having valued the mechanical way in\r\nwhich she had protected him from the fury of the mob; now he had seen\r\nhow soft and bewitching she looked when with a man she really loved. He\r\nremembered, point by point, the sharpness of her words--\xe2\x80\x9cThere was not a\r\nman in all that crowd for whom she would not have done as much, far more\r\nreadily than for him.\xe2\x80\x9d He shared with the mob, in her desire of averting\r\nbloodshed from them; but this man, this hidden lover, shared with\r\nnobody; he had looks, words, hand-cleavings, lies, concealment, all to\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton was conscious that he had never been so irritable as he was\r\nnow, in all his life long; he felt inclined to give a short abrupt\r\nanswer, more like a bark than a speech, to every one that asked him a\r\nquestion; and this consciousness hurt his pride: he had always piqued\r\nhimself on his self-control, and control himself he would. So the manner\r\nwas subdued to a quiet deliberation, but the matter was even harder and\r\nsterner than common. He was more than usually silent at home; employing\r\nhis evenings in a continual pace backwards and forwards, which would\r\nhave annoyed his mother exceedingly if it had been practised by any one\r\nelse; and did not tend to promote any forbearance on her part even to\r\nthis beloved son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you stop--can you sit down for a moment? I have something to say to\r\nyou, if you would give up that everlasting walk, walk, walk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe sat down instantly, on a chair against the wall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to speak to you about Betsy. She says she must leave us; that\r\nher lover\xe2\x80\x99s death has so affected her spirits she can\xe2\x80\x99t give her heart\r\nto her work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. I suppose other cooks are to be met with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s so like a man. It\xe2\x80\x99s not merely the cooking, it is that she knows\r\nall the ways of the house. Besides, she tells me something about your\r\nfriend Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Hale is no friend of mine. Mr. Hale is my friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad to hear you say so, for if she had been your friend, what\r\nBetsy says would have annoyed you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me hear it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with the extreme quietness of manner he had\r\nbeen assuming for the last few days.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetsy says, that the night on which her lover--I forget his name--for\r\nshe always calls him \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeonards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe night on which Leonards was last seen at the station--when he was\r\nlast seen on duty, in fact--Miss Hale was there, walking about with a\r\nyoung man who, Bessy believes, killed Leonards by some blow or push.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeonards was not killed by any blow or push.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I distinctly put the question to the surgeon of the Infirmary.\r\nHe told me there was an internal disease of long standing, caused by\r\nLeonards\xe2\x80\x99 habit of drinking to excess; that the fact of his becoming\r\nrapidly worse while in a state of intoxication, settled the question as\r\nto whether the last fatal attack was caused by excess of drinking, or\r\nthe fall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fall! What fall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaused by the blow or push of which Betsy speaks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen there was a blow or push?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who did it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs there was no inquest, in consequence of the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s opinion I\r\ncannot tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Miss Hale was there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd with a young man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill no answer. At last he said: \xe2\x80\x9cI tell you, mother, that there was no\r\ninquest--no inquiry. No judicial inquiry, I mean.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetsy says that Woolmer (some man she knows, who is in a grocer\xe2\x80\x99s shop\r\nout at Crampton) can swear that Miss Hale was at the station at that\r\nhour, walking backwards and forwards with a young man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see what we have to do with that. Miss Hale is at liberty to\r\nplease herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad to hear you say so,\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Thornton, eagerly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\ncertainly signifies very little to us--not at all to you, after what has\r\npassed! but I--I made a promise to Mrs. Hale, that I would not allow her\r\ndaughter to go wrong without advising and remonstrating with her. I\r\nshall certainly let her know my opinion of such conduct.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not see any harm in what she did that evening,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nThornton, getting up, and coming near to his mother; he stood by the\r\nchimney-piece with his face turned away from the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would not have approved of Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s being seen out, after dark, in\r\nrather a lonely place, walking about with a young man. I say nothing of\r\nthe taste which could choose the time, when her mother lay unburied, for\r\nsuch a promenade. Should you have liked your sister to have been noticed\r\nby a grocer\xe2\x80\x99s assistant for doing so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place, as it is not many years since I myself was a\r\ndraper\xe2\x80\x99s assistant, the mere circumstance of a grocer\xe2\x80\x99s assistant\r\nnoticing any act does not alter the character of the act to me. And in\r\nthe next place, I see a great deal of difference between Miss Hale and\r\nFanny. I can imagine that the one may have weighty reasons, which may\r\nand ought to make her overlook any seeming impropriety in her conduct. I\r\nnever knew Fanny have weighty reasons for anything. Other people must\r\nguard her. I believe Miss Hale is a guardian to herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pretty character of your sister, indeed! Really, John, one would have\r\nthought Miss Hale had done enough to make you clear-sighted. She drew\r\nyou on to an offer, by a bold display of pretended regard for you,--to\r\nplay you off against this very young man, I\xe2\x80\x99ve no doubt. Her whole\r\nconduct is clear to me now. You believe he is her lover, I suppose--you\r\nagree to that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned round to his mother; his face was very gray and grim. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\r\nmother. I do believe he is her lover.\xe2\x80\x9d When he had spoken, he turned\r\nround again; he writhed himself about, like one in bodily pain. He leant\r\nhis face against his hand. Then before she could speak, he turned sharp\r\nagain:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother. He is her lover, whoever he is; but she may need help and\r\nwomanly counsel;--there may be difficulties or temptations which I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow. I fear there are. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to know what they are; but as you\r\nhave ever been a good--ay! and a tender mother to me, go to her, and\r\ngain her confidence, and tell her what is best to be done. I know that\r\nsomething is wrong; some dread, which must be a terrible torture to\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, John!\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother, now really shocked, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do\r\nyou mean? What do you mean? What do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe did not reply to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I shan\xe2\x80\x99t think unless you speak. You have no\r\nright to say what you have done against her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot against her, mother! I _could_ not speak against her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! you have no right to say what you have done, unless you say more.\r\nThese half-expressions are what ruin a woman\xe2\x80\x99s character.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer character! Mother, you do not dare--\xe2\x80\x9d he faced about, and looked\r\ninto her face with his flaming eyes. Then, drawing himself up into\r\ndetermined composure and dignity, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI will not say any more than\r\nthis, which is neither more nor less than the simple truth, and I am\r\nsure you believe me,--I have good reason to believe, that Miss Hale is\r\nin some strait and difficulty connected with an attachment which, of\r\nitself, from my knowledge of Miss Hale\xe2\x80\x99s character, is perfectly\r\ninnocent and right. What my reason is, I refuse to tell. But never let\r\nme hear any one say a word against her, implying any more serious\r\nimputation than that she now needs the counsel of some kind and gentle\r\nwoman. You promised Mrs. Hale to be that woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton. \xe2\x80\x9cI am happy to say, I did not promise kindness\r\nand gentleness, for I felt at the time that it might be out of my power\r\nto render these to one of Miss Hale\xe2\x80\x99s character and disposition. I\r\npromised counsel and advice, such as I would give to my own daughter; I\r\nshall speak to her as I would do to Fanny, if she had gone gallivanting\r\nwith a young man in the dusk. I shall speak with relation to the\r\ncircumstances I know, without being influenced either one way or another\r\nby the \xe2\x80\x98strong reasons\xe2\x80\x99 which you will not confide to me. Then I shall\r\nhave fulfilled my promise, and done my duty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe will never bear it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he passionately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe will have to bear it, if I speak in her dead mother\xe2\x80\x99s name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, breaking away, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t tell me any more about it. I\r\ncannot endure to think of it. It will be better that you should speak to\r\nher any way, than that she should not be spoken to at all.--Oh! that\r\nlook of love!\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, between his teeth, as he bolted himself\r\ninto his own private room. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd that cursed lie; which showed some\r\nterrible shame in the background, to be kept from the light in which I\r\nthought she lived perpetually! Oh, Margaret, Margaret! Mother, how you\r\nhave tortured me! Oh! Margaret, could you not have loved me? I am but\r\nuncouth and hard, but I would never have led you into any falsehood for\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe more Mrs. Thornton thought over what her son had said, in pleading\r\nfor a merciful judgment for Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s indiscretion, the more bitterly\r\nshe felt inclined towards her. She took a savage pleasure in the idea of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cspeaking her mind\xe2\x80\x9d to her, in the guise of fulfilment of a duty. She\r\nenjoyed the thought of showing herself untouched by the \xe2\x80\x9cglamour,\xe2\x80\x9d which\r\nshe was well aware Margaret had the power of throwing over many people.\r\nShe snorted scornfully over the picture of the beauty of her victim; her\r\njet black hair, her clear smooth skin, her lucid eyes would not help to\r\nsave her one word of the just and stern reproach which Mrs. Thornton\r\nspent half the night in preparing to her mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Miss Hale within?\xe2\x80\x9d She knew she was, for she had seen her at the\r\nwindow, and she had her feet inside the little hall before Martha had\r\nhalf answered the question.\r\n\r\nMargaret was sitting alone, writing to Edith, and giving her many\r\nparticulars of her mother\xe2\x80\x99s last days. It was a softening employment,\r\nand she had to brush away the unbidden tears as Mrs. Thornton was\r\nannounced.\r\n\r\nShe was so gentle and ladylike in her mode of reception that her visitor\r\nwas somewhat daunted; and it became impossible to utter the speech, so\r\neasy of arrangement with no one to address it to. Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s low rich\r\nvoice was softer than usual; her manner more gracious, because in her\r\nheart she was feeling very grateful to Mrs. Thornton for the courteous\r\nattention of her call. She exerted herself to find subjects of interest\r\nfor conversation; praised Martha, the servant whom Mrs. Thornton had\r\nfound for them: had asked Edith for a little Greek air, about which she\r\nhad spoken to Miss Thornton. Mrs. Thornton was fairly discomfited. Her\r\nsharp Damascus blade seemed out of place, and useless among rose-leaves.\r\nShe was silent because she was trying to task herself up to her duty. At\r\nlast she stung herself into its performance by a suspicion which, in\r\nspite of all probability, she allowed to cross her mind, that all this\r\nsweetness was put on with a view of propitiating Mr. Thornton; that,\r\nsomehow, the other attachment had fallen through, and that it suited\r\nMiss Hale\xe2\x80\x99s purpose to recall her rejected lover. Poor Margaret! there\r\nwas perhaps so much truth in the suspicion as this; that Mrs. Thornton\r\nwas the mother of one whose regard she valued, and feared to have lost;\r\nand this thought unconsciously added to her natural desire of pleasing\r\none who was showing her kindness by her visit. Mrs. Thornton stood up to\r\ngo, but yet she seemed to have something more to say. She cleared her\r\nthroat and began:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Hale, I have a duty to perform. I promised your poor mother that,\r\nas far as my poor judgment went, I would not allow you to act in any way\r\nwrongly, or (she softened her speech down a little here) inadvertently,\r\nwithout remonstrating; at least without offering advice, whether you\r\ntook it or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret stood before her, blushing like any culprit, with her eyes\r\ndilating as she gazed at Mrs. Thornton. She thought she had come to\r\nspeak to her about the falsehood she had told--that Mr. Thornton had\r\nemployed her to explain the danger she had exposed herself to, of being\r\nconfuted in full court! and although her heart sank to think he had not\r\nrather chosen to come himself, and upbraid her, and receive her\r\npenitence, and restore her again to his good opinion, yet she was too\r\nmuch humbled not to bear any blame on this subject patiently and meekly.\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt first, when I heard from one of my servants, that you had been seen\r\nwalking about with a gentleman, so far from home as the Outwood station,\r\nat such a time of the evening, I could hardly believe it. But my son, I\r\nam sorry to say, confirmed her story. It was indiscreet, to say the\r\nleast; many a young woman has lost her character before now----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s eyes flashed fire. This was a new idea--this was too\r\ninsulting. If Mrs. Thornton had spoken to her about the lie she had\r\ntold, well and good--she would have owned it, and humiliated herself.\r\nBut to interfere with her conduct--to speak of her character! she--Mrs.\r\nThornton, a mere stranger--it was too impertinent! She would not answer\r\nher--not one word. Mrs. Thornton saw the battle-spirit in Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\neyes, and it called up her combativeness also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor your mother\xe2\x80\x99s sake, I have thought it right to warn you against\r\nsuch improprieties; they must degrade you in the long run in the\r\nestimation of the world, even if in fact they do not lead you to\r\npositive harm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor my mother\xe2\x80\x99s sake,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, in a tearful voice, \xe2\x80\x9cI will bear\r\nmuch; but I cannot bear everything. She never meant me to be exposed to\r\ninsult, I am sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInsult, Miss Hale!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madam,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret more steadily, \xe2\x80\x9cit is insult. What do you\r\nknow of me that should lead you to suspect--Oh!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, breaking\r\ndown, and covering her face with her hands--\xe2\x80\x9cI know now, Mr. Thornton\r\nhas told you----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Miss Hale,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton, her truthfulness causing her to\r\narrest the confession Margaret was on the point of making, though her\r\ncuriosity was itching to hear it. \xe2\x80\x9cStop. Mr. Thornton has told me\r\nnothing. You do not know my son. You are not worthy to know him. He said\r\nthis. Listen, young lady, that you may understand, if you can, what sort\r\nof a man you rejected. This Milton manufacturer, his great tender heart\r\nscorned as it was scorned, said to me only last night, \xe2\x80\x98Go to her. I\r\nhave good reason to know that she is in some strait arising out of some\r\nattachment; and she needs womanly counsel.\xe2\x80\x99 I believe those were his\r\nvery words. Farther than that--beyond admitting the fact of your being\r\nat the Outwood station with a gentleman, on the evening of the\r\ntwenty-sixth--he has said nothing--not one word against you. If he has\r\nknowledge of anything which should make you sob so, he keeps it to\r\nhimself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s face was still hidden in her hands, the fingers of which were\r\nwet with tears. Mrs. Thornton was a little mollified.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Miss Hale. There may be circumstances, I\xe2\x80\x99ll allow, that, if\r\nexplained, may take off from the seeming impropriety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill no answer. Margaret was considering what to say; she wished to\r\nstand well with Mrs. Thornton; and yet she could not, might not, give\r\nany explanation. Mrs. Thornton grew impatient.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be sorry to break off an acquaintance; but for Fanny\xe2\x80\x99s sake--as\r\nI told my son, if Fanny had done so we should consider it a great\r\ndisgrace--and Fanny might be led away----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can give you no explanation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, in a low voice. \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\ndone wrong, but not in the way you think or know about. I think Mr.\r\nThornton judges me more mercifully than you;\xe2\x80\x9d--she had hard work to keep\r\nherself from choking with her tears--\xe2\x80\x9cbut, I believe, madam, you mean to\r\ndo rightly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Thornton, drawing herself up; \xe2\x80\x9cI was not aware\r\nthat my meaning was doubted. It is the last time I shall interfere. I\r\nwas unwilling to consent to do it, when your mother asked me. I had not\r\napproved of my son\xe2\x80\x99s attachment to you, while I only suspected it. You\r\ndid not appear to me worthy of him. But when you compromised yourself as\r\nyou did at the time of the riot, and exposed yourself to the comments of\r\nservants and workpeople, I felt it was no longer right to set myself\r\nagainst my son\xe2\x80\x99s wish of proposing to you--a wish, by the way, which he\r\nhad always denied entertaining until the day of the riot.\xe2\x80\x9d Margaret\r\nwinced, and drew in her breath with a long, hissing sound; of which,\r\nhowever, Mrs. Thornton took no notice. \xe2\x80\x9cHe came; you had apparently\r\nchanged your mind. I told my son yesterday, that I thought it possible,\r\nshort as was the interval, you might have heard or learnt something of\r\nthis other lover----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat must you think of me, madam?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret, throwing her head\r\nback with proud disdain, till her throat curved outwards like a swan\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can say nothing more, Mrs. Thornton. I decline every attempt to\r\njustify myself for anything. You must allow me to leave the room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she swept out of it with the noiseless grace of an offended\r\nprincess. Mrs. Thornton had quite enough of natural humour to make her\r\nfeel the ludricrousness of the position in which she was left. There was\r\nnothing for it but to show herself out. She was not particularly annoyed\r\nat Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s way of behaving. She did not care enough for her for that.\r\nShe had taken Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s remonstrance to the full as keenly to\r\nheart as that lady expected; and Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s passion at once mollified\r\nher visitor, far more than any silence or reserve could have done. It\r\nshowed the effect of her words. \xe2\x80\x9cMy young lady,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Mrs. Thornton\r\nto herself; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve a pretty good temper of your own. If John and you\r\nhad come together, he would have had to keep a tight hand over you, to\r\nmake you know your place. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t think you will go a-walking again\r\nwith your beau, at such an hour of the day, in a hurry. You\xe2\x80\x99ve too much\r\npride and spirit in you for that. I like to see a girl fly out at the\r\nnotion of being talked about. It shows they\xe2\x80\x99re neither giddy, nor bold\r\nby nature. As for that girl, she might be bold, but she\xe2\x80\x99d never be\r\ngiddy. I\xe2\x80\x99ll do her that justice. Now as to Fanny, she\xe2\x80\x99d be giddy, and\r\nnot bold. She\xe2\x80\x99s no courage in her, poor thing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton was not spending the morning so satisfactorily as his\r\nmother. She, at any rate, was fulfilling her determined purpose. He was\r\ntrying to understand where he stood; what damage the strike had done\r\nhim. A good deal of his capital was locked up in new and expensive\r\nmachinery; and he had also bought cotton largely, with a view to some\r\ngreat orders which he had in hand. The strike had thrown him terribly\r\nbehindhand, as to the completion of these orders. Even with his own\r\naccustomed and skilled workpeople, he would have had some difficulty in\r\nfulfilling his engagements; as it was, the incompetence of the Irish\r\nhands, who had to be trained to their work, at a time requiring unusual\r\nactivity, was a daily annoyance.\r\n\r\nIt was not a favourable hour for Higgins to make his request. But he had\r\npromised Margaret to do it at any cost. So, though every moment added to\r\nhis repugnance, his pride, and his sullenness of temper, he stood\r\nleaning against the dead wall, hour after hour, first on one leg, then\r\non the other. At last the latch was sharply lifted, and out came Mr.\r\nThornton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want for to speak to yo\xe2\x80\x99, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t stay now, my man. I\xe2\x80\x99m too late as it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, I reckon I can wait till yo\xe2\x80\x99 come back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton was half way down the street. Higgins sighed. But it was no\r\nuse. To catch him in the street, was his only chance of seeing \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nmeaster!\xe2\x80\x9d if he had rung the lodge bell or even gone up to the house to\r\nask for him, he would have been referred to the overlooker. So he stood\r\nstill again, vouchsafing no answer, but a short nod of recognition to\r\nthe few men who knew and spoke to him, as the crowd drove out the\r\nmillyard at dinner-time, and scowling with all his might at the Irish\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cknobsticks\xe2\x80\x9d who had just been imported. At last Mr. Thornton returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! you there still!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, sir, I mun speak to yo\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in here, then. Stay, we\xe2\x80\x99ll go across the yard; the men are not\r\ncome back, and we shall have it to ourselves. These good people, I see,\r\nare at dinner;\xe2\x80\x9d said he, closing the door of the porter\xe2\x80\x99s lodge.\r\n\r\nHe stopped to speak to the overlooker. The latter said in a low tone:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you know, sir, that that man is Higgins, one of the leaders\r\nof the Union; he that made that speech in Hurstfield.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton, looking round sharply at his\r\nfollower. Higgins was known to him by name as a turbulent spirit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, and his tone was rougher than before. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is men\r\nsuch as this,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, \xe2\x80\x9cwho interrupt commerce and injure the very\r\ntown they live in: mere demagogues, lovers of power at whatever cost to\r\nothers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir! what do you want with me?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton, facing round\r\nat him, as soon as they were in the counting-house of the mill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy name is Higgins\xe2\x80\x9d--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know that,\xe2\x80\x9d broke in Mr. Thornton. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want, Mr. Higgins?\r\nThat\xe2\x80\x99s the question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWork! You\xe2\x80\x99re a pretty chap to come asking me for work. You don\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nimpudence, that\xe2\x80\x99s very clear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve getten enemies and backbiters, like my betters; but I ne\xe2\x80\x99er heerd\r\no\xe2\x80\x99 ony of them calling me o\xe2\x80\x99er-modest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Higgins. His blood was a\r\nlittle roused by Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s manner, more than by his words.\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton saw a letter addressed to himself on the table. He took it\r\nup and read it through. At the end, he looked up and said, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you\r\nwaiting for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn answer to th\xe2\x80\x99 question I axed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI gave it you before. Don\xe2\x80\x99t waste any more of your time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99 made a remark, sir, on my impudence\xe2\x80\x99 but I were taught that it was\r\nmanners to say either \xe2\x80\x98yes\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98no,\xe2\x80\x99 when I were axed a civil question.\r\nI should be thankfu\xe2\x80\x99 to yo\xe2\x80\x99 if yo\xe2\x80\x99d give me work. Hamper will speak to\r\nmy being a good hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve a notion you\xe2\x80\x99d better not send me to Hamper to ask for a\r\ncharacter, my man. I might hear more than you\xe2\x80\x99d like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d take th\xe2\x80\x99 risk. Worst they could say of me is, that I did what I\r\nthought best, even to my own wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better go and try them, then, and see whether they\xe2\x80\x99ll give you\r\nwork. I\xe2\x80\x99ve turned off upwards of a hundred of my best hands, for no\r\nother fault than following you and such as you; and d\xe2\x80\x99ye think I\xe2\x80\x99ll take\r\nyou on? I might as well put a fire-brand into the midst of the\r\ncotton-waste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHiggins turned away: then the recollection of Boucher came over him, and\r\nhe faced round with the greatest concession he could persuade himself to\r\nmake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d promise yo\xe2\x80\x99, measter, I\xe2\x80\x99d not speak a word as could do harm, if so\r\nbe yo\xe2\x80\x99 did right by us; and I\xe2\x80\x99d promise more: I\xe2\x80\x99d promise that when I\r\nseed yo\xe2\x80\x99 going wrong, and acting unfair, I\xe2\x80\x99d speak to yo\xe2\x80\x99 in private\r\nfirst; and that would be a fair warning. If yo\xe2\x80\x99 and I did na agree in\r\nour opinion o\xe2\x80\x99 your conduct, yo\xe2\x80\x99 might turn me off at an hour\xe2\x80\x99s notice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word, you don\xe2\x80\x99t think small beer of yourself! Hamper has had a\r\nloss of you. How came he to let you and your wisdom go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we parted wi\xe2\x80\x99 mutual dissatisfaction. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t gi\xe2\x80\x99e the pledge\r\nthey were asking; and they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have me at no rate. So I\xe2\x80\x99m free to\r\nmake another engagement; and as I said before, though I should na\xe2\x80\x99 say\r\nit, I\xe2\x80\x99m a good hand, measter, and a steady man--specially when I can\r\nkeep fro\xe2\x80\x99 drink; and that I shall do now, if I ne\xe2\x80\x99er did afore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat you may have more money laid up for another strike, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! I\xe2\x80\x99d be thankful if I was free to do that; it\xe2\x80\x99s for to keep th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwidow and childer of a man who was drove mad by them knobsticks o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyourn; put out of his place by a Paddy that did na know weft fro\xe2\x80\x99 warp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! you\xe2\x80\x99d better turn to something else, if you\xe2\x80\x99ve any such good\r\nintention in your head. I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t advise you to stay in Milton: you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\ntoo well known here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it were summer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Higgins, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d take to Paddy\xe2\x80\x99s work, and go as\r\na navvy, or haymaking, or summat, and ne\xe2\x80\x99er see Milton again. But it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwinter, and th\xe2\x80\x99 childer will clem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pretty navvy you\xe2\x80\x99d make! why you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do half a day\xe2\x80\x99s work at\r\ndigging against an Irishman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d only charge half-a-day for th\xe2\x80\x99 twelve hours, if I could only do\r\nhalf-a-day\xe2\x80\x99s work in th\xe2\x80\x99 time. Yo\xe2\x80\x99re not knowing of any place, where\r\nthey could gi\xe2\x80\x99 me a trial, away fro\xe2\x80\x99 the mills, if I\xe2\x80\x99m such a firebrand?\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d take any wage they thought I was worth, for the sake of those\r\nchilder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you see what you would be? You\xe2\x80\x99d be a knobstick. You\xe2\x80\x99d be taking\r\nless wages than the other labourers--all for the sake of another man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchildren. Think how you\xe2\x80\x99d abuse any poor fellow who was willing to take\r\nwhat he could get to keep his own children. You and your Union would\r\nsoon be down upon him. No! no! if it\xe2\x80\x99s only for the recollection of the\r\nway in which you\xe2\x80\x99ve used the poor knobsticks before now, I say No! to\r\nyour question. I\xe2\x80\x99ll not give you work. I won\xe2\x80\x99t say, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe your\r\npretext for coming and asking for work; I know nothing about it. It may\r\nbe true, or it may not. It\xe2\x80\x99s a very unlikely story, at any rate. Let me\r\npass. I\xe2\x80\x99ll not give you work. There\xe2\x80\x99s your answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hear, sir. I would na ha\xe2\x80\x99 troubled you\xe2\x80\x99, but that I were bid to come,\r\nby one as seemed to think yo\xe2\x80\x99d getten some place in your heart. Hoo were\r\nmistook, and I were misled. But I\xe2\x80\x99m not the first man as is misled by a\r\nwoman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell her to mind her own business the next time, instead of taking up\r\nyour time and mine too. I believe women are at the bottom of every\r\nplague in this world. Be off with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m obleeged to you for a\xe2\x80\x99 yo\xe2\x80\x99r kindness, measter, and most of a\xe2\x80\x99 for\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99r civil way o\xe2\x80\x99 saying good-bye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton did not deign a reply. But, looking out of the window a\r\nminute later, he was struck with the lean, bent figure going out of the\r\nyard; the heavy walk was in strange contrast with the resolute, clear\r\ndetermination of the man to speak to him. He crossed to the porter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlodge:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long has that man Higgins been waiting to speak to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was outside the gate before eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, sir. I think he\xe2\x80\x99s been\r\nthere ever since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it is now--?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust one, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive hours,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Mr. Thornton; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s a long time for a man to wait,\r\ndoing nothing but first hoping and then fearing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIX.\r\n\r\nMAKING FRIENDS.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cNay, I have done; you get no more of me;\r\n    And I am glad, yea glad with all my heart,\r\n    That thus so clearly I myself am free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              DRAYTON.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret shut herself up in her own room, after she had quitted Mrs.\r\nThornton. She began to walk backwards and forwards, in her old habitual\r\nway of showing agitation; but, then, remembering that in that\r\nslightly-built house every step was heard from one room to another, she\r\nsate down until she heard Mrs. Thornton go safely out of the house. She\r\nforced herself to recollect all the conversation that had passed between\r\nthem; speech by speech, she compelled her memory to go through with it.\r\nAt the end, she rose up, and said to herself, in a melancholy tone:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate, her words do not touch me; they fall off from me; for I am\r\ninnocent of all the motives she attributes to me. But still, it is hard\r\nto think that any one--any woman--can believe all this of another so\r\neasily. It is hard and sad. Where I have done wrong, she does not accuse\r\nme--she does not know. He never told her: I might have known he would\r\nnot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe lifted up her head, as if she took pride in any delicacy of feeling\r\nwhich Mr. Thornton had shown. Then, as a new thought came across her,\r\nshe pressed her hands tightly together:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe, too, must take poor Frederick for some lover.\xe2\x80\x9d (She blushed as the\r\nword passed through her mind.) \xe2\x80\x9cI see it now. It is not merely that he\r\nknows of my falsehood, but he believes that some one else cares for me;\r\nand that I---- Oh dear!--oh dear! What shall I do? What do I mean? Why\r\ndo I care what he thinks, beyond the mere loss of his good opinion as\r\nregards my telling the truth or not? I cannot tell. But I am very\r\nmiserable! Oh, how unhappy this last year has been! I have passed out of\r\nchildhood into old age. I have had no youth--no womanhood; the hopes of\r\nwomanhood have closed for me--for I shall never marry; and I anticipate\r\ncares and sorrows just as if I were an old woman, and with the same\r\ntearful spirit. I am weary of this continual call upon me for strength.\r\nI could bear up for papa; because that is a natural, pious duty. And I\r\nthink I could bear up against--at any rate, I could have the energy to\r\nresent, Mrs. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s unjust, impertinent suspicions. But it is hard\r\nto feel how completely he must misunderstand me. What has happened to\r\nmake me so morbid to-day? I do not know. I only know I cannot help it. I\r\nmust give way sometimes. No, I will not though,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, springing to\r\nher feet. \xe2\x80\x9cI will not--I _will_ not think of myself and my own position.\r\nI won\xe2\x80\x99t examine into my own feelings. It would be of no use now. Some\r\ntime, if I live to be an old woman, I may sit over the fire, and looking\r\ninto the embers, see the life that might have been.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll this time she was hastily putting on her things to go out, only\r\nstopping from time to time to wipe her eyes, with an impatience of\r\ngesture at the tears that would come again, in spite of all her bravery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say there\xe2\x80\x99s many a woman makes as sad a mistake as I have done,\r\nand only finds it out too late. And how proudly and impertinently I\r\nspoke to him that day! But I did not know then. It has come upon me\r\nlittle by little, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know where it began. Now I won\xe2\x80\x99t give way.\r\nI shall find it difficult to behave in the same way to him, with this\r\nmiserable consciousness upon me; but I will be very calm and very quiet,\r\nand say very little. But, to be sure, I may not see him; he keeps out of\r\nour way evidently. That would be worse than all. And yet no wonder that\r\nhe avoids me, believing what he must about me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe went out, going rapidly towards the country, and trying to drown\r\nreflection by swiftness of motion.\r\n\r\nAs she stood on the door-step, at her return, her father came up:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood girl!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been to Mrs. Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s. I was just meaning\r\nto go there, if I had time, before dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, papa; I have not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, reddening. \xe2\x80\x9cI never thought\r\nabout her. But I will go directly after dinner; I will go while you are\r\ntaking your nap.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAccordingly Margaret went. Mrs. Boucher was very ill; really ill--not\r\nmerely ailing. The kind and sensible neighbour, who had come in the\r\nother day, seemed to have taken charge of everything. Some of the\r\nchildren were gone to the neighbours. Mary Higgins had come for the\r\nthree youngest at dinner-time; and since then Nicholas had gone for the\r\ndoctor. He had not come as yet; Mrs. Boucher was dying; and there was\r\nnothing to do but wait. Margaret thought that she should like to hear\r\nhis opinion, and that she could not do better than go and see the\r\nHigginses in the meantime. She might then possibly hear whether Nicholas\r\nhad been able to make his application to Mr. Thornton.\r\n\r\nShe found Nicholas busily engaged in making a penny spin on the dresser,\r\nfor the amusement of three little children, who were clinging to him in\r\na fearless manner. He, as well as they, was smiling at a good long spin;\r\nand Margaret thought, that the happy look of interest in his occupation\r\nwas a good sign. When the penny stopped spinning, \xe2\x80\x9clile Johnnie\xe2\x80\x9d began\r\nto cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, taking him off the dresser, and holding him\r\nin her arms; she held her watch to his ear, while she asked Nicholas if\r\nhe had seen Mr. Thornton.\r\n\r\nThe look on his face changed instantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve seen and heerd too much on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe refused you, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, sorrowfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure. I knew he\xe2\x80\x99d do it all along. It\xe2\x80\x99s no good expecting marcy\r\nat the hands o\xe2\x80\x99 them measters. Yo\xe2\x80\x99r a stranger and a foreigner, and\r\naren\xe2\x80\x99t likely to know their ways; but I knowed it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry I asked you. Was he angry? He did not speak to you as Hamper\r\ndid, did he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe weren\xe2\x80\x99t o\xe2\x80\x99er-civil!\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholas, spinning the penny again, as\r\nmuch for his own amusement as for that of the children. \xe2\x80\x9cNever yo\xe2\x80\x99 fret,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m only where I was. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go on tramp to-morrow. I gave him as good as\r\nI got. I telled him, I\xe2\x80\x99d not that good opinion on him that I\xe2\x80\x99d ha\xe2\x80\x99 come\r\na second time of mysel\xe2\x80\x99; but yo\xe2\x80\x99d advised me for to come, and I were\r\nbeholden to yo\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou told him I sent you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dunno, if I ca\xe2\x80\x99d yo\xe2\x80\x99 by your name. I dunnot think I did. I said a\r\nwoman who knew no better had advised me for to come and see if there was\r\na soft place in his heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he--?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaid I were to tell yo\xe2\x80\x99 to mind yo\xe2\x80\x99r own business.--That\xe2\x80\x99s the longest\r\nspin yet, my lads.--And them\xe2\x80\x99s civil words to what he used to me. But\r\nne\xe2\x80\x99er mind. We\xe2\x80\x99re but where we was; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll break stones on the road\r\nafore I let these little uns clem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret put the struggling Johnnie out of her arms, back into his\r\nformer place on the dresser.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry I asked you to go to Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s. I am disappointed in\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a slight noise behind her. Both she and Nicholas turned round\r\nat the same moment, and there stood Mr. Thornton, with a look of\r\ndispleased surprise upon his face. Obeying her swift impulse, Margaret\r\npassed out before him, saying not a word, only bowing low to hide the\r\nsudden paleness that she felt had come over her face. He bent equally\r\nlow in return, and then closed the door after her. As she hurried to\r\nMrs. Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s, she heard the clang, and it seemed to fill up the\r\nmeasure of her mortification. He too was annoyed to find her there. He\r\nhad tenderness in his heart--\xe2\x80\x9ca soft place,\xe2\x80\x9d as Nicholas Higgins called\r\nit; but he had some pride in concealing it; he kept it very sacred and\r\nsafe, and was jealous of every circumstance that tried to gain\r\nadmission. But if he dreaded exposure of his tenderness, he was equally\r\ndesirous that all men should recognise his justice; and he felt that he\r\nhad been unjust in giving so scornful a hearing to any one who had\r\nwaited, with humble patience, for five hours, to speak to him. That the\r\nman had spoken saucily to him when he had the opportunity, was nothing\r\nto Mr. Thornton. He rather liked him for it; and he was conscious of his\r\nown irritability of temper at the time, which probably made them both\r\nquits. It was the five hours of waiting that struck Mr. Thornton. He had\r\nnot five hours to spare, himself; but one hour--two hours, of his hard\r\npenetrating intellectual, as well as bodily labour, did he give up to\r\ngoing about collecting evidence as to the truth of Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s story, the\r\nnature of his character, the tenor of his life. He tried not to be, but\r\nwas convinced that all that Higgins had said was true. And then the\r\nconviction went in, as if by some spell, and touched the latent\r\ntenderness of his heart; the patience of the man, the simple generosity\r\nof the motive (for he had learnt about the quarrel between Boucher and\r\nHiggins), made him forget entirely the mere reasonings of justice, and\r\noverleap them by a diviner instinct. He came to tell Higgins he would\r\ngive him work; and he was more annoyed to find Margaret there than by\r\nhearing her last words; for then he understood that she was the woman\r\nwho had urged Higgins to come to him; and he dreaded the admission of\r\nany thought of her, as a motive to what he was doing solely because it\r\nwas right.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that was the lady you spoke of as a woman?\xe2\x80\x9d said he indignantly to\r\nHiggins. \xe2\x80\x9cYou might have told me who she was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then, maybe, yo\xe2\x80\x99d have spoken of her more civil than yo\xe2\x80\x99 did; yo\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ngetten a mother who might ha\xe2\x80\x99 kept yo\xe2\x80\x99r tongue in check when yo\xe2\x80\x99 were\r\ntalking o\xe2\x80\x99 women being at the root of all the plagues.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course you told that to Miss Hale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn coorse I did. Leastways, I reckon I did. I telled her she weren\xe2\x80\x99t to\r\nmeddle again in aught that concerned yo\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhose children are those--yours?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Thornton had a pretty good notion\r\nwhose they were, from what he had heard; but he felt awkward in turning\r\nthe conversation round from this unpromising beginning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not mine, and they are mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are the children you spoke of to me this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen yo\xe2\x80\x99 said,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Higgins, turning round, with ill-smothered\r\nfierceness, \xe2\x80\x9cthat my story might be true or might not, but it were a\r\nvery unlikely one. Measter, I\xe2\x80\x99ve not forgotten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton was silent for a moment; then he said: \xe2\x80\x9cNo more have I. I\r\nremember what I said. I spoke to you about those children in a way I had\r\nno business to. I did not believe you. I could not have taken care of\r\nanother man\xe2\x80\x99s children myself, if he had acted towards me as I hear\r\nBoucher did towards you. But I know now you spoke truth. I beg your\r\npardon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHiggins did not turn round, or immediately respond to this. But when he\r\ndid speak, it was in a softened tone, although the words were gruff\r\nenough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99ve no business to go prying into what happened between Boucher and\r\nme. He\xe2\x80\x99s dead, and I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry. That\xe2\x80\x99s enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it is. Will you take work with me? That\xe2\x80\x99s what I came to ask.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHiggins\xe2\x80\x99s obstinacy wavered, recovered strength, and stood firm. He\r\nwould not speak. Mr. Thornton would not ask again. Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s eye fell on\r\nthe children.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99ve called me impudent, and a liar, and a mischief-maker, and yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmight ha\xe2\x80\x99 said wi\xe2\x80\x99 some truth, as I were now and then given to drink.\r\nAn\xe2\x80\x99, I ha\xe2\x80\x99 called you a tyrant, an\xe2\x80\x99 an oud bull dog, and a hard, cruel\r\nmaster; that\xe2\x80\x99s where it stands. But for th\xe2\x80\x99 childer, Measter, do yo\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthink we can e\xe2\x80\x99er get on together?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton, half-laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cit was not my proposal that\r\nwe should go together. But there\xe2\x80\x99s one comfort on your own showing. We\r\nneither of us can think much worse of the other than we do now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Higgins, reflectively. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been thinking ever sin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nI saw you, what a marcy it were yo\xe2\x80\x99 did na take me on, for that I ne\xe2\x80\x99er\r\nsaw a man whom I could less abide. But that\xe2\x80\x99s maybe been a hasty\r\njudgment; and work\xe2\x80\x99s work to such as me. So, measter, I\xe2\x80\x99ll come; and\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s more, I thank yo\xe2\x80\x99; and that\xe2\x80\x99s a deal fro\xe2\x80\x99 me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, more\r\nfrankly, suddenly turning round and facing Mr. Thornton fully for the\r\nfirst time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this is a deal from me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton, giving Higgins\xe2\x80\x99s hand a\r\ngood grip. \xe2\x80\x9cNow mind you come sharp to your time,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he,\r\nresuming the master. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have no laggards at my mill. What fines we\r\nhave, we keep pretty sharply. And the first time I catch you making\r\nmischief, off you go. So now you know where you are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99 spoke of my wisdom this morning. I reckon I may bring it wi\xe2\x80\x99 me; or\r\nwould yo\xe2\x80\x99 rayther have me \xe2\x80\x99bout my brains?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Bout your brains if you use them for meddling with my business; with\r\nyour brains if you can keep to your own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall need a deal o\xe2\x80\x99 brains to settle where my business ends and\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99rs begins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour business has not begun yet, and mine stands still for me. So good\r\nafternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust before Mr. Thornton came up to Mrs. Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s door, Margaret came\r\nout of it. She did not see him; and he followed her for several yards,\r\nadmiring her light and easy walk, and her tall and graceful figure. But,\r\nsuddenly, this simple emotion of pleasure was tainted, poisoned by\r\njealousy. He wished to overtake her, and speak to her, to see how she\r\nwould receive him, now she must know he was aware of some other\r\nattachment. He wished too, but of this wish he was rather ashamed, that\r\nshe should know that he had justified her wisdom in sending Higgins to\r\nhim to ask for work, and had repented him of his morning\xe2\x80\x99s decision. He\r\ncame up to her. She started.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to say, Miss Hale, that you were rather premature in\r\nexpressing your disappointment. I have taken Higgins on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said she coldly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe tells me, he repeated to you, what I said this morning about--,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr.\r\nThornton hesitated. Margaret took it up:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout women not meddling. You had a perfect right to express your\r\nopinion, which was a very correct one, I have no doubt. But,\xe2\x80\x9d she went\r\non a little more eagerly, \xe2\x80\x9cHiggins did not quite tell you the exact\r\ntruth.\xe2\x80\x9d The word \xe2\x80\x9ctruth,\xe2\x80\x9d reminded her of her own untruth, and she\r\nstopped short, feeling exceedingly uncomfortable.\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton at first was puzzled to account for her silence; and then\r\nhe remembered the lie she had told, and all that was foregone. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nexact truth!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cVery few people do speak the exact truth. I have\r\ngiven up hoping for it. Miss Hale, have you no explanation to give me?\r\nYou must perceive what I cannot but think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was silent. She was wondering whether an explanation of any\r\nkind would be consistent with her loyalty to Frederick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI will ask no farther. I may be putting temptation in\r\nyour way. At present, believe me, your secret is safe with me. But you\r\nrun great risks, allow me to say, in being so indiscreet. I am only\r\nspeaking as a friend of your father\xe2\x80\x99s: if I had any other thought or\r\nhope, of course that is at an end. I am quite disinterested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am aware of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, forcing herself to speak in an\r\nindifferent, careless way. \xe2\x80\x9cI am aware of what I must appear to you, but\r\nthe secret is another person\xe2\x80\x99s, and I cannot explain it without doing\r\nhim harm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not the slightest wish to pry into the gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s secrets,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, with growing anger. \xe2\x80\x9cMy own interest in you is--simply that of a\r\nfriend. You may not believe me, Miss Hale, but it is--in spite of the\r\npersecution I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I threatened you with at one time--but that is\r\nall given up; all passed away. You believe me, Miss Hale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, quietly and sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, really, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see any reason for us to go on walking together.\r\nI thought, perhaps, you might have had something to say, but I see we\r\nare nothing to each other. If you\xe2\x80\x99re quite convinced, that any foolish\r\npassion on my part is entirely over, I wish you good afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nwalked off very hastily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can he mean?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Margaret,--\xe2\x80\x9cwhat could he mean by speaking\r\nso, as if I were always thinking that he cared for me, when I know he\r\ndoes not; he cannot. His mother will have said all those cruel things\r\nabout me to him. But I won\xe2\x80\x99t care for him. I surely am mistress enough\r\nof myself to control this wild, strange, miserable feeling, which\r\ntempted me even to betray my own dear Frederick, so that I might but\r\nregain his good opinion--the good opinion of a man who takes such pains\r\nto tell me that I am nothing to him. Come! poor little heart! be cheery\r\nand brave. We\xe2\x80\x99ll be a great deal to one another, if we are thrown off\r\nand left desolate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer father was almost startled by her merriment this morning. She talked\r\nincessantly, and forced her natural humour to an unusual pitch; and if\r\nthere was a tinge of bitterness in much of what she said; if her\r\naccounts of the old Harley Street set were a little sarcastic, her\r\nfather could not bear to check her, as he would have done at another\r\ntime--for he was glad to see her shake off her cares. In the middle of\r\nthe evening, she was called down to speak to Mary Higgins; and when she\r\ncame back, Mr. Hale imagined that he saw traces of tears on her cheeks.\r\nBut that could not be, for she brought good news--that Higgins had got\r\nwork at Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s mill. Her spirits were damped, at any rate, and\r\nshe found it very difficult to go on talking at all, much more in the\r\nwild way that she had done. For some days her spirits varied strangely;\r\nand her father was beginning to be anxious about her, when news arrived\r\nfrom one or two quarters that promised some change and variety for her.\r\nMr. Hale received a letter from Mr. Bell, in which that gentleman\r\nvolunteered a visit to them; and Mr. Hale imagined that the promised\r\nsociety of his old Oxford friend would give as agreeable a turn to\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s ideas as it did to his own. Margaret tried to take an\r\ninterest in what pleased her father; but she was too languid to care\r\nabout any Mr. Bell, even though he were twenty times her godfather. She\r\nwas more roused by a letter from Edith, full of sympathy about her\r\naunt\xe2\x80\x99s death; full of details about herself, her husband, and child; and\r\nat the end saying, that as the climate did not suit the baby, and as\r\nMrs. Shaw was talking of returning to England, she thought it probable\r\nthat Captain Lennox might sell out, and that they might all go and live\r\nagain in the old Harley Street house; which, however, would seem very\r\nincomplete without Margaret. Margaret yearned after that old house, and\r\nthe placid tranquility of that well-ordered, monotonous life. She had\r\nfound it occasionally tiresome while it lasted; but since then she had\r\nbeen buffeted about, and felt so exhausted by this recent struggle with\r\nherself, that she thought that even stagnation would be a rest and a\r\nrefreshment. So she began to look towards a long visit to the Lennoxes,\r\non their return to England, as to a point--no, not of hope--but of\r\nleisure, in which she could regain her power and command over herself.\r\nAt present it seemed to her as if all subjects tended towards Mr.\r\nThornton; as if she could not forget him with all her endeavours. If she\r\nwent to see the Higginses, she heard of him there; her father had\r\nresumed their readings together, and quoted his opinions perpetually;\r\neven Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s visit brought his tenant\xe2\x80\x99s name upon the tapis; for he\r\nwrote word, that he believed he must be occupied some great part of his\r\ntime with Mr. Thornton, as a new lease was in preparation, and the terms\r\nof it must be agreed upon.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XL.\r\n\r\nOUT OF TUNE.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cI have no wrong, where I can claim no right,\r\n     Naught ta\xe2\x80\x99en me fro, where I have nothing had,\r\n     Yet of my woe I cannot so be quite;\r\n     Namely, since that another may be glad\r\n     With that, that thus in sorrow makes me sad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                              WYATT.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret had not expected much pleasure to herself from Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nvisit--she had only looked forward to it on her father\xe2\x80\x99s account, but\r\nwhen her godfather came, she at once fell into the most natural position\r\nof friendship in the world. He said she had no merit in being what she\r\nwas, a girl so entirely after his own heart: it was an hereditary power\r\nwhich she had, to walk in and take possession of his regard; while she,\r\nin reply, gave him much credit for being so fresh and young under his\r\nFellow\xe2\x80\x99s cap and gown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFresh and young in warmth and kindness, I mean. I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I must own,\r\nthat I think your opinions are the oldest and mustiest I have met with\r\nthis long time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear this daughter of yours, Hale! Her residence in Milton has quite\r\ncorrupted her. She\xe2\x80\x99s a democrat, a red republican, a member of the Peace\r\nSociety, a socialist--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa, it\xe2\x80\x99s all because I\xe2\x80\x99m standing up for the progress of commerce.\r\nMr. Bell would have had it keep still at exchanging wild-beast skins for\r\nacorns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no. I\xe2\x80\x99d dig the ground and grow potatoes. And I\xe2\x80\x99d shave the\r\nwild-beast skin and make the wool into broadcloth. Don\xe2\x80\x99t exaggerate,\r\nmissy. But I\xe2\x80\x99m tired of this bustle. Everybody rushing over everybody,\r\nin their hurry to get rich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not everyone who can sit comfortably in a set of college rooms\r\nand let his riches grow without any exertion of his own. No doubt there\r\nis many a man here who would be thankful if his property would increase\r\nas yours has done, without his taking any trouble about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nHale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe they would. It\xe2\x80\x99s the bustle and the struggle they like.\r\nAs for sitting still, and learning from the past, or shaping out the\r\nfuture by faithful work done in a prophetic spirit--Why! Pooh! I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbelieve there\xe2\x80\x99s a man in Milton who knows how to sit still; and it is a\r\ngreat art.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMilton people, I suspect, think Oxford men don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to move. It\r\nwould be a very good thing if they mixed a little more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt might be good for the Miltoners. Many things might be good for them\r\nwhich would be very disagreeable for other people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not a Milton man yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cI should have\r\nthought you would have been proud of your town.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI confess, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see what there is to be proud of. If you\xe2\x80\x99ll only\r\ncome to Oxford, Margaret, I will show you a place to glory in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton is coming to drink tea with us\r\nto-night, and he is as proud of Milton as you of Oxford. You two must\r\ntry and make each other a little more liberal-minded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be more liberal-minded, thank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Mr. Thornton coming to tea, papa!\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEither to tea or soon after. He could not tell. He told us not to\r\nwait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton had determined that he would make no inquiry of his mother\r\nas to how far she had put her project into execution of speaking to\r\nMargaret about the impropriety of her conduct. He felt pretty sure that,\r\nif this interview took place, his mother\xe2\x80\x99s account of what passed at it\r\nwould only annoy and chagrin him, though he would all the time be aware\r\nof the colouring which it received by passing through her mind. He\r\nshrank from hearing Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s very name mentioned; he, while he blamed\r\nher--while he was jealous of her--while he renounced her--he loved her\r\nsorely, in spite of himself. He dreamt of her; he dreamt she came\r\ndancing towards him with outspread arms, and with a lightness and gaiety\r\nwhich made him loathe her, even while it allured him. But the impression\r\nof this figure of Margaret--with all Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s character taken out of\r\nit, as completely as if some evil spirit had got possession of her\r\nform--was so deeply stamped upon his imagination, that when he wakened\r\nhe felt hardly able to separate the Una from the Duessa; and the dislike\r\nhe had to the latter seemed to envelop and disfigure the former. Yet he\r\nwas too proud to acknowledge his weakness by avoiding the sight of her.\r\nHe would neither seek an opportunity of being in her company nor avoid\r\nit. To convince himself of his power of self-control, he lingered over\r\nevery piece of business this afternoon; he forced every movement into\r\nunnatural slowness and deliberation; and it was consequently past eight\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock before he reached Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s. Then there were business\r\narrangements to be transacted in the study with Mr. Bell; and the latter\r\nkept on, sitting over the fire, and talking wearily, long after all\r\nbusiness was transacted, and when they might just as well have gone\r\nupstairs. But Mr. Thornton would not say a word about moving their\r\nquarters; he chafed and chafed, and thought Mr. Bell a most prosy\r\ncompanion; while Mr. Bell returned the compliment in secret, by\r\nconsidering Mr. Thornton about as brusque and curt a fellow as he had\r\never met with, and terribly gone off both in intelligence and manner. At\r\nlast some slight noise in the room above suggested the desirableness of\r\nmoving there. They found Margaret with a letter open before her, eagerly\r\ndiscussing its contents with her father. On the entrance of the\r\ngentlemen, it was immediately put aside; but Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s eager\r\nsenses caught some few words of Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s to Mr. Bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA letter from Henry Lennox. It makes Margaret very hopeful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bell nodded. Margaret was red as a rose when Mr. Thornton looked at\r\nher. He had the greatest mind in the world to get up and go out of the\r\nroom that very instant, and never set foot in the house again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe were thinking,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you and Mr. Thornton had taken\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s advice, and were each trying to convert the other, you were\r\nso long in the study.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you thought there would be nothing left of us but an opinion, like\r\nthe Kilkenny cat\xe2\x80\x99s tail. Pray whose opinion did you think would have the\r\nmost obstinate vitality?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton had not a notion what they were talking about, and\r\ndisdained to inquire. Mr. Hale politely enlightened him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton, we were accusing Mr. Bell this morning of a kind of\r\nOxonian medi\xc3\xa6val bigotry against his native town; and we--Margaret, I\r\nbelieve--suggested that it would do him good to associate a little with\r\nMilton manufacturers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon. Margaret thought it would do the Milton\r\nmanufacturers good to associate a little more with Oxford men. Now\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t it so, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe I thought it would do both good to see a little more of the\r\nother,--I did not know it was my idea any more than papa\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so you see, Mr. Thornton, we ought to have been improving each\r\nother down-stairs, instead of talking over vanished families of Smith\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nand Harrison\xe2\x80\x99s. However, I am willing to do my part now. I wonder when\r\nyou Milton men intend to live. All your lives seem to be spent in\r\ngathering together the materials for life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy living, I suppose you mean enjoyment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, enjoyment,--I don\xe2\x80\x99t specify of what, because I trust we should\r\nboth consider mere pleasure as very poor enjoyment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather have the nature of the enjoyment defined.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! enjoyment or leisure--enjoyment of the power and influence which\r\nmoney gives. You are all striving for money. What do you want it for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton was silent. Then he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI really don\xe2\x80\x99t know. But money\r\nis not what _I_ strive for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a home question. I shall have to lay myself open to such a\r\ncatechist, and I am not sure that I am prepared to do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t let us be personal in our catechism. You are\r\nneither of you representative men; you are each of you too individual\r\nfor that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not sure whether to consider that as a compliment or not. I should\r\nlike to be the representative of Oxford, with its beauty and its\r\nlearning, and its proud old history. What do you say, Margaret; ought I\r\nto be flattered?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know Oxford. But there is a difference between being the\r\nrepresentative of a city and the representative man of its inhabitants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery true, Miss Margaret. Now I remember, you were against me this\r\nmorning, and were quite Miltonian and manufacturing in your\r\npreferences.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret saw the quick glance of surprise that Mr. Thornton gave her,\r\nand she was annoyed at the construction which he might put on this\r\nspeech of Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s. Mr. Bell went on--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! I wish I could show you our High Street--our Radcliffe Square. I am\r\nleaving out our colleges, just as I give Mr. Thornton leave to omit his\r\nfactories in speaking of the charms of Milton. I have a right to abuse\r\nmy birth-place. Remember I am a Milton man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton was annoyed more than he ought to have been at all that Mr.\r\nBell was saying. He was not in a mood for joking. At another time, he\r\ncould have enjoyed Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s half testy condemnation of a town where\r\nthe life was so at variance with every habit he had formed; but now, he\r\nwas galled enough to attempt to defend what was never meant to be\r\nseriously attacked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t set up Milton as a model of a town.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot in architecture?\xe2\x80\x9d slyly asked Mr. Bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! We\xe2\x80\x99ve been too busy to attend to mere outward appearances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t say _mere_ outward appearances,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, gently. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\r\nimpress us all, from childhood upward--every day of our life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a little while,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton. \xe2\x80\x9cRemember we are of a\r\ndifferent race from the Greeks, to whom beauty was everything, and to\r\nwhom Mr. Bell might speak of a life of leisure and serene enjoyment,\r\nmuch of which entered in through their outward senses. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to\r\ndespise them, any more than I would ape them. But I belong to Teutonic\r\nblood; it is little mingled in this part of England to what it is in\r\nothers; we retain much of their language; we retain more of their\r\nspirit; we do not look upon life as a time for enjoyment, but as a time\r\nfor action and exertion. Our glory and our beauty arise out of our\r\noutward strength, which makes us victorious over material resistance,\r\nand over greater difficulties still. We are Teutonic up here in\r\nDarkshire in another way. We hate to have laws made for us at a\r\ndistance. We wish people would allow us to right ourselves, instead of\r\ncontinually meddling, with their imperfect legislation. We stand up for\r\nself-government, and oppose centralisation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn short, you would like the Heptarchy back again. Well, at any rate, I\r\nrevoke what I said this morning--that you Milton people did not\r\nreverence the past. You are regular worshippers of Thor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we do not reverence the past as you do in Oxford, it is because we\r\nwant something which can apply to the present more directly. It is fine\r\nwhen the study of the past leads to a prophecy of the future. But to men\r\ngroping in new circumstances, it would be finer if the words of\r\nexperience could direct us how to act in what concerns us most\r\nintimately and immediately; which is full of difficulties to be\r\nencountered; and upon the mode in which they are met and conquered--not\r\nmerely pushed aside for the time--depends our future. But no! People can\r\nspeak of Utopia much more easily than of the next day\xe2\x80\x99s duty; and yet\r\nwhen that duty is all done by others, who so ready to cry, \xe2\x80\x98Fie, for\r\nshame!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd all this time I don\xe2\x80\x99t see what you are talking about. Would you\r\nMilton men condescend to send up your to-day\xe2\x80\x99s difficulty to Oxford? You\r\nhave not tried us yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton laughed outright at this. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe I was talking with\r\nreference to a good deal that has been troubling us of late; I was\r\nthinking of the strikes we have gone through, which are troublesome and\r\ninjurious things enough, as I am finding to my cost. And yet this last\r\nstrike, under which I am smarting, has been respectable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA respectable strike!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell. \xe2\x80\x9cThat sounds as if you were far\r\ngone in the worship of Thor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret felt, rather than saw, that Mr. Thornton was chagrined by the\r\nrepeated turning into jest of what he was feeling as very serious. She\r\ntried to change the conversation from a subject about which one party\r\ncared little, while, to the other, it was deeply, because personally,\r\ninteresting. She forced herself to say something.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdith says she finds the printed calicoes in Corfu better and cheaper\r\nthan in London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes she?\xe2\x80\x9d said her father, \xe2\x80\x9cI think that must be one of Edith\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexaggerations. Are you sure of it, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure she says so, papa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I am sure of the fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell. \xe2\x80\x9cMargaret, I go so far in\r\nmy idea of your truthfulness, that it shall cover your cousin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncharacter. I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe a cousin of yours could exaggerate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Miss Hale so remarkable for truth?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton, bitterly. The\r\nmoment he had done so, he could have bitten his tongue out. What was he?\r\nAnd why should he stab her with her shame in this way? How evil he was\r\nto-night: possessed by ill-humour at being detained so long from her;\r\nirritated by the mention of some name, because he thought it belonged to\r\na more successful lover; now ill-tempered because he had been unable to\r\ncope, with a light heart, against one who was trying, by gay and\r\ncareless speeches, to make the evening pass pleasantly away,--the kind\r\nold friend to all parties, whose manner by this time might be well known\r\nto Mr. Thornton, who had been acquainted with him for many years. And\r\nthen to speak to Margaret as he had done! She did not get up and leave\r\nthe room, as she had done in former days, when his abruptness or his\r\ntemper had annoyed her. She sat quite still, after the first momentary\r\nglance of grieved surprise, that made her eyes look like some child\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwho has met with an unexpected rebuff; they slowly dilated into\r\nmournful, reproachful sadness; and then they fell, and she bent over her\r\nwork, and did not speak again. But he could not help looking at her, and\r\nhe saw a sigh tremble over her body, as if she quivered in some\r\nunwonted chill. He felt as the mother would have done, in the midst of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cher rocking it, and rating it,\xe2\x80\x9d had she been called away before her\r\nslow confiding smile, implying perfect trust in mother\xe2\x80\x99s love, had\r\nproved the renewing of its love. He gave short sharp answers; he was\r\nuneasy and cross, unable to discern between jest and earnest; anxious\r\nonly for a look, a word of hers, before which to prostrate himself in\r\npenitent humility. But she neither looked nor spoke. Her round taper\r\nfingers flew in and out of her sewing, as steadily and swiftly as if\r\nthat were the business of her life. She could not care for him, he\r\nthought, or else the passionate fervour of his wish would have forced\r\nher to raise those eyes, if but for an instant, to read the late\r\nrepentance in his. He could have struck her before he left, in order\r\nthat by some strange overt act of rudeness, he might earn the privilege\r\nof telling her the remorse that gnawed at his heart. It was well that\r\nthe long walk in the open air wound up this evening for him. It sobered\r\nhim back into grave resolution that henceforth he would see as little of\r\nher as possible,--since the very sight of that face and form, the very\r\nsounds of that voice (like the soft winds of pure melody) had such power\r\nto move him from his balance. Well! He had known what love was--a sharp\r\npang, a fierce experience, in the midst of whose flames he was\r\nstruggling! but, through the furnace he would fight his way out into the\r\nserenity of middle age,--all the richer and more human for having known\r\nthis great passion.\r\n\r\nWhen he had somewhat abruptly left the room, Margaret rose from her\r\nseat, and began silently to fold up her work. The long seams were heavy,\r\nand had an unusual weight for her languid arms. The round lines in her\r\nface took a lengthened, straighter form, and her whole appearance was\r\nthat of one who had gone through a day of great fatigue. As the three\r\nprepared for bed, Mr. Bell muttered a little condemnation of Mr.\r\nThornton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never saw a fellow so spoiled by success. He can\xe2\x80\x99t bear a word; a\r\njest of any kind. Everything seems to touch on the soreness of his high\r\ndignity. Formerly, he was as simple and noble as the open day; you could\r\nnot offend him, because he had no vanity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is not vain now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, turning round from the table, and\r\nspeaking with quiet distinctness. \xe2\x80\x9cTo-night he has not been like\r\nhimself. Something must have annoyed him before he came here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bell gave her one of his sharp glances from above his spectacles.\r\nShe stood it quite calmly; but, after she had left the room, he suddenly\r\nasked,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHale! did it ever strike you that Thornton and your daughter have what\r\nthe French call a tendresse for each other?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale, first startled and then flurried by the new\r\nidea. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I am sure you are wrong, I am almost certain you are\r\nmistaken. If there is anything, it is all on Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s side. Poor\r\nfellow! I hope and trust he is not thinking of her, for I am sure she\r\nwould not have him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! I\xe2\x80\x99m a bachelor, and have steered clear of love affairs all my\r\nlife; so perhaps my opinion is not worth having. Or else I should say\r\nthere were very pretty symptoms about her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I am sure you are wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Hale. \xe2\x80\x9cHe may care for her,\r\nthough she really has been almost rude to him at times. But she!--why,\r\nMargaret would never think of him, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure. Such a thing has never\r\nentered her head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEntering her heart would do. And whether I was wrong or right,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m very sleepy; so, having disturbed your night\xe2\x80\x99s rest (as I can see)\r\nwith my untimely fancies, I\xe2\x80\x99ll betake myself with an easy mind to my\r\nown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Mr. Hale resolved that he would not be disturbed by any such\r\nnonsensical idea; so he lay awake, determining not to think about it.\r\n\r\nMr. Bell took his leave the next day, bidding Margaret look to him as\r\none who had a right to help and protect her in all her troubles, of\r\nwhatever nature they might be. To Mr. Hale he said,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat Margaret of yours has gone deep into my heart. Take care of her,\r\nfor she is a very precious creature,--a great deal too good for\r\nMilton--only fit for Oxford, in fact. The town, I mean; not the men. I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t match her yet. When I can, I shall bring my young man to stand\r\nside by side with your young woman, just as the genii in the Arabian\r\nNights brought Prince Caralmazan to match with the fairy\xe2\x80\x99s Princess\r\nBadoura.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg you\xe2\x80\x99ll do no such thing.
