If you and your husband ever come to the town, my son and\r\ndaughter, Captain and Mrs. Lennox, will, I am sure, join with me in\r\nwishing to do anything in our power to show you attention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Thornton thought in her own mind, that Margaret had not taken much\r\ncare to enlighten her aunt as to the relationship between the Mr. and\r\nMrs. Thornton, towards whom the fine-lady aunt was extending her soft\r\npatronage; so she answered shortly,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy husband is dead. Mr. Thornton is my son. I never go to London; so I\r\nam not likely to be able to avail myself of your polite offers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this instant Mr. Thornton entered the room; he had only just returned\r\nfrom Oxford. His mourning suit spoke of the reason that had called him\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn,\xe2\x80\x9d said his mother, \xe2\x80\x9cthis lady is Mrs. Shaw, Miss Hale\xe2\x80\x99s aunt. I am\r\nsorry to say, that Miss Hale\xe2\x80\x99s call is to wish us good-bye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are going then!\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cWe leave to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy son-in-law comes this evening to escort us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Shaw.\r\n\r\nMr. Thornton turned away. He had not sat down, and now he seemed to be\r\nexamining something on the table, almost as if he had discovered an\r\nunopened letter, which had made him forget the present company. He did\r\nnot even seem to be aware when they got up to take leave. He started\r\nforwards, however, to hand Mrs. Shaw down to the carriage. As it drove\r\nup, he and Margaret stood close together on the door-step, and it was\r\nimpossible but that the recollection of the day of the riot should force\r\nitself into both their minds. Into his it came associated with the\r\nspeeches of the following day; her passionate declaration that there was\r\nnot a man in all that violent and a desperate crowd, for whom she did\r\nnot care as much as for him. And at the remembrance of her taunting\r\nwords, his brow grew stern, though his heart beat thick with longing\r\nlove. \xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI put it to the touch once, and I lost it all. Let\r\nher go,--with her stony heart, and her beauty;--how set and terrible her\r\nlook is now, for all her loveliness of feature! She is afraid I shall\r\nspeak what will require some stern repression. Let her go. Beauty and\r\nheiress as she may be, she will find it hard to meet with a truer heart\r\nthan mine. Let her go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd there was no tone of regret, or emotion of any kind in the voice\r\nwith which he said good-bye; and the offered hand was taken with a\r\nresolute calmness, and dropped as carelessly as if it had been a dead\r\nand withered flower. But none in his household saw Mr. Thornton again\r\nthat day. He was busily engaged; or so he said.\r\n\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s strength was so utterly exhausted by these visits, that she\r\nhad to submit to much watching and petting, and sighing\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI-told-you-so\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d from her aunt. Dixon said she was quite as bad as she\r\nhad been on the first day she heard of her father\xe2\x80\x99s death; and she and\r\nMrs. Shaw consulted as to the desirableness of delaying the morrow\xe2\x80\x99s\r\njourney. But when her aunt reluctantly proposed a few days\xe2\x80\x99 delay to\r\nMargaret, the latter writhed her body as if in acute suffering, and\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! let us go. I cannot be patient here. I shall not get well here. I\r\nwant to forget.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo the arrangements went on: and Captain Lennox came, and with him news\r\nof Edith and the little boy; and Margaret found that the indifferent,\r\ncareless conversation of one who, however kind, was not too warm and\r\nanxious a sympathiser, did her good. She roused up; and by the time that\r\nshe knew she might expect Higgins, she was able to leave the room\r\nquietly, and await in her own chamber the expected summons.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as she came in, \xe2\x80\x9cto think of th\xe2\x80\x99 oud gentleman dropping\r\noff as he did! Yo\xe2\x80\x99 might ha\xe2\x80\x99 knocked me down wi\xe2\x80\x99 a straw when they\r\ntelled me. \xe2\x80\x98Mr. Hale?\xe2\x80\x99 said I; \xe2\x80\x98him as was th\xe2\x80\x99 parson?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Ay,\xe2\x80\x99 said they.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s as good a man gone as ever lived on this earth,\r\nlet who will be t\xe2\x80\x99other!\xe2\x80\x99 And I came to see yo\xe2\x80\x99, and tell yo\xe2\x80\x99 how\r\ngrieved I were, but them women in th\xe2\x80\x99 kitchen wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell yo\xe2\x80\x99 I were\r\nthere. They said yo\xe2\x80\x99 were ill,--and butter me, but yo\xe2\x80\x99 dunnot look like\r\nthe same wench. And yo\xe2\x80\x99re going to be a grand lady up i\xe2\x80\x99 Lunnon, aren\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a grand lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, half smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! Thornton said--says he, a day or two ago, \xe2\x80\x98Higgins, have yo\xe2\x80\x99 seen\r\nMiss Hale?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 says I; \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s a pack o\xe2\x80\x99 women who won\xe2\x80\x99t let me at\r\nher. But I can bide my time, if she\xe2\x80\x99s ill. She and I knows each other\r\npretty well; and hoo\xe2\x80\x99l not go doubting that I\xe2\x80\x99m main sorry for th\xe2\x80\x99 oud\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x99s death, just because I can\xe2\x80\x99t get at her and tell her so.\xe2\x80\x99 And\r\nsays he, \xe2\x80\x98Yo\xe2\x80\x99ll not have much time for to try and see her, my fine chap.\r\nShe\xe2\x80\x99s not for staying with us a day longer nor she can help. She\xe2\x80\x99s got\r\ngrand relations, and they\xe2\x80\x99re carrying her off; and we shan\xe2\x80\x99t see her no\r\nmore.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Measter,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98if I dunnot see her afore hoo goes, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nstrive to get up to Lunnon next Whitsuntide, that I will. I\xe2\x80\x99ll not be\r\nbaulked of saying her good-bye by any relations whatsomdever. But bless\r\nyo\xe2\x80\x99, I knowed yo\xe2\x80\x99d come. It were only for to humour the measter, I let\r\non as if I thought yo\xe2\x80\x99d mappen leave Milton without seeing me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re quite right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cYou only do me justice. And you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nnot forget me, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure. If no one else in Milton remembers me, I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ncertain you will; and papa too. You know how good and tender he was.\r\nLook, Higgins! here is his bible. I have kept it for you. I can ill\r\nspare it; but I know he would have liked you to have it. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ncare for it, and study what is in it, for his sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYo\xe2\x80\x99 may say that. If it were the deuce\xe2\x80\x99s own scribble, and yo\xe2\x80\x99 axed me\r\nto read in it for yo\xe2\x80\x99r sake and the oud gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s, I\xe2\x80\x99d do it.\r\nWhatten\xe2\x80\x99s this, wench! I\xe2\x80\x99m not going for to take yo\xe2\x80\x99r brass, so dunnot\r\nthink it. We\xe2\x80\x99ve been great friends, \xe2\x80\x99bout the sound o\xe2\x80\x99 money passing\r\nbetween us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the children--for Boucher\xe2\x80\x99s children,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, hurriedly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey may need it. You\xe2\x80\x99ve no right to refuse it for them. I would not\r\ngive you one penny,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t think there\xe2\x80\x99s any of it\r\nfor you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, wench! I can nobbut say, Bless yo\xe2\x80\x99! and bless yo\xe2\x80\x99!--and amen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIV.\r\n\r\nEASE NOT PEACE.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cA dull rotation, never at a stay,\r\n     Yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s face twin image of to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                     COWPER.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cOf what each one should be, he sees the form and rule,\r\n     And till he reach to that, his joy can ne\xe2\x80\x99er be full.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n                    RUCKERT.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was very well for Margaret that the extreme quiet of the Harley\r\nStreet house, during Edith\xe2\x80\x99s recovery from her confinement, gave her the\r\nnatural rest which she needed. It gave her time to comprehend the sudden\r\nchange which had taken place in her circumstances within the last two\r\nmonths. She found herself at once an inmate of a luxurious house, where\r\nthe bare knowledge of the existence of every trouble or care seemed\r\nscarcely to have penetrated. The wheels of the machinery of daily life\r\nwere well oiled, and went along with delicious smoothness. Mrs. Shaw and\r\nEdith could hardly make enough of Margaret, on her return to what they\r\npersisted in calling her home. And she felt that it was almost\r\nungrateful in her to have a secret feeling that the Helstone\r\nvicarage--nay, even the poor little house at Milton, with her anxious\r\nfather and her invalid mother, and all the small household cares of\r\ncomparative poverty, composed her idea of home. Edith was impatient to\r\nget well, in order to fill Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s bed-room with all the soft\r\ncomforts, and pretty knick-knacks, with which her own abounded. Mrs.\r\nShaw and her maid found plenty of occupation in restoring Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwardrobe to a state of elegant variety. Captain Lennox was easy, kind,\r\nand gentlemanly; sate with his wife in her dressing-room an hour or two\r\nevery day; played with his little boy for another hour, and lounged away\r\nthe rest of his time at his club, when he was not engaged out to\r\ndinner. Just before Margaret had recovered from her necessity for quiet\r\nand repose--before she had begun to feel her life wanting and\r\ndull--Edith came downstairs and resumed her usual part in the household;\r\nand Margaret fell into the old habit of watching, and admiring, and\r\nministering to her cousin. She gladly took all charge of the semblances\r\nof duties off Edith\xe2\x80\x99s hands; answered notes, reminded her of\r\nengagements, tended her when no gaiety was in prospect, and she was\r\nconsequently rather inclined to fancy herself ill. But all the rest of\r\nthe family were in the full business of the London season, and Margaret\r\nwas often left alone. Then her thoughts went back to Milton, with a\r\nstrange sense of the contrast between the life there, and here. She was\r\ngetting surfeited of the eventless ease in which no struggle or\r\nendeavour was required. She was afraid lest she should even become\r\nsleepily deadened into forgetfulness of anything beyond the life which\r\nwas lapping her round with luxury. There might be toilers and moilers\r\nthere in London, but she never saw them; the very servants lived in an\r\nunderground world of their own, of which she knew neither the hopes nor\r\nthe fears; they only seemed to start into existence when some want or\r\nwhim of their master and mistress needed them. There was a strange\r\nunsatisfied vacuum in Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart and mode of life; and, once when\r\nshe had dimly hinted this to Edith, the latter, wearied with dancing the\r\nnight before, languidly stroked Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s cheek as she sat by her in\r\nthe old attitude,--she on a footstool by the sofa where Edith lay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor child!\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a little sad for you to be left, night\r\nafter night, just at this time when all the world is so gay. But we\r\nshall be having our dinner-parties soon--as soon as Henry comes back\r\nfrom circuit--and then there will be a little pleasant variety for you.\r\nNo wonder it is moped, poor darling!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret did not feel as if the dinner-parties would be a panacea. But\r\nEdith piqued herself on her dinner-parties; \xe2\x80\x9cso different,\xe2\x80\x9d as she said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfrom the old dowager dinners under mamma\xe2\x80\x99s r\xc3\xa9gime;\xe2\x80\x9d and Mrs. Shaw\r\nherself seemed to take exactly the same kind of pleasure in the very\r\ndifferent arrangements and circle of acquaintances which were to Captain\r\nand Mrs. Lennox\xe2\x80\x99s taste, as she did in the more formal and ponderous\r\nentertainments which she herself used to give. Captain Lennox was always\r\nextremely kind and brotherly to Margaret. She was really very fond of\r\nhim, excepting when he was anxiously attentive to Edith\xe2\x80\x99s dress and\r\nappearance, with a view to her beauty making a sufficient impression on\r\nthe world. Then all the latent Vashti in Margaret was roused, and she\r\ncould hardly keep herself from expressing her feelings.\r\n\r\nThe course of Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s day was this; a quiet hour or two before a late\r\nbreakfast; an unpunctual meal, lazily eaten by weary and half-awake\r\npeople, but yet at which, in all its dragged out length, she was\r\nexpected to be present, because, directly afterwards, came a discussion\r\nof plans, at which, although they none of them concerned her, she was\r\nexpected to give her sympathy, if she could not assist with her advice;\r\nan endless number of notes to write, which Edith invariably left to\r\nher, with many caressing compliments as to her eloquence du billet; a\r\nlittle play with Sholto as he returned from his morning\xe2\x80\x99s walk; besides\r\nthe care of the children during the servants\xe2\x80\x99 dinner; a drive or\r\ncallers; and some dinner or morning engagement for her aunt and cousins,\r\nwhich left Margaret free, it is true, but rather wearied with the\r\ninactivity of the day, coming upon depressed spirits and delicate\r\nhealth.\r\n\r\nShe looked forward with longing, though unspoken interest to the homely\r\nobject of Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s return from Milton; where, until now, the old servant\r\nhad been busily engaged in winding up all the affairs of the Hale\r\nfamily. It had appeared a sudden famine to her heart, this entire\r\ncessation of any news respecting the people among whom she had lived so\r\nlong. It was true, that Dixon, in her business-like letters, quoted,\r\nevery now and then, an opinion of Mr. Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s as to what she had\r\nbetter do about the furniture, or how act in regard to the landlord of\r\nthe Crampton Terrace house. But it was only here and there that the name\r\ncame in, or any Milton name, indeed; and Margaret was sitting one\r\nevening, all alone in the Lennox\xe2\x80\x99s drawing-room, not reading Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nletters, which yet she held in her hand, but thinking over them, and\r\nrecalling the days which had been, and picturing the busy life out of\r\nwhich her own had been taken and never missed; wondering if all went on\r\nin that whirl just as if she and her father had never been; questioning\r\nwithin herself, if no one in all the crowd missed her (not Higgins, she\r\nwas not thinking of him), when, suddenly Mr. Bell was announced; and\r\nMargaret hurried the letters into her work-basket, and started up,\r\nblushing as if she had been doing some guilty thing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Mr. Bell! I never thought of seeing you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you give me a welcome, I hope, as well as that very pretty start of\r\nsurprise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you dined? How did you come? Let me order you some dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re going to have any. Otherwise, you know, there is no one who\r\ncares less for eating than I do. But where are the others? Gone out to\r\ndinner? Left you alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes! and it is such a rest. I was just thinking--But will you run\r\nthe risk of dinner? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know if there is anything in the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, to tell you the truth, I dined at my club. Only they don\xe2\x80\x99t cook as\r\nwell as they did, so I thought, if you were going to dine, I might try\r\nand make out my dinner. But never mind, never mind! There aren\xe2\x80\x99t ten\r\ncooks in England to be trusted at impromptu dinners. If their skill and\r\ntheir fires will stand it, their tempers won\xe2\x80\x99t. You shall make me some\r\ntea, Margaret. And now, what were you thinking of? you were going to\r\ntell me. Whose letters were those, god-daughter, that you hid away so\r\nspeedily?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly Dixon\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Margaret, growing very red.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhew! is that all? Who do you think came up in the train with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, resolved against making a guess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour what d\xe2\x80\x99ye call him? What\xe2\x80\x99s the right name for a cousin-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Henry Lennox?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Bell. \xe2\x80\x9cYou knew him formerly, didn\xe2\x80\x99t you? What sort\r\nof a person is he, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI liked him long ago,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, glancing down for a moment. And\r\nthen she looked straight up and went on in her natural manner. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know\r\nwe have been corresponding about Frederick since; but I have not seen\r\nhim for nearly three years, and he may be changed. What did you think of\r\nhim?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. He was so busy trying to find out who I was, in the first\r\ninstance, and what I was in the second, that he never let out what he\r\nwas; unless indeed that veiled curiosity of his as to what manner of man\r\nhe had to talk to was not a good piece, and a fair indication of his\r\ncharacter. Do you call him good-looking, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! certainly not. Do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I. But I thought perhaps you might. Is he a great deal here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fancy he is when he is in town. He has been on circuit now since I\r\ncame. But--Mr. Bell--have you come from Oxford or from Milton?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Milton. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see I\xe2\x80\x99m smoke-dried?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. But I thought that it might be the effect of the antiquities\r\nof Oxford.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome now, be a sensible woman! In Oxford, I could have managed all the\r\nlandlords in the place, and had my own way, with half the trouble your\r\nMilton landlord has given me, and defeated me after all. He won\xe2\x80\x99t take\r\nthe house off our hands till next June twelve-month. Luckily, Mr.\r\nThornton found a tenant for it. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you ask after Mr. Thornton,\r\nMargaret? He has proved himself a very active friend of yours, I can\r\ntell you. Taken more than half the trouble off my hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how is he? How is Mrs. Thornton?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret hurriedly and\r\nbelow her breath, though she tried to speak out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose they\xe2\x80\x99re well. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been staying at their house till I was\r\ndriven out of it by the perpetual clack about that Thornton girl\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmarriage. It was too much for Thornton himself, though she was his\r\nsister. He used to go and sit in his own room perpetually. He\xe2\x80\x99s getting\r\npast the age for caring for such things, either as principal or\r\naccessory. I was surprised to find the old lady falling into the\r\ncurrent, and carried away by her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s enthusiasm for\r\norange-blossoms and lace. I thought Mrs. Thornton had been made of\r\nsterner stuff.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe would put on any assumption of feeling to veil her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nweakness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps so. You\xe2\x80\x99ve studied her, have you? She doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem over fond of\r\nyou, Margaret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, here is tea, at last!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed she,\r\nas if relieved. And with tea came Mr. Henry Lennox, who had walked up to\r\nHarley Street after a late dinner, and had evidently expected to find\r\nhis brother and sister-in-law at home. Margaret suspected him of being\r\nas thankful as she was at the presence of a third party, on this their\r\nfirst meeting since the memorable day of his offer, and her refusal at\r\nHelstone. She could hardly tell what to say at first, and was thankful\r\nfor all the tea-table occupations, which gave her an excuse for keeping\r\nsilence, and him an opportunity for recovering himself. For, to tell the\r\ntruth, he had rather forced himself up to Harley Street this evening,\r\nwith a view of getting over an awkward meeting, awkward even in the\r\npresence of Captain Lennox and Edith, and doubly awkward now that he\r\nfound her the only lady there, and the person to whom he must naturally\r\nand perforce address a great part of his conversation. She was the first\r\nto recover her self-possession. She began to talk on the subject which\r\ncame uppermost in her mind, after the first flush of awkward shyness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Lennox, I have been so much obliged to you for all you have done\r\nabout Frederick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am only sorry it has been so unsuccessful,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, with a quick\r\nglance towards Mr. Bell, as if reconnoitring how much he might say\r\nbefore him. Margaret, as if she read his thought, addressed herself to\r\nMr. Bell, both including him in the conversation, and implying that he\r\nwas perfectly aware of the endeavours that had been made to clear\r\nFrederick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat Horrocks--that very last witness of all, has proved as unavailing\r\nas all the others. Mr. Lennox has discovered that he sailed for\r\nAustralia only last August; only two months before Frederick was in\r\nEngland, and gave us the names of----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrederick in England! you never told me that!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Bell in\r\nsurprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you knew. I never doubted you had been told. Of course, it\r\nwas a great secret, and perhaps I should not have named it now,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMargaret, a little dismayed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have never named it to either my brother or your cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr.\r\nLennox, with a little professional dryness of implied reproach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind, Margaret. I am not living in a talking, babbling world, nor\r\nyet among people who are trying to worm facts out of me; you needn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlook so frightened because you have let the cat out of the bag to a\r\nfaithful old hermit like me. I shall never name his having been in\r\nEngland; I shall be out of temptation, for no one will ask me. Stay!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(interrupting himself rather abruptly). \xe2\x80\x9cWas it at your mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfuneral?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was with mamma when she died,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, softly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure! To be sure! Why, some one asked me if he had not been over\r\nthen, and I denied it stoutly--not many weeks ago--who could it have\r\nbeen? Oh! I recollect!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he did not say the name; and although Margaret would have given much\r\nto know if her suspicions were right, and it had been Mr. Thornton who\r\nhad made the enquiry, she could not ask the question of Mr. Bell, much\r\nas she longed to do so.\r\n\r\nThere was a pause for a moment or two. Then Mr. Lennox said, addressing\r\nhimself to Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose as Mr. Bell is now acquainted with all\r\nthe circumstances attending your brother\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate dilemma, I cannot\r\ndo better than inform him exactly how the research into the evidence we\r\nonce hoped to produce in his favour stands at present. So, if he will do\r\nme the honour to breakfast with me to-morrow, we will go over the names\r\nof these missing gentry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to hear all the particulars, if I may. Cannot you come\r\nhere? I dare not ask you both to breakfast, though I am sure you would\r\nbe welcome. But let me know all you can about Frederick, even though\r\nthere may be no hope at present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have an engagement at half-past eleven. But I will certainly come if\r\nyou wish it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Lennox with a little after-thought of extreme\r\nwillingness, which made Margaret shrink into herself, and almost wish\r\nthat she had not proposed her natural request. Mr. Bell got up and\r\nlooked around him for his hat, which had been removed to make room for\r\ntea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what Mr. Lennox is inclined to do, but\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m disposed to be moving off homewards. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been a journey to-day, and\r\njourneys begin to tell upon my sixty and odd years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe I shall stay and see my brother and sister,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Lennox,\r\nmaking no movement of departure. Margaret was seized with a shy awkward\r\ndread of being left alone with him. The scene on the little terrace in\r\nthe Helstone garden was so present to her, that she could hardly help\r\nbelieving it was so with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t go yet, please Mr. Bell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, hastily. \xe2\x80\x9cI want you to see\r\nEdith; and I want Edith to know you. He looked at her, and saw the confusion\r\nstirring in her countenance; he sate down again, as if her little touch\r\nhad been possessed of resistless strength.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see how she overpowers me, Mr. Lennox,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I hope you\r\nnoticed the happy choice of her expressions; she wants me to \xe2\x80\x98see\xe2\x80\x99 this\r\ncousin Edith, who, I am told, is a great beauty; but she has the honesty\r\nto change her word when she comes to me--Mrs. Lennox is to \xe2\x80\x98know\xe2\x80\x99 me. I\r\nsuppose I am not much to \xe2\x80\x98see,\xe2\x80\x99 eh, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe joked, to give her time to recover from the slight flutter which he\r\nhad detected in her manner on his proposal to leave; and she caught the\r\ntone, and threw the ball back. Mr. Lennox wondered how his brother, the\r\nCaptain, could have reported her as having lost all her good looks. To\r\nbe sure, in her quiet black dress, she was a contrast to Edith, dancing\r\nin her white crape mourning, and long floating golden hair, all softness\r\nand glitter. She dimpled and blushed most becomingly when introduced to\r\nMr. Bell, conscious that she had her reputation as a beauty to keep up,\r\nand that it would not do to have a Mordecai refusing to worship and\r\nadmire, even in the shape of an old Fellow of a College, which nobody\r\nhad ever heard of. Mrs. Shaw and Captain Lennox, each in their separate\r\nway, gave Mr. Bell a kind and sincere welcome, winning him over to like\r\nthem almost in spite of himself, especially when he saw how naturally\r\nMargaret took her place as sister and daughter of the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a shame that we were not at home to receive you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, too, Henry! though I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that we should have stayed at home\r\nfor you. And for Mr. Bell! for Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Bell----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no knowing what sacrifices you would not have made,\xe2\x80\x9d said her\r\nbrother-in-law. \xe2\x80\x9cEven a dinner-party! and the delight of wearing this\r\nvery becoming dress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEdith did not know whether to frown or to smile, but it did not suit Mr.\r\nLennox to drive her to the first of these alternatives; so he went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you show your readiness to make sacrifices to-morrow morning,\r\nfirst by asking me to breakfast, to meet Mr. Bell, and secondly, by\r\nbeing so kind as to order it at half-past nine, instead of at ten\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock? I have some letters and papers that I want to show to Miss Hale\r\nand Mr. Bell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope Mr. Bell will make our house his own during his stay in London,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Captain Lennox. \xe2\x80\x9cI am only so sorry we cannot offer him a bedroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you. I am much obliged to you. You would only think me a churl if\r\nyou had, for I should decline it, I believe, in spite of all the\r\ntemptations of such agreeable company,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell, bowing all round,\r\nand secretly congratulating himself on the neat turn he had given to his\r\nsentence, which, if put into plain language, would have been more to\r\nthis effect: \xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stand the restraints of such a proper-behaved\r\nand civil-spoken people as these are: it would be like meat without\r\nsalt. I\xe2\x80\x99m absolutely catching the trick of good manners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis self-satisfaction lasted him till he was fairly out in the streets,\r\nwalking side by side with Henry Lennox. Here he suddenly remembered\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s little look of entreaty as she urged him to stay longer, and\r\nhe also recollected a few hints given him long ago by an acquaintance of\r\nMr. Lennox\xe2\x80\x99s, as to his admiration of Margaret. It gave a new direction\r\nto his thoughts. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have known Miss Hale for a long time, I believe.\r\nHow do you think her looking? She strikes me as pale and ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought her looking remarkably well. Perhaps not when I first\r\ncame--now I think of. But certainly, when she grew animated, she looked\r\nas well as ever I saw her do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has had a great deal to go through,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! I have been sorry to hear of all she has had to bear; not merely\r\nthe common and universal sorrow arising from death, but all the\r\nannoyance which her father\xe2\x80\x99s conduct must have caused her, and then----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer father\xe2\x80\x99s conduct!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell, in an accent of surprise. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nmust have heard some wrong statement. He behaved in the most\r\nconscientious manner. He showed more resolute strength than I should\r\never have given him credit for formerly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I have been wrongly informed. But I have been told, by his\r\nsuccessor in the living--a clever sensible man, and a thoroughly active\r\nclergyman--that there was no call upon Mr. Hale to do what he did,\r\nrelinquish the living, and throw himself and his family on the tender\r\nmercies of private teaching in a manufacturing town; the bishop had\r\noffered him another living, it is true, but if he had come to entertain\r\ncertain doubts, he could have remained where he was, and so had no\r\noccasion to resign. But the truth is, these country clergymen live such\r\nisolated lives--isolated, I mean, from all intercourse with men of equal\r\ncultivation with themselves, by whose minds they might regulate their\r\nown, and discover when they were going either too fast or too slow--that\r\nthey are very apt to disturb themselves with imaginary doubts as to the\r\narticles of faith, and throw up certain opportunities of doing good for\r\nvery uncertain fancies of their own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI differ from you. I do not think they are very apt to do as my poor\r\nfriend Hale did.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Bell was inwardly chafing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I used too general an expression in saying \xe2\x80\x98very apt.\xe2\x80\x99 But\r\ncertainly, their lives are such as very often to produce either\r\ninordinate self-sufficiency, or a morbid state of conscience,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nMr. Lennox with perfect coolness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t meet with any self-sufficiency among the lawyers, for\r\ninstance?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Bell. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd seldom, I imagine, any cases of morbid\r\nconscience.\xe2\x80\x9d He was becoming more and more vexed, and forgetting his\r\nlately-caught trick of good manners. Mr. Lennox saw now that he had\r\nannoyed his companion; and as he had talked pretty much for the sake of\r\nsaying something, and so passing the time away while their road lay\r\ntogether, he was very indifferent as to the exact side he took upon the\r\nquestion, and quietly came round by saying: \xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, there is\r\nsomething fine in a man of Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s age leaving his home of twenty\r\nyears, and giving up all settled habits, for an idea which was probably\r\nerroneous--but that does not matter--an untangible thought. One cannot\r\nhelp admiring him, with a mixture of pity in one\xe2\x80\x99s admiration, something\r\nlike what one feels for Don Quixote. Such a gentleman as he was too! I\r\nshall never forget the refined and simple hospitality he showed to me\r\nthat last day at Helstone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOnly half-mollified, and yet anxious, in order to lull certain qualms of\r\nhis own conscience, to believe that Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s conduct had a tinge of\r\nQuixotism in it, Mr. Bell growled out--\xe2\x80\x9cAye! And you don\xe2\x80\x99t know Milton.\r\nSuch a change from Helstone! It is years since I have been at\r\nHelstone--but I\xe2\x80\x99ll answer for it, it is standing there yet--every stick\r\nand every stone as it has done for the last century, while Milton! I go\r\nthere every four or five years--and I was born there--yet I do assure\r\nyou, I often lose my way--aye, among the very piles of warehouses that\r\nare built upon my father\xe2\x80\x99s orchard. Do we part here? Well, good-night,\r\nsir; I suppose we shall meet in Harley Street to-morrow morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLV.\r\n\r\nNOT ALL A DREAM.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are the sounds that swam along\r\n    The buoyant air when I was young;\r\n    The last vibration now is o\xe2\x80\x99er,\r\n    And they who listened are no more;\r\n    Ah! let me close my eyes and dream.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              W. S. LANDOR.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe idea of Helstone had been suggested to Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s waking mind by his\r\nconversation with Mr. Lennox, and all night long it ran riot through his\r\ndreams. He was again the tutor in the college where he now held the rank\r\nof Fellow; it was again a long vacation, and he was staying with his\r\nnewly-married friend, the proud husband, and happy Vicar of Helstone.\r\nOver babbling brooks they took impossible leaps, which seemed to keep\r\nthem whole days suspended in the air. Time and space were not, though\r\nall other things seemed real. Every event was measured by the emotions\r\nof the mind, not by its actual existence, for existence it had none. But\r\nthe trees were gorgeous in their autumnal leafiness--the warm odours of\r\nflower and herb came sweet upon the sense--the young wife moved about\r\nthe house with just that mixture of annoyance at her position, as\r\nregarded wealth, with pride in her handsome and devoted husband, which\r\nMr. Bell had noticed in real life a quarter of a century ago. The dream\r\nwas so like life that, when he awoke, his present life seemed a dream.\r\nWhere was he? In the close, handsomely furnished room of a London hotel!\r\nWhere were those who spoke to him, moved around him, touched him, not an\r\ninstant ago? Dead! buried! lost for evermore, as far as earth\xe2\x80\x99s for\r\nevermore would extend. He was an old man, so lately exultant in the full\r\nstrength of manhood. The utter loneliness of his life was insupportable\r\nto think about. He got up hastily, and tried to forget what never more\r\nmight be, in a hurried dressing for the breakfast in Harley Street.\r\n\r\nHe could not attend to all the lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s details, which, as he saw, made\r\nMargaret\xe2\x80\x99s eyes dilate, and her lips grow pale, as one by one fate\r\ndecreed, or so it seemed, every morsel of evidence which would exonerate\r\nFrederick, should fall from beneath her feet and disappear. Even Mr.\r\nLennox\xe2\x80\x99s well-regulated professional voice took a softer, tenderer tone,\r\nas he drew near to the extinction of the last hope. It was not that\r\nMargaret had not been perfectly aware of the result before. It was only\r\nthat the details of each successive disappointment came with such\r\nrelentless minuteness to quench all hope, that she at last fairly gave\r\nway to tears. Mr. Lennox stopped reading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had better not go on,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in a concerned voice. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was a\r\nfoolish proposal of mine. Lieutenant Hale,\xe2\x80\x9d and even this giving him the\r\ntitle of the service from which he had so harshly been expelled, was\r\nsoothing to Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cLieutenant Hale is happy now; more secure in\r\nfortune and future prospects than he could ever have been in the navy;\r\nand has, doubtless, adopted his wife\xe2\x80\x99s country as his own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems so selfish in me to regret it,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ntrying to smile, \xe2\x80\x9cand yet he is lost to me, and I am so lonely.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr.\r\nLennox turned over his papers, and wished that he were as rich and\r\nprosperous as he believed he should be some day. Mr. Bell blew his nose,\r\nbut, otherwise, he also kept silence; and Margaret, in a minute or two,\r\nhad apparently recovered her usual composure. She thanked Mr. Lennox\r\nvery courteously for his trouble; all the more courteously and\r\ngraciously because she was conscious that, by her behaviour, he might\r\nprobably be led to imagine that he had given her needless pain. Yet it\r\nwas pain she would not have been without.\r\n\r\nMr. Bell came up to wish her good-bye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he fumbled with his gloves, \xe2\x80\x9cI am going down to\r\nHelstone to-morrow, to look at the old place. Would you like to come\r\nwith me? Or would it give you too much pain? Speak out, don\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nafraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Mr. Bell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she--and could say no more. But she took his old\r\ngouty hand, and kissed it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come; that\xe2\x80\x99s enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, reddening with awkwardness. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nsuppose your aunt Shaw will trust you with me. We\xe2\x80\x99ll go to-morrow\r\nmorning, and we shall get there about two o\xe2\x80\x99clock, I fancy. We\xe2\x80\x99ll take a\r\nsnack, and order dinner at the little inn--the Lennard Arms, it used to\r\nbe--and go and get an appetite in the forest. Can you stand it,\r\nMargaret? It will be a trial, I know, to both of us, but it will be a\r\npleasure to me, at least. And there we\xe2\x80\x99ll dine--it will be but\r\ndoe-venison, if we can get it at all--and then I\xe2\x80\x99ll take my nap, while\r\nyou go out and see old friends. I\xe2\x80\x99ll give you back safe and sound,\r\nbarring railway accidents, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll insure your life for a thousand\r\npounds before starting, which may be some comfort to your relations; but\r\notherwise, I\xe2\x80\x99ll bring you back to Mrs. Shaw by lunch time on Friday. So,\r\nif you say yes, I\xe2\x80\x99ll just go upstairs and propose it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no use my trying to say how much I shall like it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret,\r\nthrough her tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, prove your gratitude by keeping those fountains of yours\r\ndry for the next two days. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t, I shall feel queer myself about\r\nthe lachrymal ducts, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t cry a drop,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, winking her eyes to shake the tears\r\noff her eyelashes, and forcing a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s my good girl. Then we\xe2\x80\x99ll go upstairs and settle it all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nMargaret was in a state of almost trembling eagerness, while Mr. Bell\r\ndiscussed his plan with her aunt Shaw, who was first startled, then\r\ndoubtful and perplexed, and in the end, yielding rather to the rough\r\nforce of Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s words than to her own conviction; for to the last,\r\nwhether it was right or wrong, proper or improper, she could not settle\r\nto her own satisfaction, till Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s safe return, the happy\r\nfulfilment of the project, gave her decision enough to say, \xe2\x80\x9cshe was\r\nsure it had been a very kind thought of Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s, and just what she\r\nherself had been wishing for Margaret, as giving her the very change\r\nwhich she required, after all the anxious time she had had.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLVI.\r\n\r\nONCE AND NOW.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cSo on those happy days of yore\r\n    Oft as I dare to dwell once more,\r\n    Still must I miss the friends so tried,\r\n    Whom Death has severed from my side.\r\n\r\n    But ever when true friendship binds,\r\n    Spirit it is that spirit finds;\r\n    In spirit then our bliss we found,\r\n    In spirit yet to them I\xe2\x80\x99m bound.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              UHLAND.\r\n\r\n\r\nMargaret was ready long before the appointed time, and had leisure\r\nenough to cry a little, quietly, when unobserved, and to smile brightly\r\nwhen any one looked at her. Her last alarm was lest they should be too\r\nlate and miss the train; but no! they were all in time; and she breathed\r\nfreely and happily at length, seated in the carriage opposite to Mr.\r\nBell, and whirling away past the well-known stations; seeing the old\r\nsouth country-towns and hamlets sleeping in the warm light of the pure\r\nsun, which gave a yet ruddier colour to their tiled roofs, so different\r\nto the cold slates of the north. Broods of pigeons hovered around these\r\npeaked quaint gables, slowly settling here and there, and ruffling their\r\nsoft, shiny feathers, as if exposing every fibre to the delicious\r\nwarmth. There were few people about at the stations, it almost seemed as\r\nif they were too lazily content to wish to travel; none of the bustle\r\nand stir that Margaret had noticed in her two journeys on the London and\r\nNorth-Western line. Later on in the year, this line of railway should be\r\nstirring and alive with rich pleasure-seekers; but as to the constant\r\ngoing to and fro of busy tradespeople it would always be widely\r\ndifferent from the northern lines. Here a spectator or two stood\r\nlounging at nearly every station, with his hands in his pockets, so\r\nabsorbed in the simple act of watching, that it made the travellers\r\nwonder what he could find to do when the train whirled away, and only\r\nthe blank of a railway, some sheds, and a distant field or two were left\r\nfor him to gaze upon. The hot air danced over the golden stillness of\r\nthe land, farm after farm was left behind, each reminding Margaret of\r\nGerman Idylls--of Herman and Dorothea--of Evangeline. From this waking\r\ndream she was roused. It was the place to leave the train and take the\r\nfly to Helstone. And now sharper feelings came shooting through her\r\nheart, whether pain or pleasure she could hardly tell. Every mile was\r\nredolent of associations, which she would not have missed for the\r\nworld, but each of which made her cry upon \xe2\x80\x9cthe days that are no more,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwith ineffable longing. The last time she had passed along this road was\r\nwhen she had left it with her father and mother--the day, the season,\r\nhad been gloomy, and she herself hopeless, but they were there with her.\r\nNow she was alone, an orphan, and they, strangely, had gone away from\r\nher, and vanished from the face of the earth. It hurt her to see the\r\nHelstone road so flooded in the sunlight, and every turn and every\r\nfamiliar tree so precisely the same in its summer glory as it had been\r\nin former years. Nature felt no change and was ever young.\r\n\r\nMr. Bell knew something of what would be passing through her mind, and\r\nwisely and kindly held his tongue. They drove up to the Lennard Arms;\r\nhalf farm-house, half-inn, standing a little apart from the road, as\r\nmuch as to say, that the host did not so depend on the custom of\r\ntravellers, as to have to court it by any obtrusiveness; they, rather,\r\nmust seek him out. The house fronted the village green; and right before\r\nit stood an immemorial lime-tree benched all round, in some hidden\r\nrecesses of whose leafy wealth hung the grim escutcheon of the Lennards.\r\nThe door of the inn stood wide open, but there was no hospitable hurry\r\nto receive the travellers. When the landlady did appear--and they might\r\nhave abstracted many an article first--she gave them a kind welcome,\r\nalmost as if they had been invited guests, and apologised for her coming\r\nhaving been so delayed, by saying, that it was hay-time, and the\r\nprovisions for the men had to be sent a-field, and she had been too busy\r\npacking up the baskets to hear the noise of wheels over the road, which,\r\nsince they left the highway, ran over soft short turf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, bless me!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed she, as at the end of her apology a glint of\r\nsunshine showed her Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s face, hitherto unobserved in that shady\r\nparlour. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Miss Hale, Jenny,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, running to the door, and\r\ncalling to her daughter. \xe2\x80\x9cCome here, come directly, it\xe2\x80\x99s Miss Hale!\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nthen she went up to Margaret, and shook hands with motherly fondness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how are you all? How\xe2\x80\x99s the Vicar and Miss Dixon? The Vicar above\r\nall! God bless him! We\xe2\x80\x99ve never ceased to be sorry that he left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret tried to speak and tell her of her father\xe2\x80\x99s death; of her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s it was evident that Mrs. Purkis was aware, from her omission of\r\nher name. But she choked in the effort, and could only touch her deep\r\nmourning, and say the one word, \xe2\x80\x9cPapa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely, sir, it\xe2\x80\x99s never so!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Purkis, turning to Mr. Bell for\r\nconfirmation of the sad suspicion that now entered her mind. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was\r\na gentleman here in the spring--might have been as long ago as last\r\nwinter--who told us a deal of Mr. Hale and Miss Margaret; and he said\r\nMrs. Hale was gone, poor lady. But never a word of the Vicar\xe2\x80\x99s being\r\nailing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is so, however,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell. \xe2\x80\x9cHe died quite suddenly, when on a\r\nvisit to me at Oxford. He was a good man, Mrs. Purkis, and there\xe2\x80\x99s many\r\nof us that might be thankful to have as calm an end as his. Come,\r\nMargaret, my dear! Her father was my oldest friend, and she\xe2\x80\x99s my\r\ngod-daughter, so I thought we would just come down together and see the\r\nold place; and I know of old you can give us comfortable rooms and a\r\ncapital dinner. You don\xe2\x80\x99t remember me I see, but my name is Bell, and\r\nonce or twice when the parsonage has been full, I\xe2\x80\x99ve slept here, and\r\ntasted your good ale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure; I ask your pardon; but you see I was taken up with Miss\r\nHale. Let me show you to a room, Miss Margaret, where you can take off\r\nyour bonnet, and wash your face. It\xe2\x80\x99s only this very morning I plunged\r\nsome fresh-gathered roses head downward in the water-jug, for thought I,\r\nperhaps some one will be coming, and there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing so sweet as\r\nspring-water scented by a musk rose or two. To think of the Vicar being\r\ndead! Well, to be sure, we must all die; only that gentleman said, he\r\nwas quite picking up after his trouble about Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome down to me, Mrs. Purkis, after you have attended to Miss Hale. I\r\nwant to have a consultation with you about dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe little casement window in Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s bed-chamber was almost filled\r\nup with rose and vine branches; but, pushing them aside, and stretching\r\na little out, she could see the tops of the parsonage chimneys above the\r\ntrees, and distinguish many a well-known line through the leaves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Purkis, smoothing down the bed, and despatching Jenny\r\nfor an armful of lavender-scented towels, \xe2\x80\x9ctimes is changed, miss; our\r\nnew Vicar has seven children, and is building a nursery ready for more,\r\njust where the arbour and tool-house used to be in old times. And he has\r\nhad new grates put in, and a plate-glass window in the drawing-room. He\r\nand his wife are stirring people, and have done a deal of good; at least\r\nthey say it\xe2\x80\x99s doing good; if it were not, I should call it turning\r\nthings upside down for very little purpose. The new Vicar is a\r\nteetotaller, miss, and a magistrate, and his wife has a deal of receipts\r\nfor economical cooking, and is for making bread without yeast; and they\r\nboth talk so much, and both at a time, that they knock one down as it\r\nwere, and it\xe2\x80\x99s not till they\xe2\x80\x99re gone, and one\xe2\x80\x99s a little at peace, that\r\none can think that there were things one might have said on one\xe2\x80\x99s own\r\nside of the question. He\xe2\x80\x99ll be after the men\xe2\x80\x99s cans in the hay-field,\r\nand peeping in; and then there\xe2\x80\x99ll be an ado because it\xe2\x80\x99s not\r\nginger-beer, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t help it. My mother and my grandmother before me\r\nsent good malt liquor to hay-makers, and took salts and senna when\r\nanything ailed them; and I must e\xe2\x80\x99en go on in their ways, though Mrs.\r\nHepworth does want to give me comfits instead of medicine, which, as she\r\nsays, is a deal pleasanter, only I\xe2\x80\x99ve no faith in it. But I must go,\r\nmiss, though I\xe2\x80\x99m wanting to hear many a thing; I\xe2\x80\x99ll come back to you\r\nbefore long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bell had strawberries and cream, a loaf of brown bread, and a jug of\r\nmilk (together with a Stilton cheese and a bottle of port for his own\r\nprivate refreshment), ready for Margaret on her coming down stairs; and\r\nafter this rustic luncheon they set out for a walk, hardly knowing in\r\nwhat direction to turn, so many old familiar inducements were there in\r\neach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we go past the vicarage?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not yet. We will go this way, and make a round so as to come back\r\nby it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret.\r\n\r\nHere and there old trees had been felled the autumn before; or a\r\nsquatter\xe2\x80\x99s cottage roughly-built and decaying cottage had disappeared.\r\nMargaret missed them each and all, and grieved over them like old\r\nfriends. They came past the spot where she and Mr. Lennox had sketched.\r\nThe white, lightning-scarred trunk of the venerable beech, among whose\r\nroots they had sate down was there no more; the old man, the inhabitant\r\nof the ruinous cottage, was dead; the cottage had been pulled down, and\r\na new one, tidy and respectable, had been built in its stead. There was\r\na small garden on the place where the beech-tree had been.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not think I had been so old,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret after a pause of\r\nsilence; and she turned away sighing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is the first changes among familiar things\r\nthat make such a mystery of time to the young, afterwards we lose the\r\nsense of the mysterious. I take changes in all I see as a matter of\r\ncourse. The instability of all human things is familiar to me, to you it\r\nis new and oppressive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go on to see little Susan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, drawing her companion\r\nup a grassy road-way, leading under the shadow of a forest glade.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith all my heart, though I have not an idea who little Susan may be.\r\nBut I have a kindness for all Susans, for simple Susan\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy little Susan was disappointed when I left without wishing her\r\ngood-bye; and it has been on my conscience ever since, that I gave her\r\npain which a little more exertion on my part might have prevented. But\r\nit is a long way. Are you sure you will not be tired?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite sure. That is, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t walk so fast. You see, here there are\r\nno views that can give one an excuse for stopping to take breath. You\r\nwould think it romantic to be walking with a person \xe2\x80\x98fat and scant o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nbreath\xe2\x80\x99 if I were Hamlet, Prince of Denmark. Have compassion on my\r\ninfirmities for his sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will walk slower for your own sake. I like you twenty times better\r\nthan Hamlet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the principle that a living ass is better than a dead lion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps so. I don\xe2\x80\x99t analyse my feelings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am content to take your liking me, without examining too curiously\r\ninto the materials it is made of. Only we need not walk at a snail\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. Walk at your own pace, and I will follow. Or stop still and\r\nmeditate, like the Hamlet you compare yourself to, if I go too fast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you. But as my mother has not murdered my father, and afterwards\r\nmarried my uncle, I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t know what to think about, unless it were\r\nbalancing the chances of our having a well-cooked dinner or not. What do\r\nyou think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am in good hopes. She used to be considered a famous cook as far as\r\nHelstone opinion went.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut have you considered the distraction of mind produced by all this\r\nhaymaking?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret felt all Mr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s kindness in trying to make cheerful talk\r\nabout nothing, to endeavour to prevent her from thinking too curiously\r\nabout the past. But she would rather have gone over these dear-loved\r\nwalks in silence, if indeed she were not ungrateful enough to wish that\r\nshe might have been alone.\r\n\r\nThey reached the cottage where Susan\xe2\x80\x99s widowed mother lived. Susan was\r\nnot there. She was gone to the parochial school. Margaret was\r\ndisappointed, and the poor woman saw it, and began to make a kind of\r\napology.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! it is quite right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad to hear it. I\r\nmight have thought of it. Only she used to stop at home with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, she did; and I miss her sadly. I used to teach her what little I\r\nknew at nights. It were not much to be sure. But she were getting such a\r\nhandy girl, that I miss her sore. But she\xe2\x80\x99s a deal above me in learning\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d And the mother sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m all wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d growled Mr. Bell. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t mind what I say. I\xe2\x80\x99m a hundred\r\nyears behind the world. But I should say, that the child was getting a\r\nbetter and simpler, and more natural education stopping at home, and\r\nhelping her mother, and learning to read a chapter in the New Testament\r\nevery night by her side, than from all the schooling under the sun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret did not want to encourage him to go on by replying to him, and\r\nso prolonging the discussion before the mother. So she turned to her and\r\nasked,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is old Betty Barnes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman rather shortly. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99se not friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret, who had formerly been the peace-maker of the\r\nvillage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe stole my cat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she know it was yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I reckon not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! could not you get it back again when you told her it was yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! for she\xe2\x80\x99d burnt it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBurnt it!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed both Margaret and Mr. Bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRoasted it!\xe2\x80\x9d explained the woman.\r\n\r\nIt was no explanation. By dint of questioning, Margaret extracted from\r\nher the horrible fact that Betty Barnes, having been induced by a gipsy\r\nfortune-teller to lend the latter her husband\xe2\x80\x99s Sunday clothes, on\r\npromise of having them faithfully returned on the Saturday night before\r\nGoodman Barnes should have missed them, became alarmed by their\r\nnon-appearance, and her consequent dread of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s anger, and\r\nas, according to one of the savage country superstitions, the cries of a\r\ncat, in the agonies of being boiled or roasted alive; compelled (as it\r\nwere) the powers of darkness to fulfil the wishes of the executioner,\r\nresort had been had to the charm. The poor woman evidently believed in\r\nits efficacy; her only feeling was indignation that her cat had been\r\nchosen out from all others for a sacrifice. Margaret listened in horror;\r\nand endeavoured in vain to enlighten the woman\xe2\x80\x99s mind; but she was\r\nobliged to give it up in despair. Step by step she got the woman to\r\nadmit certain facts, of which the logical connexion and sequence was\r\nperfectly clear to Margaret; but at the end, the bewildered woman simply\r\nrepeated her first assertion, namely, that \xe2\x80\x9cit were very cruel for sure,\r\nand she should not like to do it; but that there was nothing like it for\r\ngiving a person what they wished for; she had heard it all her life; but\r\nit were very cruel for all that.\xe2\x80\x9d Margaret gave it up in despair, and\r\nwalked away sick at heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a good girl not to triumph over me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI own I am wrong about schooling. Anything rather than have that child\r\nbrought up in such practical paganism.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I remember. Poor little Susan! I must go and see her; would you\r\nmind calling at the school?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit. I am curious to see something of the teaching she is to\r\nreceive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey did not speak much more, but thridded their way through many a\r\nbosky dell, whose soft green influence could not charm away the shock\r\nand the pain in Margaret\xe2\x80\x99s heart, caused by the recital of such cruelty;\r\na recital too, the manner of which betrayed such utter want of\r\nimagination, and therefore of any sympathy with the suffering animal.\r\n\r\nThe buzz of voices, like the murmur of a hive of busy human bees, made\r\nitself heard as soon as they emerged from the forest on the more open\r\nvillage-green on which the school was situated. The door was wide open,\r\nand they entered. A brisk lady in black, here, there, and everywhere,\r\nperceived them, and bade them welcome with somewhat of the hostess-air\r\nwhich, Margaret remembered, her mother was wont to assume, only in a\r\nmore soft and languid manner, when any rare visitors strayed in to\r\ninspect the school. She knew at once it was the present Vicar\xe2\x80\x99s wife,\r\nher mother\xe2\x80\x99s successor; and she would have drawn back from the interview\r\nhad it been possible; but in an instant she had conquered this feeling,\r\nand modestly advanced, meeting many a bright glance of recognition, and\r\nhearing many a half-suppressed murmur of \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d The Vicar\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlady heard the name, and her manner at once became more kindly. Margaret\r\nwished she could have helped feeling that it also became more\r\npatronizing. The lady held out a hand to Mr. Bell, with,--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour father, I presume, Miss Hale. I see it by the likeness. I am sure\r\nI am very glad to see you, sir, and so will the Vicar be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret explained that it was not her father, and stammered out the\r\nfact of his death; wondering all the time how Mr. Hale could have borne\r\ncoming to revisit Helstone, if it had been as the Vicar\xe2\x80\x99s lady supposed.\r\nShe did not hear what Mrs. Hepworth was saying, and left it to Mr. Bell\r\nto reply, looking round, meanwhile, for her old acquaintances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! I see you would like to take a class, Miss Hale. I know it by\r\nmyself. First class stand up for a parsing lesson with Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor Margaret, whose visit was sentimental, not in any degree\r\ninspective, felt herself taken in; but as in some way bringing her in\r\ncontact with little eager faces, once well-known, and who had received\r\nthe solemn rite of baptism from her father, she sate down, half losing\r\nherself in tracing out the changing features of the girls, and holding\r\nSusan\xe2\x80\x99s hand for a minute or two, unobserved by all, while the first\r\nclass sought for their books, and the Vicar\xe2\x80\x99s lady went as near as a\r\nlady could towards holding Mr. Bell by the button, while she explained\r\nthe Phonetic system to him, and gave him a conversation she had had with\r\nthe Inspector about it.\r\n\r\nMargaret bent over her book, and seeing nothing but that--hearing the\r\nbuzz of children\xe2\x80\x99s voices, old times rose up, and she thought of them,\r\nand her eyes filled with tears, till all at once there was a pause--one\r\nof the girls was stumbling over the apparently simple word \xe2\x80\x9ca,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nuncertain what to call it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA, an indefinite article,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, mildly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Vicar\xe2\x80\x99s wife, all eyes and ears; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we\r\nare taught by Mr. Milsome to call \xe2\x80\x98a\xe2\x80\x99 an--who can remember?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn adjective absolute,\xe2\x80\x9d said half-a-dozen voices at once. And Margaret\r\nsate abashed. The children knew more than she did. Mr. Bell turned away,\r\nand smiled.\r\n\r\nMargaret spoke no more during the lesson. But after it was over, she\r\nwent quietly round to one or two old favourites, and talked to them a\r\nlittle. They were growing out of children into great girls; passing out\r\nof their recollection in their rapid development, as she, by her three\r\nyear\xe2\x80\x99s absence, was vanishing from theirs. Still she was glad to have\r\nseen them all again, though a tinge of sadness mixed itself with her\r\npleasure. When school was over for the day, it was yet early in the\r\nsummer afternoon; and Mrs. Hepworth proposed to Margaret that she and\r\nMr. Bell should accompany her to the parsonage, and see--the word\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cimprovements\xe2\x80\x9d had half slipped out of her mouth, but she substituted\r\nthe more cautious term \xe2\x80\x9calterations\xe2\x80\x9d which the present Vicar was making.\r\nMargaret did not care a straw about seeing the alterations, which jarred\r\nupon her fond recollection of what her home had been; but she longed to\r\nsee the old place once more, even though she shivered away from the pain\r\nwhich she knew she should feel.\r\n\r\nThe parsonage was so altered, both inside and out, that the real pain\r\nwas less than she anticipated. It was not like the same place. The\r\ngarden, the grass-plat, formerly so daintily trim that even a stray\r\nrose-leaf seemed like a fleck on the exquisite arrangement and\r\npropriety, was strewed with children\xe2\x80\x99s things; a bag of marbles here, a\r\nhoop there; a straw-hat forced down upon a rose-tree as on a peg, to the\r\ndestruction of a long beautiful tender branch laden with flowers, which\r\nin former days would have been trained up tenderly, as if beloved. The\r\nlittle square matted hall was equally filled with signs of merry healthy\r\nrough childhood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hepworth, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must excuse this untidiness, Miss Hale.\r\nWhen the nursery is finished, I shall insist upon a little order. We are\r\nbuilding a nursery out of your room, I believe. How did you manage, Miss\r\nHale, without a nursery?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe were but two,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have many children, I presume?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeven. Look here! we are throwing out a window to the road on this\r\nside. Mr. Hepworth is spending an immense deal of money on this house;\r\nbut really it was scarcely habitable when we came--for so large a family\r\nas ours I mean, of course.\xe2\x80\x9d Every room in the house was changed, besides\r\nthe one of which Mrs. Hepworth spoke, which had been Mr. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s study\r\nformerly; and where the green gloom and delicious quiet of the place had\r\nconduced, as he had said, to a habit of meditation, but, perhaps, in\r\nsome degree to the formation of a character more fitted for thought than\r\naction. The new window gave a view of the road, and had many advantages,\r\nas Mrs. Hepworth pointed out. From it the wandering sheep of her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s flock might be seen, who straggled to the tempting beer-house,\r\nunobserved as they might hope, but not unobserved in reality; for the\r\nactive Vicar kept his eye on the road, even during the composition of\r\nhis most orthodox sermons, and had a hat and stick hanging ready at hand\r\nto seize, before sallying out after his parishioners, who had need of\r\nquick legs if they could take refuge in the \xe2\x80\x9cJolly Forester\xe2\x80\x9d before the\r\nteetotal Vicar had arrested them. The whole family were quick, brisk,\r\nloud-talking, kind-hearted, and not troubled with much delicacy of\r\nperception. Margaret feared that Mrs. Hepworth would find out that Mr.\r\nBell was playing upon her, in the admiration he thought fit to express\r\nfor everything that especially grated on his taste. But no! she took it\r\nall literally, and with such good faith, that Margaret could not help\r\nremonstrating with him as they walked slowly away from the parsonage\r\nback to their inn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t scold, Margaret. It was all because of you. If she had not shown\r\nyou every change with such evident exultation in their superior sense,\r\nin perceiving what an improvement this and that would be, I could have\r\nbehaved well. But if you must go on preaching, keep it till after\r\ndinner, when it will send me to sleep, and help my digestion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were both of them tired, and Margaret herself so much so, that she\r\nwas unwilling to go out as she had proposed to do, and have another\r\nramble among the woods and fields so close to the home of her childhood.\r\nAnd, somehow, this visit to Helstone had not been all--had not been\r\nexactly what she had expected. There was change everywhere; slight, yet\r\npervading all. Households were changed by absence, or death, or\r\nmarriage, or the natural mutations brought by days and months and\r\nyears, which carry us on imperceptibly from childhood to youth, and\r\nthence through manhood to age, whence we drop like fruit, fully ripe,\r\ninto the quiet mother earth. Places were changed--a tree gone here, a\r\nbough there, bringing in a long ray of light where no light was\r\nbefore--a road was trimmed and narrowed, and the green straggling\r\npathway by its side enclosed and cultivated. A great improvement it was\r\ncalled; but Margaret sighed over the old picturesqueness, the old gloom,\r\nand the grassy way-side of former days. She sate by the window on the\r\nlittle settle, sadly gazing out upon the gathering shades of night,\r\nwhich harmonized well with her pensive thought. Mr. Bell slept soundly,\r\nafter his unusual exercise through the day. At last he was roused by the\r\nentrance of the tea-tray, brought in by a flushed-looking country-girl,\r\nwho had evidently been finding some variety from her usual occupation of\r\nwaiter, in assisting this day in the hay-field.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo! Who\xe2\x80\x99s there! Where are we? Who\xe2\x80\x99s that,--Margaret? Oh, now I\r\nremember all. I could not imagine what woman was sitting there in such a\r\ndoleful attitude, with her hands clasped straight out upon her knees,\r\nand her face looking so steadfastly before her. What are you looking\r\nat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Bell, coming to the window, and standing behind Margaret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, rising up quickly, and speaking as cheerfully as\r\nshe could at a moment\xe2\x80\x99s notice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing indeed! A bleak back-ground of trees, some white linen hung out\r\non the sweet-briar hedge, and a great waft of damp air. Shut the window,\r\nand come in and make tea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret was silent for some time. She played with her teaspoon, and did\r\nnot attend particularly to what Mr. Bell said. He contradicted her, and\r\nshe took the same sort of smiling notice of his opinion as if he had\r\nagreed with her. Then she sighed, and putting down her spoon, she began,\r\napropos of nothing at all, and in the high-pitched voice which usually\r\nshows that the speaker has been thinking for some time on the subject\r\nthat they wish to introduce--\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bell, you remember what we were saying\r\nabout Frederick last night, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLast night. Where was I? Oh, I remember! Why, it seems a week ago. Yes,\r\nto be sure, I recollect we talked about him, poor fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes--and do you remember that Mr. Lennox spoke about his having been in\r\nEngland about the time of dear mamma\xe2\x80\x99s death?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Margaret, her voice\r\nnow lower than usual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI recollect. I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t heard of it before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I thought--I always thought that papa had told you about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! he never did. But what about it, Margaret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to tell you of something I did that was very wrong, about that\r\ntime,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, suddenly looking up at him with her clear honest\r\neyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told a lie;\xe2\x80\x9d and her face became scarlet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, that was bad I own; not but what I have told a pretty round\r\nnumber in my life, not all in downright words, as I suppose you did, but\r\nin actions, or in some shabby circumlocutory way, leading people either\r\nto disbelieve the truth, or believe a falsehood. You know who is the\r\nfather of lies, Margaret? Well! a great number of folk, thinking\r\nthemselves very good, have odd sorts of connexion with lies, left-hand\r\nmarriages, and second-cousins-once-removed. The tainting blood of\r\nfalsehood runs through us all. I should have guessed you as far from it\r\nas most people. What! crying, child? Nay, now we\xe2\x80\x99ll not talk of it, if\r\nit ends in this way. I dare say you have been sorry for it, and that you\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t do it again, and it\xe2\x80\x99s long ago now, and in short I want you to be\r\nvery cheerful, and not very sad, this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret wiped her eyes, and tried to talk about something else, but\r\nsuddenly she burst out afresh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease, Mr. Bell, let me tell you about it--you could perhaps help me a\r\nlittle; no, not help me, but if you knew the truth, perhaps you could\r\nput me to rights--that is not it, after all,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, in despair at\r\nnot being able to express herself more exactly as she wished.\r\n\r\nMr. Bell\xe2\x80\x99s whole manner changed. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me all about it, child,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a long story; but when Fred came, mamma was very ill, and I was\r\nundone with anxiety, and afraid, too, that I might have drawn him into\r\ndanger; and we had an alarm just after her death, for Dixon met some one\r\nin Milton--a man called Leonards--who had known Fred, and who seemed to\r\nowe him a grudge, or at any rate to be tempted by the recollection of\r\nthe reward offered for his apprehension; and with this new fright, I\r\nthought I had better hurry off Fred to London, where, as you would\r\nunderstand from what we said the other night, he was to go to consult\r\nMr. Lennox as to his chances if he stood trial. So we--that is, he and\r\nI,--went to the railway station; it was one evening, and it was just\r\ngetting rather dusk, but still light enough to recognize and be\r\nrecognized, and we were too early, and went out to walk in a field just\r\nclose by; I was always in a panic about this Leonards, who was, I knew,\r\nsomewhere in the neighbourhood; and then, when we were in the field, the\r\nlow red sunlight just in my face, some one came by on horseback in the\r\nroad just below the field-style on which we stood.--I saw him look at\r\nme, but I did not know who it was at first, the sun was so in my eyes,\r\nbut in an instant the dazzle went off, and I saw it was Mr. Thornton,\r\nand we bowed\xe2\x80\x9d----\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he saw Frederick of course,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell, helping her on with her\r\nstory, as he thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and then at the station a man came up--tipsy and reeling--and he\r\ntried to collar Fred, and over-balanced himself as Fred wrenched himself\r\naway, and fell over the hedge of the platform; not far, not deep; not\r\nabove three feet; but oh! Mr. Bell, somehow that fall killed him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow awkward. It was this Leonards, I suppose. And how did Fred get\r\noff?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! he went off immediately after the fall, which we never thought\r\ncould have done the poor fellow any harm, it seemed so slight an\r\ninjury.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he did not die directly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! not for two or three days. And then--oh, Mr. Bell! now comes the\r\nbad part,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, nervously twining her fingers together. \xe2\x80\x9cA police\r\ninspector came and taxed me with having been a companion of the young\r\nman, whose push or blow had occasioned Leonards\xe2\x80\x99 death; that was a false\r\naccusation, you know, but we had not heard that Fred had sailed, he\r\nmight still be in London and liable to be arrested on this false charge,\r\nand his identity with the Lieutenant Hale, accused of causing the\r\nmutiny, discovered, he might be shot; all this flashed through my mind,\r\nand I said it was not me. I was not at the railway station that night. I\r\nknew nothing about it. I had no conscience or thought but to save\r\nFrederick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say it was right. I should have done the same. You forgot yourself in\r\nthought for another. I hope I should have done the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you would not. It was wrong, disobedient, faithless. At that very\r\ntime Fred was safely out of England, and in my blindness I forgot that\r\nthere was another witness who could testify to my being there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton. You know he had seen me close to the station; we had\r\nbowed to each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! he would know nothing of this riot, about the drunken fellow\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeath. I suppose the injury never came to anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! the proceedings they had begun to talk about on the inquest were\r\nstopped. Mr. Thornton did know all about it. He was a magistrate, and he\r\nfound out that it was not the fall that had caused the death. But not\r\nbefore he knew what I had said. Oh, Mr. Bell!\xe2\x80\x9d She suddenly covered her\r\nface with her hands, as if wishing to hide herself from the presence of\r\nthe recollection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you have any explanation with him? Did you ever tell him the\r\nstrong, instinctive motive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe instinctive want of faith, and clutching at a sin to keep myself\r\nfrom sinking,\xe2\x80\x9d said she bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cNo! How could I? He knew nothing of\r\nFrederick. To put myself to rights in his good opinion, was I to tell\r\nhim the secrets of our family, involving, as they seemed to do, the\r\nchances of poor Frederick\xe2\x80\x99s entire exculpation? Fred\xe2\x80\x99s last words had\r\nbeen to enjoin me to keep his visit a secret from all. You see, papa\r\nnever told, even you. No! I could bear the shame--I thought I could at\r\nleast. I did bear it. Mr. Thornton has never respected me since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe respects you, I am sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bell. \xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure it accounts a\r\nlittle for----. But he always speaks of you with regard and esteem,\r\nthough now I understand certain reservations in his manner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMargaret did not speak; did not attend to what Mr. Bell had to say; lost\r\nall sense of it. By-and-by she said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you tell me what you refer to about \xe2\x80\x98reservations\xe2\x80\x99 in his manner\r\nof speaking to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! simply he has annoyed me by not joining in my praises of you. Like\r\nan old fool, I thought that every one would have the same opinion as I\r\nhad; and he evidently could not agree with me. I was puzzled at the\r\ntime. But he must be perplexed, if the affair has never been in the\r\nleast explained. There was first your walking out with a young man in\r\nthe dark----\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it was my brother!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue. But how was he to know that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I know it now. I bitterly repent it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a long pause of silence. Margaret was the first to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not likely ever to see Mr. Thornton again,\xe2\x80\x9d--and there she\r\nstopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are many things more unlikely, I should say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mr. Bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I believe I never shall.
