They two alone?\r\n\r\nMr. Colthurst was a very clever man, and a rising member of Parliament.\r\nHe had a quick eye at discerning character, and was struck by a remark\r\nwhich Mr. Thornton made at dinner-time. He enquired from Edith who that\r\ngentleman was; and, rather to her surprise, she found, from the tone of\r\nhis \xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d that Mr. Thornton of Milton was not such an unknown name\r\nto him as she had imagined it would be. Her dinner was going off well.\r\nHenry was in good humour, and brought out his dry caustic wit admirably.\r\nMr. Thornton and Mr. Colthurst found one or two mutual subjects of\r\ninterest, which they could only touch upon then, reserving them for\r\nmore private after-dinner talk. Margaret looked beautiful in the\r\npomegranate flowers; and if she did lean back in her chair and speak but\r\nlittle, Edith was not annoyed, for the conversation flowed on smoothly\r\nwithout her. Margaret was watching Mr Thornton\xe2\x80\x99s face. He never looked\r\nat her: so she might study him unobserved, and note the changes which\r\neven this short time had wrought in him. Only at some unexpected mot of\r\nMr. Lennox\xe2\x80\x99s, his face flashed out into the old look of intense\r\nenjoyment: the merry brightness returned to his eyes, the lips just\r\nparted to suggest the brilliant smile of former days; and for an\r\ninstant, his glance instinctively sought hers, as if he wanted her\r\nsympathy. But when their eyes met, his whole countenance changed; he was\r\ngrave and anxious once more; and he resolutely avoided even looking near\r\nher again during dinner.\r\n\r\nThere were only two ladies beside their own party, and as these were\r\noccupied in conversation by her aunt and Edith, when they went up into\r\nthe drawing-room, Margaret languidly employed herself about some work.\r\nPresently the gentlemen came up, Mr. Colthurst and Mr. Thornton in close\r\nconversation. Mr. Lennox drew near to Margaret, and said in a low voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI really think Edith owes me thanks for my contribution to her party.\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99ve no idea what an agreeable, sensible fellow this tenant of yours\r\nis. He has been the very man to give Colthurst all the facts he wanted\r\ncoaching in. I can\xe2\x80\x99t conceive how he contrived to mismanage his\r\naffairs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith his powers and opportunities you would have succeeded,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMargaret. He did not quite relish the tone in which she spoke, although\r\nthe words but expressed a thought which had passed through his own mind.\r\nAs he was silent, they caught a swell in the sound of conversation going\r\non near the fire-place between Mr. Colthurst and Mr. Thornton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI assure you, I heard it spoken of with great interest--curiosity as to\r\nits result, perhaps I should rather say. I heard your name frequently\r\nmentioned during my short stay in the neighbourhood.\xe2\x80\x9d Then they lost\r\nsome words; and when next they could hear Mr. Thornton was speaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not the elements for popularity--if they spoke of me in that\r\nway, they were mistaken. I fall slowly into new projects; and I find it\r\ndifficult to let myself be known, even by those whom I desire to know,\r\nand with whom I would fain have no reserve. Yet, even with all these\r\ndrawbacks, I felt that I was on the right path, and that, starting from\r\na kind of friendship with one, I was becoming acquainted with many. The\r\nadvantages were mutual: we were both unconsciously and consciously\r\nteaching each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say \xe2\x80\x98were.\xe2\x80\x99 I trust you are intending to pursue the same course?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must stop Colthurst,\xe2\x80\x9d said Henry Lennox, hastily. And by an abrupt,\r\nyet apropos question, he turned the current of the conversation, so as\r\nnot to give Mr. Thornton the mortification of acknowledging his want of\r\nsuccess and consequent change of position. But as soon as the\r\nnewly-started subject had come to a close, Mr. Thornton resumed the\r\nconversation just where it had been interrupted, and gave Mr. Colthurst\r\nthe reply to his inquiry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been unsuccessful in business, and have had to give up my\r\nposition as a master. I am on the look-out for a situation in Milton,\r\nwhere I may meet with employment under some one who will be willing to\r\nlet me go along my own way in such matters as these. I can depend upon\r\nmyself for having no go-ahead theories that I would rashly bring into\r\npractice. My only wish is to have the opportunity of cultivating some\r\nintercourse with the hands beyond the mere \xe2\x80\x98cash nexus.\xe2\x80\x99 But it might be\r\nthe point Archimedes sought from which to move the earth, to judge by\r\nthe importance attached to it by some of our manufacturers, who shake\r\ntheir heads and look grave as soon as I name the one or two experiments\r\nthat I should like to try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou call them \xe2\x80\x98experiments\xe2\x80\x99 I notice,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Colthurst, with a\r\ndelicate increase of respect in his manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I believe them to be such. I am not sure of the consequences\r\nthat may result from them. But I am sure they ought to be tried. I have\r\narrived at the conviction that no mere institutions, however wise, and\r\nhowever much thought may have been required to organise and arrange\r\nthem, can attach class to class as they should be attached, unless the\r\nworking out of such institutions bring the individuals of the different\r\nclasses into actual personal contact. Such intercourse is the very\r\nbreath of life. A working man can hardly be made to feel and know how\r\nmuch his employer may have laboured in his study at plans for the\r\nbenefit of his workpeople. A complete plan emerges like a piece of\r\nmachinery, apparently fitted for every emergency. But the hands accept\r\nit as they do machinery, without understanding the intense mental labour\r\nand forethought required to bring it to such perfection. But I would\r\ntake an idea, the working out of which would necessitate personal\r\nintercourse; it might not go well at first, but at every hitch interest\r\nwould be felt by an increasing number of men, and at last its success in\r\nworking come to be desired by all, as all had borne a part in the\r\nformation of the plan; and even then I am sure that it would lose its\r\nvitality, cease to be living, as soon as it was no longer carried on by\r\nthat sort of common interest which invariably makes people find means\r\nand ways of seeing each other, and becoming acquainted with each others\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncharacters and persons, and even tricks of temper and modes of speech.\r\nWe should understand each other better, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll venture to say we\r\nshould like each other more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you think they may prevent recurrence of strikes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all. My utmost expectation only goes as far as this--that they\r\nmay render strikes not the bitter, venomous sources of hatred they have\r\nhitherto been. A more hopeful man might imagine that a closer and more\r\ngenial intercourse between classes might do away with strikes. But I am\r\nnot a hopeful man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuddenly, as if a new idea had struck him, he crossed over to where\r\nMargaret was sitting, and began, without preface, as if he knew she had\r\nbeen listening to all that had passed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Hale, I had a round-robin from some of my men--I suspect in\r\nHiggins\xe2\x80\x99 handwriting--stating their wish to work for me, if ever I was\r\nin a position to employ men again on my own behalf. That was good,\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Just right. I am glad of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, looking up straight\r\ninto his face with her speaking eyes, and then dropping them under his\r\neloquent glance. He gazed back at her for a minute, as if he did not\r\nknow exactly what he was about. Then sighed; and saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI knew you\r\nwould like it,\xe2\x80\x9d he turned away, and never spoke to her again until he\r\nbid her a formal \xe2\x80\x9cgood night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Mr. Lennox took his departure, Margaret said, with a blush that she\r\ncould not repress, and with some hesitation,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I speak to you to-morrow? I want your help about--something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. I will come at whatever time you name. You cannot give me a\r\ngreater pleasure than by making me of any use. At eleven? Very well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis eye brightened with exultation. How she was learning to depend upon\r\nhim! It seemed as if any day now might give him the certainty, without\r\nhaving which he had determined never to offer to her again.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER LII.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPACK CLOUDS AWAY.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cFor joy or grief, for hope or fear,\r\n    For all hereafter, as for here,\r\n    In peace or strife, in storm or shine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n              ANON.\r\n\r\n\r\nEdith went about on tip-toe, and checked Sholto in all loud speaking\r\nthat next morning, as if any sudden noise would interrupt the conference\r\nthat was taking place in the drawing-room. Two o\xe2\x80\x99clock came; and they\r\nstill sate there with closed doors. Then there was a man\xe2\x80\x99s footstep\r\nrunning down stairs; and Edith peeped out of the drawing-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Henry?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, with a look of interrogation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, rather shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in to lunch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank you, I can\xe2\x80\x99t. I\xe2\x80\x99ve lost too much time here already.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it\xe2\x80\x99s not all settled?\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith, despondingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! not at all. It never will be settled, if the \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99 is what I\r\nconjecture you mean. That will never be, Edith, so give up thinking\r\nabout it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it would be so nice for us all,\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded Edith. \xe2\x80\x9cI should always\r\nfeel comfortable about the children, if I had Margaret settled down near\r\nto me. As it is, I am always afraid of her going off to Cadiz.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will try, when I marry, to look out for a young lady who has a\r\nknowledge of the management of children. That is all I can do. Miss Hale\r\nwill not have me. And I shall not ask her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen what have you been talking about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand things you would not understand: Investments, and leases,\r\nand value of land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, go away if that\xe2\x80\x99s all. You and she will be unbearably stupid, if\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ve been talking all this time about such weary things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. I\xe2\x80\x99m coming again to-morrow, and bringing Mr. Thornton with\r\nme, to have some more talk with Miss Hale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Thornton! What has he to do with it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is Miss Hale\xe2\x80\x99s tenant,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Lennox, turning away. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd he\r\nwishes to give up his lease.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! very well. I can\xe2\x80\x99t understand details, so don\xe2\x80\x99t give them me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe only detail I want you to understand is, to let us have the back\r\ndrawing-room undisturbed, as it was to-day. In general, the children and\r\nservants are so in and out, that I can never get any business\r\nsatisfactorily explained; and the arrangements we have to make to-morrow\r\nare of importance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo one ever knew why Mr. Lennox did not keep to his appointment on the\r\nfollowing day. Mr. Thornton came true to his time; and after keeping him\r\nwaiting for nearly an hour, Margaret came in looking very white and\r\nanxious.\r\n\r\nShe began hurriedly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so sorry Mr. Lennox is not here,--he could have done it so much\r\nbetter than I can. He is my adviser in this\xe2\x80\x9d----\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry that I came, if it troubles you. Shall I go to Mr. Lennox\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchambers and try and find him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank you. I wanted to tell you, how grieved I was to find that I\r\nam to lose you as a tenant. But, Mr. Lennox says, things are sure to\r\nbrighten\xe2\x80\x9d----\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Lennox knows little about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Thornton quietly. \xe2\x80\x9cHappy\r\nand fortunate in all a man cares for, he does not understand what it is\r\nto find oneself no longer young--yet thrown back to the starting-point\r\nwhich requires the hopeful energy of youth--to feel one half of life\r\ngone, and nothing done--nothing remaining of wasted opportunity, but the\r\nbitter recollection that it has been. Miss Hale, would rather not hear\r\nMr. Lennox\xe2\x80\x99s opinion of my affairs. Those who are happy and successful\r\nthemselves are too apt to make light of the misfortunes of others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are unjust,\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, gently. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Lennox has only spoken of\r\nthe great probability which he believes there to be of your\r\nredeeming--your more than redeeming what you have lost--don\xe2\x80\x99t speak till\r\nI have ended--pray don\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d And collecting herself once more, she went on\r\nrapidly turning over some law papers, and statement of accounts in a\r\ntrembling hurried manner. \xe2\x80\x9cOh! here it is! and--he drew me out a\r\nproposal--I wish he was here to explain it--showing that if you would\r\ntake some money of mine, eighteen hundred and fifty-seven pounds, lying\r\njust at this moment unused in the bank, and bringing me in only two and\r\na half per cent.--you could pay me much better interest, and might go on\r\nworking Marlborough Mills.\xe2\x80\x9d Her voice had cleared itself and become more\r\nsteady. Mr. Thornton did not speak, and she went on looking for some\r\npaper on which were written down the proposals for security; for she was\r\nmost anxious to have it all looked upon in the light of a mere business\r\narrangement, in which the principal advantage would be on her side.\r\nWhile she sought for this paper, her very heart-pulse was arrested by\r\nthe tone in which Mr. Thornton spoke. His voice was hoarse, and\r\ntrembling with tender passion, as he said:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor an instant she looked up; and then sought to veil her luminous eyes\r\nby dropping her forehead on her hands. Again, stepping nearer, he\r\nbesought her with another tremulous eager call upon her name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMargaret!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill lower went the head; more closely hidden was the face, almost\r\nresting on the table before her. He came close to her. He knelt by her\r\nside, to bring his face to a level with her ear; and whispered--panted\r\nout the words:--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care.--If you do not speak--I shall claim you as my own in some\r\nstrange presumptuous way.--Send me away at once, if I must\r\ngo;--Margaret!--\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that third call she turned her face, still covered with her small\r\nwhite hands, towards him, and laid it on his shoulder, even hiding it\r\nthere; and it was too delicious to feel her soft cheek against his, for\r\nhim to wish to see either deep blushes or loving eyes. He clasped her\r\nclose. But they both kept silence. At length she murmured in a broken\r\nvoice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Mr. Thornton, I am not good enough!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot good enough! Don\xe2\x80\x99t mock my own deep feeling of unworthiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter a minute or two he gently disengaged her hands from her face, and\r\nlaid her arms as they had once before been placed to protect him from\r\nthe rioters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember, love?\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd how I requited you with my\r\ninsolence the next day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember how wrongly I spoke to you,--that is all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook here! Lift up your head. I have something to show you!\xe2\x80\x9d She slowly\r\nfaced him, glowing with beautiful shame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know these roses?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, drawing out his pocket-book, in\r\nwhich were treasured up some dead flowers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, with innocent curiosity. \xe2\x80\x9cDid I give them to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! Vanity; you did not. You may have worn sister roses very\r\nprobably.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked at them, wondering for a minute, then she smiled a little as\r\nshe said--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are from Helstone, are they not? I know the deep indentations\r\nround the leaves. Oh! have you been there? When were you there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wanted to see the place where Margaret grew to what she is, even at\r\nthe worst time of all, when I had no hope of ever calling her mine. I\r\nwent there on my return from Havre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must give them to me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, trying to take them out of his\r\nhand with gentle violence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. Only you must pay me for them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow shall I ever tell Aunt Shaw?\xe2\x80\x9d she whispered, after some time of\r\ndelicious silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me speak to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no! Her first exclamation will be, \xe2\x80\x98That man!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Margaret, \xe2\x80\x9cor I shall try and show you your mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nindignant tones as she says, \xe2\x80\x98That woman!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE WALTER SCOTT PRESS, NEWCASTLE-ON TYNE.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n_Walter Scott\xe2\x80\x99s New Books and New Editions._\r\n\r\n\r\nCrown 8vo, Half Antique, Paper Boards, Price 3s. 6d.\r\n\r\nThe Theatrical \xe2\x80\x98World\xe2\x80\x99 of 1897.\r\n\r\nBY WILLIAM ARCHER.\r\n\r\n     With an Introduction by SYDNEY GRUNDY, an Epilogue by WILLIAM\r\n     ARCHER, and a Synopsis of Playbills of the Year by HENRY GEORGE\r\n     HIBBERT.\r\n\r\n_May still be had uniform with the above_--\r\n\r\nTHE THEATRICAL \xe2\x80\x98WORLD\xe2\x80\x99 OF 1893, 1894, 1895, and 1896.\r\n\r\n_Each of the above vols. contains Complete Indices of the Plays,\r\nAuthors, Actors, Actresses, Managers, Critics, etc., referred to._\r\n\r\n_The above volumes are also supplied in a uniform Cloth Binding, Price\r\n3s. 6d. per vol._\r\n\r\n\r\nDramatic Essays.\r\n\r\n(3 VOLS.)\r\n\r\nEdited by WILLIAM ARCHER and ROBERT W. The most recent discoveries\r\nin science go to prove that cleanliness, with proper attention to bodily\r\nexercise, is the greatest enemy to disease and decay. Quackery has never\r\nbeen more rampant than it is to-day, and advertised secret preparations\r\nfor beautifying the person meet us at every turn. It is with the object\r\nof showing how Beauty may be preserved and aided on purely hygienic\r\nprinciples, that this work has been written, the greatest secret of\r\nBeauty being Health._\r\n\r\n\r\n_CONTENTS_--\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I.--THE SKIN.\r\nCHAPTER II.--THE HANDS.\r\nCHAPTER III.--THE FEET.\r\nCHAPTER IV.--THE HAIR.\r\nCHAPTER V.--THE TEETH.\r\nCHAPTER VI.--THE NOSE.\r\nCHAPTER VII.--THE EYE.\r\nCHAPTER VIII.--THE EAR.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Quackery,\xe2\x80\x99 says Mr. Thompson, \xe2\x80\x98was never more rampant than it is\r\nto-day\xe2\x80\x99 with regard to \xe2\x80\x98aids in beautifying the person.\xe2\x80\x99 His little book\r\nis based on purely hygienic principles, and comprises recipes for toilet\r\npurposes which he warrants are \xe2\x80\x98practical and harmless.\xe2\x80\x99 These are\r\nvirtues in any book of health and beauty, and Mr. Thompson\xe2\x80\x99s advice and\r\nguidance are, we find, not wanting in soundness and\r\ncommon-sense.\xe2\x80\x9d--_Saturday Review._\r\n\r\n\r\nLondon: WALTER SCOTT, LIMITED, Paternoster Square.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_The most attractive Birthday Book ever published._\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n_Crown Quarto, in specially designed Cover, Cloth, Price 6s._\r\n\r\n_\xe2\x80\x9cWedding Present\xe2\x80\x9d Edition, in Silver Cloth, 7s. 6d., in Box. Of late years a\r\ngreat deal of attention has been directed to the subject of women\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nemployment, and a considerable amount of useful information has been\r\npublished with regard to different occupations, but it can hardly be\r\nsaid to have yet appeared in any form rendering it generally accessible\r\nto that portion of the public for whom it is specially intended.\r\n\r\n\r\nVOLUMES ALREADY ISSUED.\r\n\r\nFoolscap 8vo, Stiff Paper Cover, Price 1s.; or in Limp Cloth, 1s. 6d.\r\n\r\n\r\nI.--SECONDARY TEACHING.\r\n\r\nBY CHRISTABEL OSBORN AND FLORENCE B. SCHARFF, B.SC., PH.D., F.Z.S.\r\n\r\nDeals with the distribution of animals in Europe, and the geological\r\nconditions which have effected that distribution. With about 200 Illustrations.\r\n\r\nTHE RACES OF MAN:\r\n\r\nA SKETCH OF ETHNOGRAPHY AND ANTHROPOLOGY.\r\n\r\nBY J. DENIKER.\r\n\r\nThis important volume attempts to present a summary of all the facts of\r\nanthropology in the light of the latest investigations. The first part\r\nof the book describes the physical and psychic characteristics of man\r\nthroughout the world and in every stage of civilisation, while the last\r\npart discusses the races into which mankind may be divided.\r\n\r\n\r\nCrown 8vo, Cloth, Price 6s. With Diagrams.\r\n\r\nTHE PSYCHOLOGY OF RELIGION.\r\n\r\nBY PROF. STARBUCK,\r\n\r\nSTANFORD UNIVERSITY, CALIFORNIA.\r\n\r\nWith an Introduction by PROF. WILLIAM JAMES, of Harvard University.\r\n\r\nThe author of this book deals for the first time in a scientific (though\r\nsympathetic) manner with the facts of religious life. He shows that\r\nconversion and the other stages of religious development may be brought\r\ninto line with the biological facts of life. His work is founded on\r\nprecise information derived from a large number of people, and is of\r\nspecial interest to teachers and ministers of religion.\r\n\r\n\r\nLondon: WALTER SCOTT, LIMITED, Paternoster Square.\r\n\r\n\r\nNEW VOLUME. ALEXANDER FRANCIS CHAMBERLAIN, M.A., Ph.D.,\r\n\r\nLecturer on Anthropology in Clark University, Worcester, Mass.\r\n\r\nThe importance of the scientific study of children is rapidly becoming\r\ngenerally recognised. Dr. Chamberlain has for many years devoted himself\r\nto this study, and is recognised as one of the most learned and\r\ncompetent authorities on the subject. He approaches it with a full sense\r\nof its wide significance, and his book is an exhaustive summary of\r\nrecent investigations.\r\n\r\n\r\nNEW EDITIONS.\r\n\r\n_THIRD EDITION, REVISED AND ENLARGED._\r\n\r\nCrown 8vo, Cloth, Price 6s. On account of the\r\nactivity with which the study of the criminal has been carried on during\r\nrecent years, it has been found necessary to enlarge, and in some cases\r\nre-write, nearly every chapter in the book. A great deal of new material\r\nhas thus been added. FIRTH, B.A., Late\r\nScholar of Queen\xe2\x80\x99s College, Oxford.\r\n\r\nThe correspondence of Pliny the Younger depicts for us the everyday life\r\nof a Roman gentleman in the best sense of the term. We see him\r\npractising at the Bar; we see him engaged in the civil magistracies at\r\nRome, and in the governorship of the important province of Bithynia; we\r\nsee him consulted by the Emperor on affairs of state, and occupying a\r\ndefinite place among the \xe2\x80\x9c_Amici Caesaris_.\xe2\x80\x9d Best of all, perhaps, we\r\nsee him in his daily life, a devoted scholar, never so happy as when he\r\nis in his study, laboriously seeking to perfect his style, whether in\r\nverse or prose, by the models of the great writers of the past and the\r\ncriticisms of the friends whom he has summoned, in a friendly way, to\r\nhear his compositions read or recited.\r\n\r\n\r\nReflections on the Revolution in France.\r\n\r\nBY EDMUND BURKE. Michaut, who was the first to publish an exact text in the order of\r\nthe original MS.\r\n\r\n\r\nLondon: WALTER SCOTT, LIMITED, Paternoster Square.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE CANTERBURY POETS.\r\n\r\nEDITED BY WILLIAM SHARP.
